hgwellsr package

Yap S S

17 November, 2020

Goal

The goal of hgwellsr package is to provides access to the full texts of 6 novels by H. G. Wells. The plain-text for each novel was sourced and lightly cleaned from Project Gutenberg. Each novel is in a character vector. Currently, the package contains:

  • timemachine: The Time Machine, (1895)

WIP

  • annveronica : Ann Veronica, (1909)
  • mrpolly : The History of Mr Polly, (1910)
  • invisibleman : The Invisible Man, (1897)
  • doctormoreau : The Island of Doctor Moreau, (1896)
  • waroftheworlds : The War of the Worlds, (1898)

Install my package as follows

library(devtools)
## Warning: package 'devtools' was built under R version 4.0.3
## Loading required package: usethis
## Warning: package 'usethis' was built under R version 4.0.3
install_github("mryap/hgwellsr")
## Skipping install of 'hgwellsr' from a github remote, the SHA1 (e404a77a) has not changed since last install.
##   Use `force = TRUE` to force installation

The War of the Worlds, (1898)

library(hgwellsr) # load library
waroftheworlds
##    [1] "CHAPTER ONE"                                                                
##    [2] ""                                                                           
##    [3] "THE EVE OF THE WAR"                                                         
##    [4] ""                                                                           
##    [5] ""                                                                           
##    [6] "No one would have believed in the last years of the nineteenth"             
##    [7] "century that this world was being watched keenly and closely by"            
##    [8] "intelligences greater than man's and yet as mortal as his own; that as"     
##    [9] "men busied themselves about their various concerns they were"               
##   [10] "scrutinised and studied, perhaps almost as narrowly as a man with a"        
##   [11] "microscope might scrutinise the transient creatures that swarm and"         
##   [12] "multiply in a drop of water.  With infinite complacency men went to"        
##   [13] "and fro over this globe about their little affairs, serene in their"        
##   [14] "assurance of their empire over matter.  It is possible that the"            
##   [15] "infusoria under the microscope do the same.  No one gave a thought to"      
##   [16] "the older worlds of space as sources of human danger, or thought of"        
##   [17] "them only to dismiss the idea of life upon them as impossible or"           
##   [18] "improbable.  It is curious to recall some of the mental habits of"          
##   [19] "those departed days.  At most terrestrial men fancied there might be"       
##   [20] "other men upon Mars, perhaps inferior to themselves and ready to"           
##   [21] "welcome a missionary enterprise.  Yet across the gulf of space, minds"      
##   [22] "that are to our minds as ours are to those of the beasts that perish,"      
##   [23] "intellects vast and cool and unsympathetic, regarded this earth with"       
##   [24] "envious eyes, and slowly and surely drew their plans against us.  And"      
##   [25] "early in the twentieth century came the great disillusionment."             
##   [26] ""                                                                           
##   [27] "The planet Mars, I scarcely need remind the reader, revolves about the"     
##   [28] "sun at a mean distance of 140,000,000 miles, and the light and heat it"     
##   [29] "receives from the sun is barely half of that received by this world."       
##   [30] "It must be, if the nebular hypothesis has any truth, older than our"        
##   [31] "world; and long before this earth ceased to be molten, life upon its"       
##   [32] "surface must have begun its course.  The fact that it is scarcely one"      
##   [33] "seventh of the volume of the earth must have accelerated its cooling"       
##   [34] "to the temperature at which life could begin.  It has air and water"        
##   [35] "and all that is necessary for the support of animated existence."           
##   [36] ""                                                                           
##   [37] "Yet so vain is man, and so blinded by his vanity, that no writer,"          
##   [38] "up to the very end of the nineteenth century, expressed any idea that"      
##   [39] "intelligent life might have developed there far, or indeed at all,"         
##   [40] "beyond its earthly level.  Nor was it generally understood that since"      
##   [41] "Mars is older than our earth, with scarcely a quarter of the"               
##   [42] "superficial area and remoter from the sun, it necessarily follows that"     
##   [43] "it is not only more distant from time's beginning but nearer its end."      
##   [44] ""                                                                           
##   [45] "The secular cooling that must someday overtake our planet has"              
##   [46] "already gone far indeed with our neighbour.  Its physical condition is"     
##   [47] "still largely a mystery, but we know now that even in its equatorial"       
##   [48] "region the midday temperature barely approaches that of our coldest"        
##   [49] "winter.  Its air is much more attenuated than ours, its oceans have"        
##   [50] "shrunk until they cover but a third of its surface, and as its slow"        
##   [51] "seasons change huge snowcaps gather and melt about either pole and"         
##   [52] "periodically inundate its temperate zones.  That last stage of"             
##   [53] "exhaustion, which to us is still incredibly remote, has become a"           
##   [54] "present-day problem for the inhabitants of Mars.  The immediate"            
##   [55] "pressure of necessity has brightened their intellects, enlarged their"      
##   [56] "powers, and hardened their hearts.  And looking across space with"          
##   [57] "instruments, and intelligences such as we have scarcely dreamed of,"        
##   [58] "they see, at its nearest distance only 35,000,000 of miles sunward of"      
##   [59] "them, a morning star of hope, our own warmer planet, green with"            
##   [60] "vegetation and grey with water, with a cloudy atmosphere eloquent of"       
##   [61] "fertility, with glimpses through its drifting cloud wisps of broad"         
##   [62] "stretches of populous country and narrow, navy-crowded seas."               
##   [63] ""                                                                           
##   [64] "And we men, the creatures who inhabit this earth, must be to them"          
##   [65] "at least as alien and lowly as are the monkeys and lemurs to us.  The"      
##   [66] "intellectual side of man already admits that life is an incessant"          
##   [67] "struggle for existence, and it would seem that this too is the belief"      
##   [68] "of the minds upon Mars.  Their world is far gone in its cooling and"        
##   [69] "this world is still crowded with life, but crowded only with what they"     
##   [70] "regard as inferior animals.  To carry warfare sunward is, indeed,"          
##   [71] "their only escape from the destruction that, generation after"              
##   [72] "generation, creeps upon them."                                              
##   [73] ""                                                                           
##   [74] "And before we judge of them too harshly we must remember what"              
##   [75] "ruthless and utter destruction our own species has wrought, not only"       
##   [76] "upon animals, such as the vanished bison and the dodo, but upon its"        
##   [77] "inferior races.  The Tasmanians, in spite of their human likeness,"         
##   [78] "were entirely swept out of existence in a war of extermination waged"       
##   [79] "by European immigrants, in the space of fifty years.  Are we such"          
##   [80] "apostles of mercy as to complain if the Martians warred in the same"        
##   [81] "spirit?"                                                                    
##   [82] ""                                                                           
##   [83] "The Martians seem to have calculated their descent with amazing"            
##   [84] "subtlety--their mathematical learning is evidently far in excess of"        
##   [85] "ours--and to have carried out their preparations with a well-nigh"          
##   [86] "perfect unanimity.  Had our instruments permitted it, we might have"        
##   [87] "seen the gathering trouble far back in the nineteenth century.  Men"        
##   [88] "like Schiaparelli watched the red planet--it is odd, by-the-bye, that"      
##   [89] "for countless centuries Mars has been the star of war--but failed to"       
##   [90] "interpret the fluctuating appearances of the markings they mapped so"       
##   [91] "well.  All that time the Martians must have been getting ready."            
##   [92] ""                                                                           
##   [93] "During the opposition of 1894 a great light was seen on the"                
##   [94] "illuminated part of the disk, first at the Lick Observatory, then by"       
##   [95] "Perrotin of Nice, and then by other observers.  English readers heard"      
##   [96] "of it first in the issue of _Nature_ dated August 2.  I am inclined to"     
##   [97] "think that this blaze may have been the casting of the huge gun, in"        
##   [98] "the vast pit sunk into their planet, from which their shots were fired"     
##   [99] "at us.  Peculiar markings, as yet unexplained, were seen near the site"     
##  [100] "of that outbreak during the next two oppositions."                          
##  [101] ""                                                                           
##  [102] "The storm burst upon us six years ago now.  As Mars approached"             
##  [103] "opposition, Lavelle of Java set the wires of the astronomical exchange"     
##  [104] "palpitating with the amazing intelligence of a huge outbreak of"            
##  [105] "incandescent gas upon the planet.  It had occurred towards midnight of"     
##  [106] "the twelfth; and the spectroscope, to which he had at once resorted,"       
##  [107] "indicated a mass of flaming gas, chiefly hydrogen, moving with an"          
##  [108] "enormous velocity towards this earth.  This jet of fire had become"         
##  [109] "invisible about a quarter past twelve.  He compared it to a colossal"       
##  [110] "puff of flame suddenly and violently squirted out of the planet, \"as"      
##  [111] "flaming gases rushed out of a gun.\""                                       
##  [112] ""                                                                           
##  [113] "A singularly appropriate phrase it proved.  Yet the next day there"         
##  [114] "was nothing of this in the papers except a little note in the _Daily"       
##  [115] "Telegraph_, and the world went in ignorance of one of the gravest"          
##  [116] "dangers that ever threatened the human race. I might not have heard of"     
##  [117] "the eruption at all had I not met Ogilvy, the well-known astronomer,"       
##  [118] "at Ottershaw.  He was immensely excited at the news, and in the excess"     
##  [119] "of his feelings invited me up to take a turn with him that night in a"      
##  [120] "scrutiny of the red planet."                                                
##  [121] ""                                                                           
##  [122] "In spite of all that has happened since, I still remember that"             
##  [123] "vigil very distinctly: the black and silent observatory, the shadowed"      
##  [124] "lantern throwing a feeble glow upon the floor in the corner, the"           
##  [125] "steady ticking of the clockwork of the telescope, the little slit in"       
##  [126] "the roof--an oblong profundity with the stardust streaked across it."       
##  [127] "Ogilvy moved about, invisible but audible.  Looking through the"            
##  [128] "telescope, one saw a circle of deep blue and the little round planet"       
##  [129] "swimming in the field.  It seemed such a little thing, so bright and"       
##  [130] "small and still, faintly marked with transverse stripes, and slightly"      
##  [131] "flattened from the perfect round.  But so little it was, so silvery"        
##  [132] "warm--a pin's-head of light! It was as if it quivered, but really this"     
##  [133] "was the telescope vibrating with the activity of the clockwork that"        
##  [134] "kept the planet in view."                                                   
##  [135] ""                                                                           
##  [136] "As I watched, the planet seemed to grow larger and smaller and to"          
##  [137] "advance and recede, but that was simply that my eye was tired.  Forty"      
##  [138] "millions of miles it was from us--more than forty millions of miles of"     
##  [139] "void.  Few people realise the immensity of vacancy in which the dust"       
##  [140] "of the material universe swims."                                            
##  [141] ""                                                                           
##  [142] "Near it in the field, I remember, were three faint points of light,"        
##  [143] "three telescopic stars infinitely remote, and all around it was the"        
##  [144] "unfathomable darkness of empty space.  You know how that blackness"         
##  [145] "looks on a frosty starlight night.  In a telescope it seems far"            
##  [146] "profounder.  And invisible to me because it was so remote and small,"       
##  [147] "flying swiftly and steadily towards me across that incredible"              
##  [148] "distance, drawing nearer every minute by so many thousands of miles,"       
##  [149] "came the Thing they were sending us, the Thing that was to bring so"        
##  [150] "much struggle and calamity and death to the earth.  I never dreamed of"     
##  [151] "it then as I watched; no one on earth dreamed of that unerring"             
##  [152] "missile."                                                                   
##  [153] ""                                                                           
##  [154] "That night, too, there was another jetting out of gas from the"             
##  [155] "distant planet.  I saw it.  A reddish flash at the edge, the slightest"     
##  [156] "projection of the outline just as the chronometer struck midnight; and"     
##  [157] "at that I told Ogilvy and he took my place.  The night was warm and I"      
##  [158] "was thirsty, and I went stretching my legs clumsily and feeling my way"     
##  [159] "in the darkness, to the little table where the siphon stood, while"         
##  [160] "Ogilvy exclaimed at the streamer of gas that came out towards us."          
##  [161] ""                                                                           
##  [162] "That night another invisible missile started on its way to the"             
##  [163] "earth from Mars, just a second or so under twenty-four hours after the"     
##  [164] "first one.  I remember how I sat on the table there in the blackness,"      
##  [165] "with patches of green and crimson swimming before my eyes.  I wished I"     
##  [166] "had a light to smoke by, little suspecting the meaning of the minute"       
##  [167] "gleam I had seen and all that it would presently bring me.  Ogilvy"         
##  [168] "watched till one, and then gave it up; and we lit the lantern and"          
##  [169] "walked over to his house.  Down below in the darkness were Ottershaw"       
##  [170] "and Chertsey and all their hundreds of people, sleeping in peace."          
##  [171] ""                                                                           
##  [172] "He was full of speculation that night about the condition of Mars,"         
##  [173] "and scoffed at the vulgar idea of its having inhabitants who were"          
##  [174] "signalling us.  His idea was that meteorites might be falling in a"         
##  [175] "heavy shower upon the planet, or that a huge volcanic explosion was in"     
##  [176] "progress.  He pointed out to me how unlikely it was that organic"           
##  [177] "evolution had taken the same direction in the two adjacent planets."        
##  [178] ""                                                                           
##  [179] "\"The chances against anything manlike on Mars are a million to"            
##  [180] "one,\" he said."                                                            
##  [181] ""                                                                           
##  [182] "Hundreds of observers saw the flame that night and the night after"         
##  [183] "about midnight, and again the night after; and so for ten nights, a"        
##  [184] "flame each night.  Why the shots ceased after the tenth no one on"          
##  [185] "earth has attempted to explain.  It may be the gases of the firing"         
##  [186] "caused the Martians inconvenience.  Dense clouds of smoke or dust,"         
##  [187] "visible through a powerful telescope on earth as little grey,"              
##  [188] "fluctuating patches, spread through the clearness of the planet's"          
##  [189] "atmosphere and obscured its more familiar features."                        
##  [190] ""                                                                           
##  [191] "Even the daily papers woke up to the disturbances at last, and"             
##  [192] "popular notes appeared here, there, and everywhere concerning the"          
##  [193] "volcanoes upon Mars.  The seriocomic periodical _Punch_, I remember,"       
##  [194] "made a happy use of it in the political cartoon.  And, all"                 
##  [195] "unsuspected, those missiles the Martians had fired at us drew"              
##  [196] "earthward, rushing now at a pace of many miles a second through the"        
##  [197] "empty gulf of space, hour by hour and day by day, nearer and nearer."       
##  [198] "It seems to me now almost incredibly wonderful that, with that swift"       
##  [199] "fate hanging over us, men could go about their petty concerns as they"      
##  [200] "did.  I remember how jubilant Markham was at securing a new photograph"     
##  [201] "of the planet for the illustrated paper he edited in those days."           
##  [202] "People in these latter times scarcely realise the abundance and"            
##  [203] "enterprise of our nineteenth-century papers.  For my own part, I was"       
##  [204] "much occupied in learning to ride the bicycle, and busy upon a series"      
##  [205] "of papers discussing the probable developments of moral ideas as"           
##  [206] "civilisation progressed."                                                   
##  [207] ""                                                                           
##  [208] "One night (the first missile then could scarcely have been"                 
##  [209] "10,000,000 miles away) I went for a walk with my wife.  It was"             
##  [210] "starlight and I explained the Signs of the Zodiac to her, and pointed"      
##  [211] "out Mars, a bright dot of light creeping zenithward, towards which so"      
##  [212] "many telescopes were pointed.  It was a warm night.  Coming home, a"        
##  [213] "party of excursionists from Chertsey or Isleworth passed us singing"        
##  [214] "and playing music.  There were lights in the upper windows of the"          
##  [215] "houses as the people went to bed.  From the railway station in the"         
##  [216] "distance came the sound of shunting trains, ringing and rumbling,"          
##  [217] "softened almost into melody by the distance.  My wife pointed out to"       
##  [218] "me the brightness of the red, green, and yellow signal lights hanging"      
##  [219] "in a framework against the sky.  It seemed so safe and tranquil."           
##  [220] ""                                                                           
##  [221] ""                                                                           
##  [222] ""                                                                           
##  [223] "CHAPTER TWO"                                                                
##  [224] ""                                                                           
##  [225] "THE FALLING STAR"                                                           
##  [226] ""                                                                           
##  [227] ""                                                                           
##  [228] "Then came the night of the first falling star.  It was seen early"          
##  [229] "in the morning, rushing over Winchester eastward, a line of flame high"     
##  [230] "in the atmosphere.  Hundreds must have seen it, and taken it for an"        
##  [231] "ordinary falling star.  Albin described it as leaving a greenish"           
##  [232] "streak behind it that glowed for some seconds.  Denning, our greatest"      
##  [233] "authority on meteorites, stated that the height of its first"               
##  [234] "appearance was about ninety or one hundred miles.  It seemed to him"        
##  [235] "that it fell to earth about one hundred miles east of him."                 
##  [236] ""                                                                           
##  [237] "I was at home at that hour and writing in my study; and although my"        
##  [238] "French windows face towards Ottershaw and the blind was up (for I"          
##  [239] "loved in those days to look up at the night sky), I saw nothing of it."     
##  [240] "Yet this strangest of all things that ever came to earth from outer"        
##  [241] "space must have fallen while I was sitting there, visible to me had I"      
##  [242] "only looked up as it passed.  Some of those who saw its flight say it"      
##  [243] "travelled with a hissing sound.  I myself heard nothing of that.  Many"     
##  [244] "people in Berkshire, Surrey, and Middlesex must have seen the fall of"      
##  [245] "it, and, at most, have thought that another meteorite had descended."       
##  [246] "No one seems to have troubled to look for the fallen mass that night."      
##  [247] ""                                                                           
##  [248] "But very early in the morning poor Ogilvy, who had seen the"                
##  [249] "shooting star and who was persuaded that a meteorite lay somewhere on"      
##  [250] "the common between Horsell, Ottershaw, and Woking, rose early with the"     
##  [251] "idea of finding it.  Find it he did, soon after dawn, and not far from"     
##  [252] "the sand pits.  An enormous hole had been made by the impact of the"        
##  [253] "projectile, and the sand and gravel had been flung violently in every"      
##  [254] "direction over the heath, forming heaps visible a mile and a half"          
##  [255] "away.  The heather was on fire eastward, and a thin blue smoke rose"        
##  [256] "against the dawn."                                                          
##  [257] ""                                                                           
##  [258] "The Thing itself lay almost entirely buried in sand, amidst the"            
##  [259] "scattered splinters of a fir tree it had shivered to fragments in its"      
##  [260] "descent.  The uncovered part had the appearance of a huge cylinder,"        
##  [261] "caked over and its outline softened by a thick scaly dun-coloured"          
##  [262] "incrustation.  It had a diameter of about thirty yards.  He approached"     
##  [263] "the mass, surprised at the size and more so at the shape, since most"       
##  [264] "meteorites are rounded more or less completely.  It was, however,"          
##  [265] "still so hot from its flight through the air as to forbid his near"         
##  [266] "approach.  A stirring noise within its cylinder he ascribed to the"         
##  [267] "unequal cooling of its surface; for at that time it had not occurred"       
##  [268] "to him that it might be hollow."                                            
##  [269] ""                                                                           
##  [270] "He remained standing at the edge of the pit that the Thing had made"        
##  [271] "for itself, staring at its strange appearance, astonished chiefly at"       
##  [272] "its unusual shape and colour, and dimly perceiving even then some"          
##  [273] "evidence of design in its arrival.  The early morning was wonderfully"      
##  [274] "still, and the sun, just clearing the pine trees towards Weybridge,"        
##  [275] "was already warm.  He did not remember hearing any birds that morning,"     
##  [276] "there was certainly no breeze stirring, and the only sounds were the"       
##  [277] "faint movements from within the cindery cylinder.  He was all alone on"     
##  [278] "the common."                                                                
##  [279] ""                                                                           
##  [280] "Then suddenly he noticed with a start that some of the grey"                
##  [281] "clinker, the ashy incrustation that covered the meteorite, was falling"     
##  [282] "off the circular edge of the end.  It was dropping off in flakes and"       
##  [283] "raining down upon the sand.  A large piece suddenly came off and fell"      
##  [284] "with a sharp noise that brought his heart into his mouth."                  
##  [285] ""                                                                           
##  [286] "For a minute he scarcely realised what this meant, and, although"           
##  [287] "the heat was excessive, he clambered down into the pit close to the"        
##  [288] "bulk to see the Thing more clearly.  He fancied even then that the"         
##  [289] "cooling of the body might account for this, but what disturbed that"        
##  [290] "idea was the fact that the ash was falling only from the end of the"        
##  [291] "cylinder."                                                                  
##  [292] ""                                                                           
##  [293] "And then he perceived that, very slowly, the circular top of the"           
##  [294] "cylinder was rotating on its body.  It was such a gradual movement"         
##  [295] "that he discovered it only through noticing that a black mark that had"     
##  [296] "been near him five minutes ago was now at the other side of the"            
##  [297] "circumference.  Even then he scarcely understood what this indicated,"      
##  [298] "until he heard a muffled grating sound and saw the black mark jerk"         
##  [299] "forward an inch or so.  Then the thing came upon him in a flash.  The"      
##  [300] "cylinder was artificial--hollow--with an end that screwed out!"             
##  [301] "Something within the cylinder was unscrewing the top!"                      
##  [302] ""                                                                           
##  [303] "\"Good heavens!\" said Ogilvy.  \"There's a man in it--men in it! Half"     
##  [304] "roasted to death!  Trying to escape!\""                                     
##  [305] ""                                                                           
##  [306] "At once, with a quick mental leap, he linked the Thing with the"            
##  [307] "flash upon Mars."                                                           
##  [308] ""                                                                           
##  [309] "The thought of the confined creature was so dreadful to him that he"        
##  [310] "forgot the heat and went forward to the cylinder to help turn.  But"        
##  [311] "luckily the dull radiation arrested him before he could burn his hands"     
##  [312] "on the still-glowing metal.  At that he stood irresolute for a moment,"     
##  [313] "then turned, scrambled out of the pit, and set off running wildly into"     
##  [314] "Woking.  The time then must have been somewhere about six o'clock."         
##  [315] "He met a waggoner and tried to make him understand, but the tale he"        
##  [316] "told and his appearance were so wild--his hat had fallen off in the"        
##  [317] "pit--that the man simply drove on.  He was equally unsuccessful with the"   
##  [318] "potman who was just unlocking the doors of the public-house by Horsell"     
##  [319] "Bridge.  The fellow thought he was a lunatic at large and made an"          
##  [320] "unsuccessful attempt to shut him into the taproom.  That sobered him a"     
##  [321] "little; and when he saw Henderson, the London journalist, in his"           
##  [322] "garden, he called over the palings and made himself understood."            
##  [323] ""                                                                           
##  [324] "\"Henderson,\" he called, \"you saw that shooting star last night?\""       
##  [325] ""                                                                           
##  [326] "\"Well?\" said Henderson."                                                  
##  [327] ""                                                                           
##  [328] "\"It's out on Horsell Common now.\""                                        
##  [329] ""                                                                           
##  [330] "\"Good Lord!\" said Henderson.  \"Fallen meteorite!  That's good.\""        
##  [331] ""                                                                           
##  [332] "\"But it's something more than a meteorite.  It's a cylinder--an"           
##  [333] "artificial cylinder, man!  And there's something inside.\""                 
##  [334] ""                                                                           
##  [335] "Henderson stood up with his spade in his hand."                             
##  [336] ""                                                                           
##  [337] "\"What's that?\" he said.  He was deaf in one ear."                         
##  [338] ""                                                                           
##  [339] "Ogilvy told him all that he had seen.  Henderson was a minute or so"        
##  [340] "taking it in.  Then he dropped his spade, snatched up his jacket, and"      
##  [341] "came out into the road.  The two men hurried back at once to the"           
##  [342] "common, and found the cylinder still lying in the same position.  But"      
##  [343] "now the sounds inside had ceased, and a thin circle of bright metal"        
##  [344] "showed between the top and the body of the cylinder.  Air was either"       
##  [345] "entering or escaping at the rim with a thin, sizzling sound."               
##  [346] ""                                                                           
##  [347] "They listened, rapped on the scaly burnt metal with a stick, and,"          
##  [348] "meeting with no response, they both concluded the man or men inside"        
##  [349] "must be insensible or dead."                                                
##  [350] ""                                                                           
##  [351] "Of course the two were quite unable to do anything.  They shouted"          
##  [352] "consolation and promises, and went off back to the town again to get"       
##  [353] "help.  One can imagine them, covered with sand, excited and"                
##  [354] "disordered, running up the little street in the bright sunlight just"       
##  [355] "as the shop folks were taking down their shutters and people were"          
##  [356] "opening their bedroom windows.  Henderson went into the railway"            
##  [357] "station at once, in order to telegraph the news to London.  The"            
##  [358] "newspaper articles had prepared men's minds for the reception of the"       
##  [359] "idea."                                                                      
##  [360] ""                                                                           
##  [361] "By eight o'clock a number of boys and unemployed men had already"           
##  [362] "started for the common to see the \"dead men from Mars.\"  That was the"    
##  [363] "form the story took.  I heard of it first from my newspaper boy about"      
##  [364] "a quarter to nine when I went out to get my _Daily Chronicle_.  I was"      
##  [365] "naturally startled, and lost no time in going out and across the"           
##  [366] "Ottershaw bridge to the sand pits."                                         
##  [367] ""                                                                           
##  [368] ""                                                                           
##  [369] ""                                                                           
##  [370] "CHAPTER THREE"                                                              
##  [371] ""                                                                           
##  [372] "ON HORSELL COMMON"                                                          
##  [373] ""                                                                           
##  [374] ""                                                                           
##  [375] "I found a little crowd of perhaps twenty people surrounding the"            
##  [376] "huge hole in which the cylinder lay.  I have already described the"         
##  [377] "appearance of that colossal bulk, embedded in the ground.  The turf"        
##  [378] "and gravel about it seemed charred as if by a sudden explosion.  No"        
##  [379] "doubt its impact had caused a flash of fire.  Henderson and Ogilvy"         
##  [380] "were not there.  I think they perceived that nothing was to be done"        
##  [381] "for the present, and had gone away to breakfast at Henderson's house."      
##  [382] ""                                                                           
##  [383] "There were four or five boys sitting on the edge of the Pit, with"          
##  [384] "their feet dangling, and amusing themselves--until I stopped them--by"      
##  [385] "throwing stones at the giant mass.  After I had spoken to them about"       
##  [386] "it, they began playing at \"touch\" in and out of the group of"             
##  [387] "bystanders."                                                                
##  [388] ""                                                                           
##  [389] "Among these were a couple of cyclists, a jobbing gardener I"                
##  [390] "employed sometimes, a girl carrying a baby, Gregg the butcher and his"      
##  [391] "little boy, and two or three loafers and golf caddies who were"             
##  [392] "accustomed to hang about the railway station.  There was very little"       
##  [393] "talking.  Few of the common people in England had anything but the"         
##  [394] "vaguest astronomical ideas in those days.  Most of them were staring"       
##  [395] "quietly at the big table like end of the cylinder, which was still as"      
##  [396] "Ogilvy and Henderson had left it.  I fancy the popular expectation of"      
##  [397] "a heap of charred corpses was disappointed at this inanimate bulk."         
##  [398] "Some went away while I was there, and other people came.  I clambered"      
##  [399] "into the pit and fancied I heard a faint movement under my feet.  The"      
##  [400] "top had certainly ceased to rotate."                                        
##  [401] ""                                                                           
##  [402] "It was only when I got thus close to it that the strangeness of"            
##  [403] "this object was at all evident to me.  At the first glance it was"          
##  [404] "really no more exciting than an overturned carriage or a tree blown"        
##  [405] "across the road.  Not so much so, indeed.  It looked like a rusty gas"      
##  [406] "float.  It required a certain amount of scientific education to"            
##  [407] "perceive that the grey scale of the Thing was no common oxide, that"        
##  [408] "the yellowish-white metal that gleamed in the crack between the lid"        
##  [409] "and the cylinder had an unfamiliar hue.  \"Extra-terrestrial\" had no"      
##  [410] "meaning for most of the onlookers."                                         
##  [411] ""                                                                           
##  [412] "At that time it was quite clear in my own mind that the Thing had"          
##  [413] "come from the planet Mars, but I judged it improbable that it"              
##  [414] "contained any living creature.  I thought the unscrewing might be"          
##  [415] "automatic.  In spite of Ogilvy, I still believed that there were men"       
##  [416] "in Mars.  My mind ran fancifully on the possibilities of its"               
##  [417] "containing manuscript, on the difficulties in translation that might"       
##  [418] "arise, whether we should find coins and models in it, and so forth."        
##  [419] "Yet it was a little too large for assurance on this idea.  I felt an"       
##  [420] "impatience to see it opened.  About eleven, as nothing seemed"              
##  [421] "happening, I walked back, full of such thought, to my home in Maybury."     
##  [422] "But I found it difficult to get to work upon my abstract"                   
##  [423] "investigations."                                                            
##  [424] ""                                                                           
##  [425] "In the afternoon the appearance of the common had altered very"             
##  [426] "much.  The early editions of the evening papers had startled London"        
##  [427] "with enormous headlines:"                                                   
##  [428] ""                                                                           
##  [429] "  \"A MESSAGE RECEIVED FROM MARS.\""                                        
##  [430] ""                                                                           
##  [431] "  \"REMARKABLE STORY FROM WOKING,\""                                        
##  [432] ""                                                                           
##  [433] "and so forth.  In addition, Ogilvy's wire to the Astronomical Exchange"     
##  [434] "had roused every observatory in the three kingdoms."                        
##  [435] ""                                                                           
##  [436] "There were half a dozen flies or more from the Woking station"              
##  [437] "standing in the road by the sand pits, a basket-chaise from Chobham,"       
##  [438] "and a rather lordly carriage.  Besides that, there was quite a heap of"     
##  [439] "bicycles.  In addition, a large number of people must have walked, in"      
##  [440] "spite of the heat of the day, from Woking and Chertsey, so that there"      
##  [441] "was altogether quite a considerable crowd--one or two gaily dressed"        
##  [442] "ladies among the others."                                                   
##  [443] ""                                                                           
##  [444] "It was glaringly hot, not a cloud in the sky nor a breath of wind,"         
##  [445] "and the only shadow was that of the few scattered pine trees.  The"         
##  [446] "burning heather had been extinguished, but the level ground towards"        
##  [447] "Ottershaw was blackened as far as one could see, and still giving off"      
##  [448] "vertical streamers of smoke.  An enterprising sweet-stuff dealer in"        
##  [449] "the Chobham Road had sent up his son with a barrow-load of green"           
##  [450] "apples and ginger beer."                                                    
##  [451] ""                                                                           
##  [452] "Going to the edge of the pit, I found it occupied by a group of"            
##  [453] "about half a dozen men--Henderson, Ogilvy, and a tall, fair-haired man"     
##  [454] "that I afterwards learned was Stent, the Astronomer Royal, with"            
##  [455] "several workmen wielding spades and pickaxes.  Stent was giving"            
##  [456] "directions in a clear, high-pitched voice.  He was standing on the"         
##  [457] "cylinder, which was now evidently much cooler; his face was crimson"        
##  [458] "and streaming with perspiration, and something seemed to have"              
##  [459] "irritated him."                                                             
##  [460] ""                                                                           
##  [461] "A large portion of the cylinder had been uncovered, though its"             
##  [462] "lower end was still embedded.  As soon as Ogilvy saw me among the"          
##  [463] "staring crowd on the edge of the pit he called to me to come down, and"     
##  [464] "asked me if I would mind going over to see Lord Hilton, the lord of"        
##  [465] "the manor."                                                                 
##  [466] ""                                                                           
##  [467] "The growing crowd, he said, was becoming a serious impediment to"           
##  [468] "their excavations, especially the boys.  They wanted a light railing"       
##  [469] "put up, and help to keep the people back.  He told me that a faint"         
##  [470] "stirring was occasionally still audible within the case, but that the"      
##  [471] "workmen had failed to unscrew the top, as it afforded no grip to them."     
##  [472] "The case appeared to be enormously thick, and it was possible that the"     
##  [473] "faint sounds we heard represented a noisy tumult in the interior."          
##  [474] ""                                                                           
##  [475] "I was very glad to do as he asked, and so become one of the"                
##  [476] "privileged spectators within the contemplated enclosure.  I failed to"      
##  [477] "find Lord Hilton at his house, but I was told he was expected from"         
##  [478] "London by the six o'clock train from Waterloo; and as it was then"          
##  [479] "about a quarter past five, I went home, had some tea, and walked up to"     
##  [480] "the station to waylay him."                                                 
##  [481] ""                                                                           
##  [482] ""                                                                           
##  [483] ""                                                                           
##  [484] "CHAPTER FOUR"                                                               
##  [485] ""                                                                           
##  [486] "THE CYLINDER OPENS"                                                         
##  [487] ""                                                                           
##  [488] ""                                                                           
##  [489] "When I returned to the common the sun was setting.  Scattered groups"       
##  [490] "were hurrying from the direction of Woking, and one or two persons"         
##  [491] "were returning.  The crowd about the pit had increased, and stood out"      
##  [492] "black against the lemon yellow of the sky--a couple of hundred people,"     
##  [493] "perhaps.  There were raised voices, and some sort of struggle appeared"     
##  [494] "to be going on about the pit.  Strange imaginings passed through my"        
##  [495] "mind.  As I drew nearer I heard Stent's voice:"                             
##  [496] ""                                                                           
##  [497] "\"Keep back!  Keep back!\""                                                 
##  [498] ""                                                                           
##  [499] "A boy came running towards me."                                             
##  [500] ""                                                                           
##  [501] "\"It's a-movin',\" he said to me as he passed; \"a-screwin' and"            
##  [502] "a-screwin' out.  I don't like it.  I'm a-goin' 'ome, I am.\""               
##  [503] ""                                                                           
##  [504] "I went on to the crowd.  There were really, I should think, two or"         
##  [505] "three hundred people elbowing and jostling one another, the one or two"     
##  [506] "ladies there being by no means the least active."                           
##  [507] ""                                                                           
##  [508] "\"He's fallen in the pit!\" cried some one."                                
##  [509] ""                                                                           
##  [510] "\"Keep back!\" said several."                                               
##  [511] ""                                                                           
##  [512] "The crowd swayed a little, and I elbowed my way through.  Every one"        
##  [513] "seemed greatly excited.  I heard a peculiar humming sound from the"         
##  [514] "pit."                                                                       
##  [515] ""                                                                           
##  [516] "\"I say!\" said Ogilvy; \"help keep these idiots back.  We don't know"      
##  [517] "what's in the confounded thing, you know!\""                                
##  [518] ""                                                                           
##  [519] "I saw a young man, a shop assistant in Woking I believe he was,"            
##  [520] "standing on the cylinder and trying to scramble out of the hole again."     
##  [521] "The crowd had pushed him in."                                               
##  [522] ""                                                                           
##  [523] "The end of the cylinder was being screwed out from within.  Nearly"         
##  [524] "two feet of shining screw projected.  Somebody blundered against me,"       
##  [525] "and I narrowly missed being pitched onto the top of the screw.  I"          
##  [526] "turned, and as I did so the screw must have come out, for the lid of"       
##  [527] "the cylinder fell upon the gravel with a ringing concussion.  I stuck"      
##  [528] "my elbow into the person behind me, and turned my head towards the"         
##  [529] "Thing again.  For a moment that circular cavity seemed perfectly black."    
##  [530] "I had the sunset in my eyes."                                               
##  [531] ""                                                                           
##  [532] "I think everyone expected to see a man emerge--possibly something a"        
##  [533] "little unlike us terrestrial men, but in all essentials a man.  I know"     
##  [534] "I did.  But, looking, I presently saw something stirring within the"        
##  [535] "shadow: greyish billowy movements, one above another, and then two"         
##  [536] "luminous disks--like eyes.  Then something resembling a little grey"        
##  [537] "snake, about the thickness of a walking stick, coiled up out of the"        
##  [538] "writhing middle, and wriggled in the air towards me--and then another."     
##  [539] ""                                                                           
##  [540] "A sudden chill came over me.  There was a loud shriek from a woman"         
##  [541] "behind.  I half turned, keeping my eyes fixed upon the cylinder still,"     
##  [542] "from which other tentacles were now projecting, and began pushing my"       
##  [543] "way back from the edge of the pit.  I saw astonishment giving place to"     
##  [544] "horror on the faces of the people about me.  I heard inarticulate"          
##  [545] "exclamations on all sides.  There was a general movement backwards."        
##  [546] "I saw the shopman struggling still on the edge of the pit.  I found"        
##  [547] "myself alone, and saw the people on the other side of the pit running"      
##  [548] "off, Stent among them.  I looked again at the cylinder, and"                
##  [549] "ungovernable terror gripped me.  I stood petrified and staring."            
##  [550] ""                                                                           
##  [551] "A big greyish rounded bulk, the size, perhaps, of a bear, was"              
##  [552] "rising slowly and painfully out of the cylinder.  As it bulged up and"      
##  [553] "caught the light, it glistened like wet leather."                           
##  [554] ""                                                                           
##  [555] "Two large dark-coloured eyes were regarding me steadfastly.  The"           
##  [556] "mass that framed them, the head of the thing, was rounded, and had,"        
##  [557] "one might say, a face.  There was a mouth under the eyes, the lipless"      
##  [558] "brim of which quivered and panted, and dropped saliva.  The whole"          
##  [559] "creature heaved and pulsated convulsively.  A lank tentacular"              
##  [560] "appendage gripped the edge of the cylinder, another swayed in the air."     
##  [561] ""                                                                           
##  [562] "Those who have never seen a living Martian can scarcely imagine the"        
##  [563] "strange horror of its appearance.  The peculiar V-shaped mouth with"        
##  [564] "its pointed upper lip, the absence of brow ridges, the absence of a"        
##  [565] "chin beneath the wedgelike lower lip, the incessant quivering of this"      
##  [566] "mouth, the Gorgon groups of tentacles, the tumultuous breathing of the"     
##  [567] "lungs in a strange atmosphere, the evident heaviness and painfulness"       
##  [568] "of movement due to the greater gravitational energy of the earth--above"    
##  [569] "all, the extraordinary intensity of the immense eyes--were at"              
##  [570] "once vital, intense, inhuman, crippled and monstrous.  There was"           
##  [571] "something fungoid in the oily brown skin, something in the clumsy"          
##  [572] "deliberation of the tedious movements unspeakably nasty.  Even at this"     
##  [573] "first encounter, this first glimpse, I was overcome with disgust and"       
##  [574] "dread."                                                                     
##  [575] ""                                                                           
##  [576] "Suddenly the monster vanished.  It had toppled over the brim of the"        
##  [577] "cylinder and fallen into the pit, with a thud like the fall of a great"     
##  [578] "mass of leather.  I heard it give a peculiar thick cry, and forthwith"      
##  [579] "another of these creatures appeared darkly in the deep shadow of the"       
##  [580] "aperture."                                                                  
##  [581] ""                                                                           
##  [582] "I turned and, running madly, made for the first group of trees,"            
##  [583] "perhaps a hundred yards away; but I ran slantingly and stumbling, for"      
##  [584] "I could not avert my face from these things."                               
##  [585] ""                                                                           
##  [586] "There, among some young pine trees and furze bushes, I stopped,"            
##  [587] "panting, and waited further developments.  The common round the sand"       
##  [588] "pits was dotted with people, standing like myself in a half-fascinated"     
##  [589] "terror, staring at these creatures, or rather at the heaped gravel at"      
##  [590] "the edge of the pit in which they lay.  And then, with a renewed"           
##  [591] "horror, I saw a round, black object bobbing up and down on the edge of"     
##  [592] "the pit.  It was the head of the shopman who had fallen in, but"            
##  [593] "showing as a little black object against the hot western sun.  Now he"      
##  [594] "got his shoulder and knee up, and again he seemed to slip back until"       
##  [595] "only his head was visible.  Suddenly he vanished, and I could have"         
##  [596] "fancied a faint shriek had reached me.  I had a momentary impulse to"       
##  [597] "go back and help him that my fears overruled."                              
##  [598] ""                                                                           
##  [599] "Everything was then quite invisible, hidden by the deep pit and the"        
##  [600] "heap of sand that the fall of the cylinder had made.  Anyone coming"        
##  [601] "along the road from Chobham or Woking would have been amazed at the"        
##  [602] "sight--a dwindling multitude of perhaps a hundred people or more"           
##  [603] "standing in a great irregular circle, in ditches, behind bushes,"           
##  [604] "behind gates and hedges, saying little to one another and that in"          
##  [605] "short, excited shouts, and staring, staring hard at a few heaps of"         
##  [606] "sand.  The barrow of ginger beer stood, a queer derelict, black"            
##  [607] "against the burning sky, and in the sand pits was a row of deserted"        
##  [608] "vehicles with their horses feeding out of nosebags or pawing the"           
##  [609] "ground."                                                                    
##  [610] ""                                                                           
##  [611] ""                                                                           
##  [612] ""                                                                           
##  [613] "CHAPTER FIVE"                                                               
##  [614] ""                                                                           
##  [615] "THE HEAT-RAY"                                                               
##  [616] ""                                                                           
##  [617] ""                                                                           
##  [618] "After the glimpse I had had of the Martians emerging from the"              
##  [619] "cylinder in which they had come to the earth from their planet, a kind"     
##  [620] "of fascination paralysed my actions.  I remained standing knee-deep in"     
##  [621] "the heather, staring at the mound that hid them.  I was a battleground"     
##  [622] "of fear and curiosity."                                                     
##  [623] ""                                                                           
##  [624] "I did not dare to go back towards the pit, but I felt a passionate"         
##  [625] "longing to peer into it.  I began walking, therefore, in a big curve,"      
##  [626] "seeking some point of vantage and continually looking at the sand"          
##  [627] "heaps that hid these new-comers to our earth.  Once a leash of thin"        
##  [628] "black whips, like the arms of an octopus, flashed across the sunset"        
##  [629] "and was immediately withdrawn, and afterwards a thin rod rose up,"          
##  [630] "joint by joint, bearing at its apex a circular disk that spun with a"       
##  [631] "wobbling motion.  What could be going on there?"                            
##  [632] ""                                                                           
##  [633] "Most of the spectators had gathered in one or two groups--one a"            
##  [634] "little crowd towards Woking, the other a knot of people in the"             
##  [635] "direction of Chobham.  Evidently they shared my mental conflict."           
##  [636] "There were few near me.  One man I approached--he was, I perceived,"        
##  [637] "a neighbour of mine, though I did not know his name--and accosted."         
##  [638] "But it was scarcely a time for articulate conversation."                    
##  [639] ""                                                                           
##  [640] "\"What ugly _brutes_!\" he said.  \"Good God!  What ugly brutes!\"  He"     
##  [641] "repeated this over and over again."                                         
##  [642] ""                                                                           
##  [643] "\"Did you see a man in the pit?\" I said; but he made no answer to"         
##  [644] "that.  We became silent, and stood watching for a time side by side,"       
##  [645] "deriving, I fancy, a certain comfort in one another's company.  Then I"     
##  [646] "shifted my position to a little knoll that gave me the advantage of a"      
##  [647] "yard or more of elevation and when I looked for him presently he was"       
##  [648] "walking towards Woking."                                                    
##  [649] ""                                                                           
##  [650] "The sunset faded to twilight before anything further happened.  The"        
##  [651] "crowd far away on the left, towards Woking, seemed to grow, and I"          
##  [652] "heard now a faint murmur from it.  The little knot of people towards"       
##  [653] "Chobham dispersed.  There was scarcely an intimation of movement from"      
##  [654] "the pit."                                                                   
##  [655] ""                                                                           
##  [656] "It was this, as much as anything, that gave people courage, and I"          
##  [657] "suppose the new arrivals from Woking also helped to restore"                
##  [658] "confidence.  At any rate, as the dusk came on a slow, intermittent"         
##  [659] "movement upon the sand pits began, a movement that seemed to gather"        
##  [660] "force as the stillness of the evening about the cylinder remained"          
##  [661] "unbroken.  Vertical black figures in twos and threes would advance,"        
##  [662] "stop, watch, and advance again, spreading out as they did so in a thin"     
##  [663] "irregular crescent that promised to enclose the pit in its attenuated"      
##  [664] "horns.  I, too, on my side began to move towards the pit."                  
##  [665] ""                                                                           
##  [666] "Then I saw some cabmen and others had walked boldly into the sand"          
##  [667] "pits, and heard the clatter of hoofs and the gride of wheels.  I saw a"     
##  [668] "lad trundling off the barrow of apples.  And then, within thirty yards"     
##  [669] "of the pit, advancing from the direction of Horsell, I noted a little"      
##  [670] "black knot of men, the foremost of whom was waving a white flag."           
##  [671] ""                                                                           
##  [672] "This was the Deputation.  There had been a hasty consultation, and"         
##  [673] "since the Martians were evidently, in spite of their repulsive forms,"      
##  [674] "intelligent creatures, it had been resolved to show them, by"               
##  [675] "approaching them with signals, that we too were intelligent."               
##  [676] ""                                                                           
##  [677] "Flutter, flutter, went the flag, first to the right, then to the"           
##  [678] "left.  It was too far for me to recognise anyone there, but afterwards"     
##  [679] "I learned that Ogilvy, Stent, and Henderson were with others in this"       
##  [680] "attempt at communication.  This little group had in its advance"            
##  [681] "dragged inward, so to speak, the circumference of the now almost"           
##  [682] "complete circle of people, and a number of dim black figures followed"      
##  [683] "it at discreet distances."                                                  
##  [684] ""                                                                           
##  [685] "Suddenly there was a flash of light, and a quantity of luminous"            
##  [686] "greenish smoke came out of the pit in three distinct puffs, which"          
##  [687] "drove up, one after the other, straight into the still air."                
##  [688] ""                                                                           
##  [689] "This smoke (or flame, perhaps, would be the better word for it) was"        
##  [690] "so bright that the deep blue sky overhead and the hazy stretches of"        
##  [691] "brown common towards Chertsey, set with black pine trees, seemed to"        
##  [692] "darken abruptly as these puffs arose, and to remain the darker after"       
##  [693] "their dispersal.  At the same time a faint hissing sound became"            
##  [694] "audible."                                                                   
##  [695] ""                                                                           
##  [696] "Beyond the pit stood the little wedge of people with the white flag"        
##  [697] "at its apex, arrested by these phenomena, a little knot of small"           
##  [698] "vertical black shapes upon the black ground.  As the green smoke arose,"    
##  [699] "their faces flashed out pallid green, and faded again as it vanished."      
##  [700] "Then slowly the hissing passed into a humming, into a long, loud,"          
##  [701] "droning noise.  Slowly a humped shape rose out of the pit, and the"         
##  [702] "ghost of a beam of light seemed to flicker out from it."                    
##  [703] ""                                                                           
##  [704] "Forthwith flashes of actual flame, a bright glare leaping from one"         
##  [705] "to another, sprang from the scattered group of men.  It was as if some"     
##  [706] "invisible jet impinged upon them and flashed into white flame.  It was"     
##  [707] "as if each man were suddenly and momentarily turned to fire."               
##  [708] ""                                                                           
##  [709] "Then, by the light of their own destruction, I saw them staggering"         
##  [710] "and falling, and their supporters turning to run."                          
##  [711] ""                                                                           
##  [712] "I stood staring, not as yet realising that this was death leaping"          
##  [713] "from man to man in that little distant crowd.  All I felt was that it"      
##  [714] "was something very strange.  An almost noiseless and blinding flash of"     
##  [715] "light, and a man fell headlong and lay still; and as the unseen shaft"      
##  [716] "of heat passed over them, pine trees burst into fire, and every dry"        
##  [717] "furze bush became with one dull thud a mass of flames.  And far away"       
##  [718] "towards Knaphill I saw the flashes of trees and hedges and wooden"          
##  [719] "buildings suddenly set alight."                                             
##  [720] ""                                                                           
##  [721] "It was sweeping round swiftly and steadily, this flaming death,"            
##  [722] "this invisible, inevitable sword of heat.  I perceived it coming"           
##  [723] "towards me by the flashing bushes it touched, and was too astounded"        
##  [724] "and stupefied to stir.  I heard the crackle of fire in the sand pits"       
##  [725] "and the sudden squeal of a horse that was as suddenly stilled.  Then"       
##  [726] "it was as if an invisible yet intensely heated finger were drawn"           
##  [727] "through the heather between me and the Martians, and all along a"           
##  [728] "curving line beyond the sand pits the dark ground smoked and crackled."     
##  [729] "Something fell with a crash far away to the left where the road from"       
##  [730] "Woking station opens out on the common.  Forth-with the hissing and"        
##  [731] "humming ceased, and the black, dome-like object sank slowly out of"         
##  [732] "sight into the pit."                                                        
##  [733] ""                                                                           
##  [734] "All this had happened with such swiftness that I had stood"                 
##  [735] "motionless, dumbfounded and dazzled by the flashes of light.  Had that"     
##  [736] "death swept through a full circle, it must inevitably have slain me in"     
##  [737] "my surprise.  But it passed and spared me, and left the night about me"     
##  [738] "suddenly dark and unfamiliar."                                              
##  [739] ""                                                                           
##  [740] "The undulating common seemed now dark almost to blackness, except"          
##  [741] "where its roadways lay grey and pale under the deep blue sky of the"        
##  [742] "early night.  It was dark, and suddenly void of men.  Overhead the"         
##  [743] "stars were mustering, and in the west the sky was still a pale,"            
##  [744] "bright, almost greenish blue.  The tops of the pine trees and the"          
##  [745] "roofs of Horsell came out sharp and black against the western"              
##  [746] "afterglow.  The Martians and their appliances were altogether"              
##  [747] "invisible, save for that thin mast upon which their restless mirror"        
##  [748] "wobbled.  Patches of bush and isolated trees here and there smoked and"     
##  [749] "glowed still, and the houses towards Woking station were sending up"        
##  [750] "spires of flame into the stillness of the evening air."                     
##  [751] ""                                                                           
##  [752] "Nothing was changed save for that and a terrible astonishment.  The"        
##  [753] "little group of black specks with the flag of white had been swept out"     
##  [754] "of existence, and the stillness of the evening, so it seemed to me,"        
##  [755] "had scarcely been broken."                                                  
##  [756] ""                                                                           
##  [757] "It came to me that I was upon this dark common, helpless,"                  
##  [758] "unprotected, and alone.  Suddenly, like a thing falling upon me from"       
##  [759] "without, came--fear."                                                       
##  [760] ""                                                                           
##  [761] "With an effort I turned and began a stumbling run through the"              
##  [762] "heather."                                                                   
##  [763] ""                                                                           
##  [764] "The fear I felt was no rational fear, but a panic terror not only"          
##  [765] "of the Martians, but of the dusk and stillness all about me.  Such an"      
##  [766] "extraordinary effect in unmanning me it had that I ran weeping"             
##  [767] "silently as a child might do.  Once I had turned, I did not dare to"        
##  [768] "look back."                                                                 
##  [769] ""                                                                           
##  [770] "I remember I felt an extraordinary persuasion that I was being"             
##  [771] "played with, that presently, when I was upon the very verge of safety,"     
##  [772] "this mysterious death--as swift as the passage of light--would leap"        
##  [773] "after me from the pit about the cylinder and strike me down."               
##  [774] ""                                                                           
##  [775] ""                                                                           
##  [776] ""                                                                           
##  [777] "CHAPTER SIX"                                                                
##  [778] ""                                                                           
##  [779] "THE HEAT-RAY IN THE CHOBHAM ROAD"                                           
##  [780] ""                                                                           
##  [781] ""                                                                           
##  [782] "It is still a matter of wonder how the Martians are able to slay"           
##  [783] "men so swiftly and so silently.  Many think that in some way they are"      
##  [784] "able to generate an intense heat in a chamber of practically absolute"      
##  [785] "non-conductivity.  This intense heat they project in a parallel beam"       
##  [786] "against any object they choose, by means of a polished parabolic"           
##  [787] "mirror of unknown composition, much as the parabolic mirror of a"           
##  [788] "lighthouse projects a beam of light.  But no one has absolutely proved"     
##  [789] "these details.  However it is done, it is certain that a beam of heat"      
##  [790] "is the essence of the matter.  Heat, and invisible, instead of"             
##  [791] "visible, light.  Whatever is combustible flashes into flame at its"         
##  [792] "touch, lead runs like water, it softens iron, cracks and melts glass,"      
##  [793] "and when it falls upon water, incontinently that explodes into steam."      
##  [794] ""                                                                           
##  [795] "That night nearly forty people lay under the starlight about the"           
##  [796] "pit, charred and distorted beyond recognition, and all night long the"      
##  [797] "common from Horsell to Maybury was deserted and brightly ablaze."           
##  [798] ""                                                                           
##  [799] "The news of the massacre probably reached Chobham, Woking, and"             
##  [800] "Ottershaw about the same time.  In Woking the shops had closed when"        
##  [801] "the tragedy happened, and a number of people, shop people and so"           
##  [802] "forth, attracted by the stories they had heard, were walking over the"      
##  [803] "Horsell Bridge and along the road between the hedges that runs out at"      
##  [804] "last upon the common.  You may imagine the young people brushed up"         
##  [805] "after the labours of the day, and making this novelty, as they would"       
##  [806] "make any novelty, the excuse for walking together and enjoying a"           
##  [807] "trivial flirtation.  You may figure to yourself the hum of voices"          
##  [808] "along the road in the gloaming. . . ."                                      
##  [809] ""                                                                           
##  [810] "As yet, of course, few people in Woking even knew that the cylinder"        
##  [811] "had opened, though poor Henderson had sent a messenger on a bicycle to"     
##  [812] "the post office with a special wire to an evening paper."                   
##  [813] ""                                                                           
##  [814] "As these folks came out by twos and threes upon the open, they"             
##  [815] "found little knots of people talking excitedly and peering at the"          
##  [816] "spinning mirror over the sand pits, and the newcomers were, no doubt,"      
##  [817] "soon infected by the excitement of the occasion."                           
##  [818] ""                                                                           
##  [819] "By half past eight, when the Deputation was destroyed, there may"           
##  [820] "have been a crowd of three hundred people or more at this place,"           
##  [821] "besides those who had left the road to approach the Martians nearer."       
##  [822] "There were three policemen too, one of whom was mounted, doing their"       
##  [823] "best, under instructions from Stent, to keep the people back and deter"     
##  [824] "them from approaching the cylinder.  There was some booing from those"      
##  [825] "more thoughtless and excitable souls to whom a crowd is always an"          
##  [826] "occasion for noise and horse-play."                                         
##  [827] ""                                                                           
##  [828] "Stent and Ogilvy, anticipating some possibilities of a collision,"          
##  [829] "had telegraphed from Horsell to the barracks as soon as the Martians"       
##  [830] "emerged, for the help of a company of soldiers to protect these"            
##  [831] "strange creatures from violence.  After that they returned to lead that"    
##  [832] "ill-fated advance.  The description of their death, as it was seen by"      
##  [833] "the crowd, tallies very closely with my own impressions: the three"         
##  [834] "puffs of green smoke, the deep humming note, and the flashes of flame."     
##  [835] ""                                                                           
##  [836] "But that crowd of people had a far narrower escape than mine.  Only"        
##  [837] "the fact that a hummock of heathery sand intercepted the lower part of"     
##  [838] "the Heat-Ray saved them.  Had the elevation of the parabolic mirror"        
##  [839] "been a few yards higher, none could have lived to tell the tale.  They"     
##  [840] "saw the flashes and the men falling and an invisible hand, as it were,"     
##  [841] "lit the bushes as it hurried towards them through the twilight.  Then,"     
##  [842] "with a whistling note that rose above the droning of the pit, the beam"     
##  [843] "swung close over their heads, lighting the tops of the beech trees"         
##  [844] "that line the road, and splitting the bricks, smashing the windows,"        
##  [845] "firing the window frames, and bringing down in crumbling ruin a"            
##  [846] "portion of the gable of the house nearest the corner."                      
##  [847] ""                                                                           
##  [848] "In the sudden thud, hiss, and glare of the igniting trees, the"             
##  [849] "panic-stricken crowd seems to have swayed hesitatingly for some"            
##  [850] "moments.  Sparks and burning twigs began to fall into the road, and"        
##  [851] "single leaves like puffs of flame.  Hats and dresses caught fire.  Then"    
##  [852] "came a crying from the common.  There were shrieks and shouts, and"         
##  [853] "suddenly a mounted policeman came galloping through the confusion with"     
##  [854] "his hands clasped over his head, screaming."                                
##  [855] ""                                                                           
##  [856] "\"They're coming!\" a woman shrieked, and incontinently everyone was"       
##  [857] "turning and pushing at those behind, in order to clear their way to"        
##  [858] "Woking again.  They must have bolted as blindly as a flock of sheep."       
##  [859] "Where the road grows narrow and black between the high banks the crowd"     
##  [860] "jammed, and a desperate struggle occurred.  All that crowd did not"         
##  [861] "escape; three persons at least, two women and a little boy, were"           
##  [862] "crushed and trampled there, and left to die amid the terror and the"        
##  [863] "darkness."                                                                  
##  [864] ""                                                                           
##  [865] ""                                                                           
##  [866] ""                                                                           
##  [867] "CHAPTER SEVEN"                                                              
##  [868] ""                                                                           
##  [869] "HOW I REACHED HOME"                                                         
##  [870] ""                                                                           
##  [871] ""                                                                           
##  [872] "For my own part, I remember nothing of my flight except the stress"         
##  [873] "of blundering against trees and stumbling through the heather.  All"        
##  [874] "about me gathered the invisible terrors of the Martians; that pitiless"     
##  [875] "sword of heat seemed whirling to and fro, flourishing overhead before"      
##  [876] "it descended and smote me out of life.  I came into the road between"       
##  [877] "the crossroads and Horsell, and ran along this to the crossroads."          
##  [878] ""                                                                           
##  [879] "At last I could go no further; I was exhausted with the violence of"        
##  [880] "my emotion and of my flight, and I staggered and fell by the wayside."      
##  [881] "That was near the bridge that crosses the canal by the gasworks.  I"        
##  [882] "fell and lay still."                                                        
##  [883] ""                                                                           
##  [884] "I must have remained there some time."                                      
##  [885] ""                                                                           
##  [886] "I sat up, strangely perplexed.  For a moment, perhaps, I could not"         
##  [887] "clearly understand how I came there.  My terror had fallen from me"         
##  [888] "like a garment.  My hat had gone, and my collar had burst away from"        
##  [889] "its fastener.  A few minutes before, there had only been three real"        
##  [890] "things before me--the immensity of the night and space and nature, my"      
##  [891] "own feebleness and anguish, and the near approach of death.  Now it"        
##  [892] "was as if something turned over, and the point of view altered"             
##  [893] "abruptly.  There was no sensible transition from one state of mind to"      
##  [894] "the other.  I was immediately the self of every day again--a decent,"       
##  [895] "ordinary citizen.  The silent common, the impulse of my flight, the"        
##  [896] "starting flames, were as if they had been in a dream.  I asked myself"
