##  [897] "had these latter things indeed happened?  I could not credit it."           
##  [898] ""                                                                           
##  [899] "I rose and walked unsteadily up the steep incline of the bridge.  My"       
##  [900] "mind was blank wonder.  My muscles and nerves seemed drained of their"      
##  [901] "strength.  I dare say I staggered drunkenly.  A head rose over the"         
##  [902] "arch, and the figure of a workman carrying a basket appeared.  Beside"      
##  [903] "him ran a little boy.  He passed me, wishing me good night.  I was"         
##  [904] "minded to speak to him, but did not.  I answered his greeting with a"       
##  [905] "meaningless mumble and went on over the bridge."                            
##  [906] ""                                                                           
##  [907] "Over the Maybury arch a train, a billowing tumult of white, firelit"        
##  [908] "smoke, and a long caterpillar of lighted windows, went flying"              
##  [909] "south--clatter, clatter, clap, rap, and it had gone.  A dim group of"       
##  [910] "people talked in the gate of one of the houses in the pretty little"        
##  [911] "row of gables that was called Oriental Terrace.  It was all so real"        
##  [912] "and so familiar.  And that behind me!  It was frantic, fantastic!"          
##  [913] "Such things, I told myself, could not be."                                  
##  [914] ""                                                                           
##  [915] "Perhaps I am a man of exceptional moods.  I do not know how far my"         
##  [916] "experience is common.  At times I suffer from the strangest sense of"       
##  [917] "detachment from myself and the world about me; I seem to watch it all"      
##  [918] "from the outside, from somewhere inconceivably remote, out of time,"        
##  [919] "out of space, out of the stress and tragedy of it all.  This feeling"       
##  [920] "was very strong upon me that night.  Here was another side to my"           
##  [921] "dream."                                                                     
##  [922] ""                                                                           
##  [923] "But the trouble was the blank incongruity of this serenity and the"         
##  [924] "swift death flying yonder, not two miles away.  There was a noise of"       
##  [925] "business from the gasworks, and the electric lamps were all alight.  I"     
##  [926] "stopped at the group of people."                                            
##  [927] ""                                                                           
##  [928] "\"What news from the common?\" said I."                                     
##  [929] ""                                                                           
##  [930] "There were two men and a woman at the gate."                                
##  [931] ""                                                                           
##  [932] "\"Eh?\" said one of the men, turning."                                      
##  [933] ""                                                                           
##  [934] "\"What news from the common?\" I said."                                     
##  [935] ""                                                                           
##  [936] "\"'Ain't yer just _been_ there?\" asked the men."                           
##  [937] ""                                                                           
##  [938] "\"People seem fair silly about the common,\" said the woman over the"       
##  [939] "gate.  \"What's it all abart?\""                                            
##  [940] ""                                                                           
##  [941] "\"Haven't you heard of the men from Mars?\" said I; \"the creatures"        
##  [942] "from Mars?\""                                                               
##  [943] ""                                                                           
##  [944] "\"Quite enough,\" said the woman over the gate.  \"Thenks\"; and all"       
##  [945] "three of them laughed."                                                     
##  [946] ""                                                                           
##  [947] "I felt foolish and angry.  I tried and found I could not tell them"         
##  [948] "what I had seen.  They laughed again at my broken sentences."               
##  [949] ""                                                                           
##  [950] "\"You'll hear more yet,\" I said, and went on to my home."                  
##  [951] ""                                                                           
##  [952] "I startled my wife at the doorway, so haggard was I.  I went into"          
##  [953] "the dining room, sat down, drank some wine, and so soon as I could"         
##  [954] "collect myself sufficiently I told her the things I had seen.  The"         
##  [955] "dinner, which was a cold one, had already been served, and remained"        
##  [956] "neglected on the table while I told my story."                              
##  [957] ""                                                                           
##  [958] "\"There is one thing,\" I said, to allay the fears I had aroused;"          
##  [959] "\"they are the most sluggish things I ever saw crawl.  They may keep"       
##  [960] "the pit and kill people who come near them, but they cannot get out"        
##  [961] "of it. . . .  But the horror of them!\""                                    
##  [962] ""                                                                           
##  [963] "\"Don't, dear!\" said my wife, knitting her brows and putting her"          
##  [964] "hand on mine."                                                              
##  [965] ""                                                                           
##  [966] "\"Poor Ogilvy!\" I said.  \"To think he may be lying dead there!\""         
##  [967] ""                                                                           
##  [968] "My wife at least did not find my experience incredible.  When I saw"        
##  [969] "how deadly white her face was, I ceased abruptly."                          
##  [970] ""                                                                           
##  [971] "\"They may come here,\" she said again and again."                          
##  [972] ""                                                                           
##  [973] "I pressed her to take wine, and tried to reassure her."                     
##  [974] ""                                                                           
##  [975] "\"They can scarcely move,\" I said."                                        
##  [976] ""                                                                           
##  [977] "I began to comfort her and myself by repeating all that Ogilvy had"         
##  [978] "told me of the impossibility of the Martians establishing themselves"       
##  [979] "on the earth.  In particular I laid stress on the gravitational"            
##  [980] "difficulty.  On the surface of the earth the force of gravity is three"     
##  [981] "times what it is on the surface of Mars.  A Martian, therefore, would"      
##  [982] "weigh three times more than on Mars, albeit his muscular strength"          
##  [983] "would be the same.  His own body would be a cope of lead to him.  That,"    
##  [984] "indeed, was the general opinion.  Both _The Times_ and the _Daily"          
##  [985] "Telegraph_, for instance, insisted on it the next morning, and both"        
##  [986] "overlooked, just as I did, two obvious modifying influences."               
##  [987] ""                                                                           
##  [988] "The atmosphere of the earth, we now know, contains far more oxygen"         
##  [989] "or far less argon (whichever way one likes to put it) than does Mars."      
##  [990] "The invigorating influences of this excess of oxygen upon the Martians"     
##  [991] "indisputably did much to counterbalance the increased weight of their"      
##  [992] "bodies.  And, in the second place, we all overlooked the fact that"         
##  [993] "such mechanical intelligence as the Martian possessed was quite able"       
##  [994] "to dispense with muscular exertion at a pinch."                             
##  [995] ""                                                                           
##  [996] "But I did not consider these points at the time, and so my"                 
##  [997] "reasoning was dead against the chances of the invaders.  With wine and"     
##  [998] "food, the confidence of my own table, and the necessity of reassuring"      
##  [999] "my wife, I grew by insensible degrees courageous and secure."               
## [1000] ""                                                                           
## [1001] "\"They have done a foolish thing,\" said I, fingering my wineglass."        
## [1002] "\"They are dangerous because, no doubt, they are mad with terror."          
## [1003] "Perhaps they expected to find no living things--certainly no"               
## [1004] "intelligent living things.\""                                               
## [1005] ""                                                                           
## [1006] "\"A shell in the pit\" said I, \"if the worst comes to the worst will"      
## [1007] "kill them all.\""                                                           
## [1008] ""                                                                           
## [1009] "The intense excitement of the events had no doubt left my"                  
## [1010] "perceptive powers in a state of erethism.  I remember that dinner"          
## [1011] "table with extraordinary vividness even now.  My dear wife's sweet"         
## [1012] "anxious face peering at me from under the pink lamp shade, the white"       
## [1013] "cloth with its silver and glass table furniture--for in those days"         
## [1014] "even philosophical writers had many little luxuries--the crimson-purple"    
## [1015] "wine in my glass, are photographically distinct.  At the end of"            
## [1016] "it I sat, tempering nuts with a cigarette, regretting Ogilvy's"             
## [1017] "rashness, and denouncing the shortsighted timidity of the Martians."        
## [1018] ""                                                                           
## [1019] "So some respectable dodo in the Mauritius might have lorded it in"          
## [1020] "his nest, and discussed the arrival of that shipful of pitiless"            
## [1021] "sailors in want of animal food.  \"We will peck them to death tomorrow,"    
## [1022] "my dear.\""                                                                 
## [1023] ""                                                                           
## [1024] "I did not know it, but that was the last civilised dinner I was to"         
## [1025] "eat for very many strange and terrible days."                               
## [1026] ""                                                                           
## [1027] ""                                                                           
## [1028] ""                                                                           
## [1029] "CHAPTER EIGHT"                                                              
## [1030] ""                                                                           
## [1031] "FRIDAY NIGHT"                                                               
## [1032] ""                                                                           
## [1033] ""                                                                           
## [1034] "The most extraordinary thing to my mind, of all the strange and"            
## [1035] "wonderful things that happened upon that Friday, was the dovetailing"       
## [1036] "of the commonplace habits of our social order with the first"               
## [1037] "beginnings of the series of events that was to topple that social"          
## [1038] "order headlong.  If on Friday night you had taken a pair of compasses"      
## [1039] "and drawn a circle with a radius of five miles round the Woking sand"       
## [1040] "pits, I doubt if you would have had one human being outside it, unless"     
## [1041] "it were some relation of Stent or of the three or four cyclists or"         
## [1042] "London people lying dead on the common, whose emotions or habits were"      
## [1043] "at all affected by the new-comers.  Many people had heard of the"           
## [1044] "cylinder, of course, and talked about it in their leisure, but it"          
## [1045] "certainly did not make the sensation that an ultimatum to Germany"          
## [1046] "would have done."                                                           
## [1047] ""                                                                           
## [1048] "In London that night poor Henderson's telegram describing the"              
## [1049] "gradual unscrewing of the shot was judged to be a canard, and his"          
## [1050] "evening paper, after wiring for authentication from him and receiving"      
## [1051] "no reply--the man was killed--decided not to print a special edition."      
## [1052] ""                                                                           
## [1053] "Even within the five-mile circle the great majority of people were"         
## [1054] "inert.  I have already described the behaviour of the men and women to"     
## [1055] "whom I spoke.  All over the district people were dining and supping;"       
## [1056] "working men were gardening after the labours of the day, children"          
## [1057] "were being put to bed, young people were wandering through the lanes"       
## [1058] "love-making, students sat over their books."                                
## [1059] ""                                                                           
## [1060] "Maybe there was a murmur in the village streets, a novel and"               
## [1061] "dominant topic in the public-houses, and here and there a messenger,"       
## [1062] "or even an eye-witness of the later occurrences, caused a whirl of"         
## [1063] "excitement, a shouting, and a running to and fro; but for the most"         
## [1064] "part the daily routine of working, eating, drinking, sleeping, went on"     
## [1065] "as it had done for countless years--as though no planet Mars existed"       
## [1066] "in the sky.  Even at Woking station and Horsell and Chobham that was"       
## [1067] "the case."                                                                  
## [1068] ""                                                                           
## [1069] "In Woking junction, until a late hour, trains were stopping and"            
## [1070] "going on, others were shunting on the sidings, passengers were"             
## [1071] "alighting and waiting, and everything was proceeding in the most"           
## [1072] "ordinary way.  A boy from the town, trenching on Smith's monopoly, was"     
## [1073] "selling papers with the afternoon's news.  The ringing impact of"           
## [1074] "trucks, the sharp whistle of the engines from the junction, mingled"        
## [1075] "with their shouts of \"Men from Mars!\"  Excited men came into the"         
## [1076] "station about nine o'clock with incredible tidings, and caused no more"     
## [1077] "disturbance than drunkards might have done.  People rattling"               
## [1078] "Londonwards peered into the darkness outside the carriage windows, and"     
## [1079] "saw only a rare, flickering, vanishing spark dance up from the"             
## [1080] "direction of Horsell, a red glow and a thin veil of smoke driving"          
## [1081] "across the stars, and thought that nothing more serious than a heath"       
## [1082] "fire was happening.  It was only round the edge of the common that any"     
## [1083] "disturbance was perceptible.  There were half a dozen villas burning"       
## [1084] "on the Woking border.  There were lights in all the houses on the"          
## [1085] "common side of the three villages, and the people there kept awake"         
## [1086] "till dawn."                                                                 
## [1087] ""                                                                           
## [1088] "A curious crowd lingered restlessly, people coming and going but"           
## [1089] "the crowd remaining, both on the Chobham and Horsell bridges.  One or"      
## [1090] "two adventurous souls, it was afterwards found, went into the darkness"     
## [1091] "and crawled quite near the Martians; but they never returned, for now"      
## [1092] "and again a light-ray, like the beam of a warship's searchlight swept"      
## [1093] "the common, and the Heat-Ray was ready to follow.  Save for such, that"     
## [1094] "big area of common was silent and desolate, and the charred bodies lay"     
## [1095] "about on it all night under the stars, and all the next day.  A noise"      
## [1096] "of hammering from the pit was heard by many people."                        
## [1097] ""                                                                           
## [1098] "So you have the state of things on Friday night.  In the centre,"           
## [1099] "sticking into the skin of our old planet Earth like a poisoned dart,"       
## [1100] "was this cylinder.  But the poison was scarcely working yet.  Around"       
## [1101] "it was a patch of silent common, smouldering in places, and with a few"     
## [1102] "dark, dimly seen objects lying in contorted attitudes here and there."      
## [1103] "Here and there was a burning bush or tree.  Beyond was a fringe of"         
## [1104] "excitement, and farther than that fringe the inflammation had not"          
## [1105] "crept as yet.  In the rest of the world the stream of life still"           
## [1106] "flowed as it had flowed for immemorial years.  The fever of war that"       
## [1107] "would presently clog vein and artery, deaden nerve and destroy brain,"      
## [1108] "had still to develop."                                                      
## [1109] ""                                                                           
## [1110] "All night long the Martians were hammering and stirring, sleepless,"        
## [1111] "indefatigable, at work upon the machines they were making ready, and"       
## [1112] "ever and again a puff of greenish-white smoke whirled up to the"            
## [1113] "starlit sky."                                                               
## [1114] ""                                                                           
## [1115] "About eleven a company of soldiers came through Horsell, and"               
## [1116] "deployed along the edge of the common to form a cordon.  Later a"           
## [1117] "second company marched through Chobham to deploy on the north side of"      
## [1118] "the common.  Several officers from the Inkerman barracks had been on"       
## [1119] "the common earlier in the day, and one, Major Eden, was reported to be"     
## [1120] "missing.  The colonel of the regiment came to the Chobham bridge and"       
## [1121] "was busy questioning the crowd at midnight.  The military authorities"      
## [1122] "were certainly alive to the seriousness of the business.  About"            
## [1123] "eleven, the next morning's papers were able to say, a squadron of"          
## [1124] "hussars, two Maxims, and about four hundred men of the Cardigan"            
## [1125] "regiment started from Aldershot."                                           
## [1126] ""                                                                           
## [1127] "A few seconds after midnight the crowd in the Chertsey road,"               
## [1128] "Woking, saw a star fall from heaven into the pine woods to the"             
## [1129] "northwest.  It had a greenish colour, and caused a silent brightness"       
## [1130] "like summer lightning.  This was the second cylinder."                      
## [1131] ""                                                                           
## [1132] ""                                                                           
## [1133] ""                                                                           
## [1134] "CHAPTER NINE"                                                               
## [1135] ""                                                                           
## [1136] "THE FIGHTING BEGINS"                                                        
## [1137] ""                                                                           
## [1138] ""                                                                           
## [1139] "Saturday lives in my memory as a day of suspense.  It was a day of"         
## [1140] "lassitude too, hot and close, with, I am told, a rapidly fluctuating"       
## [1141] "barometer.  I had slept but little, though my wife had succeeded in"        
## [1142] "sleeping, and I rose early.  I went into my garden before breakfast"        
## [1143] "and stood listening, but towards the common there was nothing stirring"     
## [1144] "but a lark."                                                                
## [1145] ""                                                                           
## [1146] "The milkman came as usual.  I heard the rattle of his chariot and I"        
## [1147] "went round to the side gate to ask the latest news.  He told me that"       
## [1148] "during the night the Martians had been surrounded by troops, and that"      
## [1149] "guns were expected.  Then--a familiar, reassuring note--I heard a train"    
## [1150] "running towards Woking."                                                    
## [1151] ""                                                                           
## [1152] "\"They aren't to be killed,\" said the milkman, \"if that can possibly"     
## [1153] "be avoided.\""                                                              
## [1154] ""                                                                           
## [1155] "I saw my neighbour gardening, chatted with him for a time, and then"        
## [1156] "strolled in to breakfast.  It was a most unexceptional morning.  My"        
## [1157] "neighbour was of opinion that the troops would be able to capture or"       
## [1158] "to destroy the Martians during the day."                                    
## [1159] ""                                                                           
## [1160] "\"It's a pity they make themselves so unapproachable,\" he said.  \"It"     
## [1161] "would be curious to know how they live on another planet; we might"         
## [1162] "learn a thing or two.\""                                                    
## [1163] ""                                                                           
## [1164] "He came up to the fence and extended a handful of strawberries, for"        
## [1165] "his gardening was as generous as it was enthusiastic.  At the same"         
## [1166] "time he told me of the burning of the pine woods about the Byfleet"         
## [1167] "Golf Links."                                                                
## [1168] ""                                                                           
## [1169] "\"They say,\" said he, \"that there's another of those blessed things"      
## [1170] "fallen there--number two.  But one's enough, surely.  This lot'll cost"     
## [1171] "the insurance people a pretty penny before everything's settled.\"  He"     
## [1172] "laughed with an air of the greatest good humour as he said this.  The"      
## [1173] "woods, he said, were still burning, and pointed out a haze of smoke to"     
## [1174] "me.  \"They will be hot under foot for days, on account of the thick"       
## [1175] "soil of pine needles and turf,\" he said, and then grew serious over"       
## [1176] "\"poor Ogilvy.\""                                                           
## [1177] ""                                                                           
## [1178] "After breakfast, instead of working, I decided to walk down"                
## [1179] "towards the common.  Under the railway bridge I found a group of"           
## [1180] "soldiers--sappers, I think, men in small round caps, dirty red jackets"     
## [1181] "unbuttoned, and showing their blue shirts, dark trousers, and boots"        
## [1182] "coming to the calf.  They told me no one was allowed over the canal,"       
## [1183] "and, looking along the road towards the bridge, I saw one of the"           
## [1184] "Cardigan men standing sentinel there.  I talked with these soldiers"        
## [1185] "for a time; I told them of my sight of the Martians on the previous"        
## [1186] "evening.  None of them had seen the Martians, and they had but the"         
## [1187] "vaguest ideas of them, so that they plied me with questions.  They"         
## [1188] "said that they did not know who had authorised the movements of the"        
## [1189] "troops; their idea was that a dispute had arisen at the Horse Guards."      
## [1190] "The ordinary sapper is a great deal better educated than the common"        
## [1191] "soldier, and they discussed the peculiar conditions of the possible"        
## [1192] "fight with some acuteness.  I described the Heat-Ray to them, and they"     
## [1193] "began to argue among themselves."                                           
## [1194] ""                                                                           
## [1195] "\"Crawl up under cover and rush 'em, say I,\" said one."                    
## [1196] ""                                                                           
## [1197] "\"Get aht!\" said another.  \"What's cover against this 'ere 'eat?"         
## [1198] "Sticks to cook yer!  What we got to do is to go as near as the"             
## [1199] "ground'll let us, and then drive a trench.\""                               
## [1200] ""                                                                           
## [1201] "\"Blow yer trenches!  You always want trenches; you ought to ha'"           
## [1202] "been born a rabbit Snippy.\""                                               
## [1203] ""                                                                           
## [1204] "\"Ain't they got any necks, then?\" said a third, abruptly--a little,"      
## [1205] "contemplative, dark man, smoking a pipe."                                   
## [1206] ""                                                                           
## [1207] "I repeated my description."                                                 
## [1208] ""                                                                           
## [1209] "\"Octopuses,\" said he, \"that's what I calls 'em.  Talk about fishers"     
## [1210] "of men--fighters of fish it is this time!\""                                
## [1211] ""                                                                           
## [1212] "\"It ain't no murder killing beasts like that,\" said the first"            
## [1213] "speaker."                                                                   
## [1214] ""                                                                           
## [1215] "\"Why not shell the darned things strite off and finish 'em?\" said"        
## [1216] "the little dark man.  \"You carn tell what they might do.\""                
## [1217] ""                                                                           
## [1218] "\"Where's your shells?\" said the first speaker.  \"There ain't no"         
## [1219] "time.  Do it in a rush, that's my tip, and do it at once.\""                
## [1220] ""                                                                           
## [1221] "So they discussed it.  After a while I left them, and went on to"           
## [1222] "the railway station to get as many morning papers as I could."              
## [1223] ""                                                                           
## [1224] "But I will not weary the reader with a description of that long"            
## [1225] "morning and of the longer afternoon.  I did not succeed in getting a"       
## [1226] "glimpse of the common, for even Horsell and Chobham church towers were"     
## [1227] "in the hands of the military authorities.  The soldiers I addressed"        
## [1228] "didn't know anything; the officers were mysterious as well as busy.  I"     
## [1229] "found people in the town quite secure again in the presence of the"         
## [1230] "military, and I heard for the first time from Marshall, the"                
## [1231] "tobacconist, that his son was among the dead on the common.  The"           
## [1232] "soldiers had made the people on the outskirts of Horsell lock up and"       
## [1233] "leave their houses."                                                        
## [1234] ""                                                                           
## [1235] "I got back to lunch about two, very tired for, as I have said, the"         
## [1236] "day was extremely hot and dull; and in order to refresh myself I took"      
## [1237] "a cold bath in the afternoon.  About half past four I went up to the"       
## [1238] "railway station to get an evening paper, for the morning papers had"        
## [1239] "contained only a very inaccurate description of the killing of Stent,"      
## [1240] "Henderson, Ogilvy, and the others.  But there was little I didn't"          
## [1241] "know.  The Martians did not show an inch of themselves.  They seemed"       
## [1242] "busy in their pit, and there was a sound of hammering and an almost"        
## [1243] "continuous streamer of smoke.  Apparently they were busy getting ready"     
## [1244] "for a struggle.  \"Fresh attempts have been made to signal, but without"    
## [1245] "success,\" was the stereotyped formula of the papers.  A sapper told me"    
## [1246] "it was done by a man in a ditch with a flag on a long pole.  The"           
## [1247] "Martians took as much notice of such advances as we should of the"          
## [1248] "lowing of a cow."                                                           
## [1249] ""                                                                           
## [1250] "I must confess the sight of all this armament, all this"                    
## [1251] "preparation, greatly excited me.  My imagination became belligerent,"       
## [1252] "and defeated the invaders in a dozen striking ways; something of my"        
## [1253] "schoolboy dreams of battle and heroism came back.  It hardly seemed a"      
## [1254] "fair fight to me at that time.  They seemed very helpless in that pit"      
## [1255] "of theirs."                                                                 
## [1256] ""                                                                           
## [1257] "About three o'clock there began the thud of a gun at measured"              
## [1258] "intervals from Chertsey or Addlestone.  I learned that the smouldering"     
## [1259] "pine wood into which the second cylinder had fallen was being shelled,"     
## [1260] "in the hope of destroying that object before it opened.  It was only"       
## [1261] "about five, however, that a field gun reached Chobham for use against"      
## [1262] "the first body of Martians."                                                
## [1263] ""                                                                           
## [1264] "About six in the evening, as I sat at tea with my wife in the"              
## [1265] "summerhouse talking vigorously about the battle that was lowering upon"     
## [1266] "us, I heard a muffled detonation from the common, and immediately"          
## [1267] "after a gust of firing.  Close on the heels of that came a violent"         
## [1268] "rattling crash, quite close to us, that shook the ground; and,"             
## [1269] "starting out upon the lawn, I saw the tops of the trees about the"          
## [1270] "Oriental College burst into smoky red flame, and the tower of the"          
## [1271] "little church beside it slide down into ruin.  The pinnacle of the"         
## [1272] "mosque had vanished, and the roof line of the college itself looked as"     
## [1273] "if a hundred-ton gun had been at work upon it.  One of our chimneys"        
## [1274] "cracked as if a shot had hit it, flew, and a piece of it came"              
## [1275] "clattering down the tiles and made a heap of broken red fragments upon"     
## [1276] "the flower bed by my study window."                                         
## [1277] ""                                                                           
## [1278] "I and my wife stood amazed.  Then I realised that the crest of"             
## [1279] "Maybury Hill must be within range of the Martians' Heat-Ray now that"       
## [1280] "the college was cleared out of the way."                                    
## [1281] ""                                                                           
## [1282] "At that I gripped my wife's arm, and without ceremony ran her out"          
## [1283] "into the road.  Then I fetched out the servant, telling her I would go"     
## [1284] "upstairs myself for the box she was clamouring for."                        
## [1285] ""                                                                           
## [1286] "\"We can't possibly stay here,\" I said; and as I spoke the firing"         
## [1287] "reopened for a moment upon the common."                                     
## [1288] ""                                                                           
## [1289] "\"But where are we to go?\" said my wife in terror."                        
## [1290] ""                                                                           
## [1291] "I thought perplexed.  Then I remembered her cousins at Leatherhead."        
## [1292] ""                                                                           
## [1293] "\"Leatherhead!\" I shouted above the sudden noise."                         
## [1294] ""                                                                           
## [1295] "She looked away from me downhill.  The people were coming out of"           
## [1296] "their houses, astonished."                                                  
## [1297] ""                                                                           
## [1298] "\"How are we to get to Leatherhead?\" she said."                            
## [1299] ""                                                                           
## [1300] "Down the hill I saw a bevy of hussars ride under the railway"               
## [1301] "bridge; three galloped through the open gates of the Oriental College;"     
## [1302] "two others dismounted, and began running from house to house.  The"         
## [1303] "sun, shining through the smoke that drove up from the tops of the"          
## [1304] "trees, seemed blood red, and threw an unfamiliar lurid light upon"          
## [1305] "everything."                                                                
## [1306] ""                                                                           
## [1307] "\"Stop here,\" said I; \"you are safe here\"; and I started off at once"    
## [1308] "for the Spotted Dog, for I knew the landlord had a horse and dog cart."     
## [1309] "I ran, for I perceived that in a moment everyone upon this side of the"     
## [1310] "hill would be moving.  I found him in his bar, quite unaware of what"       
## [1311] "was going on behind his house.  A man stood with his back to me,"           
## [1312] "talking to him."                                                            
## [1313] ""                                                                           
## [1314] "\"I must have a pound,\" said the landlord, \"and I've no one to drive"     
## [1315] "it.\""                                                                      
## [1316] ""                                                                           
## [1317] "\"I'll give you two,\" said I, over the stranger's shoulder."               
## [1318] ""                                                                           
## [1319] "\"What for?\""                                                              
## [1320] ""                                                                           
## [1321] "\"And I'll bring it back by midnight,\" I said."                            
## [1322] ""                                                                           
## [1323] "\"Lord!\" said the landlord; \"what's the hurry?  I'm selling my bit"       
## [1324] "of a pig.  Two pounds, and you bring it back?  What's going on now?\""      
## [1325] ""                                                                           
## [1326] "I explained hastily that I had to leave my home, and so secured the"        
## [1327] "dog cart.  At the time it did not seem to me nearly so urgent that the"     
## [1328] "landlord should leave his.  I took care to have the cart there and"         
## [1329] "then, drove it off down the road, and, leaving it in charge of my wife"     
## [1330] "and servant, rushed into my house and packed a few valuables, such"         
## [1331] "plate as we had, and so forth.  The beech trees below the house were"       
## [1332] "burning while I did this, and the palings up the road glowed red."          
## [1333] "While I was occupied in this way, one of the dismounted hussars came"       
## [1334] "running up.  He was going from house to house, warning people to"           
## [1335] "leave.  He was going on as I came out of my front door, lugging my"         
## [1336] "treasures, done up in a tablecloth.  I shouted after him:"                  
## [1337] ""                                                                           
## [1338] "\"What news?\""                                                             
## [1339] ""                                                                           
## [1340] "He turned, stared, bawled something about \"crawling out in a thing"        
## [1341] "like a dish cover,\" and ran on to the gate of the house at the crest."     
## [1342] "A sudden whirl of black smoke driving across the road hid him for a"        
## [1343] "moment.  I ran to my neighbour's door and rapped to satisfy myself of"      
## [1344] "what I already knew, that his wife had gone to London with him and had"     
## [1345] "locked up their house.  I went in again, according to my promise, to"       
## [1346] "get my servant's box, lugged it out, clapped it beside her on the tail"     
## [1347] "of the dog cart, and then caught the reins and jumped up into the"          
## [1348] "driver's seat beside my wife.  In another moment we were clear of the"      
## [1349] "smoke and noise, and spanking down the opposite slope of Maybury Hill"      
## [1350] "towards Old Woking."                                                        
## [1351] ""                                                                           
## [1352] "In front was a quiet sunny landscape, a wheat field ahead on either"        
## [1353] "side of the road, and the Maybury Inn with its swinging sign.  I saw"       
## [1354] "the doctor's cart ahead of me.  At the bottom of the hill I turned my"      
## [1355] "head to look at the hillside I was leaving.  Thick streamers of black"      
## [1356] "smoke shot with threads of red fire were driving up into the still"         
## [1357] "air, and throwing dark shadows upon the green treetops eastward.  The"      
## [1358] "smoke already extended far away to the east and west--to the Byfleet"       
## [1359] "pine woods eastward, and to Woking on the west.  The road was dotted"       
## [1360] "with people running towards us.  And very faint now, but very distinct"     
## [1361] "through the hot, quiet air, one heard the whirr of a machine-gun that"      
## [1362] "was presently stilled, and an intermittent cracking of rifles."             
## [1363] "Apparently the Martians were setting fire to everything within range"       
## [1364] "of their Heat-Ray."                                                         
## [1365] ""                                                                           
## [1366] "I am not an expert driver, and I had immediately to turn my"                
## [1367] "attention to the horse.  When I looked back again the second hill had"      
## [1368] "hidden the black smoke.  I slashed the horse with the whip, and gave"       
## [1369] "him a loose rein until Woking and Send lay between us and that"             
## [1370] "quivering tumult.  I overtook and passed the doctor between Woking and"     
## [1371] "Send."                                                                      
## [1372] ""                                                                           
## [1373] ""                                                                           
## [1374] ""                                                                           
## [1375] "CHAPTER TEN"                                                                
## [1376] ""                                                                           
## [1377] "IN THE STORM"                                                               
## [1378] ""                                                                           
## [1379] ""                                                                           
## [1380] "Leatherhead is about twelve miles from Maybury Hill.  The scent of"         
## [1381] "hay was in the air through the lush meadows beyond Pyrford, and the"        
## [1382] "hedges on either side were sweet and gay with multitudes of dog-roses."     
## [1383] "The heavy firing that had broken out while we were driving down"            
## [1384] "Maybury Hill ceased as abruptly as it began, leaving the evening very"      
## [1385] "peaceful and still.  We got to Leatherhead without misadventure about"      
## [1386] "nine o'clock, and the horse had an hour's rest while I took supper"         
## [1387] "with my cousins and commended my wife to their care."                       
## [1388] ""                                                                           
## [1389] "My wife was curiously silent throughout the drive, and seemed"              
## [1390] "oppressed with forebodings of evil.  I talked to her reassuringly,"         
## [1391] "pointing out that the Martians were tied to the Pit by sheer"               
## [1392] "heaviness, and at the utmost could but crawl a little out of it; but"       
## [1393] "she answered only in monosyllables.  Had it not been for my promise to"     
## [1394] "the innkeeper, she would, I think, have urged me to stay in"                
## [1395] "Leatherhead that night.  Would that I had!  Her face, I remember, was"      
## [1396] "very white as we parted."                                                   
## [1397] ""                                                                           
## [1398] "For my own part, I had been feverishly excited all day.  Something"         
## [1399] "very like the war fever that occasionally runs through a civilised"         
## [1400] "community had got into my blood, and in my heart I was not so very"         
## [1401] "sorry that I had to return to Maybury that night.  I was even afraid"       
## [1402] "that that last fusillade I had heard might mean the extermination of"       
## [1403] "our invaders from Mars.  I can best express my state of mind by saying"     
## [1404] "that I wanted to be in at the death."                                       
## [1405] ""                                                                           
## [1406] "It was nearly eleven when I started to return.  The night was"              
## [1407] "unexpectedly dark; to me, walking out of the lighted passage of my"         
## [1408] "cousins' house, it seemed indeed black, and it was as hot and close as"     
## [1409] "the day.  Overhead the clouds were driving fast, albeit not a breath"       
## [1410] "stirred the shrubs about us.  My cousins' man lit both lamps.  Happily,"    
## [1411] "I knew the road intimately.  My wife stood in the light of the"             
## [1412] "doorway, and watched me until I jumped up into the dog cart.  Then"         
## [1413] "abruptly she turned and went in, leaving my cousins side by side"           
## [1414] "wishing me good hap."                                                       
## [1415] ""                                                                           
## [1416] "I was a little depressed at first with the contagion of my wife's"          
## [1417] "fears, but very soon my thoughts reverted to the Martians.  At that"        
## [1418] "time I was absolutely in the dark as to the course of the evening's"        
## [1419] "fighting.  I did not know even the circumstances that had precipitated"     
## [1420] "the conflict.  As I came through Ockham (for that was the way I"            
## [1421] "returned, and not through Send and Old Woking) I saw along the western"     
## [1422] "horizon a blood-red glow, which as I drew nearer, crept slowly up the"      
## [1423] "sky.  The driving clouds of the gathering thunderstorm mingled there"       
## [1424] "with masses of black and red smoke."                                        
## [1425] ""                                                                           
## [1426] "Ripley Street was deserted, and except for a lighted window or so"          
## [1427] "the village showed not a sign of life; but I narrowly escaped an"           
## [1428] "accident at the corner of the road to Pyrford, where a knot of people"      
## [1429] "stood with their backs to me.  They said nothing to me as I passed.  I"     
## [1430] "do not know what they knew of the things happening beyond the hill,"        
## [1431] "nor do I know if the silent houses I passed on my way were sleeping"        
## [1432] "securely, or deserted and empty, or harassed and watching against the"      
## [1433] "terror of the night."                                                       
## [1434] ""                                                                           
## [1435] "From Ripley until I came through Pyrford I was in the valley of the"        
## [1436] "Wey, and the red glare was hidden from me.  As I ascended the little"       
## [1437] "hill beyond Pyrford Church the glare came into view again, and the"         
## [1438] "trees about me shivered with the first intimation of the storm that"        
## [1439] "was upon me.  Then I heard midnight pealing out from Pyrford Church"        
## [1440] "behind me, and then came the silhouette of Maybury Hill, with its"          
## [1441] "tree-tops and roofs black and sharp against the red."                       
## [1442] ""                                                                           
## [1443] "Even as I beheld this a lurid green glare lit the road about me and"        
## [1444] "showed the distant woods towards Addlestone.  I felt a tug at the"          
## [1445] "reins.  I saw that the driving clouds had been pierced as it were by a"     
## [1446] "thread of green fire, suddenly lighting their confusion and falling"        
## [1447] "into the field to my left.  It was the third falling star!"                 
## [1448] ""                                                                           
## [1449] "Close on its apparition, and blindingly violet by contrast, danced"         
## [1450] "out the first lightning of the gathering storm, and the thunder burst"      
## [1451] "like a rocket overhead.  The horse took the bit between his teeth and"      
## [1452] "bolted."                                                                    
## [1453] ""                                                                           
## [1454] "A moderate incline runs towards the foot of Maybury Hill, and down"         
## [1455] "this we clattered.  Once the lightning had begun, it went on in as"         
## [1456] "rapid a succession of flashes as I have ever seen.  The thunderclaps,"      
## [1457] "treading one on the heels of another and with a strange crackling"          
## [1458] "accompaniment, sounded more like the working of a gigantic electric"        
## [1459] "machine than the usual detonating reverberations.  The flickering"          
## [1460] "light was blinding and confusing, and a thin hail smote gustily at my"      
## [1461] "face as I drove down the slope."                                            
## [1462] ""                                                                           
## [1463] "At first I regarded little but the road before me, and then"                
## [1464] "abruptly my attention was arrested by something that was moving"            
## [1465] "rapidly down the opposite slope of Maybury Hill.  At first I took it"       
## [1466] "for the wet roof of a house, but one flash following another showed it"     
## [1467] "to be in swift rolling movement.  It was an elusive vision--a moment"       
## [1468] "of bewildering darkness, and then, in a flash like daylight, the red"       
## [1469] "masses of the Orphanage near the crest of the hill, the green tops of"      
## [1470] "the pine trees, and this problematical object came out clear and sharp"     
## [1471] "and bright."                                                                
## [1472] ""                                                                           
## [1473] "And this Thing I saw!  How can I describe it?  A monstrous tripod,"         
## [1474] "higher than many houses, striding over the young pine trees, and"           
## [1475] "smashing them aside in its career; a walking engine of glittering"          
## [1476] "metal, striding now across the heather; articulate ropes of steel"          
## [1477] "dangling from it, and the clattering tumult of its passage mingling"        
## [1478] "with the riot of the thunder.  A flash, and it came out vividly,"           
## [1479] "heeling over one way with two feet in the air, to vanish and reappear"      
## [1480] "almost instantly as it seemed, with the next flash, a hundred yards"        
## [1481] "nearer.  Can you imagine a milking stool tilted and bowled violently"       
## [1482] "along the ground?  That was the impression those instant flashes gave."     
## [1483] "But instead of a milking stool imagine it a great body of machinery on"     
## [1484] "a tripod stand."                                                            
## [1485] ""                                                                           
## [1486] "Then suddenly the trees in the pine wood ahead of me were parted,"          
## [1487] "as brittle reeds are parted by a man thrusting through them; they were"     
## [1488] "snapped off and driven headlong, and a second huge tripod appeared,"        
## [1489] "rushing, as it seemed, headlong towards me.  And I was galloping hard"      
## [1490] "to meet it! At the sight of the second monster my nerve went"               
## [1491] "altogether.  Not stopping to look again, I wrenched the horse's head"       
## [1492] "hard round to the right and in another moment the dog cart had heeled"      
## [1493] "over upon the horse; the shafts smashed noisily, and I was flung"           
## [1494] "sideways and fell heavily into a shallow pool of water."                    
## [1495] ""                                                                           
## [1496] "I crawled out almost immediately, and crouched, my feet still in"           
## [1497] "the water, under a clump of furze.  The horse lay motionless (his neck"     
## [1498] "was broken, poor brute!) and by the lightning flashes I saw the black"      
## [1499] "bulk of the overturned dog cart and the silhouette of the wheel still"      
## [1500] "spinning slowly.  In another moment the colossal mechanism went"            
## [1501] "striding by me, and passed uphill towards Pyrford."                         
## [1502] ""                                                                           
## [1503] "Seen nearer, the Thing was incredibly strange, for it was no mere"          
## [1504] "insensate machine driving on its way.  Machine it was, with a ringing"      
## [1505] "metallic pace, and long, flexible, glittering tentacles (one of which"      
## [1506] "gripped a young pine tree) swinging and rattling about its strange"         
## [1507] "body.  It picked its road as it went striding along, and the brazen"        
## [1508] "hood that surmounted it moved to and fro with the inevitable"               
## [1509] "suggestion of a head looking about.  Behind the main body was a huge"       
## [1510] "mass of white metal like a gigantic fisherman's basket, and puffs of"       
## [1511] "green smoke squirted out from the joints of the limbs as the monster"       
## [1512] "swept by me.  And in an instant it was gone."                               
## [1513] ""                                                                           
## [1514] "So much I saw then, all vaguely for the flickering of the"                  
## [1515] "lightning, in blinding highlights and dense black shadows."                 
## [1516] ""                                                                           
## [1517] "As it passed it set up an exultant deafening howl that drowned the"         
## [1518] "thunder--\"Aloo!  Aloo!\"--and in another minute it was with its"           
## [1519] "companion, half a mile away, stooping over something in the field.  I"      
## [1520] "have no doubt this Thing in the field was the third of the ten"             
## [1521] "cylinders they had fired at us from Mars."                                  
## [1522] ""                                                                           
## [1523] "For some minutes I lay there in the rain and darkness watching, by"         
## [1524] "the intermittent light, these monstrous beings of metal moving about"       
## [1525] "in the distance over the hedge tops.  A thin hail was now beginning,"       
## [1526] "and as it came and went their figures grew misty and then flashed into"     
## [1527] "clearness again.  Now and then came a gap in the lightning, and the"        
## [1528] "night swallowed them up."                                                   
## [1529] ""                                                                           
## [1530] "I was soaked with hail above and puddle water below.  It was some"          
## [1531] "time before my blank astonishment would let me struggle up the bank to"     
## [1532] "a drier position, or think at all of my imminent peril."                    
## [1533] ""                                                                           
## [1534] "Not far from me was a little one-roomed squatter's hut of wood,"            
## [1535] "surrounded by a patch of potato garden.  I struggled to my feet at"         
## [1536] "last, and, crouching and making use of every chance of cover, I made a"     
## [1537] "run for this.  I hammered at the door, but I could not make the people"     
## [1538] "hear (if there were any people inside), and after a time I desisted,"       
## [1539] "and, availing myself of a ditch for the greater part of the way,"           
## [1540] "succeeded in crawling, unobserved by these monstrous machines, into"        
## [1541] "the pine woods towards Maybury."                                            
## [1542] ""                                                                           
## [1543] "Under cover of this I pushed on, wet and shivering now, towards my"         
## [1544] "own house.  I walked among the trees trying to find the footpath.  It"      
## [1545] "was very dark indeed in the wood, for the lightning was now becoming"       
## [1546] "infrequent, and the hail, which was pouring down in a torrent, fell in"     
## [1547] "columns through the gaps in the heavy foliage."                             
## [1548] ""                                                                           
## [1549] "If I had fully realised the meaning of all the things I had seen I"         
## [1550] "should have immediately worked my way round through Byfleet to Street"      
## [1551] "Cobham, and so gone back to rejoin my wife at Leatherhead.  But that"       
## [1552] "night the strangeness of things about me, and my physical"                  
## [1553] "wretchedness, prevented me, for I was bruised, weary, wet to the skin,"     
## [1554] "deafened and blinded by the storm."                                         
## [1555] ""                                                                           
## [1556] "I had a vague idea of going on to my own house, and that was as"            
## [1557] "much motive as I had.  I staggered through the trees, fell into a"          
## [1558] "ditch and bruised my knees against a plank, and finally splashed out"       
## [1559] "into the lane that ran down from the College Arms.  I say splashed,"        
## [1560] "for the storm water was sweeping the sand down the hill in a muddy"         
## [1561] "torrent.  There in the darkness a man blundered into me and sent me"        
## [1562] "reeling back."                                                              
## [1563] ""                                                                           
## [1564] "He gave a cry of terror, sprang sideways, and rushed on before I"           
## [1565] "could gather my wits sufficiently to speak to him.  So heavy was the"       
## [1566] "stress of the storm just at this place that I had the hardest task to"      
## [1567] "win my way up the hill.  I went close up to the fence on the left and"      
## [1568] "worked my way along its palings."                                           
## [1569] ""                                                                           
## [1570] "Near the top I stumbled upon something soft, and, by a flash of"            
## [1571] "lightning, saw between my feet a heap of black broadcloth and a pair"       
## [1572] "of boots.  Before I could distinguish clearly how the man lay, the"         
## [1573] "flicker of light had passed.  I stood over him waiting for the next"        
## [1574] "flash.  When it came, I saw that he was a sturdy man, cheaply but not"      
## [1575] "shabbily dressed; his head was bent under his body, and he lay"             
## [1576] "crumpled up close to the fence, as though he had been flung violently"      
## [1577] "against it."                                                                
## [1578] ""                                                                           
## [1579] "Overcoming the repugnance natural to one who had never before"              
## [1580] "touched a dead body, I stooped and turned him over to feel for his"         
## [1581] "heart.  He was quite dead.  Apparently his neck had been broken.  The"      
## [1582] "lightning flashed for a third time, and his face leaped upon me.  I"        
## [1583] "sprang to my feet.  It was the landlord of the Spotted Dog, whose"          
## [1584] "conveyance I had taken."                                                    
## [1585] ""                                                                           
## [1586] "I stepped over him gingerly and pushed on up the hill.  I made my"          
## [1587] "way by the police station and the College Arms towards my own house."       
## [1588] "Nothing was burning on the hillside, though from the common there"          
## [1589] "still came a red glare and a rolling tumult of ruddy smoke beating up"      
## [1590] "against the drenching hail.  So far as I could see by the flashes, the"     
## [1591] "houses about me were mostly uninjured.  By the College Arms a dark"         
## [1592] "heap lay in the road."                                                      
## [1593] ""                                                                           
## [1594] "Down the road towards Maybury Bridge there were voices and the"             
## [1595] "sound of feet, but I had not the courage to shout or to go to them.  I"     
## [1596] "let myself in with my latchkey, closed, locked and bolted the door,"        
## [1597] "staggered to the foot of the staircase, and sat down.  My imagination"      
## [1598] "was full of those striding metallic monsters, and of the dead body"         
## [1599] "smashed against the fence."                                                 
## [1600] ""                                                                           
## [1601] "I crouched at the foot of the staircase with my back to the wall,"          
## [1602] "shivering violently."                                                       
## [1603] ""                                                                           
## [1604] ""                                                                           
## [1605] ""                                                                           
## [1606] "CHAPTER ELEVEN"                                                             
## [1607] ""                                                                           
## [1608] "AT THE WINDOW"                                                              
## [1609] ""                                                                           
## [1610] ""                                                                           
## [1611] "I have already said that my storms of emotion have a trick of"              
## [1612] "exhausting themselves.  After a time I discovered that I was cold and"      
## [1613] "wet, and with little pools of water about me on the stair carpet.  I"       
## [1614] "got up almost mechanically, went into the dining room and drank some"       
## [1615] "whiskey, and then I was moved to change my clothes."                        
## [1616] ""                                                                           
## [1617] "After I had done that I went upstairs to my study, but why I did so"        
## [1618] "I do not know.  The window of my study looks over the trees and the"        
## [1619] "railway towards Horsell Common.  In the hurry of our departure this"        
## [1620] "window had been left open.  The passage was dark, and, by contrast with"    
## [1621] "the picture the window frame enclosed, the side of the room seemed"         
## [1622] "impenetrably dark.  I stopped short in the doorway."                        
## [1623] ""                                                                           
## [1624] "The thunderstorm had passed.  The towers of the Oriental College"           
## [1625] "and the pine trees about it had gone, and very far away, lit by a"          
## [1626] "vivid red glare, the common about the sand pits was visible.  Across"       
## [1627] "the light huge black shapes, grotesque and strange, moved busily to"        
## [1628] "and fro."                                                                   
## [1629] ""                                                                           
## [1630] "It seemed indeed as if the whole country in that direction was on"          
## [1631] "fire--a broad hillside set with minute tongues of flame, swaying and"       
## [1632] "writhing with the gusts of the dying storm, and throwing a red"             
## [1633] "reflection upon the cloud-scud above.  Every now and then a haze of"        
## [1634] "smoke from some nearer conflagration drove across the window and hid"       
## [1635] "the Martian shapes.  I could not see what they were doing, nor the"         
## [1636] "clear form of them, nor recognise the black objects they were busied"       
## [1637] "upon.  Neither could I see the nearer fire, though the reflections of"      
## [1638] "it danced on the wall and ceiling of the study.  A sharp, resinous"         
## [1639] "tang of burning was in the air."                                            
## [1640] ""                                                                           
## [1641] "I closed the door noiselessly and crept towards the window.  As I"          
## [1642] "did so, the view opened out until, on the one hand, it reached to the"      
## [1643] "houses about Woking station, and on the other to the charred and"           
## [1644] "blackened pine woods of Byfleet.  There was a light down below the"         
## [1645] "hill, on the railway, near the arch, and several of the houses along"       
## [1646] "the Maybury road and the streets near the station were glowing ruins."      
## [1647] "The light upon the railway puzzled me at first; there were a black"         
## [1648] "heap and a vivid glare, and to the right of that a row of yellow"           
## [1649] "oblongs.  Then I perceived this was a wrecked train, the fore part"         
## [1650] "smashed and on fire, the hinder carriages still upon the rails."            
## [1651] ""                                                                           
## [1652] "Between these three main centres of light--the houses, the train,"          
## [1653] "and the burning county towards Chobham--stretched irregular patches of"     
## [1654] "dark country, broken here and there by intervals of dimly glowing and"      
## [1655] "smoking ground.  It was the strangest spectacle, that black expanse set"    
## [1656] "with fire.  It reminded me, more than anything else, of the Potteries"      
## [1657] "at night.  At first I could distinguish no people at all, though I"         
## [1658] "peered intently for them.  Later I saw against the light of Woking"         
## [1659] "station a number of black figures hurrying one after the other across"      
## [1660] "the line."                                                                  
## [1661] ""                                                                           
## [1662] "And this was the little world in which I had been living securely"          
## [1663] "for years, this fiery chaos!  What had happened in the last seven"          
## [1664] "hours I still did not know; nor did I know, though I was beginning to"      
## [1665] "guess, the relation between these mechanical colossi and the sluggish"      
## [1666] "lumps I had seen disgorged from the cylinder.  With a queer feeling of"     
## [1667] "impersonal interest I turned my desk chair to the window, sat down,"        
## [1668] "and stared at the blackened country, and particularly at the three"         
## [1669] "gigantic black things that were going to and fro in the glare about"        
## [1670] "the sand pits."                                                             
## [1671] ""                                                                           
## [1672] "They seemed amazingly busy.  I began to ask myself what they could"         
## [1673] "be.  Were they intelligent mechanisms?  Such a thing I felt was"            
## [1674] "impossible.  Or did a Martian sit within each, ruling, directing,"          
## [1675] "using, much as a man's brain sits and rules in his body?  I began to"       
## [1676] "compare the things to human machines, to ask myself for the first time"     
## [1677] "in my life how an ironclad or a steam engine would seem to an"              
## [1678] "intelligent lower animal."                                                  
## [1679] ""                                                                           
## [1680] "The storm had left the sky clear, and over the smoke of the burning"        
## [1681] "land the little fading pinpoint of Mars was dropping into the west,"        
## [1682] "when a soldier came into my garden.  I heard a slight scraping at the"      
## [1683] "fence, and rousing myself from the lethargy that had fallen upon me, I"     
## [1684] "looked down and saw him dimly, clambering over the palings.  At the"        
## [1685] "sight of another human being my torpor passed, and I leaned out of the"     
## [1686] "window eagerly."                                                            
## [1687] ""                                                                           
## [1688] "\"Hist!\" said I, in a whisper."                                            
## [1689] ""                                                                           
## [1690] "He stopped astride of the fence in doubt.  Then he came over and"           
## [1691] "across the lawn to the corner of the house.  He bent down and stepped"      
## [1692] "softly."                                                                    
## [1693] ""                                                                           
## [1694] "\"Who's there?\" he said, also whispering, standing under the window"       
## [1695] "and peering up."                                                            
## [1696] ""                                                                           
## [1697] "\"Where are you going?\" I asked."                                          
## [1698] ""                                                                           
## [1699] "\"God knows.\""                                                             
## [1700] ""                                                                           
## [1701] "\"Are you trying to hide?\""                                                
## [1702] ""                                                                           
## [1703] "\"That's it.\""                                                             
## [1704] ""                                                                           
## [1705] "\"Come into the house,\" I said."                                           
## [1706] ""                                                                           
## [1707] "I went down, unfastened the door, and let him in, and locked the"           
## [1708] "door again.  I could not see his face.  He was hatless, and his coat"       
## [1709] "was unbuttoned."                                                            
## [1710] ""                                                                           
## [1711] "\"My God!\" he said, as I drew him in."                                     
## [1712] ""                                                                           
## [1713] "\"What has happened?\" I asked."                                            
## [1714] ""                                                                           
## [1715] "\"What hasn't?\"  In the obscurity I could see he made a gesture of"        
## [1716] "despair.  \"They wiped us out--simply wiped us out,\" he repeated again"    
## [1717] "and again."                                                                 
## [1718] ""                                                                           
## [1719] "He followed me, almost mechanically, into the dining room."                 
## [1720] ""                                                                           
## [1721] "\"Take some whiskey,\" I said, pouring out a stiff dose."                   
## [1722] ""                                                                           
## [1723] "He drank it.  Then abruptly he sat down before the table, put his"          
## [1724] "head on his arms, and began to sob and weep like a little boy, in a"        
## [1725] "perfect passion of emotion, while I, with a curious forgetfulness of"       
## [1726] "my own recent despair, stood beside him, wondering."                        
## [1727] ""                                                                           
## [1728] "It was a long time before he could steady his nerves to answer my"          
## [1729] "questions, and then he answered perplexingly and brokenly.  He was a"       
## [1730] "driver in the artillery, and had only come into action about seven.  At"    
## [1731] "that time firing was going on across the common, and it was said the"       
## [1732] "first party of Martians were crawling slowly towards their second"          
## [1733] "cylinder under cover of a metal shield."                                    
## [1734] ""                                                                           
## [1735] "Later this shield staggered up on tripod legs and became the first"         
## [1736] "of the fighting-machines I had seen.  The gun he drove had been"            
## [1737] "unlimbered near Horsell, in order to command the sand pits, and its"        
## [1738] "arrival it was that had precipitated the action.  As the limber"            
## [1739] "gunners went to the rear, his horse trod in a rabbit hole and came"         
## [1740] "down, throwing him into a depression of the ground.  At the same"           
## [1741] "moment the gun exploded behind him, the ammunition blew up, there was"      
## [1742] "fire all about him, and he found himself lying under a heap of charred"     
## [1743] "dead men and dead horses."                                                  
## [1744] ""                                                                           
## [1745] "\"I lay still,\" he said, \"scared out of my wits, with the fore quarter"   
## [1746] "of a horse atop of me.  We'd been wiped out.  And the smell--good"          
## [1747] "God!  Like burnt meat!  I was hurt across the back by the fall of"          
## [1748] "the horse, and there I had to lie until I felt better.  Just like"          
## [1749] "parade it had been a minute before--then stumble, bang, swish!\""           
## [1750] ""                                                                           
## [1751] "\"Wiped out!\" he said."                                                    
## [1752] ""                                                                           
## [1753] "He had hid under the dead horse for a long time, peeping out"               
## [1754] "furtively across the common.  The Cardigan men had tried a rush, in"        
## [1755] "skirmishing order, at the pit, simply to be swept out of existence."        
## [1756] "Then the monster had risen to its feet and had begun to walk leisurely"     
## [1757] "to and fro across the common among the few fugitives, with its"             
## [1758] "headlike hood turning about exactly like the head of a cowled human"        
## [1759] "being.  A kind of arm carried a complicated metallic case, about which"     
## [1760] "green flashes scintillated, and out of the funnel of this there smoked"     
## [1761] "the Heat-Ray."                                                              
## [1762] ""                                                                           
## [1763] "In a few minutes there was, so far as the soldier could see, not a"         
## [1764] "living thing left upon the common, and every bush and tree upon it"         
## [1765] "that was not already a blackened skeleton was burning.  The hussars"        
## [1766] "had been on the road beyond the curvature of the ground, and he saw"        
## [1767] "nothing of them.  He heard the Maxims rattle for a time and then"           
## [1768] "become still.  The giant saved Woking station and its cluster of houses"    
## [1769] "until the last; then in a moment the Heat-Ray was brought to bear, and"     
## [1770] "the town became a heap of fiery ruins.  Then the Thing shut off the"        
## [1771] "Heat-Ray, and turning its back upon the artilleryman, began to waddle"      
## [1772] "away towards the smouldering pine woods that sheltered the second"          
## [1773] "cylinder.  As it did so a second glittering Titan built itself up out"      
## [1774] "of the pit."                                                                
## [1775] ""                                                                           
## [1776] "The second monster followed the first, and at that the artilleryman"        
## [1777] "began to crawl very cautiously across the hot heather ash towards"          
## [1778] "Horsell.  He managed to get alive into the ditch by the side of the"        
## [1779] "road, and so escaped to Woking.  There his story became ejaculatory."       
## [1780] "The place was impassable.  It seems there were a few people alive"          
## [1781] "there, frantic for the most part and many burned and scalded.  He was"      
## [1782] "turned aside by the fire, and hid among some almost scorching heaps of"     
## [1783] "broken wall as one of the Martian giants returned.  He saw this one"        
## [1784] "pursue a man, catch him up in one of its steely tentacles, and knock"       
## [1785] "his head against the trunk of a pine tree.  At last, after nightfall,"      
## [1786] "the artilleryman made a rush for it and got over the railway"               
## [1787] "embankment."                                                                
## [1788] ""                                                                           
## [1789] "Since then he had been skulking along towards Maybury, in the hope"         
## [1790] "of getting out of danger Londonward.  People were hiding in trenches"       
## [1791] "and cellars, and many of the survivors had made off towards Woking"         
## [1792] "village and Send.  He had been consumed with thirst until he found one"     
## [1793] "of the water mains near the railway arch smashed, and the water"            
## [1794] "bubbling out like a spring upon the road."                                  
## [1795] ""                                                                           
## [1796] "That was the story I got from him, bit by bit.  He grew calmer"             
## [1797] "telling me and trying to make me see the things he had seen.  He had"       
## [1798] "eaten no food since midday, he told me early in his narrative, and I"       
## [1799] "found some mutton and bread in the pantry and brought it into the"          
## [1800] "room.  We lit no lamp for fear of attracting the Martians, and ever"        
## [1801] "and again our hands would touch upon bread or meat.  As he talked,"         
## [1802] "things about us came darkly out of the darkness, and the trampled"          
## [1803] "bushes and broken rose trees outside the window grew distinct.  It"         
## [1804] "would seem that a number of men or animals had rushed across the lawn."     
## [1805] "I began to see his face, blackened and haggard, as no doubt mine was"
