## [1806] "also."                                                                      
## [1807] ""                                                                           
## [1808] "When we had finished eating we went softly upstairs to my study,"           
## [1809] "and I looked again out of the open window.  In one night the valley"        
## [1810] "had become a valley of ashes.  The fires had dwindled now.  Where"          
## [1811] "flames had been there were now streamers of smoke; but the countless"       
## [1812] "ruins of shattered and gutted houses and blasted and blackened trees"       
## [1813] "that the night had hidden stood out now gaunt and terrible in the"          
## [1814] "pitiless light of dawn.  Yet here and there some object had had the"        
## [1815] "luck to escape--a white railway signal here, the end of a greenhouse"       
## [1816] "there, white and fresh amid the wreckage.  Never before in the history"     
## [1817] "of warfare had destruction been so indiscriminate and so universal."        
## [1818] "And shining with the growing light of the east, three of the metallic"      
## [1819] "giants stood about the pit, their cowls rotating as though they were"       
## [1820] "surveying the desolation they had made."                                    
## [1821] ""                                                                           
## [1822] "It seemed to me that the pit had been enlarged, and ever and again"         
## [1823] "puffs of vivid green vapour streamed up and out of it towards the"          
## [1824] "brightening dawn--streamed up, whirled, broke, and vanished."               
## [1825] ""                                                                           
## [1826] "Beyond were the pillars of fire about Chobham.  They became pillars"        
## [1827] "of bloodshot smoke at the first touch of day."                              
## [1828] ""                                                                           
## [1829] ""                                                                           
## [1830] ""                                                                           
## [1831] "CHAPTER TWELVE"                                                             
## [1832] ""                                                                           
## [1833] "WHAT I SAW OF THE DESTRUCTION OF WEYBRIDGE AND SHEPPERTON"                  
## [1834] ""                                                                           
## [1835] ""                                                                           
## [1836] "As the dawn grew brighter we withdrew from the window from which we"        
## [1837] "had watched the Martians, and went very quietly downstairs."                
## [1838] ""                                                                           
## [1839] "The artilleryman agreed with me that the house was no place to stay"        
## [1840] "in.  He proposed, he said, to make his way Londonward, and thence"          
## [1841] "rejoin his battery--No. 12, of the Horse Artillery.  My plan was to"        
## [1842] "return at once to Leatherhead; and so greatly had the strength of the"      
## [1843] "Martians impressed me that I had determined to take my wife to"             
## [1844] "Newhaven, and go with her out of the country forthwith.  For I already"     
## [1845] "perceived clearly that the country about London must inevitably be the"     
## [1846] "scene of a disastrous struggle before such creatures as these could be"     
## [1847] "destroyed."                                                                 
## [1848] ""                                                                           
## [1849] "Between us and Leatherhead, however, lay the third cylinder, with"          
## [1850] "its guarding giants.  Had I been alone, I think I should have taken my"     
## [1851] "chance and struck across country.  But the artilleryman dissuaded me:"      
## [1852] "\"It's no kindness to the right sort of wife,\" he said, \"to make her a"   
## [1853] "widow\"; and in the end I agreed to go with him, under cover of the"        
## [1854] "woods, northward as far as Street Cobham before I parted with him."         
## [1855] "Thence I would make a big detour by Epsom to reach Leatherhead."            
## [1856] ""                                                                           
## [1857] "I should have started at once, but my companion had been in active"         
## [1858] "service and he knew better than that.  He made me ransack the house"        
## [1859] "for a flask, which he filled with whiskey; and we lined every"              
## [1860] "available pocket with packets of biscuits and slices of meat.  Then"        
## [1861] "we crept out of the house, and ran as quickly as we could down the"         
## [1862] "ill-made road by which I had come overnight.  The houses seemed"            
## [1863] "deserted. In the road lay a group of three charred bodies close"            
## [1864] "together, struck dead by the Heat-Ray; and here and there were things"      
## [1865] "that people had dropped--a clock, a slipper, a silver spoon, and the"       
## [1866] "like poor valuables.  At the corner turning up towards the post"            
## [1867] "office a little cart, filled with boxes and furniture, and horseless,"      
## [1868] "heeled over on a broken wheel.  A cash box had been hastily smashed"        
## [1869] "open and thrown under the debris."                                          
## [1870] ""                                                                           
## [1871] "Except the lodge at the Orphanage, which was still on fire, none of"        
## [1872] "the houses had suffered very greatly here.  The Heat-Ray had shaved"        
## [1873] "the chimney tops and passed.  Yet, save ourselves, there did not seem"      
## [1874] "to be a living soul on Maybury Hill.  The majority of the inhabitants"      
## [1875] "had escaped, I suppose, by way of the Old Woking road--the road I had"      
## [1876] "taken when I drove to Leatherhead--or they had hidden."                     
## [1877] ""                                                                           
## [1878] "We went down the lane, by the body of the man in black, sodden now"         
## [1879] "from the overnight hail, and broke into the woods at the foot of the"       
## [1880] "hill.  We pushed through these towards the railway without meeting a"       
## [1881] "soul.  The woods across the line were but the scarred and blackened"        
## [1882] "ruins of woods; for the most part the trees had fallen, but a certain"      
## [1883] "proportion still stood, dismal grey stems, with dark brown foliage"         
## [1884] "instead of green."                                                          
## [1885] ""                                                                           
## [1886] "On our side the fire had done no more than scorch the nearer trees;"        
## [1887] "it had failed to secure its footing.  In one place the woodmen had"         
## [1888] "been at work on Saturday; trees, felled and freshly trimmed, lay in a"      
## [1889] "clearing, with heaps of sawdust by the sawing-machine and its engine."      
## [1890] "Hard by was a temporary hut, deserted.  There was not a breath of wind"     
## [1891] "this morning, and everything was strangely still.  Even the birds were"     
## [1892] "hushed, and as we hurried along I and the artilleryman talked in"           
## [1893] "whispers and looked now and again over our shoulders.  Once or twice"       
## [1894] "we stopped to listen."                                                      
## [1895] ""                                                                           
## [1896] "After a time we drew near the road, and as we did so we heard the"          
## [1897] "clatter of hoofs and saw through the tree stems three cavalry soldiers"     
## [1898] "riding slowly towards Woking.  We hailed them, and they halted while"       
## [1899] "we hurried towards them.  It was a lieutenant and a couple of privates"     
## [1900] "of the 8th Hussars, with a stand like a theodolite, which the"              
## [1901] "artilleryman told me was a heliograph."                                     
## [1902] ""                                                                           
## [1903] "\"You are the first men I've seen coming this way this morning,\""          
## [1904] "said the lieutenant.  \"What's brewing?\""                                  
## [1905] ""                                                                           
## [1906] "His voice and face were eager.  The men behind him stared"                  
## [1907] "curiously.  The artilleryman jumped down the bank into the road and"        
## [1908] "saluted."                                                                   
## [1909] ""                                                                           
## [1910] "\"Gun destroyed last night, sir.  Have been hiding.  Trying to"             
## [1911] "rejoin battery, sir.  You'll come in sight of the Martians, I expect,"      
## [1912] "about half a mile along this road.\""                                       
## [1913] ""                                                                           
## [1914] "\"What the dickens are they like?\" asked the lieutenant."                  
## [1915] ""                                                                           
## [1916] "\"Giants in armour, sir.  Hundred feet high.  Three legs and a body"        
## [1917] "like 'luminium, with a mighty great head in a hood, sir.\""                 
## [1918] ""                                                                           
## [1919] "\"Get out!\" said the lieutenant.  \"What confounded nonsense!\""           
## [1920] ""                                                                           
## [1921] "\"You'll see, sir.  They carry a kind of box, sir, that shoots fire"        
## [1922] "and strikes you dead.\""                                                    
## [1923] ""                                                                           
## [1924] "\"What d'ye mean--a gun?\""                                                 
## [1925] ""                                                                           
## [1926] "\"No, sir,\" and the artilleryman began a vivid account of the Heat-Ray."   
## [1927] "Halfway through, the lieutenant interrupted him and looked up at"           
## [1928] "me.  I was still standing on the bank by the side of the road."             
## [1929] ""                                                                           
## [1930] "\"It's perfectly true,\" I said."                                           
## [1931] ""                                                                           
## [1932] "\"Well,\" said the lieutenant, \"I suppose it's my business to see it"      
## [1933] "too.  Look here\"--to the artilleryman--\"we're detailed here clearing"     
## [1934] "people out of their houses.  You'd better go along and report yourself"     
## [1935] "to Brigadier-General Marvin, and tell him all you know.  He's at"           
## [1936] "Weybridge.  Know the way?\""                                                
## [1937] ""                                                                           
## [1938] "\"I do,\" I said; and he turned his horse southward again."                 
## [1939] ""                                                                           
## [1940] "\"Half a mile, you say?\" said he."                                         
## [1941] ""                                                                           
## [1942] "\"At most,\" I answered, and pointed over the treetops southward.  He"      
## [1943] "thanked me and rode on, and we saw them no more."                           
## [1944] ""                                                                           
## [1945] "Farther along we came upon a group of three women and two children"         
## [1946] "in the road, busy clearing out a labourer's cottage.  They had"             
## [1947] "got hold of a little hand truck, and were piling it up with"                
## [1948] "unclean-looking bundles and shabby furniture.  They were all too"           
## [1949] "assiduously engaged to talk to us as we passed."                            
## [1950] ""                                                                           
## [1951] "By Byfleet station we emerged from the pine trees, and found the"           
## [1952] "country calm and peaceful under the morning sunlight.  We were far"         
## [1953] "beyond the range of the Heat-Ray there, and had it not been for the"        
## [1954] "silent desertion of some of the houses, the stirring movement of"           
## [1955] "packing in others, and the knot of soldiers standing on the bridge"         
## [1956] "over the railway and staring down the line towards Woking, the day"         
## [1957] "would have seemed very like any other Sunday."                              
## [1958] ""                                                                           
## [1959] "Several farm waggons and carts were moving creakily along the road"         
## [1960] "to Addlestone, and suddenly through the gate of a field we saw, across"     
## [1961] "a stretch of flat meadow, six twelve-pounders standing neatly at equal"     
## [1962] "distances pointing towards Woking.  The gunners stood by the guns"          
## [1963] "waiting, and the ammunition waggons were at a business-like distance."      
## [1964] "The men stood almost as if under inspection."                               
## [1965] ""                                                                           
## [1966] "\"That's good!\" said I.  \"They will get one fair shot, at any rate.\""    
## [1967] ""                                                                           
## [1968] "The artilleryman hesitated at the gate."                                    
## [1969] ""                                                                           
## [1970] "\"I shall go on,\" he said."                                                
## [1971] ""                                                                           
## [1972] "Farther on towards Weybridge, just over the bridge, there were a"           
## [1973] "number of men in white fatigue jackets throwing up a long rampart, and"     
## [1974] "more guns behind."                                                          
## [1975] ""                                                                           
## [1976] "\"It's bows and arrows against the lightning, anyhow,\" said the"           
## [1977] "artilleryman.  \"They 'aven't seen that fire-beam yet.\""                   
## [1978] ""                                                                           
## [1979] "The officers who were not actively engaged stood and stared over"           
## [1980] "the treetops southwestward, and the men digging would stop every now"       
## [1981] "and again to stare in the same direction."                                  
## [1982] ""                                                                           
## [1983] "Byfleet was in a tumult; people packing, and a score of hussars,"           
## [1984] "some of them dismounted, some on horseback, were hunting them about."       
## [1985] "Three or four black government waggons, with crosses in white circles,"     
## [1986] "and an old omnibus, among other vehicles, were being loaded in the"         
## [1987] "village street.  There were scores of people, most of them"                 
## [1988] "sufficiently sabbatical to have assumed their best clothes.  The"           
## [1989] "soldiers were having the greatest difficulty in making them realise"        
## [1990] "the gravity of their position.  We saw one shrivelled old fellow with"      
## [1991] "a huge box and a score or more of flower pots containing orchids,"          
## [1992] "angrily expostulating with the corporal who would leave them behind."       
## [1993] "I stopped and gripped his arm."                                             
## [1994] ""                                                                           
## [1995] "\"Do you know what's over there?\" I said, pointing at the pine tops"       
## [1996] "that hid the Martians."                                                     
## [1997] ""                                                                           
## [1998] "\"Eh?\" said he, turning.  \"I was explainin' these is vallyble.\""         
## [1999] ""                                                                           
## [2000] "\"Death!\" I shouted.  \"Death is coming!  Death!\" and leaving him to"     
## [2001] "digest that if he could, I hurried on after the artillery-man.  At the"     
## [2002] "corner I looked back.  The soldier had left him, and he was still"          
## [2003] "standing by his box, with the pots of orchids on the lid of it, and"        
## [2004] "staring vaguely over the trees."                                            
## [2005] ""                                                                           
## [2006] "No one in Weybridge could tell us where the headquarters were"              
## [2007] "established; the whole place was in such confusion as I had never seen"     
## [2008] "in any town before.  Carts, carriages everywhere, the most astonishing"     
## [2009] "miscellany of conveyances and horseflesh.  The respectable inhabitants"     
## [2010] "of the place, men in golf and boating costumes, wives prettily"             
## [2011] "dressed, were packing, river-side loafers energetically helping,"           
## [2012] "children excited, and, for the most part, highly delighted at this"         
## [2013] "astonishing variation of their Sunday experiences.  In the midst of it"     
## [2014] "all the worthy vicar was very pluckily holding an early celebration,"       
## [2015] "and his bell was jangling out above the excitement."                        
## [2016] ""                                                                           
## [2017] "I and the artilleryman, seated on the step of the drinking"                 
## [2018] "fountain, made a very passable meal upon what we had brought with"          
## [2019] "us. Patrols of soldiers--here no longer hussars, but grenadiers in"         
## [2020] "white--were warning people to move now or to take refuge in their"          
## [2021] "cellars as soon as the firing began.  We saw as we crossed the"             
## [2022] "railway bridge that a growing crowd of people had assembled in and"         
## [2023] "about the railway station, and the swarming platform was piled with"        
## [2024] "boxes and packages. The ordinary traffic had been stopped, I believe,"      
## [2025] "in order to allow of the passage of troops and guns to Chertsey, and"       
## [2026] "I have heard since that a savage struggle occurred for places in the"       
## [2027] "special trains that were put on at a later hour."                           
## [2028] ""                                                                           
## [2029] "We remained at Weybridge until midday, and at that hour we found"           
## [2030] "ourselves at the place near Shepperton Lock where the Wey and Thames"       
## [2031] "join.  Part of the time we spent helping two old women to pack a"           
## [2032] "little cart.  The Wey has a treble mouth, and at this point boats are"      
## [2033] "to be hired, and there was a ferry across the river.  On the"               
## [2034] "Shepperton side was an inn with a lawn, and beyond that the tower of"       
## [2035] "Shepperton Church--it has been replaced by a spire--rose above the"         
## [2036] "trees."                                                                     
## [2037] ""                                                                           
## [2038] "Here we found an excited and noisy crowd of fugitives.  As yet the"         
## [2039] "flight had not grown to a panic, but there were already far more"           
## [2040] "people than all the boats going to and fro could enable to cross."          
## [2041] "People came panting along under heavy burdens; one husband and wife"        
## [2042] "were even carrying a small outhouse door between them, with some of"        
## [2043] "their household goods piled thereon.  One man told us he meant to try"      
## [2044] "to get away from Shepperton station."                                       
## [2045] ""                                                                           
## [2046] "There was a lot of shouting, and one man was even jesting.  The idea"       
## [2047] "people seemed to have here was that the Martians were simply"               
## [2048] "formidable human beings, who might attack and sack the town, to be"         
## [2049] "certainly destroyed in the end.  Every now and then people would"           
## [2050] "glance nervously across the Wey, at the meadows towards Chertsey, but"      
## [2051] "everything over there was still."                                           
## [2052] ""                                                                           
## [2053] "Across the Thames, except just where the boats landed, everything"          
## [2054] "was quiet, in vivid contrast with the Surrey side.  The people who"         
## [2055] "landed there from the boats went tramping off down the lane.  The big"      
## [2056] "ferryboat had just made a journey.  Three or four soldiers stood on"        
## [2057] "the lawn of the inn, staring and jesting at the fugitives, without"         
## [2058] "offering to help.  The inn was closed, as it was now within prohibited"     
## [2059] "hours."                                                                     
## [2060] ""                                                                           
## [2061] "\"What's that?\" cried a boatman, and \"Shut up, you fool!\" said a man"    
## [2062] "near me to a yelping dog.  Then the sound came again, this time from"       
## [2063] "the direction of Chertsey, a muffled thud--the sound of a gun."             
## [2064] ""                                                                           
## [2065] "The fighting was beginning.  Almost immediately unseen batteries"           
## [2066] "across the river to our right, unseen because of the trees, took up"        
## [2067] "the chorus, firing heavily one after the other.  A woman screamed."         
## [2068] "Everyone stood arrested by the sudden stir of battle, near us and yet"      
## [2069] "invisible to us.  Nothing was to be seen save flat meadows, cows"           
## [2070] "feeding unconcernedly for the most part, and silvery pollard willows"       
## [2071] "motionless in the warm sunlight."                                           
## [2072] ""                                                                           
## [2073] "\"The sojers'll stop 'em,\" said a woman beside me, doubtfully.  A"         
## [2074] "haziness rose over the treetops."                                           
## [2075] ""                                                                           
## [2076] "Then suddenly we saw a rush of smoke far away up the river, a puff"         
## [2077] "of smoke that jerked up into the air and hung; and forthwith the"           
## [2078] "ground heaved under foot and a heavy explosion shook the air, smashing"     
## [2079] "two or three windows in the houses near, and leaving us astonished."        
## [2080] ""                                                                           
## [2081] "\"Here they are!\" shouted a man in a blue jersey.  \"Yonder! D'yer"        
## [2082] "see them?  Yonder!\""                                                       
## [2083] ""                                                                           
## [2084] "Quickly, one after the other, one, two, three, four of the armoured"        
## [2085] "Martians appeared, far away over the little trees, across the flat"         
## [2086] "meadows that stretched towards Chertsey, and striding hurriedly"            
## [2087] "towards the river.  Little cowled figures they seemed at first, going"      
## [2088] "with a rolling motion and as fast as flying birds."                         
## [2089] ""                                                                           
## [2090] "Then, advancing obliquely towards us, came a fifth.  Their armoured"        
## [2091] "bodies glittered in the sun as they swept swiftly forward upon the"         
## [2092] "guns, growing rapidly larger as they drew nearer.  One on the extreme"      
## [2093] "left, the remotest that is, flourished a huge case high in the air,"        
## [2094] "and the ghostly, terrible Heat-Ray I had already seen on Friday night"      
## [2095] "smote towards Chertsey, and struck the town."                               
## [2096] ""                                                                           
## [2097] "At sight of these strange, swift, and terrible creatures the crowd"         
## [2098] "near the water's edge seemed to me to be for a moment horror-struck."       
## [2099] "There was no screaming or shouting, but a silence.  Then a hoarse"          
## [2100] "murmur and a movement of feet--a splashing from the water.  A man, too"     
## [2101] "frightened to drop the portmanteau he carried on his shoulder, swung"       
## [2102] "round and sent me staggering with a blow from the corner of his"            
## [2103] "burden.  A woman thrust at me with her hand and rushed past me.  I"         
## [2104] "turned with the rush of the people, but I was not too terrified for"        
## [2105] "thought.  The terrible Heat-Ray was in my mind.  To get under water!"       
## [2106] "That was it!"                                                               
## [2107] ""                                                                           
## [2108] "\"Get under water!\" I shouted, unheeded."                                  
## [2109] ""                                                                           
## [2110] "I faced about again, and rushed towards the approaching Martian,"           
## [2111] "rushed right down the gravelly beach and headlong into the water."          
## [2112] "Others did the same.  A boatload of people putting back came leaping"       
## [2113] "out as I rushed past.  The stones under my feet were muddy and"             
## [2114] "slippery, and the river was so low that I ran perhaps twenty feet"          
## [2115] "scarcely waist-deep.  Then, as the Martian towered overhead scarcely"       
## [2116] "a couple of hundred yards away, I flung myself forward under the"           
## [2117] "surface.  The splashes of the people in the boats leaping into the"         
## [2118] "river sounded like thunderclaps in my ears.  People were landing"           
## [2119] "hastily on both sides of the river.  But the Martian machine took no"       
## [2120] "more notice for the moment of the people running this way and that"         
## [2121] "than a man would of the confusion of ants in a nest against which his"      
## [2122] "foot has kicked.  When, half suffocated, I raised my head above water,"     
## [2123] "the Martian's hood pointed at the batteries that were still firing"         
## [2124] "across the river, and as it advanced it swung loose what must have"         
## [2125] "been the generator of the Heat-Ray."                                        
## [2126] ""                                                                           
## [2127] "In another moment it was on the bank, and in a stride wading"               
## [2128] "halfway across.  The knees of its foremost legs bent at the farther"        
## [2129] "bank, and in another moment it had raised itself to its full height"        
## [2130] "again, close to the village of Shepperton.  Forthwith the six guns"         
## [2131] "which, unknown to anyone on the right bank, had been hidden behind the"     
## [2132] "outskirts of that village, fired simultaneously.  The sudden near"          
## [2133] "concussion, the last close upon the first, made my heart jump.  The"        
## [2134] "monster was already raising the case generating the Heat-Ray as the"        
## [2135] "first shell burst six yards above the hood."                                
## [2136] ""                                                                           
## [2137] "I gave a cry of astonishment.  I saw and thought nothing of the"            
## [2138] "other four Martian monsters; my attention was riveted upon the nearer"      
## [2139] "incident.  Simultaneously two other shells burst in the air near the"       
## [2140] "body as the hood twisted round in time to receive, but not in time to"      
## [2141] "dodge, the fourth shell."                                                   
## [2142] ""                                                                           
## [2143] "The shell burst clean in the face of the Thing.  The hood bulged,"          
## [2144] "flashed, was whirled off in a dozen tattered fragments of red flesh"        
## [2145] "and glittering metal."                                                      
## [2146] ""                                                                           
## [2147] "\"Hit!\" shouted I, with something between a scream and a cheer."           
## [2148] ""                                                                           
## [2149] "I heard answering shouts from the people in the water about me.  I"         
## [2150] "could have leaped out of the water with that momentary exultation."         
## [2151] ""                                                                           
## [2152] "The decapitated colossus reeled like a drunken giant; but it did"           
## [2153] "not fall over.  It recovered its balance by a miracle, and, no longer"      
## [2154] "heeding its steps and with the camera that fired the Heat-Ray now"          
## [2155] "rigidly upheld, it reeled swiftly upon Shepperton.  The living"             
## [2156] "intelligence, the Martian within the hood, was slain and splashed to"       
## [2157] "the four winds of heaven, and the Thing was now but a mere intricate"       
## [2158] "device of metal whirling to destruction.  It drove along in a straight"     
## [2159] "line, incapable of guidance.  It struck the tower of Shepperton"            
## [2160] "Church, smashing it down as the impact of a battering ram might have"       
## [2161] "done, swerved aside, blundered on and collapsed with tremendous force"      
## [2162] "into the river out of my sight."                                            
## [2163] ""                                                                           
## [2164] "A violent explosion shook the air, and a spout of water, steam,"            
## [2165] "mud, and shattered metal shot far up into the sky.  As the camera of"       
## [2166] "the Heat-Ray hit the water, the latter had immediately flashed into"        
## [2167] "steam.  In another moment a huge wave, like a muddy tidal bore but"         
## [2168] "almost scaldingly hot, came sweeping round the bend upstream.  I saw"       
## [2169] "people struggling shorewards, and heard their screaming and shouting"       
## [2170] "faintly above the seething and roar of the Martian's collapse."             
## [2171] ""                                                                           
## [2172] "For a moment I heeded nothing of the heat, forgot the patent need"          
## [2173] "of self-preservation.  I splashed through the tumultuous water,"            
## [2174] "pushing aside a man in black to do so, until I could see round the"         
## [2175] "bend.  Half a dozen deserted boats pitched aimlessly upon the"              
## [2176] "confusion of the waves.  The fallen Martian came into sight"                
## [2177] "downstream, lying across the river, and for the most part submerged."       
## [2178] ""                                                                           
## [2179] "Thick clouds of steam were pouring off the wreckage, and through"           
## [2180] "the tumultuously whirling wisps I could see, intermittently and"            
## [2181] "vaguely, the gigantic limbs churning the water and flinging a splash"       
## [2182] "and spray of mud and froth into the air.  The tentacles swayed and"         
## [2183] "struck like living arms, and, save for the helpless purposelessness of"     
## [2184] "these movements, it was as if some wounded thing were struggling for"       
## [2185] "its life amid the waves.  Enormous quantities of a ruddy-brown fluid"       
## [2186] "were spurting up in noisy jets out of the machine."                         
## [2187] ""                                                                           
## [2188] "My attention was diverted from this death flurry by a furious"              
## [2189] "yelling, like that of the thing called a siren in our manufacturing"        
## [2190] "towns.  A man, knee-deep near the towing path, shouted inaudibly to me"     
## [2191] "and pointed.  Looking back, I saw the other Martians advancing with"        
## [2192] "gigantic strides down the riverbank from the direction of Chertsey."        
## [2193] "The Shepperton guns spoke this time unavailingly."                          
## [2194] ""                                                                           
## [2195] "At that I ducked at once under water, and, holding my breath until"         
## [2196] "movement was an agony, blundered painfully ahead under the surface as"      
## [2197] "long as I could.  The water was in a tumult about me, and rapidly"          
## [2198] "growing hotter."                                                            
## [2199] ""                                                                           
## [2200] "When for a moment I raised my head to take breath and throw the"            
## [2201] "hair and water from my eyes, the steam was rising in a whirling white"      
## [2202] "fog that at first hid the Martians altogether.  The noise was"              
## [2203] "deafening.  Then I saw them dimly, colossal figures of grey, magnified"     
## [2204] "by the mist.  They had passed by me, and two were stooping over the"        
## [2205] "frothing, tumultuous ruins of their comrade."                               
## [2206] ""                                                                           
## [2207] "The third and fourth stood beside him in the water, one perhaps two"        
## [2208] "hundred yards from me, the other towards Laleham.  The generators of"       
## [2209] "the Heat-Rays waved high, and the hissing beams smote down this way"        
## [2210] "and that."                                                                  
## [2211] ""                                                                           
## [2212] "The air was full of sound, a deafening and confusing conflict of"           
## [2213] "noises--the clangorous din of the Martians, the crash of falling"           
## [2214] "houses, the thud of trees, fences, sheds flashing into flame, and the"      
## [2215] "crackling and roaring of fire.  Dense black smoke was leaping up to"        
## [2216] "mingle with the steam from the river, and as the Heat-Ray went to and"      
## [2217] "fro over Weybridge its impact was marked by flashes of incandescent"        
## [2218] "white, that gave place at once to a smoky dance of lurid flames.  The"      
## [2219] "nearer houses still stood intact, awaiting their fate, shadowy, faint"      
## [2220] "and pallid in the steam, with the fire behind them going to and fro."       
## [2221] ""                                                                           
## [2222] "For a moment perhaps I stood there, breast-high in the almost"              
## [2223] "boiling water, dumbfounded at my position, hopeless of escape.  Through"    
## [2224] "the reek I could see the people who had been with me in the river"          
## [2225] "scrambling out of the water through the reeds, like little frogs"           
## [2226] "hurrying through grass from the advance of a man, or running to and"        
## [2227] "fro in utter dismay on the towing path."                                    
## [2228] ""                                                                           
## [2229] "Then suddenly the white flashes of the Heat-Ray came leaping"               
## [2230] "towards me.  The houses caved in as they dissolved at its touch, and"       
## [2231] "darted out flames; the trees changed to fire with a roar.  The Ray"         
## [2232] "flickered up and down the towing path, licking off the people who ran"      
## [2233] "this way and that, and came down to the water's edge not fifty yards"       
## [2234] "from where I stood.  It swept across the river to Shepperton, and the"      
## [2235] "water in its track rose in a boiling weal crested with steam.  I"           
## [2236] "turned shoreward."                                                          
## [2237] ""                                                                           
## [2238] "In another moment the huge wave, well-nigh at the boiling-point had"        
## [2239] "rushed upon me.  I screamed aloud, and scalded, half blinded,"              
## [2240] "agonised, I staggered through the leaping, hissing water towards the"       
## [2241] "shore.  Had my foot stumbled, it would have been the end.  I fell"          
## [2242] "helplessly, in full sight of the Martians, upon the broad, bare"            
## [2243] "gravelly spit that runs down to mark the angle of the Wey and Thames."      
## [2244] "I expected nothing but death."                                              
## [2245] ""                                                                           
## [2246] "I have a dim memory of the foot of a Martian coming down within a"          
## [2247] "score of yards of my head, driving straight into the loose gravel,"         
## [2248] "whirling it this way and that and lifting again; of a long suspense,"       
## [2249] "and then of the four carrying the debris of their comrade between"          
## [2250] "them, now clear and then presently faint through a veil of smoke,"          
## [2251] "receding interminably, as it seemed to me, across a vast space of"          
## [2252] "river and meadow.  And then, very slowly, I realised that by a miracle"     
## [2253] "I had escaped."                                                             
## [2254] ""                                                                           
## [2255] ""                                                                           
## [2256] ""                                                                           
## [2257] "CHAPTER THIRTEEN"                                                           
## [2258] ""                                                                           
## [2259] "HOW I FELL IN WITH THE CURATE"                                              
## [2260] ""                                                                           
## [2261] ""                                                                           
## [2262] "After getting this sudden lesson in the power of terrestrial"               
## [2263] "weapons, the Martians retreated to their original position upon"            
## [2264] "Horsell Common; and in their haste, and encumbered with the debris of"      
## [2265] "their smashed companion, they no doubt overlooked many such a stray"        
## [2266] "and negligible victim as myself.  Had they left their comrade and"          
## [2267] "pushed on forthwith, there was nothing at that time between them and"       
## [2268] "London but batteries of twelve-pounder guns, and they would certainly"      
## [2269] "have reached the capital in advance of the tidings of their approach;"      
## [2270] "as sudden, dreadful, and destructive their advent would have been as"       
## [2271] "the earthquake that destroyed Lisbon a century ago."                        
## [2272] ""                                                                           
## [2273] "But they were in no hurry.  Cylinder followed cylinder on its"              
## [2274] "interplanetary flight; every twenty-four hours brought them"                
## [2275] "reinforcement.  And meanwhile the military and naval authorities, now"      
## [2276] "fully alive to the tremendous power of their antagonists, worked with"      
## [2277] "furious energy.  Every minute a fresh gun came into position until,"        
## [2278] "before twilight, every copse, every row of suburban villas on the"          
## [2279] "hilly slopes about Kingston and Richmond, masked an expectant black"        
## [2280] "muzzle.  And through the charred and desolated area--perhaps twenty"        
## [2281] "square miles altogether--that encircled the Martian encampment on"          
## [2282] "Horsell Common, through charred and ruined villages among the green"        
## [2283] "trees, through the blackened and smoking arcades that had been but a"       
## [2284] "day ago pine spinneys, crawled the devoted scouts with the heliographs"     
## [2285] "that were presently to warn the gunners of the Martian approach.  But"      
## [2286] "the Martians now understood our command of artillery and the danger of"     
## [2287] "human proximity, and not a man ventured within a mile of either"            
## [2288] "cylinder, save at the price of his life."                                   
## [2289] ""                                                                           
## [2290] "It would seem that these giants spent the earlier part of the"              
## [2291] "afternoon in going to and fro, transferring everything from the second"     
## [2292] "and third cylinders--the second in Addlestone Golf Links and the third"     
## [2293] "at Pyrford--to their original pit on Horsell Common.  Over that, above"     
## [2294] "the blackened heather and ruined buildings that stretched far and"          
## [2295] "wide, stood one as sentinel, while the rest abandoned their vast"           
## [2296] "fighting-machines and descended into the pit.  They were hard at work"      
## [2297] "there far into the night, and the towering pillar of dense green smoke"     
## [2298] "that rose therefrom could be seen from the hills about Merrow, and"         
## [2299] "even, it is said, from Banstead and Epsom Downs."                           
## [2300] ""                                                                           
## [2301] "And while the Martians behind me were thus preparing for their next"        
## [2302] "sally, and in front of me Humanity gathered for the battle, I made my"      
## [2303] "way with infinite pains and labour from the fire and smoke of burning"      
## [2304] "Weybridge towards London."                                                  
## [2305] ""                                                                           
## [2306] "I saw an abandoned boat, very small and remote, drifting down-stream;"      
## [2307] "and throwing off the most of my sodden clothes, I went after it,"           
## [2308] "gained it, and so escaped out of that destruction.  There were no"          
## [2309] "oars in the boat, but I contrived to paddle, as well as my parboiled"       
## [2310] "hands would allow, down the river towards Halliford and Walton, going"      
## [2311] "very tediously and continually looking behind me, as you may well"          
## [2312] "understand.  I followed the river, because I considered that the water"     
## [2313] "gave me my best chance of escape should these giants return."               
## [2314] ""                                                                           
## [2315] "The hot water from the Martian's overthrow drifted downstream with"         
## [2316] "me, so that for the best part of a mile I could see little of either"       
## [2317] "bank.  Once, however, I made out a string of black figures hurrying"        
## [2318] "across the meadows from the direction of Weybridge.  Halliford, it"         
## [2319] "seemed, was deserted, and several of the houses facing the river were"      
## [2320] "on fire.  It was strange to see the place quite tranquil, quite"            
## [2321] "desolate under the hot blue sky, with the smoke and little threads of"      
## [2322] "flame going straight up into the heat of the afternoon.  Never before"      
## [2323] "had I seen houses burning without the accompaniment of an obstructive"      
## [2324] "crowd.  A little farther on the dry reeds up the bank were smoking and"     
## [2325] "glowing, and a line of fire inland was marching steadily across a late"     
## [2326] "field of hay."                                                              
## [2327] ""                                                                           
## [2328] "For a long time I drifted, so painful and weary was I after the"            
## [2329] "violence I had been through, and so intense the heat upon the water."       
## [2330] "Then my fears got the better of me again, and I resumed my paddling."       
## [2331] "The sun scorched my bare back.  At last, as the bridge at Walton was"       
## [2332] "coming into sight round the bend, my fever and faintness overcame my"       
## [2333] "fears, and I landed on the Middlesex bank and lay down, deadly sick,"       
## [2334] "amid the long grass.  I suppose the time was then about four or five"       
## [2335] "o'clock.  I got up presently, walked perhaps half a mile without"           
## [2336] "meeting a soul, and then lay down again in the shadow of a hedge.  I"       
## [2337] "seem to remember talking, wanderingly, to myself during that last"          
## [2338] "spurt.  I was also very thirsty, and bitterly regretful I had drunk no"     
## [2339] "more water.  It is a curious thing that I felt angry with my wife; I"       
## [2340] "cannot account for it, but my impotent desire to reach Leatherhead"         
## [2341] "worried me excessively."                                                    
## [2342] ""                                                                           
## [2343] "I do not clearly remember the arrival of the curate, so that probably"      
## [2344] "I dozed.  I became aware of him as a seated figure in soot-smudged"         
## [2345] "shirt sleeves, and with his upturned, clean-shaven face staring at"         
## [2346] "a faint flickering that danced over the sky.  The sky was what is"          
## [2347] "called a mackerel sky--rows and rows of faint down-plumes of"               
## [2348] "cloud, just tinted with the midsummer sunset."                              
## [2349] ""                                                                           
## [2350] "I sat up, and at the rustle of my motion he looked at me quickly."          
## [2351] ""                                                                           
## [2352] "\"Have you any water?\" I asked abruptly."                                  
## [2353] ""                                                                           
## [2354] "He shook his head."                                                         
## [2355] ""                                                                           
## [2356] "\"You have been asking for water for the last hour,\" he said."             
## [2357] ""                                                                           
## [2358] "For a moment we were silent, taking stock of each other.  I"                
## [2359] "dare say he found me a strange enough figure, naked, save for my"           
## [2360] "water-soaked trousers and socks, scalded, and my face and shoulders"        
## [2361] "blackened by the smoke.  His face was a fair weakness, his chin"            
## [2362] "retreated, and his hair lay in crisp, almost flaxen curls on his low"       
## [2363] "forehead; his eyes were rather large, pale blue, and blankly staring."      
## [2364] "He spoke abruptly, looking vacantly away from me."                          
## [2365] ""                                                                           
## [2366] "\"What does it mean?\" he said.  \"What do these things mean?\""            
## [2367] ""                                                                           
## [2368] "I stared at him and made no answer."                                        
## [2369] ""                                                                           
## [2370] "He extended a thin white hand and spoke in almost a complaining"            
## [2371] "tone."                                                                      
## [2372] ""                                                                           
## [2373] "\"Why are these things permitted?  What sins have we done?  The"            
## [2374] "morning service was over, I was walking through the roads to clear my"      
## [2375] "brain for the afternoon, and then--fire, earthquake, death!  As if it"      
## [2376] "were Sodom and Gomorrah!  All our work undone, all the work---- What"       
## [2377] "are these Martians?\""                                                      
## [2378] ""                                                                           
## [2379] "\"What are we?\" I answered, clearing my throat."                           
## [2380] ""                                                                           
## [2381] "He gripped his knees and turned to look at me again.  For half a"           
## [2382] "minute, perhaps, he stared silently."                                       
## [2383] ""                                                                           
## [2384] "\"I was walking through the roads to clear my brain,\" he said.  \"And"     
## [2385] "suddenly--fire, earthquake, death!\""                                       
## [2386] ""                                                                           
## [2387] "He relapsed into silence, with his chin now sunken almost to his"           
## [2388] "knees."                                                                     
## [2389] ""                                                                           
## [2390] "Presently he began waving his hand."                                        
## [2391] ""                                                                           
## [2392] "\"All the work--all the Sunday schools--What have we done--what has"        
## [2393] "Weybridge done?  Everything gone--everything destroyed.  The church!"       
## [2394] "We rebuilt it only three years ago.  Gone!  Swept out of existence!"        
## [2395] "Why?\""                                                                     
## [2396] ""                                                                           
## [2397] "Another pause, and he broke out again like one demented."                   
## [2398] ""                                                                           
## [2399] "\"The smoke of her burning goeth up for ever and ever!\" he shouted."       
## [2400] ""                                                                           
## [2401] "His eyes flamed, and he pointed a lean finger in the direction of"          
## [2402] "Weybridge."                                                                 
## [2403] ""                                                                           
## [2404] "By this time I was beginning to take his measure.  The tremendous"          
## [2405] "tragedy in which he had been involved--it was evident he was a"             
## [2406] "fugitive from Weybridge--had driven him to the very verge of his"           
## [2407] "reason."                                                                    
## [2408] ""                                                                           
## [2409] "\"Are we far from Sunbury?\" I said, in a matter-of-fact tone."             
## [2410] ""                                                                           
## [2411] "\"What are we to do?\" he asked.  \"Are these creatures everywhere?"        
## [2412] "Has the earth been given over to them?\""                                   
## [2413] ""                                                                           
## [2414] "\"Are we far from Sunbury?\""                                               
## [2415] ""                                                                           
## [2416] "\"Only this morning I officiated at early celebration----\""                
## [2417] ""                                                                           
## [2418] "\"Things have changed,\" I said, quietly.  \"You must keep your head."      
## [2419] "There is still hope.\""                                                     
## [2420] ""                                                                           
## [2421] "\"Hope!\""                                                                  
## [2422] ""                                                                           
## [2423] "\"Yes.  Plentiful hope--for all this destruction!\""                        
## [2424] ""                                                                           
## [2425] "I began to explain my view of our position.  He listened at first,"         
## [2426] "but as I went on the interest dawning in his eyes gave place to their"      
## [2427] "former stare, and his regard wandered from me."                             
## [2428] ""                                                                           
## [2429] "\"This must be the beginning of the end,\" he said, interrupting me."       
## [2430] "\"The end!  The great and terrible day of the Lord!  When men shall"        
## [2431] "call upon the mountains and the rocks to fall upon them and hide"           
## [2432] "them--hide them from the face of Him that sitteth upon the throne!\""       
## [2433] ""                                                                           
## [2434] "I began to understand the position.  I ceased my laboured"                  
## [2435] "reasoning, struggled to my feet, and, standing over him, laid my hand"      
## [2436] "on his shoulder."                                                           
## [2437] ""                                                                           
## [2438] "\"Be a man!\" said I.  \"You are scared out of your wits!  What good"       
## [2439] "is religion if it collapses under calamity?  Think of what earthquakes"     
## [2440] "and floods, wars and volcanoes, have done before to men!  Did you"          
## [2441] "think God had exempted Weybridge?  He is not an insurance agent.\""         
## [2442] ""                                                                           
## [2443] "For a time he sat in blank silence."                                        
## [2444] ""                                                                           
## [2445] "\"But how can we escape?\" he asked, suddenly.  \"They are"                 
## [2446] "invulnerable, they are pitiless.\""                                         
## [2447] ""                                                                           
## [2448] "\"Neither the one nor, perhaps, the other,\" I answered. \"And the"         
## [2449] "mightier they are the more sane and wary should we be.  One of them"        
## [2450] "was killed yonder not three hours ago.\""                                   
## [2451] ""                                                                           
## [2452] "\"Killed!\" he said, staring about him.  \"How can God's ministers be"      
## [2453] "killed?\""                                                                  
## [2454] ""                                                                           
## [2455] "\"I saw it happen.\" I proceeded to tell him.  \"We have chanced to"        
## [2456] "come in for the thick of it,\" said I, \"and that is all.\""                
## [2457] ""                                                                           
## [2458] "\"What is that flicker in the sky?\" he asked abruptly."                    
## [2459] ""                                                                           
## [2460] "I told him it was the heliograph signalling--that it was the sign"          
## [2461] "of human help and effort in the sky."                                       
## [2462] ""                                                                           
## [2463] "\"We are in the midst of it,\" I said, \"quiet as it is.  That flicker"     
## [2464] "in the sky tells of the gathering storm.  Yonder, I take it are the"        
## [2465] "Martians, and Londonward, where those hills rise about Richmond and"        
## [2466] "Kingston and the trees give cover, earthworks are being thrown up and"      
## [2467] "guns are being placed.  Presently the Martians will be coming this way"     
## [2468] "again.\""                                                                   
## [2469] ""                                                                           
## [2470] "And even as I spoke he sprang to his feet and stopped me by a"              
## [2471] "gesture."                                                                   
## [2472] ""                                                                           
## [2473] "\"Listen!\" he said."                                                       
## [2474] ""                                                                           
## [2475] "From beyond the low hills across the water came the dull resonance"         
## [2476] "of distant guns and a remote weird crying.  Then everything was still."     
## [2477] "A cockchafer came droning over the hedge and past us.  High in the"         
## [2478] "west the crescent moon hung faint and pale above the smoke of"              
## [2479] "Weybridge and Shepperton and the hot, still splendour of the sunset."       
## [2480] ""                                                                           
## [2481] "\"We had better follow this path,\" I said, \"northward.\""                 
## [2482] ""                                                                           
## [2483] ""                                                                           
## [2484] ""                                                                           
## [2485] "CHAPTER FOURTEEN"                                                           
## [2486] ""                                                                           
## [2487] "IN LONDON"                                                                  
## [2488] ""                                                                           
## [2489] ""                                                                           
## [2490] "My younger brother was in London when the Martians fell at Woking."         
## [2491] "He was a medical student working for an imminent examination, and he"       
## [2492] "heard nothing of the arrival until Saturday morning.  The morning"          
## [2493] "papers on Saturday contained, in addition to lengthy special articles"      
## [2494] "on the planet Mars, on life in the planets, and so forth, a brief and"      
## [2495] "vaguely worded telegram, all the more striking for its brevity."            
## [2496] ""                                                                           
## [2497] "The Martians, alarmed by the approach of a crowd, had killed a"             
## [2498] "number of people with a quick-firing gun, so the story ran.  The"           
## [2499] "telegram concluded with the words: \"Formidable as they seem to be, the"    
## [2500] "Martians have not moved from the pit into which they have fallen, and,"     
## [2501] "indeed, seem incapable of doing so.  Probably this is due to the"           
## [2502] "relative strength of the earth's gravitational energy.\"  On that last"     
## [2503] "text their leader-writer expanded very comfortingly."                       
## [2504] ""                                                                           
## [2505] "Of course all the students in the crammer's biology class, to which"        
## [2506] "my brother went that day, were intensely interested, but there were no"     
## [2507] "signs of any unusual excitement in the streets.  The afternoon papers"      
## [2508] "puffed scraps of news under big headlines.  They had nothing to tell"       
## [2509] "beyond the movements of troops about the common, and the burning of"        
## [2510] "the pine woods between Woking and Weybridge, until eight.  Then the"        
## [2511] "_St. James's Gazette_, in an extra-special edition, announced the bare"     
## [2512] "fact of the interruption of telegraphic communication.  This was"           
## [2513] "thought to be due to the falling of burning pine trees across the"          
## [2514] "line.  Nothing more of the fighting was known that night, the night of"     
## [2515] "my drive to Leatherhead and back."                                          
## [2516] ""                                                                           
## [2517] "My brother felt no anxiety about us, as he knew from the"                   
## [2518] "description in the papers that the cylinder was a good two miles from"      
## [2519] "my house.  He made up his mind to run down that night to me, in order,"     
## [2520] "as he says, to see the Things before they were killed.  He dispatched"      
## [2521] "a telegram, which never reached me, about four o'clock, and spent the"      
## [2522] "evening at a music hall."                                                   
## [2523] ""                                                                           
## [2524] "In London, also, on Saturday night there was a thunderstorm, and my"        
## [2525] "brother reached Waterloo in a cab.  On the platform from which the"         
## [2526] "midnight train usually starts he learned, after some waiting, that an"      
## [2527] "accident prevented trains from reaching Woking that night.  The nature"     
## [2528] "of the accident he could not ascertain; indeed, the railway"                
## [2529] "authorities did not clearly know at that time.  There was very little"      
## [2530] "excitement in the station, as the officials, failing to realise that"       
## [2531] "anything further than a breakdown between Byfleet and Woking junction"      
## [2532] "had occurred, were running the theatre trains which usually passed"         
## [2533] "through Woking round by Virginia Water or Guildford.  They were busy"       
## [2534] "making the necessary arrangements to alter the route of the"                
## [2535] "Southampton and Portsmouth Sunday League excursions.  A nocturnal"          
## [2536] "newspaper reporter, mistaking my brother for the traffic manager, to"       
## [2537] "whom he bears a slight resemblance, waylaid and tried to interview"         
## [2538] "him.  Few people, excepting the railway officials, connected the"           
## [2539] "breakdown with the Martians."                                               
## [2540] ""                                                                           
## [2541] "I have read, in another account of these events, that on Sunday"            
## [2542] "morning \"all London was electrified by the news from Woking.\"  As a"      
## [2543] "matter of fact, there was nothing to justify that very extravagant"         
## [2544] "phrase.  Plenty of Londoners did not hear of the Martians until the"        
## [2545] "panic of Monday morning.  Those who did took some time to realise all"      
## [2546] "that the hastily worded telegrams in the Sunday papers conveyed.  The"      
## [2547] "majority of people in London do not read Sunday papers."                    
## [2548] ""                                                                           
## [2549] "The habit of personal security, moreover, is so deeply fixed in the"        
## [2550] "Londoner's mind, and startling intelligence so much a matter of course"     
## [2551] "in the papers, that they could read without any personal tremors:"          
## [2552] "\"About seven o'clock last night the Martians came out of the cylinder,"    
## [2553] "and, moving about under an armour of metallic shields, have completely"     
## [2554] "wrecked Woking station with the adjacent houses, and massacred an"          
## [2555] "entire battalion of the Cardigan Regiment.  No details are known."          
## [2556] "Maxims have been absolutely useless against their armour; the field"        
## [2557] "guns have been disabled by them.  Flying hussars have been galloping"       
## [2558] "into Chertsey.  The Martians appear to be moving slowly towards"            
## [2559] "Chertsey or Windsor.  Great anxiety prevails in West Surrey, and"           
## [2560] "earthworks are being thrown up to check the advance Londonward.\"  That"    
## [2561] "was how the Sunday _Sun_ put it, and a clever and remarkably prompt"        
## [2562] "\"handbook\" article in the _Referee_ compared the affair to a menagerie"   
## [2563] "suddenly let loose in a village."                                           
## [2564] ""                                                                           
## [2565] "No one in London knew positively of the nature of the armoured"             
## [2566] "Martians, and there was still a fixed idea that these monsters must be"     
## [2567] "sluggish: \"crawling,\" \"creeping painfully\"--such expressions occurred"  
## [2568] "in almost all the earlier reports.  None of the telegrams could have"       
## [2569] "been written by an eyewitness of their advance.  The Sunday papers"         
## [2570] "printed separate editions as further news came to hand, some even in"       
## [2571] "default of it.  But there was practically nothing more to tell people"      
## [2572] "until late in the afternoon, when the authorities gave the press"           
## [2573] "agencies the news in their possession.  It was stated that the people"      
## [2574] "of Walton and Weybridge, and all the district were pouring along the"       
## [2575] "roads Londonward, and that was all."                                        
## [2576] ""                                                                           
## [2577] "My brother went to church at the Foundling Hospital in the morning,"        
## [2578] "still in ignorance of what had happened on the previous night.  There"      
## [2579] "he heard allusions made to the invasion, and a special prayer for"          
## [2580] "peace.  Coming out, he bought a _Referee_.  He became alarmed at the"       
## [2581] "news in this, and went again to Waterloo station to find out if"            
## [2582] "communication were restored.  The omnibuses, carriages, cyclists, and"      
## [2583] "innumerable people walking in their best clothes seemed scarcely"           
## [2584] "affected by the strange intelligence that the news venders were"            
## [2585] "disseminating.  People were interested, or, if alarmed, alarmed only"       
## [2586] "on account of the local residents.  At the station he heard for the"        
## [2587] "first time that the Windsor and Chertsey lines were now interrupted."       
## [2588] "The porters told him that several remarkable telegrams had been"            
## [2589] "received in the morning from Byfleet and Chertsey stations, but that"       
## [2590] "these had abruptly ceased.  My brother could get very little precise"       
## [2591] "detail out of them."                                                        
## [2592] ""                                                                           
## [2593] "\"There's fighting going on about Weybridge\" was the extent of their"      
## [2594] "information."                                                               
## [2595] ""                                                                           
## [2596] "The train service was now very much disorganised.  Quite a number"          
## [2597] "of people who had been expecting friends from places on the"                
## [2598] "South-Western network were standing about the station.  One"                
## [2599] "grey-headed old gentleman came and abused the South-Western Company"        
## [2600] "bitterly to my brother.  \"It wants showing up,\" he said."                 
## [2601] ""                                                                           
## [2602] "One or two trains came in from Richmond, Putney, and Kingston,"             
## [2603] "containing people who had gone out for a day's boating and found the"       
## [2604] "locks closed and a feeling of panic in the air.  A man in a blue and"       
## [2605] "white blazer addressed my brother, full of strange tidings."                
## [2606] ""                                                                           
## [2607] "\"There's hosts of people driving into Kingston in traps and carts"         
## [2608] "and things, with boxes of valuables and all that,\" he said.  \"They"       
## [2609] "come from Molesey and Weybridge and Walton, and they say there's been"      
## [2610] "guns heard at Chertsey, heavy firing, and that mounted soldiers have"       
## [2611] "told them to get off at once because the Martians are coming.  We"          
## [2612] "heard guns firing at Hampton Court station, but we thought it was"          
## [2613] "thunder.  What the dickens does it all mean?  The Martians can't get"       
## [2614] "out of their pit, can they?\""                                              
## [2615] ""                                                                           
## [2616] "My brother could not tell him."                                             
## [2617] ""                                                                           
## [2618] "Afterwards he found that the vague feeling of alarm had spread to"          
## [2619] "the clients of the underground railway, and that the Sunday"                
## [2620] "excursionists began to return from all over the South-Western"              
## [2621] "\"lung\"--Barnes, Wimbledon, Richmond Park, Kew, and so forth--at"          
## [2622] "unnaturally early hours; but not a soul had anything more than vague"       
## [2623] "hearsay to tell of.  Everyone connected with the terminus seemed"           
## [2624] "ill-tempered."                                                              
## [2625] ""                                                                           
## [2626] "About five o'clock the gathering crowd in the station was immensely"        
## [2627] "excited by the opening of the line of communication, which is almost"       
## [2628] "invariably closed, between the South-Eastern and the South-Western"         
## [2629] "stations, and the passage of carriage trucks bearing huge guns and"         
## [2630] "carriages crammed with soldiers.  These were the guns that were"            
## [2631] "brought up from Woolwich and Chatham to cover Kingston.  There was"         
## [2632] "an exchange of pleasantries: \"You'll get eaten!\"  \"We're the"            
## [2633] "beast-tamers!\" and so forth.  A little while after that a squad of"        
## [2634] "police came into the station and began to clear the public off the"         
## [2635] "platforms, and my brother went out into the street again."                  
## [2636] ""                                                                           
## [2637] "The church bells were ringing for evensong, and a squad of"                 
## [2638] "Salvation Army lassies came singing down Waterloo Road.  On the bridge"     
## [2639] "a number of loafers were watching a curious brown scum that came"           
## [2640] "drifting down the stream in patches.  The sun was just setting, and the"    
## [2641] "Clock Tower and the Houses of Parliament rose against one of the most"      
## [2642] "peaceful skies it is possible to imagine, a sky of gold, barred with"       
## [2643] "long transverse stripes of reddish-purple cloud.  There was talk of a"      
## [2644] "floating body.  One of the men there, a reservist he said he was, told"     
## [2645] "my brother he had seen the heliograph flickering in the west."              
## [2646] ""                                                                           
## [2647] "In Wellington Street my brother met a couple of sturdy roughs who"          
## [2648] "had just been rushed out of Fleet Street with still-wet newspapers and"     
## [2649] "staring placards.  \"Dreadful catastrophe!\" they bawled one to the"        
## [2650] "other down Wellington Street.  \"Fighting at Weybridge!  Full"              
## [2651] "description!  Repulse of the Martians! London in Danger!\"  He had to"      
## [2652] "give threepence for a copy of that paper."                                  
## [2653] ""                                                                           
## [2654] "Then it was, and then only, that he realised something of the full"         
## [2655] "power and terror of these monsters.  He learned that they were not"         
## [2656] "merely a handful of small sluggish creatures, but that they were minds"     
## [2657] "swaying vast mechanical bodies; and that they could move swiftly and"       
## [2658] "smite with such power that even the mightiest guns could not stand"         
## [2659] "against them."                                                              
## [2660] ""                                                                           
## [2661] "They were described as \"vast spiderlike machines, nearly a hundred"        
## [2662] "feet high, capable of the speed of an express train, and able to shoot"     
## [2663] "out a beam of intense heat.\"  Masked batteries, chiefly of field guns,"    
## [2664] "had been planted in the country about Horsell Common, and especially"       
## [2665] "between the Woking district and London.  Five of the machines had been"     
## [2666] "seen moving towards the Thames, and one, by a happy chance, had been"       
## [2667] "destroyed.  In the other cases the shells had missed, and the"              
## [2668] "batteries had been at once annihilated by the Heat-Rays.  Heavy"            
## [2669] "losses of soldiers were mentioned, but the tone of the dispatch was"        
## [2670] "optimistic."                                                                
## [2671] ""                                                                           
## [2672] "The Martians had been repulsed; they were not invulnerable.  They"          
## [2673] "had retreated to their triangle of cylinders again, in the circle"          
## [2674] "about Woking.  Signallers with heliographs were pushing forward upon"       
## [2675] "them from all sides.  Guns were in rapid transit from Windsor,"             
## [2676] "Portsmouth, Aldershot, Woolwich--even from the north; among others,"        
## [2677] "long wire-guns of ninety-five tons from Woolwich.  Altogether one"          
## [2678] "hundred and sixteen were in position or being hastily placed, chiefly"      
## [2679] "covering London.  Never before in England had there been such a vast"       
## [2680] "or rapid concentration of military material."                               
## [2681] ""                                                                           
## [2682] "Any further cylinders that fell, it was hoped, could be destroyed"          
## [2683] "at once by high explosives, which were being rapidly manufactured and"      
## [2684] "distributed.  No doubt, ran the report, the situation was of the"           
## [2685] "strangest and gravest description, but the public was exhorted to"          
## [2686] "avoid and discourage panic.  No doubt the Martians were strange and"        
## [2687] "terrible in the extreme, but at the outside there could not be more"        
## [2688] "than twenty of them against our millions."                                  
## [2689] ""                                                                           
## [2690] "The authorities had reason to suppose, from the size of the"                
## [2691] "cylinders, that at the outside there could not be more than five in"        
## [2692] "each cylinder--fifteen altogether.  And one at least was disposed"          
## [2693] "of--perhaps more.  The public would be fairly warned of the approach"       
## [2694] "of danger, and elaborate measures were being taken for the protection"      
## [2695] "of the people in the threatened southwestern suburbs.  And so, with"        
## [2696] "reiterated assurances of the safety of London and the ability of the"       
## [2697] "authorities to cope with the difficulty, this quasi-proclamation"           
## [2698] "closed."                                                                    
## [2699] ""                                                                           
## [2700] "This was printed in enormous type on paper so fresh that it was"            
## [2701] "still wet, and there had been no time to add a word of comment.  It"        
## [2702] "was curious, my brother said, to see how ruthlessly the usual contents"     
## [2703] "of the paper had been hacked and taken out to give this place."             
## [2704] ""                                                                           
## [2705] "All down Wellington Street people could be seen fluttering out the"         
## [2706] "pink sheets and reading, and the Strand was suddenly noisy with the"        
## [2707] "voices of an army of hawkers following these pioneers.  Men came"           
## [2708] "scrambling off buses to secure copies.  Certainly this news excited"        
## [2709] "people intensely, whatever their previous apathy.  The shutters of a"       
## [2710] "map shop in the Strand were being taken down, my brother said, and a"       
## [2711] "man in his Sunday raiment, lemon-yellow gloves even, was visible"           
## [2712] "inside the window hastily fastening maps of Surrey to the glass."           
## [2713] ""                                                                           
## [2714] "Going on along the Strand to Trafalgar Square, the paper in his"
