## [2715] "hand, my brother saw some of the fugitives from West Surrey.  There"        
## [2716] "was a man with his wife and two boys and some articles of furniture in"     
## [2717] "a cart such as greengrocers use.  He was driving from the direction of"     
## [2718] "Westminster Bridge; and close behind him came a hay waggon with five"       
## [2719] "or six respectable-looking people in it, and some boxes and bundles."       
## [2720] "The faces of these people were haggard, and their entire appearance"        
## [2721] "contrasted conspicuously with the Sabbath-best appearance of the"           
## [2722] "people on the omnibuses.  People in fashionable clothing peeped at"         
## [2723] "them out of cabs.  They stopped at the Square as if undecided which"        
## [2724] "way to take, and finally turned eastward along the Strand.  Some way"       
## [2725] "behind these came a man in workday clothes, riding one of those"            
## [2726] "old-fashioned tricycles with a small front wheel.  He was dirty and"        
## [2727] "white in the face."                                                         
## [2728] ""                                                                           
## [2729] "My brother turned down towards Victoria, and met a number of such"          
## [2730] "people.  He had a vague idea that he might see something of me.  He"        
## [2731] "noticed an unusual number of police regulating the traffic.  Some of"       
## [2732] "the refugees were exchanging news with the people on the omnibuses."        
## [2733] "One was professing to have seen the Martians.  \"Boilers on stilts, I"      
## [2734] "tell you, striding along like men.\"  Most of them were excited and"        
## [2735] "animated by their strange experience."                                      
## [2736] ""                                                                           
## [2737] "Beyond Victoria the public-houses were doing a lively trade with"           
## [2738] "these arrivals.  At all the street corners groups of people were"           
## [2739] "reading papers, talking excitedly, or staring at these unusual Sunday"      
## [2740] "visitors.  They seemed to increase as night drew on, until at last the"     
## [2741] "roads, my brother said, were like Epsom High Street on a Derby Day.  My"    
## [2742] "brother addressed several of these fugitives and got unsatisfactory"        
## [2743] "answers from most."                                                         
## [2744] ""                                                                           
## [2745] "None of them could tell him any news of Woking except one man, who"         
## [2746] "assured him that Woking had been entirely destroyed on the previous"        
## [2747] "night."                                                                     
## [2748] ""                                                                           
## [2749] "\"I come from Byfleet,\" he said; \"man on a bicycle came through the"      
## [2750] "place in the early morning, and ran from door to door warning us to"        
## [2751] "come away.  Then came soldiers.  We went out to look, and there were"       
## [2752] "clouds of smoke to the south--nothing but smoke, and not a soul coming"     
## [2753] "that way.  Then we heard the guns at Chertsey, and folks coming from"       
## [2754] "Weybridge.  So I've locked up my house and come on.\""                      
## [2755] ""                                                                           
## [2756] "At the time there was a strong feeling in the streets that the"             
## [2757] "authorities were to blame for their incapacity to dispose of the"           
## [2758] "invaders without all this inconvenience."                                   
## [2759] ""                                                                           
## [2760] "About eight o'clock a noise of heavy firing was distinctly audible"         
## [2761] "all over the south of London.  My brother could not hear it for the"        
## [2762] "traffic in the main thoroughfares, but by striking through the quiet"       
## [2763] "back streets to the river he was able to distinguish it quite plainly."     
## [2764] ""                                                                           
## [2765] "He walked from Westminster to his apartments near Regent's Park,"           
## [2766] "about two.  He was now very anxious on my account, and disturbed at"        
## [2767] "the evident magnitude of the trouble.  His mind was inclined to run,"       
## [2768] "even as mine had run on Saturday, on military details.  He thought of"      
## [2769] "all those silent, expectant guns, of the suddenly nomadic countryside;"     
## [2770] "he tried to imagine \"boilers on stilts\" a hundred feet high."             
## [2771] ""                                                                           
## [2772] "There were one or two cartloads of refugees passing along Oxford"           
## [2773] "Street, and several in the Marylebone Road, but so slowly was the news"     
## [2774] "spreading that Regent Street and Portland Place were full of their"         
## [2775] "usual Sunday-night promenaders, albeit they talked in groups, and"          
## [2776] "along the edge of Regent's Park there were as many silent couples"          
## [2777] "\"walking out\" together under the scattered gas lamps as ever there had"   
## [2778] "been.  The night was warm and still, and a little oppressive; the"          
## [2779] "sound of guns continued intermittently, and after midnight there"           
## [2780] "seemed to be sheet lightning in the south."                                 
## [2781] ""                                                                           
## [2782] "He read and re-read the paper, fearing the worst had happened to me."       
## [2783] "He was restless, and after supper prowled out again aimlessly.  He"         
## [2784] "returned and tried in vain to divert his attention to his examination"      
## [2785] "notes.  He went to bed a little after midnight, and was awakened from"      
## [2786] "lurid dreams in the small hours of Monday by the sound of door"             
## [2787] "knockers, feet running in the street, distant drumming, and a clamour"      
## [2788] "of bells.  Red reflections danced on the ceiling.  For a moment he lay"     
## [2789] "astonished, wondering whether day had come or the world gone mad."          
## [2790] "Then he jumped out of bed and ran to the window."                           
## [2791] ""                                                                           
## [2792] "His room was an attic and as he thrust his head out, up and down"           
## [2793] "the street there were a dozen echoes to the noise of his window sash,"      
## [2794] "and heads in every kind of night disarray appeared.  Enquiries were"        
## [2795] "being shouted.  \"They are coming!\" bawled a policeman, hammering at"      
## [2796] "the door; \"the Martians are coming!\" and hurried to the next door."       
## [2797] ""                                                                           
## [2798] "The sound of drumming and trumpeting came from the Albany Street"           
## [2799] "Barracks, and every church within earshot was hard at work killing"         
## [2800] "sleep with a vehement disorderly tocsin.  There was a noise of doors"       
## [2801] "opening, and window after window in the houses opposite flashed from"       
## [2802] "darkness into yellow illumination."                                         
## [2803] ""                                                                           
## [2804] "Up the street came galloping a closed carriage, bursting abruptly"          
## [2805] "into noise at the corner, rising to a clattering climax under the"          
## [2806] "window, and dying away slowly in the distance.  Close on the rear of"       
## [2807] "this came a couple of cabs, the forerunners of a long procession of"        
## [2808] "flying vehicles, going for the most part to Chalk Farm station, where"      
## [2809] "the North-Western special trains were loading up, instead of coming"        
## [2810] "down the gradient into Euston."                                             
## [2811] ""                                                                           
## [2812] "For a long time my brother stared out of the window in blank"               
## [2813] "astonishment, watching the policemen hammering at door after door, and"     
## [2814] "delivering their incomprehensible message.  Then the door behind him"       
## [2815] "opened, and the man who lodged across the landing came in, dressed"         
## [2816] "only in shirt, trousers, and slippers, his braces loose about his"          
## [2817] "waist, his hair disordered from his pillow."                                
## [2818] ""                                                                           
## [2819] "\"What the devil is it?\" he asked.  \"A fire?  What a devil of a"          
## [2820] "row!\""                                                                     
## [2821] ""                                                                           
## [2822] "They both craned their heads out of the window, straining to hear"          
## [2823] "what the policemen were shouting.  People were coming out of the side"      
## [2824] "streets, and standing in groups at the corners talking."                    
## [2825] ""                                                                           
## [2826] "\"What the devil is it all about?\" said my brother's fellow lodger."       
## [2827] ""                                                                           
## [2828] "My brother answered him vaguely and began to dress, running with"           
## [2829] "each garment to the window in order to miss nothing of the growing"         
## [2830] "excitement.  And presently men selling unnaturally early newspapers"        
## [2831] "came bawling into the street:"                                              
## [2832] ""                                                                           
## [2833] "\"London in danger of suffocation!  The Kingston and Richmond"              
## [2834] "defences forced!  Fearful massacres in the Thames Valley!\""                
## [2835] ""                                                                           
## [2836] "And all about him--in the rooms below, in the houses on each side"          
## [2837] "and across the road, and behind in the Park Terraces and in the"            
## [2838] "hundred other streets of that part of Marylebone, and the Westbourne"       
## [2839] "Park district and St. Pancras, and westward and northward in Kilburn"       
## [2840] "and St. John's Wood and Hampstead, and eastward in Shoreditch and"          
## [2841] "Highbury and Haggerston and Hoxton, and, indeed, through all the"           
## [2842] "vastness of London from Ealing to East Ham--people were rubbing their"      
## [2843] "eyes, and opening windows to stare out and ask aimless questions,"          
## [2844] "dressing hastily as the first breath of the coming storm of Fear blew"      
## [2845] "through the streets.  It was the dawn of the great panic.  London,"         
## [2846] "which had gone to bed on Sunday night oblivious and inert, was"             
## [2847] "awakened, in the small hours of Monday morning, to a vivid sense of"        
## [2848] "danger."                                                                    
## [2849] ""                                                                           
## [2850] "Unable from his window to learn what was happening, my brother went"        
## [2851] "down and out into the street, just as the sky between the parapets of"      
## [2852] "the houses grew pink with the early dawn.  The flying people on foot"       
## [2853] "and in vehicles grew more numerous every moment.  \"Black Smoke!\" he"      
## [2854] "heard people crying, and again \"Black Smoke!\"  The contagion of such"     
## [2855] "a unanimous fear was inevitable.  As my brother hesitated on the"           
## [2856] "door-step, he saw another news vender approaching, and got a paper"         
## [2857] "forthwith.  The man was running away with the rest, and selling his"        
## [2858] "papers for a shilling each as he ran--a grotesque mingling of profit"       
## [2859] "and panic."                                                                 
## [2860] ""                                                                           
## [2861] "And from this paper my brother read that catastrophic dispatch of"          
## [2862] "the Commander-in-Chief:"                                                    
## [2863] ""                                                                           
## [2864] "\"The Martians are able to discharge enormous clouds of a black and"        
## [2865] "poisonous vapour by means of rockets.  They have smothered our"             
## [2866] "batteries, destroyed Richmond, Kingston, and Wimbledon, and are"            
## [2867] "advancing slowly towards London, destroying everything on the way.  It"     
## [2868] "is impossible to stop them.  There is no safety from the Black Smoke"       
## [2869] "but in instant flight.\""                                                   
## [2870] ""                                                                           
## [2871] "That was all, but it was enough.  The whole population of the great"        
## [2872] "six-million city was stirring, slipping, running; presently it would"       
## [2873] "be pouring _en masse_ northward."                                           
## [2874] ""                                                                           
## [2875] "\"Black Smoke!\" the voices cried.  \"Fire!\""                              
## [2876] ""                                                                           
## [2877] "The bells of the neighbouring church made a jangling tumult, a cart"        
## [2878] "carelessly driven smashed, amid shrieks and curses, against the water"      
## [2879] "trough up the street.  Sickly yellow lights went to and fro in the"         
## [2880] "houses, and some of the passing cabs flaunted unextinguished lamps."        
## [2881] "And overhead the dawn was growing brighter, clear and steady and calm."     
## [2882] ""                                                                           
## [2883] "He heard footsteps running to and fro in the rooms, and up and down"        
## [2884] "stairs behind him.  His landlady came to the door, loosely wrapped in"      
## [2885] "dressing gown and shawl; her husband followed ejaculating."                 
## [2886] ""                                                                           
## [2887] "As my brother began to realise the import of all these things, he"          
## [2888] "turned hastily to his own room, put all his available money--some ten"      
## [2889] "pounds altogether--into his pockets, and went out again into the"           
## [2890] "streets."                                                                   
## [2891] ""                                                                           
## [2892] ""                                                                           
## [2893] ""                                                                           
## [2894] "CHAPTER FIFTEEN"                                                            
## [2895] ""                                                                           
## [2896] "WHAT HAD HAPPENED IN SURREY"                                                
## [2897] ""                                                                           
## [2898] ""                                                                           
## [2899] "It was while the curate had sat and talked so wildly to me under"           
## [2900] "the hedge in the flat meadows near Halliford, and while my brother was"     
## [2901] "watching the fugitives stream over Westminster Bridge, that the"            
## [2902] "Martians had resumed the offensive.  So far as one can ascertain from"      
## [2903] "the conflicting accounts that have been put forth, the majority of"         
## [2904] "them remained busied with preparations in the Horsell pit until nine"       
## [2905] "that night, hurrying on some operation that disengaged huge volumes of"     
## [2906] "green smoke."                                                               
## [2907] ""                                                                           
## [2908] "But three certainly came out about eight o'clock and, advancing"            
## [2909] "slowly and cautiously, made their way through Byfleet and Pyrford"          
## [2910] "towards Ripley and Weybridge, and so came in sight of the expectant"        
## [2911] "batteries against the setting sun.  These Martians did not advance in"      
## [2912] "a body, but in a line, each perhaps a mile and a half from his nearest"     
## [2913] "fellow.  They communicated with one another by means of sirenlike"          
## [2914] "howls, running up and down the scale from one note to another."             
## [2915] ""                                                                           
## [2916] "It was this howling and firing of the guns at Ripley and St."               
## [2917] "George's Hill that we had heard at Upper Halliford.  The Ripley"            
## [2918] "gunners, unseasoned artillery volunteers who ought never to have been"      
## [2919] "placed in such a position, fired one wild, premature, ineffectual"          
## [2920] "volley, and bolted on horse and foot through the deserted village,"         
## [2921] "while the Martian, without using his Heat-Ray, walked serenely over"        
## [2922] "their guns, stepped gingerly among them, passed in front of them, and"      
## [2923] "so came unexpectedly upon the guns in Painshill Park, which he"             
## [2924] "destroyed."                                                                 
## [2925] ""                                                                           
## [2926] "The St. George's Hill men, however, were better led or of a better"         
## [2927] "mettle.  Hidden by a pine wood as they were, they seem to have been"        
## [2928] "quite unsuspected by the Martian nearest to them.  They laid their"         
## [2929] "guns as deliberately as if they had been on parade, and fired at about"     
## [2930] "a thousand yards' range."                                                   
## [2931] ""                                                                           
## [2932] "The shells flashed all round him, and he was seen to advance a few"         
## [2933] "paces, stagger, and go down.  Everybody yelled together, and the guns"      
## [2934] "were reloaded in frantic haste.  The overthrown Martian set up a"           
## [2935] "prolonged ululation, and immediately a second glittering giant,"            
## [2936] "answering him, appeared over the trees to the south.  It would seem"        
## [2937] "that a leg of the tripod had been smashed by one of the shells.  The"       
## [2938] "whole of the second volley flew wide of the Martian on the ground,"         
## [2939] "and, simultaneously, both his companions brought their Heat-Rays to"        
## [2940] "bear on the battery.  The ammunition blew up, the pine trees all about"     
## [2941] "the guns flashed into fire, and only one or two of the men who were"        
## [2942] "already running over the crest of the hill escaped."                        
## [2943] ""                                                                           
## [2944] "After this it would seem that the three took counsel together and"          
## [2945] "halted, and the scouts who were watching them report that they"             
## [2946] "remained absolutely stationary for the next half hour.  The Martian"        
## [2947] "who had been overthrown crawled tediously out of his hood, a small"         
## [2948] "brown figure, oddly suggestive from that distance of a speck of"            
## [2949] "blight, and apparently engaged in the repair of his support.  About"        
## [2950] "nine he had finished, for his cowl was then seen above the trees"           
## [2951] "again."                                                                     
## [2952] ""                                                                           
## [2953] "It was a few minutes past nine that night when these three"                 
## [2954] "sentinels were joined by four other Martians, each carrying a thick"        
## [2955] "black tube.  A similar tube was handed to each of the three, and the"       
## [2956] "seven proceeded to distribute themselves at equal distances along a"        
## [2957] "curved line between St. George's Hill, Weybridge, and the village of"       
## [2958] "Send, southwest of Ripley."                                                 
## [2959] ""                                                                           
## [2960] "A dozen rockets sprang out of the hills before them so soon as they"        
## [2961] "began to move, and warned the waiting batteries about Ditton and"           
## [2962] "Esher.  At the same time four of their fighting machines, similarly"        
## [2963] "armed with tubes, crossed the river, and two of them, black against"        
## [2964] "the western sky, came into sight of myself and the curate as we"            
## [2965] "hurried wearily and painfully along the road that runs northward out"       
## [2966] "of Halliford.  They moved, as it seemed to us, upon a cloud, for a"         
## [2967] "milky mist covered the fields and rose to a third of their height."         
## [2968] ""                                                                           
## [2969] "At this sight the curate cried faintly in his throat, and began"            
## [2970] "running; but I knew it was no good running from a Martian, and I"           
## [2971] "turned aside and crawled through dewy nettles and brambles into the"        
## [2972] "broad ditch by the side of the road.  He looked back, saw what I was"       
## [2973] "doing, and turned to join me."                                              
## [2974] ""                                                                           
## [2975] "The two halted, the nearer to us standing and facing Sunbury, the"          
## [2976] "remoter being a grey indistinctness towards the evening star, away"         
## [2977] "towards Staines."                                                           
## [2978] ""                                                                           
## [2979] "The occasional howling of the Martians had ceased; they took up"            
## [2980] "their positions in the huge crescent about their cylinders in absolute"     
## [2981] "silence.  It was a crescent with twelve miles between its horns.  Never"    
## [2982] "since the devising of gunpowder was the beginning of a battle so"           
## [2983] "still.  To us and to an observer about Ripley it would have had"            
## [2984] "precisely the same effect--the Martians seemed in solitary possession"      
## [2985] "of the darkling night, lit only as it was by the slender moon, the"         
## [2986] "stars, the afterglow of the daylight, and the ruddy glare from St."         
## [2987] "George's Hill and the woods of Painshill."                                  
## [2988] ""                                                                           
## [2989] "But facing that crescent everywhere--at Staines, Hounslow, Ditton,"         
## [2990] "Esher, Ockham, behind hills and woods south of the river, and across"       
## [2991] "the flat grass meadows to the north of it, wherever a cluster of trees"     
## [2992] "or village houses gave sufficient cover--the guns were waiting.  The"       
## [2993] "signal rockets burst and rained their sparks through the night and"         
## [2994] "vanished, and the spirit of all those watching batteries rose to a"         
## [2995] "tense expectation.  The Martians had but to advance into the line of"       
## [2996] "fire, and instantly those motionless black forms of men, those guns"        
## [2997] "glittering so darkly in the early night, would explode into a"              
## [2998] "thunderous fury of battle."                                                 
## [2999] ""                                                                           
## [3000] "No doubt the thought that was uppermost in a thousand of those"             
## [3001] "vigilant minds, even as it was uppermost in mine, was the riddle--how"      
## [3002] "much they understood of us.  Did they grasp that we in our millions"        
## [3003] "were organized, disciplined, working together?  Or did they interpret"      
## [3004] "our spurts of fire, the sudden stinging of our shells, our steady"          
## [3005] "investment of their encampment, as we should the furious unanimity of"      
## [3006] "onslaught in a disturbed hive of bees?  Did they dream they might"          
## [3007] "exterminate us?  (At that time no one knew what food they needed.)  A"      
## [3008] "hundred such questions struggled together in my mind as I watched that"     
## [3009] "vast sentinel shape.  And in the back of my mind was the sense of all"      
## [3010] "the huge unknown and hidden forces Londonward.  Had they prepared"          
## [3011] "pitfalls? Were the powder mills at Hounslow ready as a snare?  Would"       
## [3012] "the Londoners have the heart and courage to make a greater Moscow of"       
## [3013] "their mighty province of houses?"                                           
## [3014] ""                                                                           
## [3015] "Then, after an interminable time, as it seemed to us, crouching and"        
## [3016] "peering through the hedge, came a sound like the distant concussion of"     
## [3017] "a gun.  Another nearer, and then another.  And then the Martian beside"     
## [3018] "us raised his tube on high and discharged it, gunwise, with a heavy"        
## [3019] "report that made the ground heave.  The one towards Staines answered"       
## [3020] "him.  There was no flash, no smoke, simply that loaded detonation."         
## [3021] ""                                                                           
## [3022] "I was so excited by these heavy minute-guns following one another"          
## [3023] "that I so far forgot my personal safety and my scalded hands as to"         
## [3024] "clamber up into the hedge and stare towards Sunbury.  As I did so a"        
## [3025] "second report followed, and a big projectile hurtled overhead towards"      
## [3026] "Hounslow.  I expected at least to see smoke or fire, or some such"          
## [3027] "evidence of its work.  But all I saw was the deep blue sky above, with"     
## [3028] "one solitary star, and the white mist spreading wide and low beneath."      
## [3029] "And there had been no crash, no answering explosion.  The silence was"      
## [3030] "restored; the minute lengthened to three."                                  
## [3031] ""                                                                           
## [3032] "\"What has happened?\" said the curate, standing up beside me."             
## [3033] ""                                                                           
## [3034] "\"Heaven knows!\" said I."                                                  
## [3035] ""                                                                           
## [3036] "A bat flickered by and vanished.  A distant tumult of shouting"             
## [3037] "began and ceased.  I looked again at the Martian, and saw he was now"       
## [3038] "moving eastward along the riverbank, with a swift, rolling motion."         
## [3039] ""                                                                           
## [3040] "Every moment I expected the fire of some hidden battery to spring"          
## [3041] "upon him; but the evening calm was unbroken.  The figure of the Martian"    
## [3042] "grew smaller as he receded, and presently the mist and the gathering"       
## [3043] "night had swallowed him up.  By a common impulse we clambered higher."      
## [3044] "Towards Sunbury was a dark appearance, as though a conical hill had"        
## [3045] "suddenly come into being there, hiding our view of the farther"             
## [3046] "country; and then, remoter across the river, over Walton, we saw"           
## [3047] "another such summit.  These hill-like forms grew lower and broader"         
## [3048] "even as we stared."                                                         
## [3049] ""                                                                           
## [3050] "Moved by a sudden thought, I looked northward, and there I"                 
## [3051] "perceived a third of these cloudy black kopjes had risen."                  
## [3052] ""                                                                           
## [3053] "Everything had suddenly become very still.  Far away to the"                
## [3054] "southeast, marking the quiet, we heard the Martians hooting to one"         
## [3055] "another, and then the air quivered again with the distant thud of"          
## [3056] "their guns.  But the earthly artillery made no reply."                      
## [3057] ""                                                                           
## [3058] "Now at the time we could not understand these things, but later I"          
## [3059] "was to learn the meaning of these ominous kopjes that gathered in the"      
## [3060] "twilight.  Each of the Martians, standing in the great crescent I have"     
## [3061] "described, had discharged, by means of the gunlike tube he carried, a"      
## [3062] "huge canister over whatever hill, copse, cluster of houses, or other"       
## [3063] "possible cover for guns, chanced to be in front of him.  Some fired"        
## [3064] "only one of these, some two--as in the case of the one we had seen;"        
## [3065] "the one at Ripley is said to have discharged no fewer than five at"         
## [3066] "that time.  These canisters smashed on striking the ground--they did"       
## [3067] "not explode--and incontinently disengaged an enormous volume of heavy,"     
## [3068] "inky vapour, coiling and pouring upward in a huge and ebony cumulus"        
## [3069] "cloud, a gaseous hill that sank and spread itself slowly over the"          
## [3070] "surrounding country.  And the touch of that vapour, the inhaling of"        
## [3071] "its pungent wisps, was death to all that breathes."                         
## [3072] ""                                                                           
## [3073] "It was heavy, this vapour, heavier than the densest smoke, so that,"        
## [3074] "after the first tumultuous uprush and outflow of its impact, it sank"       
## [3075] "down through the air and poured over the ground in a manner rather"         
## [3076] "liquid than gaseous, abandoning the hills, and streaming into the"          
## [3077] "valleys and ditches and watercourses even as I have heard the"              
## [3078] "carbonic-acid gas that pours from volcanic clefts is wont to do.  And"      
## [3079] "where it came upon water some chemical action occurred, and the"            
## [3080] "surface would be instantly covered with a powdery scum that sank"           
## [3081] "slowly and made way for more.  The scum was absolutely insoluble, and"      
## [3082] "it is a strange thing, seeing the instant effect of the gas, that one"      
## [3083] "could drink without hurt the water from which it had been strained."        
## [3084] "The vapour did not diffuse as a true gas would do.  It hung together"       
## [3085] "in banks, flowing sluggishly down the slope of the land and driving"        
## [3086] "reluctantly before the wind, and very slowly it combined with the mist"     
## [3087] "and moisture of the air, and sank to the earth in the form of dust."        
## [3088] "Save that an unknown element giving a group of four lines in the blue"      
## [3089] "of the spectrum is concerned, we are still entirely ignorant of the"        
## [3090] "nature of this substance."                                                  
## [3091] ""                                                                           
## [3092] "Once the tumultuous upheaval of its dispersion was over, the black"         
## [3093] "smoke clung so closely to the ground, even before its precipitation,"       
## [3094] "that fifty feet up in the air, on the roofs and upper stories of high"      
## [3095] "houses and on great trees, there was a chance of escaping its poison"       
## [3096] "altogether, as was proved even that night at Street Cobham and Ditton."     
## [3097] ""                                                                           
## [3098] "The man who escaped at the former place tells a wonderful story of"         
## [3099] "the strangeness of its coiling flow, and how he looked down from the"       
## [3100] "church spire and saw the houses of the village rising like ghosts out"      
## [3101] "of its inky nothingness.  For a day and a half he remained there,"          
## [3102] "weary, starving and sun-scorched, the earth under the blue sky and"         
## [3103] "against the prospect of the distant hills a velvet-black expanse, with"     
## [3104] "red roofs, green trees, and, later, black-veiled shrubs and gates,"         
## [3105] "barns, outhouses, and walls, rising here and there into the sunlight."      
## [3106] ""                                                                           
## [3107] "But that was at Street Cobham, where the black vapour was allowed"          
## [3108] "to remain until it sank of its own accord into the ground.  As a rule"      
## [3109] "the Martians, when it had served its purpose, cleared the air of it"        
## [3110] "again by wading into it and directing a jet of steam upon it."              
## [3111] ""                                                                           
## [3112] "This they did with the vapour banks near us, as we saw in the"              
## [3113] "starlight from the window of a deserted house at Upper Halliford,"          
## [3114] "whither we had returned.  From there we could see the searchlights on"      
## [3115] "Richmond Hill and Kingston Hill going to and fro, and about eleven the"     
## [3116] "windows rattled, and we heard the sound of the huge siege guns that"        
## [3117] "had been put in position there.  These continued intermittently for"        
## [3118] "the space of a quarter of an hour, sending chance shots at the"             
## [3119] "invisible Martians at Hampton and Ditton, and then the pale beams of"       
## [3120] "the electric light vanished, and were replaced by a bright red glow."       
## [3121] ""                                                                           
## [3122] "Then the fourth cylinder fell--a brilliant green meteor--as I"              
## [3123] "learned afterwards, in Bushey Park.  Before the guns on the Richmond"       
## [3124] "and Kingston line of hills began, there was a fitful cannonade far"         
## [3125] "away in the southwest, due, I believe, to guns being fired haphazard"       
## [3126] "before the black vapour could overwhelm the gunners."                       
## [3127] ""                                                                           
## [3128] "So, setting about it as methodically as men might smoke out a"              
## [3129] "wasps' nest, the Martians spread this strange stifling vapour over the"     
## [3130] "Londonward country.  The horns of the crescent slowly moved apart,"         
## [3131] "until at last they formed a line from Hanwell to Coombe and Malden."        
## [3132] "All night through their destructive tubes advanced.  Never once, after"     
## [3133] "the Martian at St. George's Hill was brought down, did they give the"       
## [3134] "artillery the ghost of a chance against them.  Wherever there was a"        
## [3135] "possibility of guns being laid for them unseen, a fresh canister of"        
## [3136] "the black vapour was discharged, and where the guns were openly"            
## [3137] "displayed the Heat-Ray was brought to bear."                                
## [3138] ""                                                                           
## [3139] "By midnight the blazing trees along the slopes of Richmond Park and"        
## [3140] "the glare of Kingston Hill threw their light upon a network of black"       
## [3141] "smoke, blotting out the whole valley of the Thames and extending as"        
## [3142] "far as the eye could reach.  And through this two Martians slowly"          
## [3143] "waded, and turned their hissing steam jets this way and that."              
## [3144] ""                                                                           
## [3145] "They were sparing of the Heat-Ray that night, either because they"          
## [3146] "had but a limited supply of material for its production or because"         
## [3147] "they did not wish to destroy the country but only to crush and overawe"     
## [3148] "the opposition they had aroused.  In the latter aim they certainly"         
## [3149] "succeeded.  Sunday night was the end of the organised opposition to"        
## [3150] "their movements.  After that no body of men would stand against them,"      
## [3151] "so hopeless was the enterprise.  Even the crews of the torpedo-boats"       
## [3152] "and destroyers that had brought their quick-firers up the Thames"           
## [3153] "refused to stop, mutinied, and went down again.  The only offensive"        
## [3154] "operation men ventured upon after that night was the preparation of"        
## [3155] "mines and pitfalls, and even in that their energies were frantic and"       
## [3156] "spasmodic."                                                                 
## [3157] ""                                                                           
## [3158] "One has to imagine, as well as one may, the fate of those batteries"        
## [3159] "towards Esher, waiting so tensely in the twilight.  Survivors there"        
## [3160] "were none.  One may picture the orderly expectation, the officers"          
## [3161] "alert and watchful, the gunners ready, the ammunition piled to hand,"       
## [3162] "the limber gunners with their horses and waggons, the groups of"            
## [3163] "civilian spectators standing as near as they were permitted, the"           
## [3164] "evening stillness, the ambulances and hospital tents with the burned"       
## [3165] "and wounded from Weybridge; then the dull resonance of the shots the"       
## [3166] "Martians fired, and the clumsy projectile whirling over the trees and"      
## [3167] "houses and smashing amid the neighbouring fields."                          
## [3168] ""                                                                           
## [3169] "One may picture, too, the sudden shifting of the attention, the"            
## [3170] "swiftly spreading coils and bellyings of that blackness advancing"          
## [3171] "headlong, towering heavenward, turning the twilight to a palpable"          
## [3172] "darkness, a strange and horrible antagonist of vapour striding upon"        
## [3173] "its victims, men and horses near it seen dimly, running, shrieking,"        
## [3174] "falling headlong, shouts of dismay, the guns suddenly abandoned, men"       
## [3175] "choking and writhing on the ground, and the swift broadening-out of"        
## [3176] "the opaque cone of smoke.  And then night and extinction--nothing but"      
## [3177] "a silent mass of impenetrable vapour hiding its dead."                      
## [3178] ""                                                                           
## [3179] "Before dawn the black vapour was pouring through the streets of"            
## [3180] "Richmond, and the disintegrating organism of government was, with a"        
## [3181] "last expiring effort, rousing the population of London to the"              
## [3182] "necessity of flight."                                                       
## [3183] ""                                                                           
## [3184] ""                                                                           
## [3185] ""                                                                           
## [3186] "CHAPTER SIXTEEN"                                                            
## [3187] ""                                                                           
## [3188] "THE EXODUS FROM LONDON"                                                     
## [3189] ""                                                                           
## [3190] ""                                                                           
## [3191] "So you understand the roaring wave of fear that swept through the"          
## [3192] "greatest city in the world just as Monday was dawning--the stream of"       
## [3193] "flight rising swiftly to a torrent, lashing in a foaming tumult round"      
## [3194] "the railway stations, banked up into a horrible struggle about the"         
## [3195] "shipping in the Thames, and hurrying by every available channel"            
## [3196] "northward and eastward.  By ten o'clock the police organisation, and"       
## [3197] "by midday even the railway organisations, were losing coherency,"           
## [3198] "losing shape and efficiency, guttering, softening, running at last in"      
## [3199] "that swift liquefaction of the social body."                                
## [3200] ""                                                                           
## [3201] "All the railway lines north of the Thames and the South-Eastern"            
## [3202] "people at Cannon Street had been warned by midnight on Sunday, and"         
## [3203] "trains were being filled.  People were fighting savagely for"               
## [3204] "standing-room in the carriages even at two o'clock.  By three, people"      
## [3205] "were being trampled and crushed even in Bishopsgate Street, a couple"       
## [3206] "of hundred yards or more from Liverpool Street station; revolvers were"     
## [3207] "fired, people stabbed, and the policemen who had been sent to direct"       
## [3208] "the traffic, exhausted and infuriated, were breaking the heads of the"      
## [3209] "people they were called out to protect."                                    
## [3210] ""                                                                           
## [3211] "And as the day advanced and the engine drivers and stokers refused"         
## [3212] "to return to London, the pressure of the flight drove the people in an"     
## [3213] "ever-thickening multitude away from the stations and along the"             
## [3214] "northward-running roads.  By midday a Martian had been seen at Barnes,"     
## [3215] "and a cloud of slowly sinking black vapour drove along the Thames and"      
## [3216] "across the flats of Lambeth, cutting off all escape over the bridges"       
## [3217] "in its sluggish advance.  Another bank drove over Ealing, and"              
## [3218] "surrounded a little island of survivors on Castle Hill, alive, but"         
## [3219] "unable to escape."                                                          
## [3220] ""                                                                           
## [3221] "After a fruitless struggle to get aboard a North-Western train at"          
## [3222] "Chalk Farm--the engines of the trains that had loaded in the goods"         
## [3223] "yard there _ploughed_ through shrieking people, and a dozen stalwart men"   
## [3224] "fought to keep the crowd from crushing the driver against his"              
## [3225] "furnace--my brother emerged upon the Chalk Farm road, dodged across"        
## [3226] "through a hurrying swarm of vehicles, and had the luck to be foremost"      
## [3227] "in the sack of a cycle shop.  The front tire of the machine he got was"     
## [3228] "punctured in dragging it through the window, but he got up and off,"        
## [3229] "notwithstanding, with no further injury than a cut wrist.  The steep"       
## [3230] "foot of Haverstock Hill was impassable owing to several overturned"         
## [3231] "horses, and my brother struck into Belsize Road."                           
## [3232] ""                                                                           
## [3233] "So he got out of the fury of the panic, and, skirting the Edgware"          
## [3234] "Road, reached Edgware about seven, fasting and wearied, but well ahead"     
## [3235] "of the crowd.  Along the road people were standing in the roadway,"         
## [3236] "curious, wondering.  He was passed by a number of cyclists, some"           
## [3237] "horsemen, and two motor cars.  A mile from Edgware the rim of the"          
## [3238] "wheel broke, and the machine became unridable.  He left it by the"          
## [3239] "roadside and trudged through the village.  There were shops half"           
## [3240] "opened in the main street of the place, and people crowded on the"          
## [3241] "pavement and in the doorways and windows, staring astonished at this"       
## [3242] "extraordinary procession of fugitives that was beginning.  He"              
## [3243] "succeeded in getting some food at an inn."                                  
## [3244] ""                                                                           
## [3245] "For a time he remained in Edgware not knowing what next to do.  The"        
## [3246] "flying people increased in number.  Many of them, like my brother,"         
## [3247] "seemed inclined to loiter in the place.  There was no fresh news of"        
## [3248] "the invaders from Mars."                                                    
## [3249] ""                                                                           
## [3250] "At that time the road was crowded, but as yet far from congested."          
## [3251] "Most of the fugitives at that hour were mounted on cycles, but there"       
## [3252] "were soon motor cars, hansom cabs, and carriages hurrying along, and"       
## [3253] "the dust hung in heavy clouds along the road to St. Albans."                
## [3254] ""                                                                           
## [3255] "It was perhaps a vague idea of making his way to Chelmsford, where"         
## [3256] "some friends of his lived, that at last induced my brother to strike"       
## [3257] "into a quiet lane running eastward.  Presently he came upon a stile,"       
## [3258] "and, crossing it, followed a footpath northeastward.  He passed near"       
## [3259] "several farmhouses and some little places whose names he did not"           
## [3260] "learn.  He saw few fugitives until, in a grass lane towards High"           
## [3261] "Barnet, he happened upon two ladies who became his fellow travellers."      
## [3262] "He came upon them just in time to save them."                               
## [3263] ""                                                                           
## [3264] "He heard their screams, and, hurrying round the corner, saw a"              
## [3265] "couple of men struggling to drag them out of the little pony-chaise in"     
## [3266] "which they had been driving, while a third with difficulty held the"        
## [3267] "frightened pony's head.  One of the ladies, a short woman dressed in"       
## [3268] "white, was simply screaming; the other, a dark, slender figure,"            
## [3269] "slashed at the man who gripped her arm with a whip she held in her"         
## [3270] "disengaged hand."                                                           
## [3271] ""                                                                           
## [3272] "My brother immediately grasped the situation, shouted, and hurried"         
## [3273] "towards the struggle.  One of the men desisted and turned towards him,"     
## [3274] "and my brother, realising from his antagonist's face that a fight was"      
## [3275] "unavoidable, and being an expert boxer, went into him forthwith and"        
## [3276] "sent him down against the wheel of the chaise."                             
## [3277] ""                                                                           
## [3278] "It was no time for pugilistic chivalry and my brother laid him"             
## [3279] "quiet with a kick, and gripped the collar of the man who pulled at the"     
## [3280] "slender lady's arm.  He heard the clatter of hoofs, the whip stung"         
## [3281] "across his face, a third antagonist struck him between the eyes, and"       
## [3282] "the man he held wrenched himself free and made off down the lane in"        
## [3283] "the direction from which he had come."                                      
## [3284] ""                                                                           
## [3285] "Partly stunned, he found himself facing the man who had held the"           
## [3286] "horse's head, and became aware of the chaise receding from him down"        
## [3287] "the lane, swaying from side to side, and with the women in it looking"      
## [3288] "back.  The man before him, a burly rough, tried to close, and he"           
## [3289] "stopped him with a blow in the face.  Then, realising that he was"          
## [3290] "deserted, he dodged round and made off down the lane after the chaise,"     
## [3291] "with the sturdy man close behind him, and the fugitive, who had turned"     
## [3292] "now, following remotely."                                                   
## [3293] ""                                                                           
## [3294] "Suddenly he stumbled and fell; his immediate pursuer went headlong,"        
## [3295] "and he rose to his feet to find himself with a couple of antagonists"       
## [3296] "again.  He would have had little chance against them had not the"           
## [3297] "slender lady very pluckily pulled up and returned to his help.  It"         
## [3298] "seems she had had a revolver all this time, but it had been under the"      
## [3299] "seat when she and her companion were attacked.  She fired at six"           
## [3300] "yards' distance, narrowly missing my brother.  The less courageous of"      
## [3301] "the robbers made off, and his companion followed him, cursing his"          
## [3302] "cowardice.  They both stopped in sight down the lane, where the third"      
## [3303] "man lay insensible."                                                        
## [3304] ""                                                                           
## [3305] "\"Take this!\" said the slender lady, and she gave my brother her"          
## [3306] "revolver."                                                                  
## [3307] ""                                                                           
## [3308] "\"Go back to the chaise,\" said my brother, wiping the blood from his"      
## [3309] "split lip."                                                                 
## [3310] ""                                                                           
## [3311] "She turned without a word--they were both panting--and they went"           
## [3312] "back to where the lady in white struggled to hold back the frightened"      
## [3313] "pony."                                                                      
## [3314] ""                                                                           
## [3315] "The robbers had evidently had enough of it.  When my brother looked"        
## [3316] "again they were retreating."                                                
## [3317] ""                                                                           
## [3318] "\"I'll sit here,\" said my brother, \"if I may\"; and he got upon the"      
## [3319] "empty front seat.  The lady looked over her shoulder."                      
## [3320] ""                                                                           
## [3321] "\"Give me the reins,\" she said, and laid the whip along the pony's"        
## [3322] "side.  In another moment a bend in the road hid the three men from my"      
## [3323] "brother's eyes."                                                            
## [3324] ""                                                                           
## [3325] "So, quite unexpectedly, my brother found himself, panting, with a"          
## [3326] "cut mouth, a bruised jaw, and bloodstained knuckles, driving along an"      
## [3327] "unknown lane with these two women."                                         
## [3328] ""                                                                           
## [3329] "He learned they were the wife and the younger sister of a surgeon"          
## [3330] "living at Stanmore, who had come in the small hours from a dangerous"       
## [3331] "case at Pinner, and heard at some railway station on his way of the"        
## [3332] "Martian advance.  He had hurried home, roused the women--their servant"     
## [3333] "had left them two days before--packed some provisions, put his"             
## [3334] "revolver under the seat--luckily for my brother--and told them to"          
## [3335] "drive on to Edgware, with the idea of getting a train there.  He"           
## [3336] "stopped behind to tell the neighbours.  He would overtake them, he"         
## [3337] "said, at about half past four in the morning, and now it was nearly"        
## [3338] "nine and they had seen nothing of him.  They could not stop in Edgware"     
## [3339] "because of the growing traffic through the place, and so they had come"     
## [3340] "into this side lane."                                                       
## [3341] ""                                                                           
## [3342] "That was the story they told my brother in fragments when presently"        
## [3343] "they stopped again, nearer to New Barnet.  He promised to stay with"        
## [3344] "them, at least until they could determine what to do, or until the"         
## [3345] "missing man arrived, and professed to be an expert shot with the"           
## [3346] "revolver--a weapon strange to him--in order to give them confidence."       
## [3347] ""                                                                           
## [3348] "They made a sort of encampment by the wayside, and the pony became"         
## [3349] "happy in the hedge.  He told them of his own escape out of London, and"     
## [3350] "all that he knew of these Martians and their ways.  The sun crept"          
## [3351] "higher in the sky, and after a time their talk died out and gave place"     
## [3352] "to an uneasy state of anticipation.  Several wayfarers came along the"      
## [3353] "lane, and of these my brother gathered such news as he could.  Every"       
## [3354] "broken answer he had deepened his impression of the great disaster"         
## [3355] "that had come on humanity, deepened his persuasion of the immediate"        
## [3356] "necessity for prosecuting this flight.  He urged the matter upon them."     
## [3357] ""                                                                           
## [3358] "\"We have money,\" said the slender woman, and hesitated."                  
## [3359] ""                                                                           
## [3360] "Her eyes met my brother's, and her hesitation ended."                       
## [3361] ""                                                                           
## [3362] "\"So have I,\" said my brother."                                            
## [3363] ""                                                                           
## [3364] "She explained that they had as much as thirty pounds in gold,"              
## [3365] "besides a five-pound note, and suggested that with that they might get"     
## [3366] "upon a train at St. Albans or New Barnet.  My brother thought that was"     
## [3367] "hopeless, seeing the fury of the Londoners to crowd upon the trains,"       
## [3368] "and broached his own idea of striking across Essex towards Harwich and"     
## [3369] "thence escaping from the country altogether."                               
## [3370] ""                                                                           
## [3371] "Mrs. Elphinstone--that was the name of the woman in white--would"           
## [3372] "listen to no reasoning, and kept calling upon \"George\"; but her"          
## [3373] "sister-in-law was astonishingly quiet and deliberate, and at last"          
## [3374] "agreed to my brother's suggestion.  So, designing to cross the Great"       
## [3375] "North Road, they went on towards Barnet, my brother leading the pony"       
## [3376] "to save it as much as possible.  As the sun crept up the sky the day"       
## [3377] "became excessively hot, and under foot a thick, whitish sand grew"          
## [3378] "burning and blinding, so that they travelled only very slowly.  The"        
## [3379] "hedges were grey with dust.  And as they advanced towards Barnet a"         
## [3380] "tumultuous murmuring grew stronger."                                        
## [3381] ""                                                                           
## [3382] "They began to meet more people.  For the most part these were"              
## [3383] "staring before them, murmuring indistinct questions, jaded, haggard,"       
## [3384] "unclean.  One man in evening dress passed them on foot, his eyes on"        
## [3385] "the ground.  They heard his voice, and, looking back at him, saw one"       
## [3386] "hand clutched in his hair and the other beating invisible things.  His"     
## [3387] "paroxysm of rage over, he went on his way without once looking back."       
## [3388] ""                                                                           
## [3389] "As my brother's party went on towards the crossroads to the south"          
## [3390] "of Barnet they saw a woman approaching the road across some fields on"      
## [3391] "their left, carrying a child and with two other children; and then"         
## [3392] "passed a man in dirty black, with a thick stick in one hand and a"          
## [3393] "small portmanteau in the other.  Then round the corner of the lane,"        
## [3394] "from between the villas that guarded it at its confluence with the"         
## [3395] "high road, came a little cart drawn by a sweating black pony and"           
## [3396] "driven by a sallow youth in a bowler hat, grey with dust.  There were"      
## [3397] "three girls, East End factory girls, and a couple of little children"       
## [3398] "crowded in the cart."                                                       
## [3399] ""                                                                           
## [3400] "\"This'll tike us rahnd Edgware?\" asked the driver, wild-eyed,"            
## [3401] "white-faced; and when my brother told him it would if he turned to the"     
## [3402] "left, he whipped up at once without the formality of thanks."               
## [3403] ""                                                                           
## [3404] "My brother noticed a pale grey smoke or haze rising among the"              
## [3405] "houses in front of them, and veiling the white facade of a terrace"         
## [3406] "beyond the road that appeared between the backs of the villas.  Mrs."       
## [3407] "Elphinstone suddenly cried out at a number of tongues of smoky red"         
## [3408] "flame leaping up above the houses in front of them against the hot,"        
## [3409] "blue sky.  The tumultuous noise resolved itself now into the"               
## [3410] "disorderly mingling of many voices, the gride of many wheels, the"          
## [3411] "creaking of waggons, and the staccato of hoofs.  The lane came round"       
## [3412] "sharply not fifty yards from the crossroads."                               
## [3413] ""                                                                           
## [3414] "\"Good heavens!\" cried Mrs. Elphinstone.  \"What is this you are"          
## [3415] "driving us into?\""                                                         
## [3416] ""                                                                           
## [3417] "My brother stopped."                                                        
## [3418] ""                                                                           
## [3419] "For the main road was a boiling stream of people, a torrent of"             
## [3420] "human beings rushing northward, one pressing on another.  A great bank"     
## [3421] "of dust, white and luminous in the blaze of the sun, made everything"       
## [3422] "within twenty feet of the ground grey and indistinct and was"               
## [3423] "perpetually renewed by the hurrying feet of a dense crowd of horses"        
## [3424] "and of men and women on foot, and by the wheels of vehicles of every"       
## [3425] "description."                                                               
## [3426] ""                                                                           
## [3427] "\"Way!\" my brother heard voices crying.  \"Make way!\""                    
## [3428] ""                                                                           
## [3429] "It was like riding into the smoke of a fire to approach the meeting"        
## [3430] "point of the lane and road; the crowd roared like a fire, and the dust"     
## [3431] "was hot and pungent.  And, indeed, a little way up the road a villa"        
## [3432] "was burning and sending rolling masses of black smoke across the road"      
## [3433] "to add to the confusion."                                                   
## [3434] ""                                                                           
## [3435] "Two men came past them.  Then a dirty woman, carrying a heavy"              
## [3436] "bundle and weeping.  A lost retriever dog, with hanging tongue,"            
## [3437] "circled dubiously round them, scared and wretched, and fled at my"          
## [3438] "brother's threat."                                                          
## [3439] ""                                                                           
## [3440] "So much as they could see of the road Londonward between the houses"        
## [3441] "to the right was a tumultuous stream of dirty, hurrying people, pent"       
## [3442] "in between the villas on either side; the black heads, the crowded"         
## [3443] "forms, grew into distinctness as they rushed towards the corner,"           
## [3444] "hurried past, and merged their individuality again in a receding"           
## [3445] "multitude that was swallowed up at last in a cloud of dust."                
## [3446] ""                                                                           
## [3447] "\"Go on!  Go on!\" cried the voices.  \"Way!  Way!\""                       
## [3448] ""                                                                           
## [3449] "One man's hands pressed on the back of another.  My brother stood"          
## [3450] "at the pony's head.  Irresistibly attracted, he advanced slowly, pace"      
## [3451] "by pace, down the lane."                                                    
## [3452] ""                                                                           
## [3453] "Edgware had been a scene of confusion, Chalk Farm a riotous tumult,"        
## [3454] "but this was a whole population in movement.  It is hard to imagine"        
## [3455] "that host.  It had no character of its own.  The figures poured out"        
## [3456] "past the corner, and receded with their backs to the group in the"          
## [3457] "lane.  Along the margin came those who were on foot threatened by the"      
## [3458] "wheels, stumbling in the ditches, blundering into one another."             
## [3459] ""                                                                           
## [3460] "The carts and carriages crowded close upon one another, making"             
## [3461] "little way for those swifter and more impatient vehicles that darted"       
## [3462] "forward every now and then when an opportunity showed itself of doing"      
## [3463] "so, sending the people scattering against the fences and gates of the"      
## [3464] "villas."                                                                    
## [3465] ""                                                                           
## [3466] "\"Push on!\" was the cry.  \"Push on!  They are coming!\""                  
## [3467] ""                                                                           
## [3468] "In one cart stood a blind man in the uniform of the Salvation Army,"        
## [3469] "gesticulating with his crooked fingers and bawling, \"Eternity!"            
## [3470] "Eternity!\"  His voice was hoarse and very loud so that my brother"         
## [3471] "could hear him long after he was lost to sight in the dust.  Some of"       
## [3472] "the people who crowded in the carts whipped stupidly at their horses"       
## [3473] "and quarrelled with other drivers; some sat motionless, staring at"         
## [3474] "nothing with miserable eyes; some gnawed their hands with thirst, or"       
## [3475] "lay prostrate in the bottoms of their conveyances.  The horses' bits"       
## [3476] "were covered with foam, their eyes bloodshot."                              
## [3477] ""                                                                           
## [3478] "There were cabs, carriages, shop cars, waggons, beyond counting; a"         
## [3479] "mail cart, a road-cleaner's cart marked \"Vestry of St. Pancras,\" a"       
## [3480] "huge timber waggon crowded with roughs.  A brewer's dray rumbled by"        
## [3481] "with its two near wheels splashed with fresh blood."                        
## [3482] ""                                                                           
## [3483] "\"Clear the way!\" cried the voices.  \"Clear the way!\""                   
## [3484] ""                                                                           
## [3485] "\"Eter-nity!  Eter-nity!\" came echoing down the road."                     
## [3486] ""                                                                           
## [3487] "There were sad, haggard women tramping by, well dressed, with"              
## [3488] "children that cried and stumbled, their dainty clothes smothered in"        
## [3489] "dust, their weary faces smeared with tears.  With many of these came"       
## [3490] "men, sometimes helpful, sometimes lowering and savage.  Fighting side"      
## [3491] "by side with them pushed some weary street outcast in faded black"          
## [3492] "rags, wide-eyed, loud-voiced, and foul-mouthed.  There were sturdy"         
## [3493] "workmen thrusting their way along, wretched, unkempt men, clothed like"     
## [3494] "clerks or shopmen, struggling spasmodically; a wounded soldier my"          
## [3495] "brother noticed, men dressed in the clothes of railway porters, one"        
## [3496] "wretched creature in a nightshirt with a coat thrown over it."              
## [3497] ""                                                                           
## [3498] "But varied as its composition was, certain things all that host had"        
## [3499] "in common.  There were fear and pain on their faces, and fear behind"       
## [3500] "them.  A tumult up the road, a quarrel for a place in a waggon, sent"       
## [3501] "the whole host of them quickening their pace; even a man so scared and"     
## [3502] "broken that his knees bent under him was galvanised for a moment into"      
## [3503] "renewed activity.  The heat and dust had already been at work upon"         
## [3504] "this multitude.  Their skins were dry, their lips black and cracked."       
## [3505] "They were all thirsty, weary, and footsore.  And amid the various"          
## [3506] "cries one heard disputes, reproaches, groans of weariness and fatigue;"     
## [3507] "the voices of most of them were hoarse and weak.  Through it all ran a"     
## [3508] "refrain:"                                                                   
## [3509] ""                                                                           
## [3510] "\"Way!  Way!  The Martians are coming!\""                                   
## [3511] ""                                                                           
## [3512] "Few stopped and came aside from that flood.  The lane opened"               
## [3513] "slantingly into the main road with a narrow opening, and had a"             
## [3514] "delusive appearance of coming from the direction of London.  Yet a"         
## [3515] "kind of eddy of people drove into its mouth; weaklings elbowed out of"      
## [3516] "the stream, who for the most part rested but a moment before plunging"      
## [3517] "into it again.  A little way down the lane, with two friends bending"       
## [3518] "over him, lay a man with a bare leg, wrapped about with bloody rags."       
## [3519] "He was a lucky man to have friends."                                        
## [3520] ""                                                                           
## [3521] "A little old man, with a grey military moustache and a filthy black"        
## [3522] "frock coat, limped out and sat down beside the trap, removed his"           
## [3523] "boot--his sock was blood-stained--shook out a pebble, and hobbled on"       
## [3524] "again; and then a little girl of eight or nine, all alone, threw"           
## [3525] "herself under the hedge close by my brother, weeping."                      
## [3526] ""                                                                           
## [3527] "\"I can't go on!  I can't go on!\""                                         
## [3528] ""                                                                           
## [3529] "My brother woke from his torpor of astonishment and lifted her up,"         
## [3530] "speaking gently to her, and carried her to Miss Elphinstone.  So soon"      
## [3531] "as my brother touched her she became quite still, as if frightened."        
## [3532] ""                                                                           
## [3533] "\"Ellen!\" shrieked a woman in the crowd, with tears in her"                
## [3534] "voice--\"Ellen!\"  And the child suddenly darted away from my brother,"     
## [3535] "crying \"Mother!\""                                                         
## [3536] ""                                                                           
## [3537] "\"They are coming,\" said a man on horseback, riding past along the"        
## [3538] "lane."                                                                      
## [3539] ""                                                                           
## [3540] "\"Out of the way, there!\" bawled a coachman, towering high; and my"        
## [3541] "brother saw a closed carriage turning into the lane."                       
## [3542] ""                                                                           
## [3543] "The people crushed back on one another to avoid the horse.  My"             
## [3544] "brother pushed the pony and chaise back into the hedge, and the man"        
## [3545] "drove by and stopped at the turn of the way.  It was a carriage, with"      
## [3546] "a pole for a pair of horses, but only one was in the traces.  My"           
## [3547] "brother saw dimly through the dust that two men lifted out something"       
## [3548] "on a white stretcher and put it gently on the grass beneath the privet"     
## [3549] "hedge."                                                                     
## [3550] ""                                                                           
## [3551] "One of the men came running to my brother."                                 
## [3552] ""                                                                           
## [3553] "\"Where is there any water?\" he said.  \"He is dying fast, and very"       
## [3554] "thirsty.  It is Lord Garrick.\""                                            
## [3555] ""                                                                           
## [3556] "\"Lord Garrick!\" said my brother; \"the Chief Justice?\""                  
## [3557] ""                                                                           
## [3558] "\"The water?\" he said."                                                    
## [3559] ""                                                                           
## [3560] "\"There may be a tap,\" said my brother, \"in some of the houses.  We"      
## [3561] "have no water.  I dare not leave my people.\""                              
## [3562] ""                                                                           
## [3563] "The man pushed against the crowd towards the gate of the corner"            
## [3564] "house."                                                                     
## [3565] ""                                                                           
## [3566] "\"Go on!\" said the people, thrusting at him.  \"They are coming!  Go"      
## [3567] "on!\""                                                                      
## [3568] ""                                                                           
## [3569] "Then my brother's attention was distracted by a bearded, eagle-faced"       
## [3570] "man lugging a small handbag, which split even as my brother's"              
## [3571] "eyes rested on it and disgorged a mass of sovereigns that seemed to"        
## [3572] "break up into separate coins as it struck the ground.  They rolled"         
## [3573] "hither and thither among the struggling feet of men and horses.  The"       
## [3574] "man stopped and looked stupidly at the heap, and the shaft of a cab"        
## [3575] "struck his shoulder and sent him reeling.  He gave a shriek and dodged"     
## [3576] "back, and a cartwheel shaved him narrowly."                                 
## [3577] ""                                                                           
## [3578] "\"Way!\" cried the men all about him.  \"Make way!\""                       
## [3579] ""                                                                           
## [3580] "So soon as the cab had passed, he flung himself, with both hands"           
## [3581] "open, upon the heap of coins, and began thrusting handfuls in his"          
## [3582] "pocket.  A horse rose close upon him, and in another moment, half"          
## [3583] "rising, he had been borne down under the horse's hoofs."                    
## [3584] ""                                                                           
## [3585] "\"Stop!\" screamed my brother, and pushing a woman out of his way,"         
## [3586] "tried to clutch the bit of the horse."                                      
## [3587] ""                                                                           
## [3588] "Before he could get to it, he heard a scream under the wheels, and"         
## [3589] "saw through the dust the rim passing over the poor wretch's back.  The"     
## [3590] "driver of the cart slashed his whip at my brother, who ran round"           
## [3591] "behind the cart.  The multitudinous shouting confused his ears.  The"       
## [3592] "man was writhing in the dust among his scattered money, unable to"          
## [3593] "rise, for the wheel had broken his back, and his lower limbs lay limp"      
## [3594] "and dead.  My brother stood up and yelled at the next driver, and a"        
## [3595] "man on a black horse came to his assistance."                               
## [3596] ""                                                                           
## [3597] "\"Get him out of the road,\" said he; and, clutching the man's collar"      
## [3598] "with his free hand, my brother lugged him sideways.  But he still"          
## [3599] "clutched after his money, and regarded my brother fiercely, hammering"      
## [3600] "at his arm with a handful of gold.  \"Go on!  Go on!\" shouted angry"       
## [3601] "voices behind."                                                             
## [3602] ""                                                                           
## [3603] "\"Way!  Way!\""                                                             
## [3604] ""                                                                           
## [3605] "There was a smash as the pole of a carriage crashed into the cart"          
## [3606] "that the man on horseback stopped.  My brother looked up, and the man"      
## [3607] "with the gold twisted his head round and bit the wrist that held his"       
## [3608] "collar.  There was a concussion, and the black horse came staggering"       
## [3609] "sideways, and the carthorse pushed beside it.  A hoof missed my"            
## [3610] "brother's foot by a hair's breadth.  He released his grip on the"           
## [3611] "fallen man and jumped back.  He saw anger change to terror on the face"     
## [3612] "of the poor wretch on the ground, and in a moment he was hidden and my"     
## [3613] "brother was borne backward and carried past the entrance of the lane,"      
## [3614] "and had to fight hard in the torrent to recover it."                        
## [3615] ""                                                                           
## [3616] "He saw Miss Elphinstone covering her eyes, and a little child, with"        
## [3617] "all a child's want of sympathetic imagination, staring with dilated"        
## [3618] "eyes at a dusty something that lay black and still, ground and crushed"     
## [3619] "under the rolling wheels.  \"Let us go back!\" he shouted, and began"       
## [3620] "turning the pony round. \"We cannot cross this--hell,\" he said and they"   
## [3621] "went back a hundred yards the way they had come, until the fighting"        
## [3622] "crowd was hidden.  As they passed the bend in the lane my brother saw"      
## [3623] "the face of the dying man in the ditch under the privet, deadly white"
