## [3624] "and drawn, and shining with perspiration.  The two women sat silent,"       
## [3625] "crouching in their seat and shivering."                                     
## [3626] ""                                                                           
## [3627] "Then beyond the bend my brother stopped again.  Miss Elphinstone"           
## [3628] "was white and pale, and her sister-in-law sat weeping, too wretched"        
## [3629] "even to call upon \"George.\"  My brother was horrified and perplexed."     
## [3630] "So soon as they had retreated he realised how urgent and unavoidable"       
## [3631] "it was to attempt this crossing.  He turned to Miss Elphinstone,"           
## [3632] "suddenly resolute."                                                         
## [3633] ""                                                                           
## [3634] "\"We must go that way,\" he said, and led the pony round again."            
## [3635] ""                                                                           
## [3636] "For the second time that day this girl proved her quality.  To force"       
## [3637] "their way into the torrent of people, my brother plunged into the"          
## [3638] "traffic and held back a cab horse, while she drove the pony across its"     
## [3639] "head.  A waggon locked wheels for a moment and ripped a long splinter"      
## [3640] "from the chaise.  In another moment they were caught and swept forward"     
## [3641] "by the stream.  My brother, with the cabman's whip marks red across"        
## [3642] "his face and hands, scrambled into the chaise and took the reins from"      
## [3643] "her."                                                                       
## [3644] ""                                                                           
## [3645] "\"Point the revolver at the man behind,\" he said, giving it to her,"       
## [3646] "\"if he presses us too hard.  No!--point it at his horse.\""                
## [3647] ""                                                                           
## [3648] "Then he began to look out for a chance of edging to the right"              
## [3649] "across the road.  But once in the stream he seemed to lose volition,"       
## [3650] "to become a part of that dusty rout.  They swept through Chipping"          
## [3651] "Barnet with the torrent; they were nearly a mile beyond the centre of"      
## [3652] "the town before they had fought across to the opposite side of the"         
## [3653] "way.  It was din and confusion indescribable; but in and beyond the"        
## [3654] "town the road forks repeatedly, and this to some extent relieved the"       
## [3655] "stress."                                                                    
## [3656] ""                                                                           
## [3657] "They struck eastward through Hadley, and there on either side of"           
## [3658] "the road, and at another place farther on they came upon a great"           
## [3659] "multitude of people drinking at the stream, some fighting to come at"       
## [3660] "the water.  And farther on, from a lull near East Barnet, they saw"         
## [3661] "two trains running slowly one after the other without signal or"            
## [3662] "order--trains swarming with people, with men even among the coals"          
## [3663] "behind the engines--going northward along the Great Northern Railway."      
## [3664] "My brother supposes they must have filled outside London, for at that"      
## [3665] "time the furious terror of the people had rendered the central"             
## [3666] "termini impossible."                                                        
## [3667] ""                                                                           
## [3668] "Near this place they halted for the rest of the afternoon, for the"         
## [3669] "violence of the day had already utterly exhausted all three of them."       
## [3670] "They began to suffer the beginnings of hunger; the night was cold, and"     
## [3671] "none of them dared to sleep.  And in the evening many people came"          
## [3672] "hurrying along the road nearby their stopping place, fleeing from"          
## [3673] "unknown dangers before them, and going in the direction from which my"      
## [3674] "brother had come."                                                          
## [3675] ""                                                                           
## [3676] ""                                                                           
## [3677] ""                                                                           
## [3678] "CHAPTER SEVENTEEN"                                                          
## [3679] ""                                                                           
## [3680] "THE \"THUNDER CHILD\""                                                      
## [3681] ""                                                                           
## [3682] ""                                                                           
## [3683] "Had the Martians aimed only at destruction, they might on Monday"           
## [3684] "have annihilated the entire population of London, as it spread itself"      
## [3685] "slowly through the home counties.  Not only along the road through"         
## [3686] "Barnet, but also through Edgware and Waltham Abbey, and along the"          
## [3687] "roads eastward to Southend and Shoeburyness, and south of the Thames"       
## [3688] "to Deal and Broadstairs, poured the same frantic rout.  If one could"       
## [3689] "have hung that June morning in a balloon in the blazing blue above"         
## [3690] "London every northward and eastward road running out of the tangled"        
## [3691] "maze of streets would have seemed stippled black with the streaming"        
## [3692] "fugitives, each dot a human agony of terror and physical distress.  I"      
## [3693] "have set forth at length in the last chapter my brother's account of"       
## [3694] "the road through Chipping Barnet, in order that my readers may realise"     
## [3695] "how that swarming of black dots appeared to one of those concerned."        
## [3696] "Never before in the history of the world had such a mass of human"          
## [3697] "beings moved and suffered together.  The legendary hosts of Goths and"      
## [3698] "Huns, the hugest armies Asia has ever seen, would have been but a drop"     
## [3699] "in that current.  And this was no disciplined march; it was a"              
## [3700] "stampede--a stampede gigantic and terrible--without order and without"      
## [3701] "a goal, six million people unarmed and unprovisioned, driving"              
## [3702] "headlong.  It was the beginning of the rout of civilisation, of the"        
## [3703] "massacre of mankind."                                                       
## [3704] ""                                                                           
## [3705] "Directly below him the balloonist would have seen the network of"           
## [3706] "streets far and wide, houses, churches, squares, crescents,"                
## [3707] "gardens--already derelict--spread out like a huge map, and in the"          
## [3708] "southward _blotted_.  Over Ealing, Richmond, Wimbledon, it would"           
## [3709] "have seemed as if some monstrous pen had flung ink upon the chart."         
## [3710] "Steadily, incessantly, each black splash grew and spread, shooting out"     
## [3711] "ramifications this way and that, now banking itself against rising"         
## [3712] "ground, now pouring swiftly over a crest into a new-found valley,"          
## [3713] "exactly as a gout of ink would spread itself upon blotting paper."          
## [3714] ""                                                                           
## [3715] "And beyond, over the blue hills that rise southward of the river,"          
## [3716] "the glittering Martians went to and fro, calmly and methodically"           
## [3717] "spreading their poison cloud over this patch of country and then over"      
## [3718] "that, laying it again with their steam jets when it had served its"         
## [3719] "purpose, and taking possession of the conquered country.  They do not"      
## [3720] "seem to have aimed at extermination so much as at complete"                 
## [3721] "demoralisation and the destruction of any opposition.  They exploded"       
## [3722] "any stores of powder they came upon, cut every telegraph, and wrecked"      
## [3723] "the railways here and there.  They were hamstringing mankind.  They"        
## [3724] "seemed in no hurry to extend the field of their operations, and did"        
## [3725] "not come beyond the central part of London all that day.  It is"            
## [3726] "possible that a very considerable number of people in London stuck to"      
## [3727] "their houses through Monday morning.  Certain it is that many died at"      
## [3728] "home suffocated by the Black Smoke."                                        
## [3729] ""                                                                           
## [3730] "Until about midday the Pool of London was an astonishing scene."            
## [3731] "Steamboats and shipping of all sorts lay there, tempted by the"             
## [3732] "enormous sums of money offered by fugitives, and it is said that many"      
## [3733] "who swam out to these vessels were thrust off with boathooks and"           
## [3734] "drowned.  About one o'clock in the afternoon the thinning remnant of a"     
## [3735] "cloud of the black vapour appeared between the arches of Blackfriars"       
## [3736] "Bridge.  At that the Pool became a scene of mad confusion, fighting,"       
## [3737] "and collision, and for some time a multitude of boats and barges"           
## [3738] "jammed in the northern arch of the Tower Bridge, and the sailors and"       
## [3739] "lightermen had to fight savagely against the people who swarmed upon"       
## [3740] "them from the riverfront.  People were actually clambering down the"        
## [3741] "piers of the bridge from above."                                            
## [3742] ""                                                                           
## [3743] "When, an hour later, a Martian appeared beyond the Clock Tower and"         
## [3744] "waded down the river, nothing but wreckage floated above Limehouse."        
## [3745] ""                                                                           
## [3746] "Of the falling of the fifth cylinder I have presently to tell.  The"        
## [3747] "sixth star fell at Wimbledon.  My brother, keeping watch beside the"        
## [3748] "women in the chaise in a meadow, saw the green flash of it far beyond"      
## [3749] "the hills.  On Tuesday the little party, still set upon getting across"     
## [3750] "the sea, made its way through the swarming country towards Colchester."     
## [3751] "The news that the Martians were now in possession of the whole of"          
## [3752] "London was confirmed.  They had been seen at Highgate, and even, it"        
## [3753] "was said, at Neasden.  But they did not come into my brother's view"        
## [3754] "until the morrow."                                                          
## [3755] ""                                                                           
## [3756] "That day the scattered multitudes began to realise the urgent need"         
## [3757] "of provisions.  As they grew hungry the rights of property ceased to"       
## [3758] "be regarded.  Farmers were out to defend their cattle-sheds,"               
## [3759] "granaries, and ripening root crops with arms in their hands.  A number"     
## [3760] "of people now, like my brother, had their faces eastward, and there"        
## [3761] "were some desperate souls even going back towards London to get food."      
## [3762] "These were chiefly people from the northern suburbs, whose knowledge"       
## [3763] "of the Black Smoke came by hearsay.  He heard that about half the"          
## [3764] "members of the government had gathered at Birmingham, and that"             
## [3765] "enormous quantities of high explosives were being prepared to be used"      
## [3766] "in automatic mines across the Midland counties."                            
## [3767] ""                                                                           
## [3768] "He was also told that the Midland Railway Company had replaced the"         
## [3769] "desertions of the first day's panic, had resumed traffic, and was"          
## [3770] "running northward trains from St. Albans to relieve the congestion of"      
## [3771] "the home counties.  There was also a placard in Chipping Ongar"             
## [3772] "announcing that large stores of flour were available in the northern"       
## [3773] "towns and that within twenty-four hours bread would be distributed"         
## [3774] "among the starving people in the neighbourhood.  But this intelligence"     
## [3775] "did not deter him from the plan of escape he had formed, and the three"     
## [3776] "pressed eastward all day, and heard no more of the bread distribution"      
## [3777] "than this promise.  Nor, as a matter of fact, did anyone else hear"         
## [3778] "more of it.  That night fell the seventh star, falling upon Primrose"       
## [3779] "Hill.  It fell while Miss Elphinstone was watching, for she took that"      
## [3780] "duty alternately with my brother.  She saw it."                             
## [3781] ""                                                                           
## [3782] "On Wednesday the three fugitives--they had passed the night in a"           
## [3783] "field of unripe wheat--reached Chelmsford, and there a body of the"         
## [3784] "inhabitants, calling itself the Committee of Public Supply, seized the"     
## [3785] "pony as provisions, and would give nothing in exchange for it but the"      
## [3786] "promise of a share in it the next day.  Here there were rumours of"         
## [3787] "Martians at Epping, and news of the destruction of Waltham Abbey"           
## [3788] "Powder Mills in a vain attempt to blow up one of the invaders."             
## [3789] ""                                                                           
## [3790] "People were watching for Martians here from the church towers.  My"         
## [3791] "brother, very luckily for him as it chanced, preferred to push on at"       
## [3792] "once to the coast rather than wait for food, although all three of"         
## [3793] "them were very hungry.  By midday they passed through Tillingham,"          
## [3794] "which, strangely enough, seemed to be quite silent and deserted, save"      
## [3795] "for a few furtive plunderers hunting for food.  Near Tillingham they"       
## [3796] "suddenly came in sight of the sea, and the most amazing crowd of"           
## [3797] "shipping of all sorts that it is possible to imagine."                      
## [3798] ""                                                                           
## [3799] "For after the sailors could no longer come up the Thames, they came"        
## [3800] "on to the Essex coast, to Harwich and Walton and Clacton, and"              
## [3801] "afterwards to Foulness and Shoebury, to bring off the people.  They"        
## [3802] "lay in a huge sickle-shaped curve that vanished into mist at last"          
## [3803] "towards the Naze.  Close inshore was a multitude of fishing"                
## [3804] "smacks--English, Scotch, French, Dutch, and Swedish; steam launches"        
## [3805] "from the Thames, yachts, electric boats; and beyond were ships of large"    
## [3806] "burden, a multitude of filthy colliers, trim merchantmen, cattle ships,"    
## [3807] "passenger boats, petroleum tanks, ocean tramps, an old white transport"     
## [3808] "even, neat white and grey liners from Southampton and Hamburg; and"         
## [3809] "along the blue coast across the Blackwater my brother could make out"       
## [3810] "dimly a dense swarm of boats chaffering with the people on the beach,"      
## [3811] "a swarm which also extended up the Blackwater almost to Maldon."            
## [3812] ""                                                                           
## [3813] "About a couple of miles out lay an ironclad, very low in the water,"        
## [3814] "almost, to my brother's perception, like a water-logged ship.  This"        
## [3815] "was the ram _Thunder Child_.  It was the only warship in sight, but far"    
## [3816] "away to the right over the smooth surface of the sea--for that day"         
## [3817] "there was a dead calm--lay a serpent of black smoke to mark the next"       
## [3818] "ironclads of the Channel Fleet, which hovered in an extended line,"         
## [3819] "steam up and ready for action, across the Thames estuary during the"        
## [3820] "course of the Martian conquest, vigilant and yet powerless to prevent"      
## [3821] "it."                                                                        
## [3822] ""                                                                           
## [3823] "At the sight of the sea, Mrs. Elphinstone, in spite of the"                 
## [3824] "assurances of her sister-in-law, gave way to panic.  She had never"         
## [3825] "been out of England before, she would rather die than trust herself"        
## [3826] "friendless in a foreign country, and so forth.  She seemed, poor woman,"    
## [3827] "to imagine that the French and the Martians might prove very similar."      
## [3828] "She had been growing increasingly hysterical, fearful, and depressed"       
## [3829] "during the two days' journeyings.  Her great idea was to return to"         
## [3830] "Stanmore.  Things had been always well and safe at Stanmore.  They"         
## [3831] "would find George at Stanmore."                                             
## [3832] ""                                                                           
## [3833] "It was with the greatest difficulty they could get her down to the"         
## [3834] "beach, where presently my brother succeeded in attracting the"              
## [3835] "attention of some men on a paddle steamer from the Thames.  They sent"      
## [3836] "a boat and drove a bargain for thirty-six pounds for the three.  The"       
## [3837] "steamer was going, these men said, to Ostend."                              
## [3838] ""                                                                           
## [3839] "It was about two o'clock when my brother, having paid their fares"          
## [3840] "at the gangway, found himself safely aboard the steamboat with his"         
## [3841] "charges.  There was food aboard, albeit at exorbitant prices, and the"      
## [3842] "three of them contrived to eat a meal on one of the seats forward."         
## [3843] ""                                                                           
## [3844] "There were already a couple of score of passengers aboard, some of"         
## [3845] "whom had expended their last money in securing a passage, but the"          
## [3846] "captain lay off the Blackwater until five in the afternoon, picking up"     
## [3847] "passengers until the seated decks were even dangerously crowded.  He"       
## [3848] "would probably have remained longer had it not been for the sound of"       
## [3849] "guns that began about that hour in the south.  As if in answer, the"        
## [3850] "ironclad seaward fired a small gun and hoisted a string of flags.  A"       
## [3851] "jet of smoke sprang out of her funnels."                                    
## [3852] ""                                                                           
## [3853] "Some of the passengers were of opinion that this firing came from"          
## [3854] "Shoeburyness, until it was noticed that it was growing louder.  At the"     
## [3855] "same time, far away in the southeast the masts and upperworks of three"     
## [3856] "ironclads rose one after the other out of the sea, beneath clouds of"       
## [3857] "black smoke.  But my brother's attention speedily reverted to the"          
## [3858] "distant firing in the south.  He fancied he saw a column of smoke"          
## [3859] "rising out of the distant grey haze."                                       
## [3860] ""                                                                           
## [3861] "The little steamer was already flapping her way eastward of the big"        
## [3862] "crescent of shipping, and the low Essex coast was growing blue and"         
## [3863] "hazy, when a Martian appeared, small and faint in the remote distance,"     
## [3864] "advancing along the muddy coast from the direction of Foulness.  At"        
## [3865] "that the captain on the bridge swore at the top of his voice with fear"     
## [3866] "and anger at his own delay, and the paddles seemed infected with his"       
## [3867] "terror.  Every soul aboard stood at the bulwarks or on the seats of"        
## [3868] "the steamer and stared at that distant shape, higher than the trees or"     
## [3869] "church towers inland, and advancing with a leisurely parody of a human"     
## [3870] "stride."                                                                    
## [3871] ""                                                                           
## [3872] "It was the first Martian my brother had seen, and he stood, more"           
## [3873] "amazed than terrified, watching this Titan advancing deliberately"          
## [3874] "towards the shipping, wading farther and farther into the water as the"     
## [3875] "coast fell away.  Then, far away beyond the Crouch, came another,"          
## [3876] "striding over some stunted trees, and then yet another, still farther"      
## [3877] "off, wading deeply through a shiny mudflat that seemed to hang halfway"     
## [3878] "up between sea and sky.  They were all stalking seaward, as if to"          
## [3879] "intercept the escape of the multitudinous vessels that were crowded"        
## [3880] "between Foulness and the Naze.  In spite of the throbbing exertions of"     
## [3881] "the engines of the little paddle-boat, and the pouring foam that her"       
## [3882] "wheels flung behind her, she receded with terrifying slowness from"         
## [3883] "this ominous advance."                                                      
## [3884] ""                                                                           
## [3885] "Glancing northwestward, my brother saw the large crescent of"               
## [3886] "shipping already writhing with the approaching terror; one ship"            
## [3887] "passing behind another, another coming round from broadside to end on,"     
## [3888] "steamships whistling and giving off volumes of steam, sails being let"      
## [3889] "out, launches rushing hither and thither.  He was so fascinated by"         
## [3890] "this and by the creeping danger away to the left that he had no eyes"       
## [3891] "for anything seaward.  And then a swift movement of the steamboat (she"     
## [3892] "had suddenly come round to avoid being run down) flung him headlong"        
## [3893] "from the seat upon which he was standing.  There was a shouting all"        
## [3894] "about him, a trampling of feet, and a cheer that seemed to be answered"     
## [3895] "faintly.  The steamboat lurched and rolled him over upon his hands."        
## [3896] ""                                                                           
## [3897] "He sprang to his feet and saw to starboard, and not a hundred yards"        
## [3898] "from their heeling, pitching boat, a vast iron bulk like the blade of"      
## [3899] "a plough tearing through the water, tossing it on either side in huge"      
## [3900] "waves of foam that leaped towards the steamer, flinging her paddles"        
## [3901] "helplessly in the air, and then sucking her deck down almost to the"        
## [3902] "waterline."                                                                 
## [3903] ""                                                                           
## [3904] "A douche of spray blinded my brother for a moment.  When his eyes"          
## [3905] "were clear again he saw the monster had passed and was rushing"             
## [3906] "landward.  Big iron upperworks rose out of this headlong structure,"        
## [3907] "and from that twin funnels projected and spat a smoking blast shot"         
## [3908] "with fire.  It was the torpedo ram, _Thunder Child_, steaming headlong,"    
## [3909] "coming to the rescue of the threatened shipping."                           
## [3910] ""                                                                           
## [3911] "Keeping his footing on the heaving deck by clutching the bulwarks,"         
## [3912] "my brother looked past this charging leviathan at the Martians again,"      
## [3913] "and he saw the three of them now close together, and standing so far"       
## [3914] "out to sea that their tripod supports were almost entirely submerged."      
## [3915] "Thus sunken, and seen in remote perspective, they appeared far less"        
## [3916] "formidable than the huge iron bulk in whose wake the steamer was"           
## [3917] "pitching so helplessly.  It would seem they were regarding this new"        
## [3918] "antagonist with astonishment.  To their intelligence, it may be, the"       
## [3919] "giant was even such another as themselves.  The _Thunder Child_ fired no"   
## [3920] "gun, but simply drove full speed towards them.  It was probably her"        
## [3921] "not firing that enabled her to get so near the enemy as she did.  They"     
## [3922] "did not know what to make of her.  One shell, and they would have sent"     
## [3923] "her to the bottom forthwith with the Heat-Ray."                             
## [3924] ""                                                                           
## [3925] "She was steaming at such a pace that in a minute she seemed halfway"        
## [3926] "between the steamboat and the Martians--a diminishing black bulk"           
## [3927] "against the receding horizontal expanse of the Essex coast."                
## [3928] ""                                                                           
## [3929] "Suddenly the foremost Martian lowered his tube and discharged a"            
## [3930] "canister of the black gas at the ironclad.  It hit her larboard side"       
## [3931] "and glanced off in an inky jet that rolled away to seaward, an"             
## [3932] "unfolding torrent of Black Smoke, from which the ironclad drove clear."     
## [3933] "To the watchers from the steamer, low in the water and with the sun in"     
## [3934] "their eyes, it seemed as though she were already among the Martians."       
## [3935] ""                                                                           
## [3936] "They saw the gaunt figures separating and rising out of the water"          
## [3937] "as they retreated shoreward, and one of them raised the camera-like"        
## [3938] "generator of the Heat-Ray.  He held it pointing obliquely downward,"        
## [3939] "and a bank of steam sprang from the water at its touch.  It must have"      
## [3940] "driven through the iron of the ship's side like a white-hot iron rod"       
## [3941] "through paper."                                                             
## [3942] ""                                                                           
## [3943] "A flicker of flame went up through the rising steam, and then the"          
## [3944] "Martian reeled and staggered.  In another moment he was cut down, and"      
## [3945] "a great body of water and steam shot high in the air.  The guns of the"     
## [3946] "_Thunder Child_ sounded through the reek, going off one after the other,"   
## [3947] "and one shot splashed the water high close by the steamer, ricocheted"      
## [3948] "towards the other flying ships to the north, and smashed a smack to"        
## [3949] "matchwood."                                                                 
## [3950] ""                                                                           
## [3951] "But no one heeded that very much.  At the sight of the Martian's"           
## [3952] "collapse the captain on the bridge yelled inarticulately, and all the"      
## [3953] "crowding passengers on the steamer's stern shouted together.  And then"     
## [3954] "they yelled again.  For, surging out beyond the white tumult, drove"        
## [3955] "something long and black, the flames streaming from its middle parts,"      
## [3956] "its ventilators and funnels spouting fire."                                 
## [3957] ""                                                                           
## [3958] "She was alive still; the steering gear, it seems, was intact and"           
## [3959] "her engines working.  She headed straight for a second Martian, and"        
## [3960] "was within a hundred yards of him when the Heat-Ray came to bear.  Then"    
## [3961] "with a violent thud, a blinding flash, her decks, her funnels, leaped"      
## [3962] "upward.  The Martian staggered with the violence of her explosion, and"     
## [3963] "in another moment the flaming wreckage, still driving forward with the"     
## [3964] "impetus of its pace, had struck him and crumpled him up like a thing"       
## [3965] "of cardboard.  My brother shouted involuntarily.  A boiling tumult of"      
## [3966] "steam hid everything again."                                                
## [3967] ""                                                                           
## [3968] "\"Two!\" yelled the captain."                                               
## [3969] ""                                                                           
## [3970] "Everyone was shouting.  The whole steamer from end to end rang with"        
## [3971] "frantic cheering that was taken up first by one and then by all in the"     
## [3972] "crowding multitude of ships and boats that was driving out to sea."         
## [3973] ""                                                                           
## [3974] "The steam hung upon the water for many minutes, hiding the third"           
## [3975] "Martian and the coast altogether.  And all this time the boat was"          
## [3976] "paddling steadily out to sea and away from the fight; and when at last"     
## [3977] "the confusion cleared, the drifting bank of black vapour intervened,"       
## [3978] "and nothing of the _Thunder Child_ could be made out, nor could the"        
## [3979] "third Martian be seen.  But the ironclads to seaward were now quite"        
## [3980] "close and standing in towards shore past the steamboat."                    
## [3981] ""                                                                           
## [3982] "The little vessel continued to beat its way seaward, and the"               
## [3983] "ironclads receded slowly towards the coast, which was hidden still by"      
## [3984] "a marbled bank of vapour, part steam, part black gas, eddying and"          
## [3985] "combining in the strangest way.  The fleet of refugees was scattering"      
## [3986] "to the northeast; several smacks were sailing between the ironclads"        
## [3987] "and the steamboat.  After a time, and before they reached the sinking"      
## [3988] "cloud bank, the warships turned northward, and then abruptly went"          
## [3989] "about and passed into the thickening haze of evening southward.  The"       
## [3990] "coast grew faint, and at last indistinguishable amid the low banks of"      
## [3991] "clouds that were gathering about the sinking sun."                          
## [3992] ""                                                                           
## [3993] "Then suddenly out of the golden haze of the sunset came the"                
## [3994] "vibration of guns, and a form of black shadows moving.  Everyone"           
## [3995] "struggled to the rail of the steamer and peered into the blinding"          
## [3996] "furnace of the west, but nothing was to be distinguished clearly.  A"       
## [3997] "mass of smoke rose slanting and barred the face of the sun.  The"           
## [3998] "steamboat throbbed on its way through an interminable suspense."            
## [3999] ""                                                                           
## [4000] "The sun sank into grey clouds, the sky flushed and darkened, the"           
## [4001] "evening star trembled into sight.  It was deep twilight when the"           
## [4002] "captain cried out and pointed.  My brother strained his eyes."              
## [4003] "Something rushed up into the sky out of the greyness--rushed"               
## [4004] "slantingly upward and very swiftly into the luminous clearness above"       
## [4005] "the clouds in the western sky; something flat and broad, and very"          
## [4006] "large, that swept round in a vast curve, grew smaller, sank slowly,"        
## [4007] "and vanished again into the grey mystery of the night.  And as it flew"     
## [4008] "it rained down darkness upon the land."                                     
## [4009] ""                                                                           
## [4010] ""                                                                           
## [4011] ""                                                                           
## [4012] "BOOK TWO"                                                                   
## [4013] ""                                                                           
## [4014] "THE EARTH UNDER THE MARTIANS"                                               
## [4015] ""                                                                           
## [4016] ""                                                                           
## [4017] ""                                                                           
## [4018] "CHAPTER ONE"                                                                
## [4019] ""                                                                           
## [4020] "UNDER FOOT"                                                                 
## [4021] ""                                                                           
## [4022] ""                                                                           
## [4023] "In the first book I have wandered so much from my own adventures to"        
## [4024] "tell of the experiences of my brother that all through the last two"        
## [4025] "chapters I and the curate have been lurking in the empty house at"          
## [4026] "Halliford whither we fled to escape the Black Smoke.  There I will"         
## [4027] "resume.  We stopped there all Sunday night and all the next day--the"       
## [4028] "day of the panic--in a little island of daylight, cut off by the Black"     
## [4029] "Smoke from the rest of the world.  We could do nothing but wait in"         
## [4030] "aching inactivity during those two weary days."                             
## [4031] ""                                                                           
## [4032] "My mind was occupied by anxiety for my wife.  I figured her at"             
## [4033] "Leatherhead, terrified, in danger, mourning me already as a dead man."      
## [4034] "I paced the rooms and cried aloud when I thought of how I was cut off"      
## [4035] "from her, of all that might happen to her in my absence.  My cousin I"      
## [4036] "knew was brave enough for any emergency, but he was not the sort of"        
## [4037] "man to realise danger quickly, to rise promptly.  What was needed now"      
## [4038] "was not bravery, but circumspection.  My only consolation was to"           
## [4039] "believe that the Martians were moving London-ward and away from her."       
## [4040] "Such vague anxieties keep the mind sensitive and painful.  I grew very"     
## [4041] "weary and irritable with the curate's perpetual ejaculations; I tired"      
## [4042] "of the sight of his selfish despair.  After some ineffectual"               
## [4043] "remonstrance I kept away from him, staying in a room--evidently a"          
## [4044] "children's schoolroom--containing globes, forms, and copybooks.  When"      
## [4045] "he followed me thither, I went to a box room at the top of the house"       
## [4046] "and, in order to be alone with my aching miseries, locked myself in."       
## [4047] ""                                                                           
## [4048] "We were hopelessly hemmed in by the Black Smoke all that day and"           
## [4049] "the morning of the next.  There were signs of people in the next house"     
## [4050] "on Sunday evening--a face at a window and moving lights, and later the"     
## [4051] "slamming of a door.  But I do not know who these people were, nor what"     
## [4052] "became of them.  We saw nothing of them next day.  The Black Smoke"         
## [4053] "drifted slowly riverward all through Monday morning, creeping nearer"       
## [4054] "and nearer to us, driving at last along the roadway outside the house"      
## [4055] "that hid us."                                                               
## [4056] ""                                                                           
## [4057] "A Martian came across the fields about midday, laying the stuff"            
## [4058] "with a jet of superheated steam that hissed against the walls, smashed"     
## [4059] "all the windows it touched, and scalded the curate's hand as he fled"       
## [4060] "out of the front room.  When at last we crept across the sodden rooms"      
## [4061] "and looked out again, the country northward was as though a black"          
## [4062] "snowstorm had passed over it.  Looking towards the river, we were"          
## [4063] "astonished to see an unaccountable redness mingling with the black of"      
## [4064] "the scorched meadows."                                                      
## [4065] ""                                                                           
## [4066] "For a time we did not see how this change affected our position,"           
## [4067] "save that we were relieved of our fear of the Black Smoke.  But later"      
## [4068] "I perceived that we were no longer hemmed in, that now we might get"        
## [4069] "away.  So soon as I realised that the way of escape was open, my dream"     
## [4070] "of action returned.  But the curate was lethargic, unreasonable."           
## [4071] ""                                                                           
## [4072] "\"We are safe here,\" he repeated; \"safe here.\""                          
## [4073] ""                                                                           
## [4074] "I resolved to leave him--would that I had!  Wiser now for the"              
## [4075] "artilleryman's teaching, I sought out food and drink.  I had found oil"     
## [4076] "and rags for my burns, and I also took a hat and a flannel shirt that"      
## [4077] "I found in one of the bedrooms.  When it was clear to him that I meant"     
## [4078] "to go alone--had reconciled myself to going alone--he suddenly roused"      
## [4079] "himself to come.  And all being quiet throughout the afternoon, we"         
## [4080] "started about five o'clock, as I should judge, along the blackened"         
## [4081] "road to Sunbury."                                                           
## [4082] ""                                                                           
## [4083] "In Sunbury, and at intervals along the road, were dead bodies lying"        
## [4084] "in contorted attitudes, horses as well as men, overturned carts and"        
## [4085] "luggage, all covered thickly with black dust.  That pall of cindery"        
## [4086] "powder made me think of what I had read of the destruction of Pompeii."     
## [4087] "We got to Hampton Court without misadventure, our minds full of"            
## [4088] "strange and unfamiliar appearances, and at Hampton Court our eyes were"     
## [4089] "relieved to find a patch of green that had escaped the suffocating"         
## [4090] "drift.  We went through Bushey Park, with its deer going to and fro"        
## [4091] "under the chestnuts, and some men and women hurrying in the distance"       
## [4092] "towards Hampton, and so we came to Twickenham.  These were the first"       
## [4093] "people we saw."                                                             
## [4094] ""                                                                           
## [4095] "Away across the road the woods beyond Ham and Petersham were still"         
## [4096] "afire.  Twickenham was uninjured by either Heat-Ray or Black Smoke,"        
## [4097] "and there were more people about here, though none could give us news."     
## [4098] "For the most part they were like ourselves, taking advantage of a lull"     
## [4099] "to shift their quarters.  I have an impression that many of the houses"     
## [4100] "here were still occupied by scared inhabitants, too frightened even"        
## [4101] "for flight.  Here too the evidence of a hasty rout was abundant along"      
## [4102] "the road.  I remember most vividly three smashed bicycles in a heap,"       
## [4103] "pounded into the road by the wheels of subsequent carts.  We crossed"       
## [4104] "Richmond Bridge about half past eight.  We hurried across the exposed"      
## [4105] "bridge, of course, but I noticed floating down the stream a number"         
## [4106] "of red masses, some many feet across.  I did not know what these"           
## [4107] "were--there was no time for scrutiny--and I put a more horrible"            
## [4108] "interpretation on them than they deserved.  Here again on the Surrey"       
## [4109] "side were black dust that had once been smoke, and dead bodies--a heap"     
## [4110] "near the approach to the station; but we had no glimpse of the"             
## [4111] "Martians until we were some way towards Barnes."                            
## [4112] ""                                                                           
## [4113] "We saw in the blackened distance a group of three people running"           
## [4114] "down a side street towards the river, but otherwise it seemed"              
## [4115] "deserted.  Up the hill Richmond town was burning briskly; outside the"      
## [4116] "town of Richmond there was no trace of the Black Smoke."                    
## [4117] ""                                                                           
## [4118] "Then suddenly, as we approached Kew, came a number of people"               
## [4119] "running, and the upperworks of a Martian fighting-machine loomed in"        
## [4120] "sight over the housetops, not a hundred yards away from us.  We stood"      
## [4121] "aghast at our danger, and had the Martian looked down we must"              
## [4122] "immediately have perished.  We were so terrified that we dared not go"      
## [4123] "on, but turned aside and hid in a shed in a garden.  There the curate"      
## [4124] "crouched, weeping silently, and refusing to stir again."                    
## [4125] ""                                                                           
## [4126] "But my fixed idea of reaching Leatherhead would not let me rest,"           
## [4127] "and in the twilight I ventured out again.  I went through a shrubbery,"     
## [4128] "and along a passage beside a big house standing in its own grounds,"        
## [4129] "and so emerged upon the road towards Kew.  The curate I left in the"        
## [4130] "shed, but he came hurrying after me."                                       
## [4131] ""                                                                           
## [4132] "That second start was the most foolhardy thing I ever did.  For it"         
## [4133] "was manifest the Martians were about us.  No sooner had the curate"         
## [4134] "overtaken me than we saw either the fighting-machine we had seen"           
## [4135] "before or another, far away across the meadows in the direction of Kew"     
## [4136] "Lodge.  Four or five little black figures hurried before it across the"     
## [4137] "green-grey of the field, and in a moment it was evident this Martian"       
## [4138] "pursued them.  In three strides he was among them, and they ran"            
## [4139] "radiating from his feet in all directions.  He used no Heat-Ray to"         
## [4140] "destroy them, but picked them up one by one.  Apparently he tossed"         
## [4141] "them into the great metallic carrier which projected behind him, much"      
## [4142] "as a workman's basket hangs over his shoulder."                             
## [4143] ""                                                                           
## [4144] "It was the first time I realised that the Martians might have any"          
## [4145] "other purpose than destruction with defeated humanity.  We stood for a"     
## [4146] "moment petrified, then turned and fled through a gate behind us into a"     
## [4147] "walled garden, fell into, rather than found, a fortunate ditch, and"        
## [4148] "lay there, scarce daring to whisper to each other until the stars were"     
## [4149] "out."                                                                       
## [4150] ""                                                                           
## [4151] "I suppose it was nearly eleven o'clock before we gathered courage"          
## [4152] "to start again, no longer venturing into the road, but sneaking along"      
## [4153] "hedgerows and through plantations, and watching keenly through the"         
## [4154] "darkness, he on the right and I on the left, for the Martians, who"         
## [4155] "seemed to be all about us.  In one place we blundered upon a scorched"      
## [4156] "and blackened area, now cooling and ashen, and a number of scattered"       
## [4157] "dead bodies of men, burned horribly about the heads and trunks but"         
## [4158] "with their legs and boots mostly intact; and of dead horses, fifty"         
## [4159] "feet, perhaps, behind a line of four ripped guns and smashed gun"           
## [4160] "carriages."                                                                 
## [4161] ""                                                                           
## [4162] "Sheen, it seemed, had escaped destruction, but the place was silent"        
## [4163] "and deserted.  Here we happened on no dead, though the night was too"       
## [4164] "dark for us to see into the side roads of the place.  In Sheen my"          
## [4165] "companion suddenly complained of faintness and thirst, and we decided"      
## [4166] "to try one of the houses."                                                  
## [4167] ""                                                                           
## [4168] "The first house we entered, after a little difficulty with the"             
## [4169] "window, was a small semi-detached villa, and I found nothing eatable"       
## [4170] "left in the place but some mouldy cheese.  There was, however, water"       
## [4171] "to drink; and I took a hatchet, which promised to be useful in our"         
## [4172] "next house-breaking."                                                       
## [4173] ""                                                                           
## [4174] "We then crossed to a place where the road turns towards Mortlake."          
## [4175] "Here there stood a white house within a walled garden, and in the"          
## [4176] "pantry of this domicile we found a store of food--two loaves of bread"      
## [4177] "in a pan, an uncooked steak, and the half of a ham.  I give this"           
## [4178] "catalogue so precisely because, as it happened, we were destined to"        
## [4179] "subsist upon this store for the next fortnight.  Bottled beer stood"        
## [4180] "under a shelf, and there were two bags of haricot beans and some limp"      
## [4181] "lettuces.  This pantry opened into a kind of wash-up kitchen, and in"       
## [4182] "this was firewood; there was also a cupboard, in which we found nearly"     
## [4183] "a dozen of burgundy, tinned soups and salmon, and two tins of"              
## [4184] "biscuits."                                                                  
## [4185] ""                                                                           
## [4186] "We sat in the adjacent kitchen in the dark--for we dared not strike"        
## [4187] "a light--and ate bread and ham, and drank beer out of the same bottle."     
## [4188] "The curate, who was still timorous and restless, was now, oddly"            
## [4189] "enough, for pushing on, and I was urging him to keep up his strength"       
## [4190] "by eating when the thing happened that was to imprison us."                 
## [4191] ""                                                                           
## [4192] "\"It can't be midnight yet,\" I said, and then came a blinding glare"       
## [4193] "of vivid green light.  Everything in the kitchen leaped out, clearly"       
## [4194] "visible in green and black, and vanished again.  And then followed such"    
## [4195] "a concussion as I have never heard before or since.  So close on the"       
## [4196] "heels of this as to seem instantaneous came a thud behind me, a clash"      
## [4197] "of glass, a crash and rattle of falling masonry all about us, and the"      
## [4198] "plaster of the ceiling came down upon us, smashing into a multitude of"     
## [4199] "fragments upon our heads.  I was knocked headlong across the floor"         
## [4200] "against the oven handle and stunned.  I was insensible for a long"          
## [4201] "time, the curate told me, and when I came to we were in darkness"           
## [4202] "again, and he, with a face wet, as I found afterwards, with blood from"     
## [4203] "a cut forehead, was dabbing water over me."                                 
## [4204] ""                                                                           
## [4205] "For some time I could not recollect what had happened.  Then things"        
## [4206] "came to me slowly.  A bruise on my temple asserted itself."                 
## [4207] ""                                                                           
## [4208] "\"Are you better?\" asked the curate in a whisper."                         
## [4209] ""                                                                           
## [4210] "At last I answered him.  I sat up."                                         
## [4211] ""                                                                           
## [4212] "\"Don't move,\" he said.  \"The floor is covered with smashed crockery"     
## [4213] "from the dresser.  You can't possibly move without making a noise, and"     
## [4214] "I fancy _they_ are outside.\""                                              
## [4215] ""                                                                           
## [4216] "We both sat quite silent, so that we could scarcely hear each other"        
## [4217] "breathing.  Everything seemed deadly still, but once something near"        
## [4218] "us, some plaster or broken brickwork, slid down with a rumbling sound."     
## [4219] "Outside and very near was an intermittent, metallic rattle."                
## [4220] ""                                                                           
## [4221] "\"That!\" said the curate, when presently it happened again."               
## [4222] ""                                                                           
## [4223] "\"Yes,\" I said.  \"But what is it?\""                                      
## [4224] ""                                                                           
## [4225] "\"A Martian!\" said the curate."                                            
## [4226] ""                                                                           
## [4227] "I listened again."                                                          
## [4228] ""                                                                           
## [4229] "\"It was not like the Heat-Ray,\" I said, and for a time I was"             
## [4230] "inclined to think one of the great fighting-machines had stumbled"          
## [4231] "against the house, as I had seen one stumble against the tower of"          
## [4232] "Shepperton Church."                                                         
## [4233] ""                                                                           
## [4234] "Our situation was so strange and incomprehensible that for three or"        
## [4235] "four hours, until the dawn came, we scarcely moved.  And then the light"    
## [4236] "filtered in, not through the window, which remained black, but through"     
## [4237] "a triangular aperture between a beam and a heap of broken bricks in"        
## [4238] "the wall behind us.  The interior of the kitchen we now saw greyly for"     
## [4239] "the first time."                                                            
## [4240] ""                                                                           
## [4241] "The window had been burst in by a mass of garden mould, which"              
## [4242] "flowed over the table upon which we had been sitting and lay about our"     
## [4243] "feet.  Outside, the soil was banked high against the house.  At the"        
## [4244] "top of the window frame we could see an uprooted drainpipe.  The floor"     
## [4245] "was littered with smashed hardware; the end of the kitchen towards the"     
## [4246] "house was broken into, and since the daylight shone in there, it was"       
## [4247] "evident the greater part of the house had collapsed.  Contrasting"          
## [4248] "vividly with this ruin was the neat dresser, stained in the fashion,"       
## [4249] "pale green, and with a number of copper and tin vessels below it, the"      
## [4250] "wallpaper imitating blue and white tiles, and a couple of coloured"         
## [4251] "supplements fluttering from the walls above the kitchen range."             
## [4252] ""                                                                           
## [4253] "As the dawn grew clearer, we saw through the gap in the wall the"           
## [4254] "body of a Martian, standing sentinel, I suppose, over the still"            
## [4255] "glowing cylinder.  At the sight of that we crawled as circumspectly as"     
## [4256] "possible out of the twilight of the kitchen into the darkness of the"       
## [4257] "scullery."                                                                  
## [4258] ""                                                                           
## [4259] "Abruptly the right interpretation dawned upon my mind."                     
## [4260] ""                                                                           
## [4261] "\"The fifth cylinder,\" I whispered, \"the fifth shot from Mars, has"       
## [4262] "struck this house and buried us under the ruins!\""                         
## [4263] ""                                                                           
## [4264] "For a time the curate was silent, and then he whispered:"                   
## [4265] ""                                                                           
## [4266] "\"God have mercy upon us!\""                                                
## [4267] ""                                                                           
## [4268] "I heard him presently whimpering to himself."                               
## [4269] ""                                                                           
## [4270] "Save for that sound we lay quite still in the scullery; I for my"           
## [4271] "part scarce dared breathe, and sat with my eyes fixed on the faint"         
## [4272] "light of the kitchen door.  I could just see the curate's face, a dim,"     
## [4273] "oval shape, and his collar and cuffs.  Outside there began a metallic"      
## [4274] "hammering, then a violent hooting, and then again, after a quiet"           
## [4275] "interval, a hissing like the hissing of an engine.  These noises, for"      
## [4276] "the most part problematical, continued intermittently, and seemed if"       
## [4277] "anything to increase in number as time wore on.  Presently a measured"      
## [4278] "thudding and a vibration that made everything about us quiver and the"      
## [4279] "vessels in the pantry ring and shift, began and continued.  Once the"       
## [4280] "light was eclipsed, and the ghostly kitchen doorway became absolutely"      
## [4281] "dark.  For many hours we must have crouched there, silent and"              
## [4282] "shivering, until our tired attention failed. . . ."                         
## [4283] ""                                                                           
## [4284] "At last I found myself awake and very hungry.  I am inclined to"            
## [4285] "believe we must have spent the greater portion of a day before that"        
## [4286] "awakening.  My hunger was at a stride so insistent that it moved me to"     
## [4287] "action.  I told the curate I was going to seek food, and felt my way"       
## [4288] "towards the pantry.  He made me no answer, but so soon as I began"          
## [4289] "eating the faint noise I made stirred him up and I heard him crawling"      
## [4290] "after me."                                                                  
## [4291] ""                                                                           
## [4292] ""                                                                           
## [4293] ""                                                                           
## [4294] "CHAPTER TWO"                                                                
## [4295] ""                                                                           
## [4296] "WHAT WE SAW FROM THE RUINED HOUSE"                                          
## [4297] ""                                                                           
## [4298] ""                                                                           
## [4299] "After eating we crept back to the scullery, and there I must have"          
## [4300] "dozed again, for when presently I looked round I was alone.  The"           
## [4301] "thudding vibration continued with wearisome persistence.  I whispered"      
## [4302] "for the curate several times, and at last felt my way to the door of"       
## [4303] "the kitchen.  It was still daylight, and I perceived him across the"        
## [4304] "room, lying against the triangular hole that looked out upon the"           
## [4305] "Martians.  His shoulders were hunched, so that his head was hidden"         
## [4306] "from me."                                                                   
## [4307] ""                                                                           
## [4308] "I could hear a number of noises almost like those in an engine"             
## [4309] "shed; and the place rocked with that beating thud.  Through the"            
## [4310] "aperture in the wall I could see the top of a tree touched with gold"       
## [4311] "and the warm blue of a tranquil evening sky.  For a minute or so I"         
## [4312] "remained watching the curate, and then I advanced, crouching and"           
## [4313] "stepping with extreme care amid the broken crockery that littered the"      
## [4314] "floor."                                                                     
## [4315] ""                                                                           
## [4316] "I touched the curate's leg, and he started so violently that a mass"        
## [4317] "of plaster went sliding down outside and fell with a loud impact.  I"       
## [4318] "gripped his arm, fearing he might cry out, and for a long time we"          
## [4319] "crouched motionless.  Then I turned to see how much of our rampart"         
## [4320] "remained.  The detachment of the plaster had left a vertical slit open"     
## [4321] "in the debris, and by raising myself cautiously across a beam I was"        
## [4322] "able to see out of this gap into what had been overnight a quiet"           
## [4323] "suburban roadway.  Vast, indeed, was the change that we beheld."            
## [4324] ""                                                                           
## [4325] "The fifth cylinder must have fallen right into the midst of the"            
## [4326] "house we had first visited.  The building had vanished, completely"         
## [4327] "smashed, pulverised, and dispersed by the blow.  The cylinder lay now"      
## [4328] "far beneath the original foundations--deep in a hole, already vastly"       
## [4329] "larger than the pit I had looked into at Woking.  The earth all round"      
## [4330] "it had splashed under that tremendous impact--\"splashed\" is the only"     
## [4331] "word--and lay in heaped piles that hid the masses of the adjacent"          
## [4332] "houses.  It had behaved exactly like mud under the violent blow of a"       
## [4333] "hammer.  Our house had collapsed backward; the front portion, even on"      
## [4334] "the ground floor, had been destroyed completely; by a chance the"           
## [4335] "kitchen and scullery had escaped, and stood buried now under soil and"      
## [4336] "ruins, closed in by tons of earth on every side save towards the"           
## [4337] "cylinder.  Over that aspect we hung now on the very edge of the great"      
## [4338] "circular pit the Martians were engaged in making.  The heavy beating"       
## [4339] "sound was evidently just behind us, and ever and again a bright green"      
## [4340] "vapour drove up like a veil across our peephole."                           
## [4341] ""                                                                           
## [4342] "The cylinder was already opened in the centre of the pit, and on"           
## [4343] "the farther edge of the pit, amid the smashed and gravel-heaped"            
## [4344] "shrubbery, one of the great fighting-machines, deserted by its"             
## [4345] "occupant, stood stiff and tall against the evening sky.  At first I"        
## [4346] "scarcely noticed the pit and the cylinder, although it has been"            
## [4347] "convenient to describe them first, on account of the extraordinary"         
## [4348] "glittering mechanism I saw busy in the excavation, and on account of"       
## [4349] "the strange creatures that were crawling slowly and painfully across"       
## [4350] "the heaped mould near it."                                                  
## [4351] ""                                                                           
## [4352] "The mechanism it certainly was that held my attention first.  It"           
## [4353] "was one of those complicated fabrics that have since been called"           
## [4354] "handling-machines, and the study of which has already given such an"        
## [4355] "enormous impetus to terrestrial invention.  As it dawned upon me"           
## [4356] "first, it presented a sort of metallic spider with five jointed,"           
## [4357] "agile legs, and with an extraordinary number of jointed levers, bars,"      
## [4358] "and reaching and clutching tentacles about its body.  Most of its"          
## [4359] "arms were retracted, but with three long tentacles it was fishing"          
## [4360] "out a number of rods, plates, and bars which lined the covering and"        
## [4361] "apparently strengthened the walls of the cylinder.  These, as it"           
## [4362] "extracted them, were lifted out and deposited upon a level surface"         
## [4363] "of earth behind it."                                                        
## [4364] ""                                                                           
## [4365] "Its motion was so swift, complex, and perfect that at first I did"          
## [4366] "not see it as a machine, in spite of its metallic glitter.  The"            
## [4367] "fighting-machines were coordinated and animated to an extraordinary"        
## [4368] "pitch, but nothing to compare with this.  People who have never seen"       
## [4369] "these structures, and have only the ill-imagined efforts of artists or"     
## [4370] "the imperfect descriptions of such eye-witnesses as myself to go upon,"     
## [4371] "scarcely realise that living quality."                                      
## [4372] ""                                                                           
## [4373] "I recall particularly the illustration of one of the first"                 
## [4374] "pamphlets to give a consecutive account of the war.  The artist had"        
## [4375] "evidently made a hasty study of one of the fighting-machines, and"          
## [4376] "there his knowledge ended.  He presented them as tilted, stiff"             
## [4377] "tripods, without either flexibility or subtlety, and with an"               
## [4378] "altogether misleading monotony of effect.  The pamphlet containing"         
## [4379] "these renderings had a considerable vogue, and I mention them here"         
## [4380] "simply to warn the reader against the impression they may have"             
## [4381] "created.  They were no more like the Martians I saw in action than a"       
## [4382] "Dutch doll is like a human being.  To my mind, the pamphlet would have"     
## [4383] "been much better without them."                                             
## [4384] ""                                                                           
## [4385] "At first, I say, the handling-machine did not impress me as a"              
## [4386] "machine, but as a crablike creature with a glittering integument, the"      
## [4387] "controlling Martian whose delicate tentacles actuated its movements"        
## [4388] "seeming to be simply the equivalent of the crab's cerebral portion."        
## [4389] "But then I perceived the resemblance of its grey-brown, shiny,"             
## [4390] "leathery integument to that of the other sprawling bodies beyond, and"      
## [4391] "the true nature of this dexterous workman dawned upon me.  With that"       
## [4392] "realisation my interest shifted to those other creatures, the real"         
## [4393] "Martians.  Already I had had a transient impression of these, and the"      
## [4394] "first nausea no longer obscured my observation.  Moreover, I was"           
## [4395] "concealed and motionless, and under no urgency of action."                  
## [4396] ""                                                                           
## [4397] "They were, I now saw, the most unearthly creatures it is possible"          
## [4398] "to conceive.  They were huge round bodies--or, rather, heads--about"        
## [4399] "four feet in diameter, each body having in front of it a face.  This"       
## [4400] "face had no nostrils--indeed, the Martians do not seem to have had any"     
## [4401] "sense of smell, but it had a pair of very large dark-coloured eyes,"        
## [4402] "and just beneath this a kind of fleshy beak.  In the back of this head"     
## [4403] "or body--I scarcely know how to speak of it--was the single tight"          
## [4404] "tympanic surface, since known to be anatomically an ear, though it"         
## [4405] "must have been almost useless in our dense air.  In a group round the"      
## [4406] "mouth were sixteen slender, almost whiplike tentacles, arranged in two"     
## [4407] "bunches of eight each.  These bunches have since been named rather"         
## [4408] "aptly, by that distinguished anatomist, Professor Howes, the _hands_."      
## [4409] "Even as I saw these Martians for the first time they seemed to be"          
## [4410] "endeavouring to raise themselves on these hands, but of course, with"       
## [4411] "the increased weight of terrestrial conditions, this was impossible."       
## [4412] "There is reason to suppose that on Mars they may have progressed upon"      
## [4413] "them with some facility."                                                   
## [4414] ""                                                                           
## [4415] "The internal anatomy, I may remark here, as dissection has since"           
## [4416] "shown, was almost equally simple.  The greater part of the structure"       
## [4417] "was the brain, sending enormous nerves to the eyes, ear, and tactile"       
## [4418] "tentacles.  Besides this were the bulky lungs, into which the mouth"        
## [4419] "opened, and the heart and its vessels.  The pulmonary distress caused"      
## [4420] "by the denser atmosphere and greater gravitational attraction was only"     
## [4421] "too evident in the convulsive movements of the outer skin."                 
## [4422] ""                                                                           
## [4423] "And this was the sum of the Martian organs.  Strange as it may seem"        
## [4424] "to a human being, all the complex apparatus of digestion, which makes"      
## [4425] "up the bulk of our bodies, did not exist in the Martians.  They were"       
## [4426] "heads--merely heads.  Entrails they had none.  They did not eat, much"      
## [4427] "less digest.  Instead, they took the fresh, living blood of other"          
## [4428] "creatures, and _injected_ it into their own veins.  I have myself seen"     
## [4429] "this being done, as I shall mention in its place.  But, squeamish as I"     
## [4430] "may seem, I cannot bring myself to describe what I could not endure"        
## [4431] "even to continue watching.  Let it suffice to say, blood obtained from"     
## [4432] "a still living animal, in most cases from a human being, was run"           
## [4433] "directly by means of a little pipette into the recipient canal. . . ."      
## [4434] ""                                                                           
## [4435] "The bare idea of this is no doubt horribly repulsive to us, but at"         
## [4436] "the same time I think that we should remember how repulsive our"            
## [4437] "carnivorous habits would seem to an intelligent rabbit."                    
## [4438] ""                                                                           
## [4439] "The physiological advantages of the practice of injection are"              
## [4440] "undeniable, if one thinks of the tremendous waste of human time and"        
## [4441] "energy occasioned by eating and the digestive process.  Our bodies are"     
## [4442] "half made up of glands and tubes and organs, occupied in turning"           
## [4443] "heterogeneous food into blood.  The digestive processes and their"          
## [4444] "reaction upon the nervous system sap our strength and colour our"           
## [4445] "minds.  Men go happy or miserable as they have healthy or unhealthy"        
## [4446] "livers, or sound gastric glands.  But the Martians were lifted above"       
## [4447] "all these organic fluctuations of mood and emotion."                        
## [4448] ""                                                                           
## [4449] "Their undeniable preference for men as their source of nourishment"         
## [4450] "is partly explained by the nature of the remains of the victims they"       
## [4451] "had brought with them as provisions from Mars.  These creatures, to"        
## [4452] "judge from the shrivelled remains that have fallen into human hands,"       
## [4453] "were bipeds with flimsy, silicious skeletons (almost like those of the"     
## [4454] "silicious sponges) and feeble musculature, standing about six feet"         
## [4455] "high and having round, erect heads, and large eyes in flinty sockets."      
## [4456] "Two or three of these seem to have been brought in each cylinder, and"      
## [4457] "all were killed before earth was reached.  It was just as well for"         
## [4458] "them, for the mere attempt to stand upright upon our planet would have"     
## [4459] "broken every bone in their bodies."                                         
## [4460] ""                                                                           
## [4461] "And while I am engaged in this description, I may add in this place"        
## [4462] "certain further details which, although they were not all evident to"       
## [4463] "us at the time, will enable the reader who is unacquainted with them"       
## [4464] "to form a clearer picture of these offensive creatures."                    
## [4465] ""                                                                           
## [4466] "In three other points their physiology differed strangely from"             
## [4467] "ours.  Their organisms did not sleep, any more than the heart of man"       
## [4468] "sleeps.  Since they had no extensive muscular mechanism to recuperate,"     
## [4469] "that periodical extinction was unknown to them.  They had little or"        
## [4470] "no sense of fatigue, it would seem.  On earth they could never have"        
## [4471] "moved without effort, yet even to the last they kept in action.  In"        
## [4472] "twenty-four hours they did twenty-four hours of work, as even on earth"     
## [4473] "is perhaps the case with the ants."                                         
## [4474] ""                                                                           
## [4475] "In the next place, wonderful as it seems in a sexual world, the"            
## [4476] "Martians were absolutely without sex, and therefore without any of the"     
## [4477] "tumultuous emotions that arise from that difference among men.  A"          
## [4478] "young Martian, there can now be no dispute, was really born upon earth"     
## [4479] "during the war, and it was found attached to its parent, partially"         
## [4480] "_budded_ off, just as young lilybulbs bud off, or like the young animals"   
## [4481] "in the fresh-water polyp."                                                  
## [4482] ""                                                                           
## [4483] "In man, in all the higher terrestrial animals, such a method of"            
## [4484] "increase has disappeared; but even on this earth it was certainly the"      
## [4485] "primitive method.  Among the lower animals, up even to those first"         
## [4486] "cousins of the vertebrated animals, the Tunicates, the two processes"       
## [4487] "occur side by side, but finally the sexual method superseded its"           
## [4488] "competitor altogether.  On Mars, however, just the reverse has"             
## [4489] "apparently been the case."                                                  
## [4490] ""                                                                           
## [4491] "It is worthy of remark that a certain speculative writer of"                
## [4492] "quasi-scientific repute, writing long before the Martian invasion, did"     
## [4493] "forecast for man a final structure not unlike the actual Martian"           
## [4494] "condition.  His prophecy, I remember, appeared in November or"              
## [4495] "December, 1893, in a long-defunct publication, the _Pall Mall Budget_,"     
## [4496] "and I recall a caricature of it in a pre-Martian periodical called"         
## [4497] "_Punch_.  He pointed out--writing in a foolish, facetious tone--that the"   
## [4498] "perfection of mechanical appliances must ultimately supersede limbs;"       
## [4499] "the perfection of chemical devices, digestion; that such organs as"         
## [4500] "hair, external nose, teeth, ears, and chin were no longer essential"        
## [4501] "parts of the human being, and that the tendency of natural selection"       
## [4502] "would lie in the direction of their steady diminution through the"          
## [4503] "coming ages.  The brain alone remained a cardinal necessity.  Only one"     
## [4504] "other part of the body had a strong case for survival, and that was"        
## [4505] "the hand, \"teacher and agent of the brain.\"  While the rest of the"       
## [4506] "body dwindled, the hands would grow larger."                                
## [4507] ""                                                                           
## [4508] "There is many a true word written in jest, and here in the Martians"        
## [4509] "we have beyond dispute the actual accomplishment of such a suppression"     
## [4510] "of the animal side of the organism by the intelligence.  To me it is"       
## [4511] "quite credible that the Martians may be descended from beings not"          
## [4512] "unlike ourselves, by a gradual development of brain and hands (the"         
## [4513] "latter giving rise to the two bunches of delicate tentacles at last)"       
## [4514] "at the expense of the rest of the body.  Without the body the brain"        
## [4515] "would, of course, become a mere selfish intelligence, without any of"       
## [4516] "the emotional substratum of the human being."                               
## [4517] ""                                                                           
## [4518] "The last salient point in which the systems of these creatures"             
## [4519] "differed from ours was in what one might have thought a very trivial"       
## [4520] "particular.  Micro-organisms, which cause so much disease and pain on"      
## [4521] "earth, have either never appeared upon Mars or Martian sanitary"            
## [4522] "science eliminated them ages ago.  A hundred diseases, all the fevers"      
## [4523] "and contagions of human life, consumption, cancers, tumours and such"       
## [4524] "morbidities, never enter the scheme of their life.  And speaking of"        
## [4525] "the differences between the life on Mars and terrestrial life, I may"       
## [4526] "allude here to the curious suggestions of the red weed."                    
## [4527] ""                                                                           
## [4528] "Apparently the vegetable kingdom in Mars, instead of having green"          
## [4529] "for a dominant colour, is of a vivid blood-red tint.  At any rate, the"     
## [4530] "seeds which the Martians (intentionally or accidentally) brought with"      
## [4531] "them gave rise in all cases to red-coloured growths.  Only that known"      
## [4532] "popularly as the red weed, however, gained any footing in competition"
