## [4533] "with terrestrial forms.  The red creeper was quite a transitory"            
## [4534] "growth, and few people have seen it growing.  For a time, however, the"     
## [4535] "red weed grew with astonishing vigour and luxuriance.  It spread up"        
## [4536] "the sides of the pit by the third or fourth day of our imprisonment,"       
## [4537] "and its cactus-like branches formed a carmine fringe to the edges of"       
## [4538] "our triangular window.  And afterwards I found it broadcast throughout"     
## [4539] "the country, and especially wherever there was a stream of water."          
## [4540] ""                                                                           
## [4541] "The Martians had what appears to have been an auditory organ, a"            
## [4542] "single round drum at the back of the head-body, and eyes with a visual"     
## [4543] "range not very different from ours except that, according to Philips,"      
## [4544] "blue and violet were as black to them.  It is commonly supposed that"       
## [4545] "they communicated by sounds and tentacular gesticulations; this is"         
## [4546] "asserted, for instance, in the able but hastily compiled pamphlet"          
## [4547] "(written evidently by someone not an eye-witness of Martian actions)"       
## [4548] "to which I have already alluded, and which, so far, has been the chief"     
## [4549] "source of information concerning them.  Now no surviving human being"       
## [4550] "saw so much of the Martians in action as I did.  I take no credit to"       
## [4551] "myself for an accident, but the fact is so.  And I assert that I"           
## [4552] "watched them closely time after time, and that I have seen four, five,"     
## [4553] "and (once) six of them sluggishly performing the most elaborately"          
## [4554] "complicated operations together without either sound or gesture.  Their"    
## [4555] "peculiar hooting invariably preceded feeding; it had no modulation,"        
## [4556] "and was, I believe, in no sense a signal, but merely the expiration of"     
## [4557] "air preparatory to the suctional operation.  I have a certain claim to"     
## [4558] "at least an elementary knowledge of psychology, and in this matter I"       
## [4559] "am convinced--as firmly as I am convinced of anything--that the"            
## [4560] "Martians interchanged thoughts without any physical intermediation."        
## [4561] "And I have been convinced of this in spite of strong preconceptions."       
## [4562] "Before the Martian invasion, as an occasional reader here or there may"     
## [4563] "remember, I had written with some little vehemence against the"             
## [4564] "telepathic theory."                                                         
## [4565] ""                                                                           
## [4566] "The Martians wore no clothing.  Their conceptions of ornament and"          
## [4567] "decorum were necessarily different from ours; and not only were they"       
## [4568] "evidently much less sensible of changes of temperature than we are,"        
## [4569] "but changes of pressure do not seem to have affected their health at"       
## [4570] "all seriously.  Yet though they wore no clothing, it was in the other"      
## [4571] "artificial additions to their bodily resources that their great"            
## [4572] "superiority over man lay.  We men, with our bicycles and road-skates,"      
## [4573] "our Lilienthal soaring-machines, our guns and sticks and so forth, are"     
## [4574] "just in the beginning of the evolution that the Martians have worked"       
## [4575] "out.  They have become practically mere brains, wearing different"          
## [4576] "bodies according to their needs just as men wear suits of clothes and"      
## [4577] "take a bicycle in a hurry or an umbrella in the wet.  And of their"         
## [4578] "appliances, perhaps nothing is more wonderful to a man than the"            
## [4579] "curious fact that what is the dominant feature of almost all human"         
## [4580] "devices in mechanism is absent--the _wheel_ is absent; among all the"       
## [4581] "things they brought to earth there is no trace or suggestion of their"      
## [4582] "use of wheels.  One would have at least expected it in locomotion.  And"    
## [4583] "in this connection it is curious to remark that even on this earth"         
## [4584] "Nature has never hit upon the wheel, or has preferred other expedients"     
## [4585] "to its development.  And not only did the Martians either not know of"      
## [4586] "(which is incredible), or abstain from, the wheel, but in their"            
## [4587] "apparatus singularly little use is made of the fixed pivot or"              
## [4588] "relatively fixed pivot, with circular motions thereabout confined"          
## [4589] "to one plane.  Almost all the joints of the machinery present a"            
## [4590] "complicated system of sliding parts moving over small but beautifully"      
## [4591] "curved friction bearings.  And while upon this matter of detail, it is"     
## [4592] "remarkable that the long leverages of their machines are in most cases"     
## [4593] "actuated by a sort of sham musculature of the disks in an elastic"          
## [4594] "sheath; these disks become polarised and drawn closely and powerfully"      
## [4595] "together when traversed by a current of electricity.  In this way the"      
## [4596] "curious parallelism to animal motions, which was so striking and"           
## [4597] "disturbing to the human beholder, was attained.  Such quasi-muscles"        
## [4598] "abounded in the crablike handling-machine which, on my first peeping"       
## [4599] "out of the slit, I watched unpacking the cylinder.  It seemed"              
## [4600] "infinitely more alive than the actual Martians lying beyond it in the"      
## [4601] "sunset light, panting, stirring ineffectual tentacles, and moving"          
## [4602] "feebly after their vast journey across space."                              
## [4603] ""                                                                           
## [4604] "While I was still watching their sluggish motions in the sunlight,"         
## [4605] "and noting each strange detail of their form, the curate reminded me"       
## [4606] "of his presence by pulling violently at my arm.  I turned to a"             
## [4607] "scowling face, and silent, eloquent lips.  He wanted the slit, which"       
## [4608] "permitted only one of us to peep through; and so I had to forego"           
## [4609] "watching them for a time while he enjoyed that privilege."                  
## [4610] ""                                                                           
## [4611] "When I looked again, the busy handling-machine had already put"             
## [4612] "together several of the pieces of apparatus it had taken out of the"        
## [4613] "cylinder into a shape having an unmistakable likeness to its own; and"      
## [4614] "down on the left a busy little digging mechanism had come into view,"       
## [4615] "emitting jets of green vapour and working its way round the pit,"           
## [4616] "excavating and embanking in a methodical and discriminating manner."        
## [4617] "This it was which had caused the regular beating noise, and the"            
## [4618] "rhythmic shocks that had kept our ruinous refuge quivering.  It piped"      
## [4619] "and whistled as it worked.  So far as I could see, the thing was"           
## [4620] "without a directing Martian at all."                                        
## [4621] ""                                                                           
## [4622] ""                                                                           
## [4623] ""                                                                           
## [4624] "CHAPTER THREE"                                                              
## [4625] ""                                                                           
## [4626] "THE DAYS OF IMPRISONMENT"                                                   
## [4627] ""                                                                           
## [4628] ""                                                                           
## [4629] "The arrival of a second fighting-machine drove us from our peephole"        
## [4630] "into the scullery, for we feared that from his elevation the Martian"       
## [4631] "might see down upon us behind our barrier.  At a later date we began"       
## [4632] "to feel less in danger of their eyes, for to an eye in the dazzle of"       
## [4633] "the sunlight outside our refuge must have been blank blackness, but at"     
## [4634] "first the slightest suggestion of approach drove us into the scullery"      
## [4635] "in heart-throbbing retreat.  Yet terrible as was the danger we"             
## [4636] "incurred, the attraction of peeping was for both of us irresistible."       
## [4637] "And I recall now with a sort of wonder that, in spite of the infinite"      
## [4638] "danger in which we were between starvation and a still more terrible"       
## [4639] "death, we could yet struggle bitterly for that horrible privilege of"       
## [4640] "sight.  We would race across the kitchen in a grotesque way between"        
## [4641] "eagerness and the dread of making a noise, and strike each other, and"      
## [4642] "thrust and kick, within a few inches of exposure."                          
## [4643] ""                                                                           
## [4644] "The fact is that we had absolutely incompatible dispositions and"           
## [4645] "habits of thought and action, and our danger and isolation only"            
## [4646] "accentuated the incompatibility.  At Halliford I had already come to"       
## [4647] "hate the curate's trick of helpless exclamation, his stupid rigidity"       
## [4648] "of mind.  His endless muttering monologue vitiated every effort I made"     
## [4649] "to think out a line of action, and drove me at times, thus pent up and"     
## [4650] "intensified, almost to the verge of craziness.  He was as lacking in"       
## [4651] "restraint as a silly woman.  He would weep for hours together, and I"       
## [4652] "verily believe that to the very end this spoiled child of life thought"     
## [4653] "his weak tears in some way efficacious.  And I would sit in the"            
## [4654] "darkness unable to keep my mind off him by reason of his"                   
## [4655] "importunities.  He ate more than I did, and it was in vain I pointed"       
## [4656] "out that our only chance of life was to stop in the house until the"        
## [4657] "Martians had done with their pit, that in that long patience a time"        
## [4658] "might presently come when we should need food.  He ate and drank"           
## [4659] "impulsively in heavy meals at long intervals.  He slept little."            
## [4660] ""                                                                           
## [4661] "As the days wore on, his utter carelessness of any consideration so"        
## [4662] "intensified our distress and danger that I had, much as I loathed"          
## [4663] "doing it, to resort to threats, and at last to blows.  That brought him"    
## [4664] "to reason for a time.  But he was one of those weak creatures, void of"     
## [4665] "pride, timorous, anaemic, hateful souls, full of shifty cunning, who"       
## [4666] "face neither God nor man, who face not even themselves."                    
## [4667] ""                                                                           
## [4668] "It is disagreeable for me to recall and write these things, but I"          
## [4669] "set them down that my story may lack nothing.  Those who have escaped"      
## [4670] "the dark and terrible aspects of life will find my brutality, my flash"     
## [4671] "of rage in our final tragedy, easy enough to blame; for they know what"     
## [4672] "is wrong as well as any, but not what is possible to tortured men.  But"    
## [4673] "those who have been under the shadow, who have gone down at last to"        
## [4674] "elemental things, will have a wider charity."                               
## [4675] ""                                                                           
## [4676] "And while within we fought out our dark, dim contest of whispers,"          
## [4677] "snatched food and drink, and gripping hands and blows, without, in the"     
## [4678] "pitiless sunlight of that terrible June, was the strange wonder, the"       
## [4679] "unfamiliar routine of the Martians in the pit.  Let me return to those"     
## [4680] "first new experiences of mine.  After a long time I ventured back to"       
## [4681] "the peephole, to find that the new-comers had been reinforced by the"       
## [4682] "occupants of no fewer than three of the fighting-machines.  These last"     
## [4683] "had brought with them certain fresh appliances that stood in an"            
## [4684] "orderly manner about the cylinder.  The second handling-machine was now"    
## [4685] "completed, and was busied in serving one of the novel contrivances the"     
## [4686] "big machine had brought.  This was a body resembling a milk can in its"     
## [4687] "general form, above which oscillated a pear-shaped receptacle, and"         
## [4688] "from which a stream of white powder flowed into a circular basin"           
## [4689] "below."                                                                     
## [4690] ""                                                                           
## [4691] "The oscillatory motion was imparted to this by one tentacle of the"         
## [4692] "handling-machine.  With two spatulate hands the handling-machine was"       
## [4693] "digging out and flinging masses of clay into the pear-shaped"               
## [4694] "receptacle above, while with another arm it periodically opened a door"     
## [4695] "and removed rusty and blackened clinkers from the middle part of the"       
## [4696] "machine.  Another steely tentacle directed the powder from the basin"       
## [4697] "along a ribbed channel towards some receiver that was hidden from me"       
## [4698] "by the mound of bluish dust.  From this unseen receiver a little"           
## [4699] "thread of green smoke rose vertically into the quiet air.  As I looked,"    
## [4700] "the handling-machine, with a faint and musical clinking, extended,"         
## [4701] "telescopic fashion, a tentacle that had been a moment before a mere"        
## [4702] "blunt projection, until its end was hidden behind the mound of clay."       
## [4703] "In another second it had lifted a bar of white aluminium into sight,"       
## [4704] "untarnished as yet, and shining dazzlingly, and deposited it in a"          
## [4705] "growing stack of bars that stood at the side of the pit.  Between"          
## [4706] "sunset and starlight this dexterous machine must have made more than a"     
## [4707] "hundred such bars out of the crude clay, and the mound of bluish dust"      
## [4708] "rose steadily until it topped the side of the pit."                         
## [4709] ""                                                                           
## [4710] "The contrast between the swift and complex movements of these"              
## [4711] "contrivances and the inert panting clumsiness of their masters was"         
## [4712] "acute, and for days I had to tell myself repeatedly that these latter"      
## [4713] "were indeed the living of the two things."                                  
## [4714] ""                                                                           
## [4715] "The curate had possession of the slit when the first men were"              
## [4716] "brought to the pit.  I was sitting below, huddled up, listening with"       
## [4717] "all my ears.  He made a sudden movement backward, and I, fearful that"      
## [4718] "we were observed, crouched in a spasm of terror.  He came sliding down"     
## [4719] "the rubbish and crept beside me in the darkness, inarticulate,"             
## [4720] "gesticulating, and for a moment I shared his panic.  His gesture"           
## [4721] "suggested a resignation of the slit, and after a little while my"           
## [4722] "curiosity gave me courage, and I rose up, stepped across him, and"          
## [4723] "clambered up to it.  At first I could see no reason for his frantic"        
## [4724] "behaviour.  The twilight had now come, the stars were little and"           
## [4725] "faint, but the pit was illuminated by the flickering green fire that"       
## [4726] "came from the aluminium-making.  The whole picture was a flickering"        
## [4727] "scheme of green gleams and shifting rusty black shadows, strangely"         
## [4728] "trying to the eyes.  Over and through it all went the bats, heeding it"     
## [4729] "not at all.  The sprawling Martians were no longer to be seen, the"         
## [4730] "mound of blue-green powder had risen to cover them from sight, and a"       
## [4731] "fighting-machine, with its legs contracted, crumpled, and abbreviated,"     
## [4732] "stood across the corner of the pit.  And then, amid the clangour of"        
## [4733] "the machinery, came a drifting suspicion of human voices, that I"           
## [4734] "entertained at first only to dismiss."                                      
## [4735] ""                                                                           
## [4736] "I crouched, watching this fighting-machine closely, satisfying"             
## [4737] "myself now for the first time that the hood did indeed contain a"           
## [4738] "Martian.  As the green flames lifted I could see the oily gleam of"         
## [4739] "his integument and the brightness of his eyes.  And suddenly I heard"       
## [4740] "a yell, and saw a long tentacle reaching over the shoulder of the"          
## [4741] "machine to the little cage that hunched upon its back.  Then"               
## [4742] "something--something struggling violently--was lifted high against the"     
## [4743] "sky, a black, vague enigma against the starlight; and as this black"        
## [4744] "object came down again, I saw by the green brightness that it was a"        
## [4745] "man.  For an instant he was clearly visible.  He was a stout, ruddy,"       
## [4746] "middle-aged man, well dressed; three days before, he must have been"        
## [4747] "walking the world, a man of considerable consequence.  I could see his"     
## [4748] "staring eyes and gleams of light on his studs and watch chain.  He"         
## [4749] "vanished behind the mound, and for a moment there was silence.  And"        
## [4750] "then began a shrieking and a sustained and cheerful hooting from the"       
## [4751] "Martians."                                                                  
## [4752] ""                                                                           
## [4753] "I slid down the rubbish, struggled to my feet, clapped my hands"            
## [4754] "over my ears, and bolted into the scullery.  The curate, who had been"      
## [4755] "crouching silently with his arms over his head, looked up as I passed,"     
## [4756] "cried out quite loudly at my desertion of him, and came running after"      
## [4757] "me."                                                                        
## [4758] ""                                                                           
## [4759] "That night, as we lurked in the scullery, balanced between our"             
## [4760] "horror and the terrible fascination this peeping had, although I felt"      
## [4761] "an urgent need of action I tried in vain to conceive some plan of"          
## [4762] "escape; but afterwards, during the second day, I was able to consider"      
## [4763] "our position with great clearness.  The curate, I found, was quite"         
## [4764] "incapable of discussion; this new and culminating atrocity had robbed"      
## [4765] "him of all vestiges of reason or forethought.  Practically he had"          
## [4766] "already sunk to the level of an animal.  But as the saying goes, I"         
## [4767] "gripped myself with both hands.  It grew upon my mind, once I could"        
## [4768] "face the facts, that terrible as our position was, there was as yet"        
## [4769] "no justification for absolute despair.  Our chief chance lay in the"        
## [4770] "possibility of the Martians making the pit nothing more than a"             
## [4771] "temporary encampment.  Or even if they kept it permanently, they might"     
## [4772] "not consider it necessary to guard it, and a chance of escape might be"     
## [4773] "afforded us.  I also weighed very carefully the possibility of our"         
## [4774] "digging a way out in a direction away from the pit, but the chances of"     
## [4775] "our emerging within sight of some sentinel fighting-machine seemed at"      
## [4776] "first too great.  And I should have had to do all the digging myself."      
## [4777] "The curate would certainly have failed me."                                 
## [4778] ""                                                                           
## [4779] "It was on the third day, if my memory serves me right, that I saw"          
## [4780] "the lad killed.  It was the only occasion on which I actually saw the"      
## [4781] "Martians feed.  After that experience I avoided the hole in the wall"       
## [4782] "for the better part of a day.  I went into the scullery, removed the"       
## [4783] "door, and spent some hours digging with my hatchet as silently as"          
## [4784] "possible; but when I had made a hole about a couple of feet deep the"       
## [4785] "loose earth collapsed noisily, and I did not dare continue.  I lost"        
## [4786] "heart, and lay down on the scullery floor for a long time, having no"       
## [4787] "spirit even to move.  And after that I abandoned altogether the idea"       
## [4788] "of escaping by excavation."                                                 
## [4789] ""                                                                           
## [4790] "It says much for the impression the Martians had made upon me that"         
## [4791] "at first I entertained little or no hope of our escape being brought"       
## [4792] "about by their overthrow through any human effort.  But on the fourth"      
## [4793] "or fifth night I heard a sound like heavy guns."                            
## [4794] ""                                                                           
## [4795] "It was very late in the night, and the moon was shining brightly."          
## [4796] "The Martians had taken away the excavating-machine, and, save for a"        
## [4797] "fighting-machine that stood in the remoter bank of the pit and a"           
## [4798] "handling-machine that was buried out of my sight in a corner of the"        
## [4799] "pit immediately beneath my peephole, the place was deserted by them."       
## [4800] "Except for the pale glow from the handling-machine and the bars and"        
## [4801] "patches of white moonlight the pit was in darkness, and, except for"        
## [4802] "the clinking of the handling-machine, quite still.  That night was a"       
## [4803] "beautiful serenity; save for one planet, the moon seemed to have the"       
## [4804] "sky to herself.  I heard a dog howling, and that familiar sound it was"     
## [4805] "that made me listen.  Then I heard quite distinctly a booming exactly"      
## [4806] "like the sound of great guns.  Six distinct reports I counted, and"         
## [4807] "after a long interval six again.  And that was all."                        
## [4808] ""                                                                           
## [4809] ""                                                                           
## [4810] ""                                                                           
## [4811] "CHAPTER FOUR"                                                               
## [4812] ""                                                                           
## [4813] "THE DEATH OF THE CURATE"                                                    
## [4814] ""                                                                           
## [4815] ""                                                                           
## [4816] "It was on the sixth day of our imprisonment that I peeped for the"          
## [4817] "last time, and presently found myself alone.  Instead of keeping close"     
## [4818] "to me and trying to oust me from the slit, the curate had gone back"        
## [4819] "into the scullery.  I was struck by a sudden thought.  I went back"         
## [4820] "quickly and quietly into the scullery.  In the darkness I heard the"        
## [4821] "curate drinking.  I snatched in the darkness, and my fingers caught a"      
## [4822] "bottle of burgundy."                                                        
## [4823] ""                                                                           
## [4824] "For a few minutes there was a tussle.  The bottle struck the floor"         
## [4825] "and broke, and I desisted and rose.  We stood panting and threatening"      
## [4826] "each other.  In the end I planted myself between him and the food, and"     
## [4827] "told him of my determination to begin a discipline.  I divided the"         
## [4828] "food in the pantry, into rations to last us ten days.  I would not let"     
## [4829] "him eat any more that day.  In the afternoon he made a feeble effort"       
## [4830] "to get at the food.  I had been dozing, but in an instant I was awake."     
## [4831] "All day and all night we sat face to face, I weary but resolute, and"       
## [4832] "he weeping and complaining of his immediate hunger.  It was, I know, a"     
## [4833] "night and a day, but to me it seemed--it seems now--an interminable"        
## [4834] "length of time."                                                            
## [4835] ""                                                                           
## [4836] "And so our widened incompatibility ended at last in open conflict."         
## [4837] "For two vast days we struggled in undertones and wrestling contests."       
## [4838] "There were times when I beat and kicked him madly, times when I"            
## [4839] "cajoled and persuaded him, and once I tried to bribe him with the last"     
## [4840] "bottle of burgundy, for there was a rain-water pump from which I could"     
## [4841] "get water.  But neither force nor kindness availed; he was indeed"          
## [4842] "beyond reason.  He would neither desist from his attacks on the food"       
## [4843] "nor from his noisy babbling to himself.  The rudimentary precautions"       
## [4844] "to keep our imprisonment endurable he would not observe.  Slowly I"         
## [4845] "began to realise the complete overthrow of his intelligence, to"            
## [4846] "perceive that my sole companion in this close and sickly darkness was"      
## [4847] "a man insane."                                                              
## [4848] ""                                                                           
## [4849] "From certain vague memories I am inclined to think my own mind"             
## [4850] "wandered at times.  I had strange and hideous dreams whenever I slept."     
## [4851] "It sounds paradoxical, but I am inclined to think that the weakness"        
## [4852] "and insanity of the curate warned me, braced me, and kept me a sane"        
## [4853] "man."                                                                       
## [4854] ""                                                                           
## [4855] "On the eighth day he began to talk aloud instead of whispering, and"        
## [4856] "nothing I could do would moderate his speech."                              
## [4857] ""                                                                           
## [4858] "\"It is just, O God!\" he would say, over and over again. \"It is"          
## [4859] "just.  On me and mine be the punishment laid.  We have sinned, we have"     
## [4860] "fallen short.  There was poverty, sorrow; the poor were trodden in"         
## [4861] "the dust, and I held my peace.  I preached acceptable folly--my God,"       
## [4862] "what folly!--when I should have stood up, though I died for it, and"        
## [4863] "called upon them to repent--repent! . . .  Oppressors of the poor and"      
## [4864] "needy . . . !  The wine press of God!\""                                    
## [4865] ""                                                                           
## [4866] "Then he would suddenly revert to the matter of the food I withheld"         
## [4867] "from him, praying, begging, weeping, at last threatening.  He began to"     
## [4868] "raise his voice--I prayed him not to.  He perceived a hold on me--he"       
## [4869] "threatened he would shout and bring the Martians upon us.  For a time"      
## [4870] "that scared me; but any concession would have shortened our chance of"      
## [4871] "escape beyond estimating.  I defied him, although I felt no assurance"      
## [4872] "that he might not do this thing.  But that day, at any rate, he did"        
## [4873] "not.  He talked with his voice rising slowly, through the greater part"     
## [4874] "of the eighth and ninth days--threats, entreaties, mingled with a"          
## [4875] "torrent of half-sane and always frothy repentance for his vacant sham"      
## [4876] "of God's service, such as made me pity him.  Then he slept awhile, and"     
## [4877] "began again with renewed strength, so loudly that I must needs make"        
## [4878] "him desist."                                                                
## [4879] ""                                                                           
## [4880] "\"Be still!\" I implored."                                                  
## [4881] ""                                                                           
## [4882] "He rose to his knees, for he had been sitting in the darkness near"         
## [4883] "the copper."                                                                
## [4884] ""                                                                           
## [4885] "\"I have been still too long,\" he said, in a tone that must have"          
## [4886] "reached the pit, \"and now I must bear my witness.  Woe unto this"          
## [4887] "unfaithful city!  Woe!  Woe!  Woe!  Woe!  Woe! To the inhabitants of"       
## [4888] "the earth by reason of the other voices of the trumpet----\""               
## [4889] ""                                                                           
## [4890] "\"Shut up!\" I said, rising to my feet, and in a terror lest the"           
## [4891] "Martians should hear us.  \"For God's sake----\""                           
## [4892] ""                                                                           
## [4893] "\"Nay,\" shouted the curate, at the top of his voice, standing"             
## [4894] "likewise and extending his arms.  \"Speak!  The word of the Lord is"        
## [4895] "upon me!\""                                                                 
## [4896] ""                                                                           
## [4897] "In three strides he was at the door leading into the kitchen."              
## [4898] ""                                                                           
## [4899] "\"I must bear my witness!  I go!  It has already been too long"             
## [4900] "delayed.\""                                                                 
## [4901] ""                                                                           
## [4902] "I put out my hand and felt the meat chopper hanging to the wall."           
## [4903] "In a flash I was after him.  I was fierce with fear.  Before he was"        
## [4904] "halfway across the kitchen I had overtaken him.  With one last touch"       
## [4905] "of humanity I turned the blade back and struck him with the butt.  He"      
## [4906] "went headlong forward and lay stretched on the ground.  I stumbled"         
## [4907] "over him and stood panting.  He lay still."                                 
## [4908] ""                                                                           
## [4909] "Suddenly I heard a noise without, the run and smash of slipping"            
## [4910] "plaster, and the triangular aperture in the wall was darkened.  I"          
## [4911] "looked up and saw the lower surface of a handling-machine coming"           
## [4912] "slowly across the hole.  One of its gripping limbs curled amid the"         
## [4913] "debris; another limb appeared, feeling its way over the fallen beams."      
## [4914] "I stood petrified, staring.  Then I saw through a sort of glass plate"      
## [4915] "near the edge of the body the face, as we may call it, and the large"       
## [4916] "dark eyes of a Martian, peering, and then a long metallic snake of"         
## [4917] "tentacle came feeling slowly through the hole."                             
## [4918] ""                                                                           
## [4919] "I turned by an effort, stumbled over the curate, and stopped at the"        
## [4920] "scullery door.  The tentacle was now some way, two yards or more, in"       
## [4921] "the room, and twisting and turning, with queer sudden movements, this"      
## [4922] "way and that.  For a while I stood fascinated by that slow, fitful"         
## [4923] "advance.  Then, with a faint, hoarse cry, I forced myself across the"       
## [4924] "scullery.  I trembled violently; I could scarcely stand upright.  I"        
## [4925] "opened the door of the coal cellar, and stood there in the darkness"        
## [4926] "staring at the faintly lit doorway into the kitchen, and listening."        
## [4927] "Had the Martian seen me?  What was it doing now?"                           
## [4928] ""                                                                           
## [4929] "Something was moving to and fro there, very quietly; every now and"         
## [4930] "then it tapped against the wall, or started on its movements with a"        
## [4931] "faint metallic ringing, like the movements of keys on a split-ring."        
## [4932] "Then a heavy body--I knew too well what--was dragged across the floor"      
## [4933] "of the kitchen towards the opening.  Irresistibly attracted, I crept"       
## [4934] "to the door and peeped into the kitchen.  In the triangle of bright"        
## [4935] "outer sunlight I saw the Martian, in its Briareus of a handling-machine,"   
## [4936] "scrutinizing the curate's head.  I thought at once that it would infer"     
## [4937] "my presence from the mark of the blow I had given him."                     
## [4938] ""                                                                           
## [4939] "I crept back to the coal cellar, shut the door, and began to cover"         
## [4940] "myself up as much as I could, and as noiselessly as possible in the"        
## [4941] "darkness, among the firewood and coal therein.  Every now and then I"       
## [4942] "paused, rigid, to hear if the Martian had thrust its tentacles through"     
## [4943] "the opening again."                                                         
## [4944] ""                                                                           
## [4945] "Then the faint metallic jingle returned.  I traced it slowly"               
## [4946] "feeling over the kitchen.  Presently I heard it nearer--in the"             
## [4947] "scullery, as I judged.  I thought that its length might be"                 
## [4948] "insufficient to reach me.  I prayed copiously.  It passed, scraping"        
## [4949] "faintly across the cellar door.  An age of almost intolerable suspense"     
## [4950] "intervened; then I heard it fumbling at the latch! It had found the"        
## [4951] "door!  The Martians understood doors!"                                      
## [4952] ""                                                                           
## [4953] "It worried at the catch for a minute, perhaps, and then the door"           
## [4954] "opened."                                                                    
## [4955] ""                                                                           
## [4956] "In the darkness I could just see the thing--like an elephant's"             
## [4957] "trunk more than anything else--waving towards me and touching and"          
## [4958] "examining the wall, coals, wood and ceiling.  It was like a black worm"     
## [4959] "swaying its blind head to and fro."                                         
## [4960] ""                                                                           
## [4961] "Once, even, it touched the heel of my boot.  I was on the verge of"         
## [4962] "screaming; I bit my hand.  For a time the tentacle was silent.  I"          
## [4963] "could have fancied it had been withdrawn.  Presently, with an abrupt"       
## [4964] "click, it gripped something--I thought it had me!--and seemed to go"        
## [4965] "out of the cellar again.  For a minute I was not sure.  Apparently it"      
## [4966] "had taken a lump of coal to examine."                                       
## [4967] ""                                                                           
## [4968] "I seized the opportunity of slightly shifting my position, which"           
## [4969] "had become cramped, and then listened.  I whispered passionate prayers"     
## [4970] "for safety."                                                                
## [4971] ""                                                                           
## [4972] "Then I heard the slow, deliberate sound creeping towards me again."         
## [4973] "Slowly, slowly it drew near, scratching against the walls and tapping"      
## [4974] "the furniture."                                                             
## [4975] ""                                                                           
## [4976] "While I was still doubtful, it rapped smartly against the cellar"           
## [4977] "door and closed it.  I heard it go into the pantry, and the biscuit-tins"   
## [4978] "rattled and a bottle smashed, and then came a heavy bump against"           
## [4979] "the cellar door.  Then silence that passed into an infinity of"             
## [4980] "suspense."                                                                  
## [4981] ""                                                                           
## [4982] "Had it gone?"                                                               
## [4983] ""                                                                           
## [4984] "At last I decided that it had."                                             
## [4985] ""                                                                           
## [4986] "It came into the scullery no more; but I lay all the tenth day in"          
## [4987] "the close darkness, buried among coals and firewood, not daring even"       
## [4988] "to crawl out for the drink for which I craved.  It was the eleventh day"    
## [4989] "before I ventured so far from my security."                                 
## [4990] ""                                                                           
## [4991] ""                                                                           
## [4992] ""                                                                           
## [4993] "CHAPTER FIVE"                                                               
## [4994] ""                                                                           
## [4995] "THE STILLNESS"                                                              
## [4996] ""                                                                           
## [4997] ""                                                                           
## [4998] "My first act before I went into the pantry was to fasten the door"          
## [4999] "between the kitchen and the scullery.  But the pantry was empty; every"     
## [5000] "scrap of food had gone.  Apparently, the Martian had taken it all on"       
## [5001] "the previous day.  At that discovery I despaired for the first time.  I"    
## [5002] "took no food, or no drink either, on the eleventh or the twelfth day."      
## [5003] ""                                                                           
## [5004] "At first my mouth and throat were parched, and my strength ebbed"           
## [5005] "sensibly.  I sat about in the darkness of the scullery, in a state of"      
## [5006] "despondent wretchedness.  My mind ran on eating.  I thought I had"          
## [5007] "become deaf, for the noises of movement I had been accustomed to hear"      
## [5008] "from the pit had ceased absolutely.  I did not feel strong enough to"       
## [5009] "crawl noiselessly to the peephole, or I would have gone there."             
## [5010] ""                                                                           
## [5011] "On the twelfth day my throat was so painful that, taking the chance"        
## [5012] "of alarming the Martians, I attacked the creaking rain-water pump that"     
## [5013] "stood by the sink, and got a couple of glassfuls of blackened and"          
## [5014] "tainted rain water.  I was greatly refreshed by this, and emboldened"       
## [5015] "by the fact that no enquiring tentacle followed the noise of my"            
## [5016] "pumping."                                                                   
## [5017] ""                                                                           
## [5018] "During these days, in a rambling, inconclusive way, I thought much"         
## [5019] "of the curate and of the manner of his death."                              
## [5020] ""                                                                           
## [5021] "On the thirteenth day I drank some more water, and dozed and"               
## [5022] "thought disjointedly of eating and of vague impossible plans of"            
## [5023] "escape.  Whenever I dozed I dreamt of horrible phantasms, of the death"     
## [5024] "of the curate, or of sumptuous dinners; but, asleep or awake, I felt a"     
## [5025] "keen pain that urged me to drink again and again.  The light that came"     
## [5026] "into the scullery was no longer grey, but red.  To my disordered"           
## [5027] "imagination it seemed the colour of blood."                                 
## [5028] ""                                                                           
## [5029] "On the fourteenth day I went into the kitchen, and I was surprised"         
## [5030] "to find that the fronds of the red weed had grown right across"             
## [5031] "the hole in the wall, turning the half-light of the place into a"           
## [5032] "crimson-coloured obscurity."                                                
## [5033] ""                                                                           
## [5034] "It was early on the fifteenth day that I heard a curious, familiar"         
## [5035] "sequence of sounds in the kitchen, and, listening, identified it as"        
## [5036] "the snuffing and scratching of a dog.  Going into the kitchen, I saw a"     
## [5037] "dog's nose peering in through a break among the ruddy fronds.  This"        
## [5038] "greatly surprised me.  At the scent of me he barked shortly."               
## [5039] ""                                                                           
## [5040] "I thought if I could induce him to come into the place quietly I"           
## [5041] "should be able, perhaps, to kill and eat him; and in any case, it"          
## [5042] "would be advisable to kill him, lest his actions attracted the"             
## [5043] "attention of the Martians."                                                 
## [5044] ""                                                                           
## [5045] "I crept forward, saying \"Good dog!\" very softly; but he suddenly"         
## [5046] "withdrew his head and disappeared."                                         
## [5047] ""                                                                           
## [5048] "I listened--I was not deaf--but certainly the pit was still.  I"            
## [5049] "heard a sound like the flutter of a bird's wings, and a hoarse"             
## [5050] "croaking, but that was all."                                                
## [5051] ""                                                                           
## [5052] "For a long while I lay close to the peephole, but not daring to"            
## [5053] "move aside the red plants that obscured it.  Once or twice I heard a"       
## [5054] "faint pitter-patter like the feet of the dog going hither and thither"      
## [5055] "on the sand far below me, and there were more birdlike sounds, but"         
## [5056] "that was all.  At length, encouraged by the silence, I looked out."         
## [5057] ""                                                                           
## [5058] "Except in the corner, where a multitude of crows hopped and fought"         
## [5059] "over the skeletons of the dead the Martians had consumed, there was"        
## [5060] "not a living thing in the pit."                                             
## [5061] ""                                                                           
## [5062] "I stared about me, scarcely believing my eyes.  All the machinery"          
## [5063] "had gone.  Save for the big mound of greyish-blue powder in one"            
## [5064] "corner, certain bars of aluminium in another, the black birds, and the"     
## [5065] "skeletons of the killed, the place was merely an empty circular pit in"     
## [5066] "the sand."                                                                  
## [5067] ""                                                                           
## [5068] "Slowly I thrust myself out through the red weed, and stood upon the"        
## [5069] "mound of rubble.  I could see in any direction save behind me, to the"      
## [5070] "north, and neither Martians nor sign of Martians were to be seen.  The"     
## [5071] "pit dropped sheerly from my feet, but a little way along the rubbish"       
## [5072] "afforded a practicable slope to the summit of the ruins.  My chance of"     
## [5073] "escape had come.  I began to tremble."                                      
## [5074] ""                                                                           
## [5075] "I hesitated for some time, and then, in a gust of desperate"                
## [5076] "resolution, and with a heart that throbbed violently, I scrambled to"       
## [5077] "the top of the mound in which I had been buried so long."                   
## [5078] ""                                                                           
## [5079] "I looked about again.  To the northward, too, no Martian was"               
## [5080] "visible."                                                                   
## [5081] ""                                                                           
## [5082] "When I had last seen this part of Sheen in the daylight it had been"        
## [5083] "a straggling street of comfortable white and red houses, interspersed"      
## [5084] "with abundant shady trees.  Now I stood on a mound of smashed"              
## [5085] "brickwork, clay, and gravel, over which spread a multitude of red"          
## [5086] "cactus-shaped plants, knee-high, without a solitary terrestrial growth"     
## [5087] "to dispute their footing.  The trees near me were dead and brown, but"      
## [5088] "further a network of red thread scaled the still living stems."             
## [5089] ""                                                                           
## [5090] "The neighbouring houses had all been wrecked, but none had been"            
## [5091] "burned; their walls stood, sometimes to the second story, with smashed"     
## [5092] "windows and shattered doors.  The red weed grew tumultuously in their"      
## [5093] "roofless rooms.  Below me was the great pit, with the crows struggling"     
## [5094] "for its refuse.  A number of other birds hopped about among the ruins."     
## [5095] "Far away I saw a gaunt cat slink crouchingly along a wall, but traces"      
## [5096] "of men there were none."                                                    
## [5097] ""                                                                           
## [5098] "The day seemed, by contrast with my recent confinement, dazzlingly"         
## [5099] "bright, the sky a glowing blue.  A gentle breeze kept the red weed"         
## [5100] "that covered every scrap of unoccupied ground gently swaying.  And oh!"     
## [5101] "the sweetness of the air!"                                                  
## [5102] ""                                                                           
## [5103] ""                                                                           
## [5104] ""                                                                           
## [5105] "CHAPTER SIX"                                                                
## [5106] ""                                                                           
## [5107] "THE WORK OF FIFTEEN DAYS"                                                   
## [5108] ""                                                                           
## [5109] ""                                                                           
## [5110] "For some time I stood tottering on the mound regardless of my"              
## [5111] "safety.  Within that noisome den from which I had emerged I had"            
## [5112] "thought with a narrow intensity only of our immediate security.  I had"     
## [5113] "not realised what had been happening to the world, had not anticipated"     
## [5114] "this startling vision of unfamiliar things.  I had expected to see"         
## [5115] "Sheen in ruins--I found about me the landscape, weird and lurid, of"        
## [5116] "another planet."                                                            
## [5117] ""                                                                           
## [5118] "For that moment I touched an emotion beyond the common range of"            
## [5119] "men, yet one that the poor brutes we dominate know only too well.  I"       
## [5120] "felt as a rabbit might feel returning to his burrow and suddenly"           
## [5121] "confronted by the work of a dozen busy navvies digging the foundations"     
## [5122] "of a house.  I felt the first inkling of a thing that presently grew"       
## [5123] "quite clear in my mind, that oppressed me for many days, a sense of"        
## [5124] "dethronement, a persuasion that I was no longer a master, but an"           
## [5125] "animal among the animals, under the Martian heel.  With us it would be"     
## [5126] "as with them, to lurk and watch, to run and hide; the fear and empire"      
## [5127] "of man had passed away."                                                    
## [5128] ""                                                                           
## [5129] "But so soon as this strangeness had been realised it passed, and my"        
## [5130] "dominant motive became the hunger of my long and dismal fast.  In the"      
## [5131] "direction away from the pit I saw, beyond a red-covered wall, a patch"      
## [5132] "of garden ground unburied.  This gave me a hint, and I went knee-deep,"     
## [5133] "and sometimes neck-deep, in the red weed.  The density of the"              
## [5134] "weed gave me a reassuring sense of hiding.  The wall was some six feet"     
## [5135] "high, and when I attempted to clamber it I found I could not lift my"       
## [5136] "feet to the crest.  So I went along by the side of it, and came to a"       
## [5137] "corner and a rockwork that enabled me to get to the top, and tumble"        
## [5138] "into the garden I coveted.  Here I found some young onions, a couple"       
## [5139] "of gladiolus bulbs, and a quantity of immature carrots, all of which I"     
## [5140] "secured, and, scrambling over a ruined wall, went on my way through"        
## [5141] "scarlet and crimson trees towards Kew--it was like walking through an"      
## [5142] "avenue of gigantic blood drops--possessed with two ideas: to get more"      
## [5143] "food, and to limp, as soon and as far as my strength permitted, out of"     
## [5144] "this accursed unearthly region of the pit."                                 
## [5145] ""                                                                           
## [5146] "Some way farther, in a grassy place, was a group of mushrooms which"        
## [5147] "also I devoured, and then I came upon a brown sheet of flowing shallow"     
## [5148] "water, where meadows used to be.  These fragments of nourishment served"    
## [5149] "only to whet my hunger.  At first I was surprised at this flood in a"       
## [5150] "hot, dry summer, but afterwards I discovered that it was caused by the"     
## [5151] "tropical exuberance of the red weed.  Directly this extraordinary"          
## [5152] "growth encountered water it straightway became gigantic and of"             
## [5153] "unparalleled fecundity.  Its seeds were simply poured down into the"        
## [5154] "water of the Wey and Thames, and its swiftly growing and Titanic water"     
## [5155] "fronds speedily choked both those rivers."                                  
## [5156] ""                                                                           
## [5157] "At Putney, as I afterwards saw, the bridge was almost lost in a"            
## [5158] "tangle of this weed, and at Richmond, too, the Thames water poured in"      
## [5159] "a broad and shallow stream across the meadows of Hampton and"               
## [5160] "Twickenham.  As the water spread the weed followed them, until the"         
## [5161] "ruined villas of the Thames valley were for a time lost in this red"        
## [5162] "swamp, whose margin I explored, and much of the desolation the"             
## [5163] "Martians had caused was concealed."                                         
## [5164] ""                                                                           
## [5165] "In the end the red weed succumbed almost as quickly as it had"              
## [5166] "spread.  A cankering disease, due, it is believed, to the action of"        
## [5167] "certain bacteria, presently seized upon it.  Now by the action of"          
## [5168] "natural selection, all terrestrial plants have acquired a resisting"        
## [5169] "power against bacterial diseases--they never succumb without a severe"      
## [5170] "struggle, but the red weed rotted like a thing already dead.  The"          
## [5171] "fronds became bleached, and then shrivelled and brittle.  They broke"       
## [5172] "off at the least touch, and the waters that had stimulated their early"     
## [5173] "growth carried their last vestiges out to sea."                             
## [5174] ""                                                                           
## [5175] "My first act on coming to this water was, of course, to slake my"           
## [5176] "thirst.  I drank a great deal of it and, moved by an impulse, gnawed"       
## [5177] "some fronds of red weed; but they were watery, and had a sickly,"           
## [5178] "metallic taste.  I found the water was sufficiently shallow for me to"      
## [5179] "wade securely, although the red weed impeded my feet a little; but the"     
## [5180] "flood evidently got deeper towards the river, and I turned back to"         
## [5181] "Mortlake.  I managed to make out the road by means of occasional ruins"     
## [5182] "of its villas and fences and lamps, and so presently I got out of this"     
## [5183] "spate and made my way to the hill going up towards Roehampton and came"     
## [5184] "out on Putney Common."                                                      
## [5185] ""                                                                           
## [5186] "Here the scenery changed from the strange and unfamiliar to the"            
## [5187] "wreckage of the familiar: patches of ground exhibited the devastation"      
## [5188] "of a cyclone, and in a few score yards I would come upon perfectly"         
## [5189] "undisturbed spaces, houses with their blinds trimly drawn and doors"        
## [5190] "closed, as if they had been left for a day by the owners, or as if"         
## [5191] "their inhabitants slept within.  The red weed was less abundant; the"       
## [5192] "tall trees along the lane were free from the red creeper.  I hunted"        
## [5193] "for food among the trees, finding nothing, and I also raided a couple"      
## [5194] "of silent houses, but they had already been broken into and ransacked."     
## [5195] "I rested for the remainder of the daylight in a shrubbery, being, in"       
## [5196] "my enfeebled condition, too fatigued to push on."                           
## [5197] ""                                                                           
## [5198] "All this time I saw no human beings, and no signs of the Martians."         
## [5199] "I encountered a couple of hungry-looking dogs, but both hurried"            
## [5200] "circuitously away from the advances I made them.  Near Roehampton I"        
## [5201] "had seen two human skeletons--not bodies, but skeletons, picked"            
## [5202] "clean--and in the wood by me I found the crushed and scattered bones"       
## [5203] "of several cats and rabbits and the skull of a sheep.  But though I"        
## [5204] "gnawed parts of these in my mouth, there was nothing to be got from"        
## [5205] "them."                                                                      
## [5206] ""                                                                           
## [5207] "After sunset I struggled on along the road towards Putney, where I"         
## [5208] "think the Heat-Ray must have been used for some reason.  And in the"        
## [5209] "garden beyond Roehampton I got a quantity of immature potatoes,"            
## [5210] "sufficient to stay my hunger.  From this garden one looked down upon"       
## [5211] "Putney and the river.  The aspect of the place in the dusk was"             
## [5212] "singularly desolate: blackened trees, blackened, desolate ruins, and"       
## [5213] "down the hill the sheets of the flooded river, red-tinged with the"         
## [5214] "weed.  And over all--silence.  It filled me with indescribable terror"      
## [5215] "to think how swiftly that desolating change had come."                      
## [5216] ""                                                                           
## [5217] "For a time I believed that mankind had been swept out of existence,"        
## [5218] "and that I stood there alone, the last man left alive.  Hard by the"        
## [5219] "top of Putney Hill I came upon another skeleton, with the arms"             
## [5220] "dislocated and removed several yards from the rest of the body.  As I"      
## [5221] "proceeded I became more and more convinced that the extermination of"       
## [5222] "mankind was, save for such stragglers as myself, already accomplished"      
## [5223] "in this part of the world.  The Martians, I thought, had gone on and"       
## [5224] "left the country desolated, seeking food elsewhere.  Perhaps even now"      
## [5225] "they were destroying Berlin or Paris, or it might be they had gone"         
## [5226] "northward."                                                                 
## [5227] ""                                                                           
## [5228] ""                                                                           
## [5229] ""                                                                           
## [5230] "CHAPTER SEVEN"                                                              
## [5231] ""                                                                           
## [5232] "THE MAN ON PUTNEY HILL"                                                     
## [5233] ""                                                                           
## [5234] ""                                                                           
## [5235] "I spent that night in the inn that stands at the top of Putney"             
## [5236] "Hill, sleeping in a made bed for the first time since my flight to"         
## [5237] "Leatherhead.  I will not tell the needless trouble I had breaking into"     
## [5238] "that house--afterwards I found the front door was on the latch--nor"        
## [5239] "how I ransacked every room for food, until just on the verge of"            
## [5240] "despair, in what seemed to me to be a servant's bedroom, I found a"         
## [5241] "rat-gnawed crust and two tins of pineapple.  The place had been"            
## [5242] "already searched and emptied.  In the bar I afterwards found some"          
## [5243] "biscuits and sandwiches that had been overlooked.  The latter I could"      
## [5244] "not eat, they were too rotten, but the former not only stayed my"           
## [5245] "hunger, but filled my pockets.  I lit no lamps, fearing some Martian"       
## [5246] "might come beating that part of London for food in the night.  Before"      
## [5247] "I went to bed I had an interval of restlessness, and prowled from"          
## [5248] "window to window, peering out for some sign of these monsters.  I"          
## [5249] "slept little.  As I lay in bed I found myself thinking consecutively--a"    
## [5250] "thing I do not remember to have done since my last argument with the"       
## [5251] "curate.  During all the intervening time my mental condition had been"      
## [5252] "a hurrying succession of vague emotional states or a sort of stupid"        
## [5253] "receptivity.  But in the night my brain, reinforced, I suppose, by the"     
## [5254] "food I had eaten, grew clear again, and I thought."                         
## [5255] ""                                                                           
## [5256] "Three things struggled for possession of my mind: the killing of"           
## [5257] "the curate, the whereabouts of the Martians, and the possible fate of"      
## [5258] "my wife.  The former gave me no sensation of horror or remorse to"          
## [5259] "recall; I saw it simply as a thing done, a memory infinitely"               
## [5260] "disagreeable but quite without the quality of remorse.  I saw myself"       
## [5261] "then as I see myself now, driven step by step towards that hasty blow,"     
## [5262] "the creature of a sequence of accidents leading inevitably to that.  I"     
## [5263] "felt no condemnation; yet the memory, static, unprogressive, haunted"       
## [5264] "me.  In the silence of the night, with that sense of the nearness of"       
## [5265] "God that sometimes comes into the stillness and the darkness, I stood"      
## [5266] "my trial, my only trial, for that moment of wrath and fear.  I"             
## [5267] "retraced every step of our conversation from the moment when I had"         
## [5268] "found him crouching beside me, heedless of my thirst, and pointing to"      
## [5269] "the fire and smoke that streamed up from the ruins of Weybridge.  We"       
## [5270] "had been incapable of co-operation--grim chance had taken no heed of"       
## [5271] "that.  Had I foreseen, I should have left him at Halliford.  But I did"     
## [5272] "not foresee; and crime is to foresee and do.  And I set this down as I"     
## [5273] "have set all this story down, as it was.  There were no witnesses--all"     
## [5274] "these things I might have concealed.  But I set it down, and the"           
## [5275] "reader must form his judgment as he will."                                  
## [5276] ""                                                                           
## [5277] "And when, by an effort, I had set aside that picture of a prostrate"        
## [5278] "body, I faced the problem of the Martians and the fate of my wife.  For"    
## [5279] "the former I had no data; I could imagine a hundred things, and so,"        
## [5280] "unhappily, I could for the latter.  And suddenly that night became"         
## [5281] "terrible.  I found myself sitting up in bed, staring at the dark.  I"       
## [5282] "found myself praying that the Heat-Ray might have suddenly and"             
## [5283] "painlessly struck her out of being.  Since the night of my return from"     
## [5284] "Leatherhead I had not prayed.  I had uttered prayers, fetish prayers,"      
## [5285] "had prayed as heathens mutter charms when I was in extremity; but now"      
## [5286] "I prayed indeed, pleading steadfastly and sanely, face to face with"        
## [5287] "the darkness of God.  Strange night!  Strangest in this, that so soon"      
## [5288] "as dawn had come, I, who had talked with God, crept out of the house"       
## [5289] "like a rat leaving its hiding place--a creature scarcely larger, an"        
## [5290] "inferior animal, a thing that for any passing whim of our masters"          
## [5291] "might be hunted and killed.  Perhaps they also prayed confidently to"       
## [5292] "God.  Surely, if we have learned nothing else, this war has taught us"      
## [5293] "pity--pity for those witless souls that suffer our dominion."               
## [5294] ""                                                                           
## [5295] "The morning was bright and fine, and the eastern sky glowed pink,"          
## [5296] "and was fretted with little golden clouds.  In the road that runs from"     
## [5297] "the top of Putney Hill to Wimbledon was a number of poor vestiges of"       
## [5298] "the panic torrent that must have poured Londonward on the Sunday night"     
## [5299] "after the fighting began.  There was a little two-wheeled cart"             
## [5300] "inscribed with the name of Thomas Lobb, Greengrocer, New Malden, with"      
## [5301] "a smashed wheel and an abandoned tin trunk; there was a straw hat"          
## [5302] "trampled into the now hardened mud, and at the top of West Hill a lot"      
## [5303] "of blood-stained glass about the overturned water trough.  My"              
## [5304] "movements were languid, my plans of the vaguest.  I had an idea of"         
## [5305] "going to Leatherhead, though I knew that there I had the poorest"           
## [5306] "chance of finding my wife.  Certainly, unless death had overtaken them"     
## [5307] "suddenly, my cousins and she would have fled thence; but it seemed to"      
## [5308] "me I might find or learn there whither the Surrey people had fled.  I"      
## [5309] "knew I wanted to find my wife, that my heart ached for her and the"         
## [5310] "world of men, but I had no clear idea how the finding might be done.  I"    
## [5311] "was also sharply aware now of my intense loneliness.  From the corner"      
## [5312] "I went, under cover of a thicket of trees and bushes, to the edge of"       
## [5313] "Wimbledon Common, stretching wide and far."                                 
## [5314] ""                                                                           
## [5315] "That dark expanse was lit in patches by yellow gorse and broom;"            
## [5316] "there was no red weed to be seen, and as I prowled, hesitating, on the"     
## [5317] "verge of the open, the sun rose, flooding it all with light and"            
## [5318] "vitality.  I came upon a busy swarm of little frogs in a swampy place"      
## [5319] "among the trees.  I stopped to look at them, drawing a lesson from"         
## [5320] "their stout resolve to live.  And presently, turning suddenly, with an"     
## [5321] "odd feeling of being watched, I beheld something crouching amid a"          
## [5322] "clump of bushes.  I stood regarding this.  I made a step towards it,"       
## [5323] "and it rose up and became a man armed with a cutlass.  I approached"        
## [5324] "him slowly.  He stood silent and motionless, regarding me."                 
## [5325] ""                                                                           
## [5326] "As I drew nearer I perceived he was dressed in clothes as dusty and"        
## [5327] "filthy as my own; he looked, indeed, as though he had been dragged"         
## [5328] "through a culvert.  Nearer, I distinguished the green slime of ditches"     
## [5329] "mixing with the pale drab of dried clay and shiny, coaly patches.  His"     
## [5330] "black hair fell over his eyes, and his face was dark and dirty and"         
## [5331] "sunken, so that at first I did not recognise him.  There was a red cut"     
## [5332] "across the lower part of his face."                                         
## [5333] ""                                                                           
## [5334] "\"Stop!\" he cried, when I was within ten yards of him, and I"              
## [5335] "stopped.  His voice was hoarse.  \"Where do you come from?\" he said."      
## [5336] ""                                                                           
## [5337] "I thought, surveying him."                                                  
## [5338] ""                                                                           
## [5339] "\"I come from Mortlake,\" I said.  \"I was buried near the pit the"         
## [5340] "Martians made about their cylinder.  I have worked my way out and"          
## [5341] "escaped.\""                                                                 
## [5342] ""                                                                           
## [5343] "\"There is no food about here,\" he said.  \"This is my country.  All"      
## [5344] "this hill down to the river, and back to Clapham, and up to the edge"       
## [5345] "of the common.  There is only food for one.  Which way are you going?\""    
## [5346] ""                                                                           
## [5347] "I answered slowly."                                                         
## [5348] ""                                                                           
## [5349] "\"I don't know,\" I said.  \"I have been buried in the ruins of a"          
## [5350] "house thirteen or fourteen days.  I don't know what has happened.\""        
## [5351] ""                                                                           
## [5352] "He looked at me doubtfully, then started, and looked with a changed"        
## [5353] "expression."                                                                
## [5354] ""                                                                           
## [5355] "\"I've no wish to stop about here,\" said I.  \"I think I shall go to"      
## [5356] "Leatherhead, for my wife was there.\""                                      
## [5357] ""                                                                           
## [5358] "He shot out a pointing finger."                                             
## [5359] ""                                                                           
## [5360] "\"It is you,\" said he; \"the man from Woking.  And you weren't killed"     
## [5361] "at Weybridge?\""                                                            
## [5362] ""                                                                           
## [5363] "I recognised him at the same moment."                                       
## [5364] ""                                                                           
## [5365] "\"You are the artilleryman who came into my garden.\""                      
## [5366] ""                                                                           
## [5367] "\"Good luck!\" he said.  \"We are lucky ones!  Fancy _you_!\"  He put out"  
## [5368] "a hand, and I took it.  \"I crawled up a drain,\" he said. \"But they"      
## [5369] "didn't kill everyone.  And after they went away I got off towards"          
## [5370] "Walton across the fields.  But---- It's not sixteen days altogether--and"   
## [5371] "your hair is grey.\"  He looked over his shoulder suddenly.  \"Only"        
## [5372] "a rook,\" he said.  \"One gets to know that birds have shadows these"       
## [5373] "days.  This is a bit open.  Let us crawl under those bushes and talk.\""    
## [5374] ""                                                                           
## [5375] "\"Have you seen any Martians?\" I said.  \"Since I crawled out----\""       
## [5376] ""                                                                           
## [5377] "\"They've gone away across London,\" he said.  \"I guess they've got a"     
## [5378] "bigger camp there.  Of a night, all over there, Hampstead way, the sky"     
## [5379] "is alive with their lights.  It's like a great city, and in the glare"      
## [5380] "you can just see them moving.  By daylight you can't.  But nearer--I"       
## [5381] "haven't seen them--\" (he counted on his fingers) \"five days.  Then I"     
## [5382] "saw a couple across Hammersmith way carrying something big.  And the"       
## [5383] "night before last\"--he stopped and spoke impressively--\"it was just a"    
## [5384] "matter of lights, but it was something up in the air.  I believe"           
## [5385] "they've built a flying-machine, and are learning to fly.\""                 
## [5386] ""                                                                           
## [5387] "I stopped, on hands and knees, for we had come to the bushes."              
## [5388] ""                                                                           
## [5389] "\"Fly!\""                                                                   
## [5390] ""                                                                           
## [5391] "\"Yes,\" he said, \"fly.\""                                                 
## [5392] ""                                                                           
## [5393] "I went on into a little bower, and sat down."                               
## [5394] ""                                                                           
## [5395] "\"It is all over with humanity,\" I said.  \"If they can do that they"      
## [5396] "will simply go round the world.\""                                          
## [5397] ""                                                                           
## [5398] "He nodded."                                                                 
## [5399] ""                                                                           
## [5400] "\"They will.  But---- It will relieve things over here a bit.  And"         
## [5401] "besides----\"  He looked at me.  \"Aren't you satisfied it _is_ up with"    
## [5402] "humanity?  I am.  We're down; we're beat.\""                                
## [5403] ""                                                                           
## [5404] "I stared.  Strange as it may seem, I had not arrived at this fact--a"       
## [5405] "fact perfectly obvious so soon as he spoke.  I had still held a"            
## [5406] "vague hope; rather, I had kept a lifelong habit of mind.  He repeated"      
## [5407] "his words, \"We're beat.\"  They carried absolute conviction."              
## [5408] ""                                                                           
## [5409] "\"It's all over,\" he said.  \"They've lost _one_--just _one_.  And they've"
## [5410] "made their footing good and crippled the greatest power in the world."      
## [5411] "They've walked over us.  The death of that one at Weybridge was an"         
## [5412] "accident.  And these are only pioneers.  They kept on coming.  These"       
## [5413] "green stars--I've seen none these five or six days, but I've no doubt"      
## [5414] "they're falling somewhere every night.  Nothing's to be done.  We're"       
## [5415] "under! We're beat!\""                                                       
## [5416] ""                                                                           
## [5417] "I made him no answer.  I sat staring before me, trying in vain to"          
## [5418] "devise some countervailing thought."                                        
## [5419] ""                                                                           
## [5420] "\"This isn't a war,\" said the artilleryman.  \"It never was a war,"        
## [5421] "any more than there's war between man and ants.\""                          
## [5422] ""                                                                           
## [5423] "Suddenly I recalled the night in the observatory."                          
## [5424] ""                                                                           
## [5425] "\"After the tenth shot they fired no more--at least, until the first"       
## [5426] "cylinder came.\""                                                           
## [5427] ""                                                                           
## [5428] "\"How do you know?\" said the artilleryman.  I explained.  He thought."     
## [5429] "\"Something wrong with the gun,\" he said.  \"But what if there is?"        
## [5430] "They'll get it right again.  And even if there's a delay, how can it"       
## [5431] "alter the end?  It's just men and ants.  There's the ants builds their"     
## [5432] "cities, live their lives, have wars, revolutions, until the men want"       
## [5433] "them out of the way, and then they go out of the way.  That's what we"      
## [5434] "are now--just ants.  Only----\""                                            
## [5435] ""                                                                           
## [5436] "\"Yes,\" I said."                                                           
## [5437] ""                                                                           
## [5438] "\"We're eatable ants.\""                                                    
## [5439] ""                                                                           
## [5440] "We sat looking at each other."                                              
## [5441] ""
