## [5442] "\"And what will they do with us?\" I said."                                 
## [5443] ""                                                                           
## [5444] "\"That's what I've been thinking,\" he said; \"that's what I've been"       
## [5445] "thinking.  After Weybridge I went south--thinking.  I saw what was up."     
## [5446] "Most of the people were hard at it squealing and exciting themselves."      
## [5447] "But I'm not so fond of squealing.  I've been in sight of death once or"     
## [5448] "twice; I'm not an ornamental soldier, and at the best and worst,"           
## [5449] "death--it's just death.  And it's the man that keeps on thinking comes"     
## [5450] "through.  I saw everyone tracking away south.  Says I, 'Food won't"         
## [5451] "last this way,' and I turned right back.  I went for the Martians like"     
## [5452] "a sparrow goes for man.  All round\"--he waved a hand to the"               
## [5453] "horizon--\"they're starving in heaps, bolting, treading on each other."     
## [5454] ". . .\""                                                                    
## [5455] ""                                                                           
## [5456] "He saw my face, and halted awkwardly."                                      
## [5457] ""                                                                           
## [5458] "\"No doubt lots who had money have gone away to France,\" he said.  He"     
## [5459] "seemed to hesitate whether to apologise, met my eyes, and went on:"         
## [5460] "\"There's food all about here.  Canned things in shops; wines, spirits,"    
## [5461] "mineral waters; and the water mains and drains are empty.  Well, I was"     
## [5462] "telling you what I was thinking.  'Here's intelligent things,' I said,"     
## [5463] "'and it seems they want us for food.  First, they'll smash us up--ships,"   
## [5464] "machines, guns, cities, all the order and organisation.  All"               
## [5465] "that will go.  If we were the size of ants we might pull through.  But"     
## [5466] "we're not.  It's all too bulky to stop.  That's the first certainty.'"      
## [5467] "Eh?\""                                                                      
## [5468] ""                                                                           
## [5469] "I assented."                                                                
## [5470] ""                                                                           
## [5471] "\"It is; I've thought it out.  Very well, then--next; at present"           
## [5472] "we're caught as we're wanted.  A Martian has only to go a few miles to"     
## [5473] "get a crowd on the run.  And I saw one, one day, out by Wandsworth,"        
## [5474] "picking houses to pieces and routing among the wreckage.  But they"         
## [5475] "won't keep on doing that.  So soon as they've settled all our guns and"     
## [5476] "ships, and smashed our railways, and done all the things they are"          
## [5477] "doing over there, they will begin catching us systematic, picking the"      
## [5478] "best and storing us in cages and things.  That's what they will start"      
## [5479] "doing in a bit.  Lord!  They haven't begun on us yet.  Don't you see"       
## [5480] "that?\""                                                                    
## [5481] ""                                                                           
## [5482] "\"Not begun!\" I exclaimed."                                                
## [5483] ""                                                                           
## [5484] "\"Not begun.  All that's happened so far is through our not having"         
## [5485] "the sense to keep quiet--worrying them with guns and such foolery.  And"    
## [5486] "losing our heads, and rushing off in crowds to where there wasn't any"      
## [5487] "more safety than where we were.  They don't want to bother us yet."         
## [5488] "They're making their things--making all the things they couldn't bring"     
## [5489] "with them, getting things ready for the rest of their people.  Very"        
## [5490] "likely that's why the cylinders have stopped for a bit, for fear of"        
## [5491] "hitting those who are here.  And instead of our rushing about blind,"       
## [5492] "on the howl, or getting dynamite on the chance of busting them up,"         
## [5493] "we've got to fix ourselves up according to the new state of affairs."       
## [5494] "That's how I figure it out.  It isn't quite according to what a man"        
## [5495] "wants for his species, but it's about what the facts point to.  And"        
## [5496] "that's the principle I acted upon.  Cities, nations, civilisation,"         
## [5497] "progress--it's all over.  That game's up.  We're beat.\""                   
## [5498] ""                                                                           
## [5499] "\"But if that is so, what is there to live for?\""                          
## [5500] ""                                                                           
## [5501] "The artilleryman looked at me for a moment."                                
## [5502] ""                                                                           
## [5503] "\"There won't be any more blessed concerts for a million years or"          
## [5504] "so; there won't be any Royal Academy of Arts, and no nice little feeds"     
## [5505] "at restaurants.  If it's amusement you're after, I reckon the game is"      
## [5506] "up.  If you've got any drawing-room manners or a dislike to eating"         
## [5507] "peas with a knife or dropping aitches, you'd better chuck 'em away."        
## [5508] "They ain't no further use.\""                                               
## [5509] ""                                                                           
## [5510] "\"You mean----\""                                                           
## [5511] ""                                                                           
## [5512] "\"I mean that men like me are going on living--for the sake of the"         
## [5513] "breed.  I tell you, I'm grim set on living.  And if I'm not mistaken,"      
## [5514] "you'll show what insides _you've_ got, too, before long.  We aren't"        
## [5515] "going to be exterminated.  And I don't mean to be caught either, and"       
## [5516] "tamed and fattened and bred like a thundering ox.  Ugh! Fancy those"        
## [5517] "brown creepers!\""                                                          
## [5518] ""                                                                           
## [5519] "\"You don't mean to say----\""                                              
## [5520] ""                                                                           
## [5521] "\"I do.  I'm going on, under their feet.  I've got it planned; I've"        
## [5522] "thought it out.  We men are beat.  We don't know enough.  We've got to"     
## [5523] "learn before we've got a chance.  And we've got to live and keep"           
## [5524] "independent while we learn.  See! That's what has to be done.\""            
## [5525] ""                                                                           
## [5526] "I stared, astonished, and stirred profoundly by the man's"                  
## [5527] "resolution."                                                                
## [5528] ""                                                                           
## [5529] "\"Great God!\" cried I.  \"But you are a man indeed!\"  And suddenly I"     
## [5530] "gripped his hand."                                                          
## [5531] ""                                                                           
## [5532] "\"Eh!\" he said, with his eyes shining.  \"I've thought it out, eh?\""      
## [5533] ""                                                                           
## [5534] "\"Go on,\" I said."                                                         
## [5535] ""                                                                           
## [5536] "\"Well, those who mean to escape their catching must get ready.  I'm"       
## [5537] "getting ready.  Mind you, it isn't all of us that are made for wild"        
## [5538] "beasts; and that's what it's got to be.  That's why I watched you.  I"      
## [5539] "had my doubts.  You're slender.  I didn't know that it was you, you"        
## [5540] "see, or just how you'd been buried.  All these--the sort of people"         
## [5541] "that lived in these houses, and all those damn little clerks that used"     
## [5542] "to live down that way--they'd be no good.  They haven't any spirit in"      
## [5543] "them--no proud dreams and no proud lusts; and a man who hasn't one or"      
## [5544] "the other--Lord!  What is he but funk and precautions?  They just used"     
## [5545] "to skedaddle off to work--I've seen hundreds of 'em, bit of breakfast"      
## [5546] "in hand, running wild and shining to catch their little season-ticket"      
## [5547] "train, for fear they'd get dismissed if they didn't; working at"            
## [5548] "businesses they were afraid to take the trouble to understand;"             
## [5549] "skedaddling back for fear they wouldn't be in time for dinner; keeping"     
## [5550] "indoors after dinner for fear of the back streets, and sleeping with"       
## [5551] "the wives they married, not because they wanted them, but because they"     
## [5552] "had a bit of money that would make for safety in their one little"          
## [5553] "miserable skedaddle through the world.  Lives insured and a bit"            
## [5554] "invested for fear of accidents.  And on Sundays--fear of the"               
## [5555] "hereafter.  As if hell was built for rabbits!  Well, the Martians will"     
## [5556] "just be a godsend to these.  Nice roomy cages, fattening food, careful"     
## [5557] "breeding, no worry.  After a week or so chasing about the fields and"       
## [5558] "lands on empty stomachs, they'll come and be caught cheerful.  They'll"     
## [5559] "be quite glad after a bit.  They'll wonder what people did before"          
## [5560] "there were Martians to take care of them.  And the bar loafers, and"        
## [5561] "mashers, and singers--I can imagine them.  I can imagine them,\" he"        
## [5562] "said, with a sort of sombre gratification.  \"There'll be any amount of"    
## [5563] "sentiment and religion loose among them.  There's hundreds of things I"     
## [5564] "saw with my eyes that I've only begun to see clearly these last few"        
## [5565] "days.  There's lots will take things as they are--fat and stupid; and"      
## [5566] "lots will be worried by a sort of feeling that it's all wrong, and"         
## [5567] "that they ought to be doing something.  Now whenever things are so"         
## [5568] "that a lot of people feel they ought to be doing something, the weak,"      
## [5569] "and those who go weak with a lot of complicated thinking, always make"      
## [5570] "for a sort of do-nothing religion, very pious and superior, and"            
## [5571] "submit to persecution and the will of the Lord.  Very likely you've"        
## [5572] "seen the same thing.  It's energy in a gale of funk, and turned clean"      
## [5573] "inside out.  These cages will be full of psalms and hymns and piety."       
## [5574] "And those of a less simple sort will work in a bit of--what is"             
## [5575] "it?--eroticism.\""                                                          
## [5576] ""                                                                           
## [5577] "He paused."                                                                 
## [5578] ""                                                                           
## [5579] "\"Very likely these Martians will make pets of some of them; train"         
## [5580] "them to do tricks--who knows?--get sentimental over the pet boy who"        
## [5581] "grew up and had to be killed.  And some, maybe, they will train to"         
## [5582] "hunt us.\""                                                                 
## [5583] ""                                                                           
## [5584] "\"No,\" I cried, \"that's impossible!  No human being----\""                
## [5585] ""                                                                           
## [5586] "\"What's the good of going on with such lies?\" said the"                   
## [5587] "artilleryman.  \"There's men who'd do it cheerful.  What nonsense to"       
## [5588] "pretend there isn't!\""                                                     
## [5589] ""                                                                           
## [5590] "And I succumbed to his conviction."                                         
## [5591] ""                                                                           
## [5592] "\"If they come after me,\" he said; \"Lord, if they come after me!\""       
## [5593] "and subsided into a grim meditation."                                       
## [5594] ""                                                                           
## [5595] "I sat contemplating these things.  I could find nothing to bring"           
## [5596] "against this man's reasoning.  In the days before the invasion no one"      
## [5597] "would have questioned my intellectual superiority to his--I, a"             
## [5598] "professed and recognised writer on philosophical themes, and he, a"         
## [5599] "common soldier; and yet he had already formulated a situation that I"       
## [5600] "had scarcely realised."                                                     
## [5601] ""                                                                           
## [5602] "\"What are you doing?\" I said presently.  \"What plans have you"           
## [5603] "made?\""                                                                    
## [5604] ""                                                                           
## [5605] "He hesitated."                                                              
## [5606] ""                                                                           
## [5607] "\"Well, it's like this,\" he said.  \"What have we to do?  We have to"      
## [5608] "invent a sort of life where men can live and breed, and be"                 
## [5609] "sufficiently secure to bring the children up.  Yes--wait a bit, and"        
## [5610] "I'll make it clearer what I think ought to be done.  The tame ones"         
## [5611] "will go like all tame beasts; in a few generations they'll be big,"         
## [5612] "beautiful, rich-blooded, stupid--rubbish! The risk is that we who keep"     
## [5613] "wild will go savage--degenerate into a sort of big, savage rat. . . ."      
## [5614] "You see, how I mean to live is underground.  I've been thinking about"      
## [5615] "the drains.  Of course those who don't know drains think horrible"          
## [5616] "things; but under this London are miles and miles--hundreds of"             
## [5617] "miles--and a few days rain and London empty will leave them sweet and"      
## [5618] "clean. The main drains are big enough and airy enough for anyone."          
## [5619] "Then there's cellars, vaults, stores, from which bolting passages may"      
## [5620] "be made to the drains. And the railway tunnels and subways.  Eh?  You"      
## [5621] "begin to see?  And we form a band--able-bodied, clean-minded men."          
## [5622] "We're not going to pick up any rubbish that drifts in.  Weaklings"          
## [5623] "go out again.\""                                                            
## [5624] ""                                                                           
## [5625] "\"As you meant me to go?\""                                                 
## [5626] ""                                                                           
## [5627] "\"Well--I parleyed, didn't I?\""                                            
## [5628] ""                                                                           
## [5629] "\"We won't quarrel about that.  Go on.\""                                   
## [5630] ""                                                                           
## [5631] "\"Those who stop obey orders.  Able-bodied, clean-minded women we"          
## [5632] "want also--mothers and teachers.  No lackadaisical ladies--no blasted"      
## [5633] "rolling eyes.  We can't have any weak or silly.  Life is real again,"       
## [5634] "and the useless and cumbersome and mischievous have to die.  They"          
## [5635] "ought to die.  They ought to be willing to die.  It's a sort of"            
## [5636] "disloyalty, after all, to live and taint the race.  And they can't be"      
## [5637] "happy.  Moreover, dying's none so dreadful; it's the funking makes it"      
## [5638] "bad.  And in all those places we shall gather.  Our district will be"       
## [5639] "London.  And we may even be able to keep a watch, and run about in the"     
## [5640] "open when the Martians keep away.  Play cricket, perhaps.  That's how"      
## [5641] "we shall save the race.  Eh?  It's a possible thing?  But saving the"       
## [5642] "race is nothing in itself.  As I say, that's only being rats.  It's"        
## [5643] "saving our knowledge and adding to it is the thing.  There men like"        
## [5644] "you come in.  There's books, there's models.  We must make great safe"      
## [5645] "places down deep, and get all the books we can; not novels and poetry"      
## [5646] "swipes, but ideas, science books.  That's where men like you come in."      
## [5647] "We must go to the British Museum and pick all those books through."         
## [5648] "Especially we must keep up our science--learn more.  We must watch"         
## [5649] "these Martians.  Some of us must go as spies.  When it's all working,"      
## [5650] "perhaps I will.  Get caught, I mean.  And the great thing is, we must"      
## [5651] "leave the Martians alone.  We mustn't even steal.  If we get in their"      
## [5652] "way, we clear out.  We must show them we mean no harm.  Yes, I know."       
## [5653] "But they're intelligent things, and they won't hunt us down if they"        
## [5654] "have all they want, and think we're just harmless vermin.\""                
## [5655] ""                                                                           
## [5656] "The artilleryman paused and laid a brown hand upon my arm."                 
## [5657] ""                                                                           
## [5658] "\"After all, it may not be so much we may have to learn before--Just"       
## [5659] "imagine this: four or five of their fighting machines suddenly"             
## [5660] "starting off--Heat-Rays right and left, and not a Martian in 'em.  Not"     
## [5661] "a Martian in 'em, but men--men who have learned the way how.  It may"       
## [5662] "be in my time, even--those men.  Fancy having one of them lovely"           
## [5663] "things, with its Heat-Ray wide and free!  Fancy having it in control!"      
## [5664] "What would it matter if you smashed to smithereens at the end of the"       
## [5665] "run, after a bust like that?  I reckon the Martians'll open their"          
## [5666] "beautiful eyes!  Can't you see them, man?  Can't you see them"              
## [5667] "hurrying, hurrying--puffing and blowing and hooting to their other"         
## [5668] "mechanical affairs?  Something out of gear in every case.  And swish,"      
## [5669] "bang, rattle, swish!  Just as they are fumbling over it, _swish_ comes"     
## [5670] "the Heat-Ray, and, behold! man has come back to his own.\""                 
## [5671] ""                                                                           
## [5672] "For a while the imaginative daring of the artilleryman, and the"            
## [5673] "tone of assurance and courage he assumed, completely dominated my"          
## [5674] "mind.  I believed unhesitatingly both in his forecast of human destiny"     
## [5675] "and in the practicability of his astonishing scheme, and the reader"        
## [5676] "who thinks me susceptible and foolish must contrast his position,"          
## [5677] "reading steadily with all his thoughts about his subject, and mine,"        
## [5678] "crouching fearfully in the bushes and listening, distracted by"             
## [5679] "apprehension.  We talked in this manner through the early morning"          
## [5680] "time, and later crept out of the bushes, and, after scanning the sky"       
## [5681] "for Martians, hurried precipitately to the house on Putney Hill where"      
## [5682] "he had made his lair.  It was the coal cellar of the place, and when I"     
## [5683] "saw the work he had spent a week upon--it was a burrow scarcely ten"        
## [5684] "yards long, which he designed to reach to the main drain on Putney"         
## [5685] "Hill--I had my first inkling of the gulf between his dreams and his"        
## [5686] "powers.  Such a hole I could have dug in a day.  But I believed in him"     
## [5687] "sufficiently to work with him all that morning until past midday at"        
## [5688] "his digging.  We had a garden barrow and shot the earth we removed"         
## [5689] "against the kitchen range.  We refreshed ourselves with a tin of"           
## [5690] "mock-turtle soup and wine from the neighbouring pantry.  I found a"         
## [5691] "curious relief from the aching strangeness of the world in this steady"     
## [5692] "labour. As we worked, I turned his project over in my mind, and"            
## [5693] "presently objections and doubts began to arise; but I worked there all"     
## [5694] "the morning, so glad was I to find myself with a purpose again.  After"     
## [5695] "working an hour I began to speculate on the distance one had to go"         
## [5696] "before the cloaca was reached, the chances we had of missing it"            
## [5697] "altogether.  My immediate trouble was why we should dig this long"          
## [5698] "tunnel, when it was possible to get into the drain at once down one of"     
## [5699] "the manholes, and work back to the house.  It seemed to me, too, that"      
## [5700] "the house was inconveniently chosen, and required a needless length of"     
## [5701] "tunnel.  And just as I was beginning to face these things, the"             
## [5702] "artilleryman stopped digging, and looked at me."                            
## [5703] ""                                                                           
## [5704] "\"We're working well,\" he said.  He put down his spade. \"Let us"          
## [5705] "knock off a bit\" he said.  \"I think it's time we reconnoitred from the"   
## [5706] "roof of the house.\""                                                       
## [5707] ""                                                                           
## [5708] "I was for going on, and after a little hesitation he resumed his"           
## [5709] "spade; and then suddenly I was struck by a thought.  I stopped, and so"     
## [5710] "did he at once."                                                            
## [5711] ""                                                                           
## [5712] "\"Why were you walking about the common,\" I said, \"instead of being"      
## [5713] "here?\""                                                                    
## [5714] ""                                                                           
## [5715] "\"Taking the air,\" he said.  \"I was coming back.  It's safer by"          
## [5716] "night.\""                                                                   
## [5717] ""                                                                           
## [5718] "\"But the work?\""                                                          
## [5719] ""                                                                           
## [5720] "\"Oh, one can't always work,\" he said, and in a flash I saw the man"       
## [5721] "plain.  He hesitated, holding his spade.  \"We ought to reconnoitre"        
## [5722] "now,\" he said, \"because if any come near they may hear the spades and"    
## [5723] "drop upon us unawares.\""                                                   
## [5724] ""                                                                           
## [5725] "I was no longer disposed to object.  We went together to the roof"          
## [5726] "and stood on a ladder peeping out of the roof door.  No Martians were"      
## [5727] "to be seen, and we ventured out on the tiles, and slipped down under"       
## [5728] "shelter of the parapet."                                                    
## [5729] ""                                                                           
## [5730] "From this position a shrubbery hid the greater portion of Putney,"          
## [5731] "but we could see the river below, a bubbly mass of red weed, and the"       
## [5732] "low parts of Lambeth flooded and red.  The red creeper swarmed up the"      
## [5733] "trees about the old palace, and their branches stretched gaunt and"         
## [5734] "dead, and set with shrivelled leaves, from amid its clusters.  It was"      
## [5735] "strange how entirely dependent both these things were upon flowing"         
## [5736] "water for their propagation.  About us neither had gained a footing;"       
## [5737] "laburnums, pink mays, snowballs, and trees of arbor-vitae, rose out of"     
## [5738] "laurels and hydrangeas, green and brilliant into the sunlight.  Beyond"     
## [5739] "Kensington dense smoke was rising, and that and a blue haze hid the"        
## [5740] "northward hills."                                                           
## [5741] ""                                                                           
## [5742] "The artilleryman began to tell me of the sort of people who still"          
## [5743] "remained in London."                                                        
## [5744] ""                                                                           
## [5745] "\"One night last week,\" he said, \"some fools got the electric light"      
## [5746] "in order, and there was all Regent Street and the Circus ablaze,"           
## [5747] "crowded with painted and ragged drunkards, men and women, dancing and"      
## [5748] "shouting till dawn.  A man who was there told me.  And as the day came"     
## [5749] "they became aware of a fighting-machine standing near by the Langham"       
## [5750] "and looking down at them.  Heaven knows how long he had been there."        
## [5751] "It must have given some of them a nasty turn.  He came down the road"       
## [5752] "towards them, and picked up nearly a hundred too drunk or frightened"       
## [5753] "to run away.\""                                                             
## [5754] ""                                                                           
## [5755] "Grotesque gleam of a time no history will ever fully describe!"             
## [5756] ""                                                                           
## [5757] "From that, in answer to my questions, he came round to his"                 
## [5758] "grandiose plans again.  He grew enthusiastic.  He talked so eloquently"     
## [5759] "of the possibility of capturing a fighting-machine that I more than"        
## [5760] "half believed in him again.  But now that I was beginning to"               
## [5761] "understand something of his quality, I could divine the stress he laid"     
## [5762] "on doing nothing precipitately.  And I noted that now there was no"         
## [5763] "question that he personally was to capture and fight the great"             
## [5764] "machine."                                                                   
## [5765] ""                                                                           
## [5766] "After a time we went down to the cellar.  Neither of us seemed"             
## [5767] "disposed to resume digging, and when he suggested a meal, I was"            
## [5768] "nothing loath.  He became suddenly very generous, and when we had"          
## [5769] "eaten he went away and returned with some excellent cigars.  We lit"        
## [5770] "these, and his optimism glowed.  He was inclined to regard my coming"       
## [5771] "as a great occasion."                                                       
## [5772] ""                                                                           
## [5773] "\"There's some champagne in the cellar,\" he said."                         
## [5774] ""                                                                           
## [5775] "\"We can dig better on this Thames-side burgundy,\" said I."                
## [5776] ""                                                                           
## [5777] "\"No,\" said he; \"I am host today.  Champagne!  Great God! We've a"        
## [5778] "heavy enough task before us!  Let us take a rest and gather strength"       
## [5779] "while we may.  Look at these blistered hands!\""                            
## [5780] ""                                                                           
## [5781] "And pursuant to this idea of a holiday, he insisted upon playing"           
## [5782] "cards after we had eaten.  He taught me euchre, and after dividing"         
## [5783] "London between us, I taking the northern side and he the southern, we"      
## [5784] "played for parish points.  Grotesque and foolish as this will seem to"      
## [5785] "the sober reader, it is absolutely true, and what is more remarkable,"      
## [5786] "I found the card game and several others we played extremely"               
## [5787] "interesting."                                                               
## [5788] ""                                                                           
## [5789] "Strange mind of man! that, with our species upon the edge of"               
## [5790] "extermination or appalling degradation, with no clear prospect before"      
## [5791] "us but the chance of a horrible death, we could sit following the"          
## [5792] "chance of this painted pasteboard, and playing the \"joker\" with vivid"    
## [5793] "delight.  Afterwards he taught me poker, and I beat him at three tough"     
## [5794] "chess games.  When dark came we decided to take the risk, and lit a"        
## [5795] "lamp."                                                                      
## [5796] ""                                                                           
## [5797] "After an interminable string of games, we supped, and the"                  
## [5798] "artilleryman finished the champagne.  We went on smoking the cigars."       
## [5799] "He was no longer the energetic regenerator of his species I had"            
## [5800] "encountered in the morning.  He was still optimistic, but it was a"         
## [5801] "less kinetic, a more thoughtful optimism.  I remember he wound up with"     
## [5802] "my health, proposed in a speech of small variety and considerable"          
## [5803] "intermittence.  I took a cigar, and went upstairs to look at the"           
## [5804] "lights of which he had spoken that blazed so greenly along the"             
## [5805] "Highgate hills."                                                            
## [5806] ""                                                                           
## [5807] "At first I stared unintelligently across the London valley.  The"           
## [5808] "northern hills were shrouded in darkness; the fires near Kensington"        
## [5809] "glowed redly, and now and then an orange-red tongue of flame flashed"       
## [5810] "up and vanished in the deep blue night.  All the rest of London"            
## [5811] "was black.  Then, nearer, I perceived a strange light, a pale,"             
## [5812] "violet-purple fluorescent glow, quivering under the night breeze.  For"     
## [5813] "a space I could not understand it, and then I knew that it must be"         
## [5814] "the red weed from which this faint irradiation proceeded.  With that"       
## [5815] "realisation my dormant sense of wonder, my sense of the proportion of"      
## [5816] "things, awoke again.  I glanced from that to Mars, red and clear,"          
## [5817] "glowing high in the west, and then gazed long and earnestly at the"         
## [5818] "darkness of Hampstead and Highgate."                                        
## [5819] ""                                                                           
## [5820] "I remained a very long time upon the roof, wondering at the"                
## [5821] "grotesque changes of the day.  I recalled my mental states from the"        
## [5822] "midnight prayer to the foolish card-playing.  I had a violent"              
## [5823] "revulsion of feeling.  I remember I flung away the cigar with a"            
## [5824] "certain wasteful symbolism.  My folly came to me with glaring"              
## [5825] "exaggeration.  I seemed a traitor to my wife and to my kind; I was"         
## [5826] "filled with remorse.  I resolved to leave this strange undisciplined"       
## [5827] "dreamer of great things to his drink and gluttony, and to go on into"       
## [5828] "London.  There, it seemed to me, I had the best chance of learning"         
## [5829] "what the Martians and my fellowmen were doing.  I was still upon the"       
## [5830] "roof when the late moon rose."                                              
## [5831] ""                                                                           
## [5832] ""                                                                           
## [5833] ""                                                                           
## [5834] "CHAPTER EIGHT"                                                              
## [5835] ""                                                                           
## [5836] "DEAD LONDON"                                                                
## [5837] ""                                                                           
## [5838] ""                                                                           
## [5839] "After I had parted from the artilleryman, I went down the hill, and"        
## [5840] "by the High Street across the bridge to Fulham.  The red weed was"          
## [5841] "tumultuous at that time, and nearly choked the bridge roadway; but its"     
## [5842] "fronds were already whitened in patches by the spreading disease that"      
## [5843] "presently removed it so swiftly."                                           
## [5844] ""                                                                           
## [5845] "At the corner of the lane that runs to Putney Bridge station I"             
## [5846] "found a man lying.  He was as black as a sweep with the black dust,"        
## [5847] "alive, but helplessly and speechlessly drunk.  I could get nothing"         
## [5848] "from him but curses and furious lunges at my head.  I think I should"       
## [5849] "have stayed by him but for the brutal expression of his face."              
## [5850] ""                                                                           
## [5851] "There was black dust along the roadway from the bridge onwards, and"        
## [5852] "it grew thicker in Fulham.  The streets were horribly quiet.  I got"        
## [5853] "food--sour, hard, and mouldy, but quite eatable--in a baker's shop"         
## [5854] "here.  Some way towards Walham Green the streets became clear of"           
## [5855] "powder, and I passed a white terrace of houses on fire; the noise of"       
## [5856] "the burning was an absolute relief.  Going on towards Brompton, the"        
## [5857] "streets were quiet again."                                                  
## [5858] ""                                                                           
## [5859] "Here I came once more upon the black powder in the streets and upon"        
## [5860] "dead bodies.  I saw altogether about a dozen in the length of the"          
## [5861] "Fulham Road.  They had been dead many days, so that I hurried quickly"      
## [5862] "past them.  The black powder covered them over, and softened their"         
## [5863] "outlines.  One or two had been disturbed by dogs."                          
## [5864] ""                                                                           
## [5865] "Where there was no black powder, it was curiously like a Sunday in"         
## [5866] "the City, with the closed shops, the houses locked up and the blinds"       
## [5867] "drawn, the desertion, and the stillness.  In some places plunderers"        
## [5868] "had been at work, but rarely at other than the provision and wine"          
## [5869] "shops.  A jeweller's window had been broken open in one place, but"         
## [5870] "apparently the thief had been disturbed, and a number of gold chains"       
## [5871] "and a watch lay scattered on the pavement.  I did not trouble to touch"     
## [5872] "them.  Farther on was a tattered woman in a heap on a doorstep; the"        
## [5873] "hand that hung over her knee was gashed and bled down her rusty brown"      
## [5874] "dress, and a smashed magnum of champagne formed a pool across the"          
## [5875] "pavement.  She seemed asleep, but she was dead."                            
## [5876] ""                                                                           
## [5877] "The farther I penetrated into London, the profounder grew the"              
## [5878] "stillness.  But it was not so much the stillness of death--it was the"      
## [5879] "stillness of suspense, of expectation.  At any time the destruction"        
## [5880] "that had already singed the northwestern borders of the metropolis,"        
## [5881] "and had annihilated Ealing and Kilburn, might strike among these"           
## [5882] "houses and leave them smoking ruins.  It was a city condemned and"          
## [5883] "derelict. . . ."                                                            
## [5884] ""                                                                           
## [5885] "In South Kensington the streets were clear of dead and of black"            
## [5886] "powder.  It was near South Kensington that I first heard the howling."      
## [5887] "It crept almost imperceptibly upon my senses.  It was a sobbing"            
## [5888] "alternation of two notes, \"Ulla, ulla, ulla, ulla,\" keeping on"           
## [5889] "perpetually.  When I passed streets that ran northward it grew in"          
## [5890] "volume, and houses and buildings seemed to deaden and cut it off"           
## [5891] "again.  It came in a full tide down Exhibition Road.  I stopped,"           
## [5892] "staring towards Kensington Gardens, wondering at this strange, remote"      
## [5893] "wailing.  It was as if that mighty desert of houses had found a voice"      
## [5894] "for its fear and solitude."                                                 
## [5895] ""                                                                           
## [5896] "\"Ulla, ulla, ulla, ulla,\" wailed that superhuman note--great waves"       
## [5897] "of sound sweeping down the broad, sunlit roadway, between the tall"         
## [5898] "buildings on each side.  I turned northwards, marvelling, towards the"      
## [5899] "iron gates of Hyde Park.  I had half a mind to break into the Natural"      
## [5900] "History Museum and find my way up to the summits of the towers, in"         
## [5901] "order to see across the park.  But I decided to keep to the ground,"        
## [5902] "where quick hiding was possible, and so went on up the Exhibition"          
## [5903] "Road.  All the large mansions on each side of the road were empty and"      
## [5904] "still, and my footsteps echoed against the sides of the houses.  At"        
## [5905] "the top, near the park gate, I came upon a strange sight--a bus"            
## [5906] "overturned, and the skeleton of a horse picked clean.  I puzzled over"      
## [5907] "this for a time, and then went on to the bridge over the Serpentine."       
## [5908] "The voice grew stronger and stronger, though I could see nothing above"     
## [5909] "the housetops on the north side of the park, save a haze of smoke to"       
## [5910] "the northwest."                                                             
## [5911] ""                                                                           
## [5912] "\"Ulla, ulla, ulla, ulla,\" cried the voice, coming, as it seemed to"       
## [5913] "me, from the district about Regent's Park.  The desolating cry worked"      
## [5914] "upon my mind.  The mood that had sustained me passed.  The wailing"         
## [5915] "took possession of me.  I found I was intensely weary, footsore, and"       
## [5916] "now again hungry and thirsty."                                              
## [5917] ""                                                                           
## [5918] "It was already past noon.  Why was I wandering alone in this city"          
## [5919] "of the dead?  Why was I alone when all London was lying in state, and"      
## [5920] "in its black shroud?  I felt intolerably lonely.  My mind ran on old"       
## [5921] "friends that I had forgotten for years.  I thought of the poisons in"       
## [5922] "the chemists' shops, of the liquors the wine merchants stored; I"           
## [5923] "recalled the two sodden creatures of despair, who so far as I knew,"        
## [5924] "shared the city with myself. . . ."                                         
## [5925] ""                                                                           
## [5926] "I came into Oxford Street by the Marble Arch, and here again were"          
## [5927] "black powder and several bodies, and an evil, ominous smell from the"       
## [5928] "gratings of the cellars of some of the houses.  I grew very thirsty"        
## [5929] "after the heat of my long walk.  With infinite trouble I managed to"        
## [5930] "break into a public-house and get food and drink.  I was weary after"       
## [5931] "eating, and went into the parlour behind the bar, and slept on a black"     
## [5932] "horsehair sofa I found there."                                              
## [5933] ""                                                                           
## [5934] "I awoke to find that dismal howling still in my ears, \"Ulla, ulla,"        
## [5935] "ulla, ulla.\"  It was now dusk, and after I had routed out some"            
## [5936] "biscuits and a cheese in the bar--there was a meat safe, but it"            
## [5937] "contained nothing but maggots--I wandered on through the silent"            
## [5938] "residential squares to Baker Street--Portman Square is the only one I"      
## [5939] "can name--and so came out at last upon Regent's Park.  And as I"            
## [5940] "emerged from the top of Baker Street, I saw far away over the trees in"     
## [5941] "the clearness of the sunset the hood of the Martian giant from which"       
## [5942] "this howling proceeded.  I was not terrified.  I came upon him as if"       
## [5943] "it were a matter of course.  I watched him for some time, but he did"       
## [5944] "not move.  He appeared to be standing and yelling, for no reason that"      
## [5945] "I could discover."                                                          
## [5946] ""                                                                           
## [5947] "I tried to formulate a plan of action.  That perpetual sound of"            
## [5948] "\"Ulla, ulla, ulla, ulla,\" confused my mind.  Perhaps I was too tired"     
## [5949] "to be very fearful.  Certainly I was more curious to know the reason"       
## [5950] "of this monotonous crying than afraid.  I turned back away from the"        
## [5951] "park and struck into Park Road, intending to skirt the park, went"          
## [5952] "along under the shelter of the terraces, and got a view of this"            
## [5953] "stationary, howling Martian from the direction of St. John's Wood.  A"      
## [5954] "couple of hundred yards out of Baker Street I heard a yelping chorus,"      
## [5955] "and saw, first a dog with a piece of putrescent red meat in his jaws"       
## [5956] "coming headlong towards me, and then a pack of starving mongrels in"        
## [5957] "pursuit of him.  He made a wide curve to avoid me, as though he feared"     
## [5958] "I might prove a fresh competitor.  As the yelping died away down the"       
## [5959] "silent road, the wailing sound of \"Ulla, ulla, ulla, ulla,\" reasserted"   
## [5960] "itself."                                                                    
## [5961] ""                                                                           
## [5962] "I came upon the wrecked handling-machine halfway to St. John's Wood"        
## [5963] "station.  At first I thought a house had fallen across the road.  It"       
## [5964] "was only as I clambered among the ruins that I saw, with a start, this"     
## [5965] "mechanical Samson lying, with its tentacles bent and smashed and"           
## [5966] "twisted, among the ruins it had made.  The forepart was shattered.  It"     
## [5967] "seemed as if it had driven blindly straight at the house, and had been"     
## [5968] "overwhelmed in its overthrow.  It seemed to me then that this might"        
## [5969] "have happened by a handling-machine escaping from the guidance of its"      
## [5970] "Martian.  I could not clamber among the ruins to see it, and the"           
## [5971] "twilight was now so far advanced that the blood with which its seat"        
## [5972] "was smeared, and the gnawed gristle of the Martian that the dogs had"       
## [5973] "left, were invisible to me."                                                
## [5974] ""                                                                           
## [5975] "Wondering still more at all that I had seen, I pushed on towards"           
## [5976] "Primrose Hill.  Far away, through a gap in the trees, I saw a second"       
## [5977] "Martian, as motionless as the first, standing in the park towards the"      
## [5978] "Zoological Gardens, and silent.  A little beyond the ruins about the"       
## [5979] "smashed handling-machine I came upon the red weed again, and found the"     
## [5980] "Regent's Canal, a spongy mass of dark-red vegetation."                      
## [5981] ""                                                                           
## [5982] "As I crossed the bridge, the sound of \"Ulla, ulla, ulla, ulla,\""          
## [5983] "ceased.  It was, as it were, cut off.  The silence came like a"             
## [5984] "thunderclap."                                                               
## [5985] ""                                                                           
## [5986] "The dusky houses about me stood faint and tall and dim; the trees"          
## [5987] "towards the park were growing black.  All about me the red weed"            
## [5988] "clambered among the ruins, writhing to get above me in the dimness."        
## [5989] "Night, the mother of fear and mystery, was coming upon me.  But while"      
## [5990] "that voice sounded the solitude, the desolation, had been endurable;"       
## [5991] "by virtue of it London had still seemed alive, and the sense of life"       
## [5992] "about me had upheld me.  Then suddenly a change, the passing of"            
## [5993] "something--I knew not what--and then a stillness that could be felt."       
## [5994] "Nothing but this gaunt quiet."                                              
## [5995] ""                                                                           
## [5996] "London about me gazed at me spectrally.  The windows in the white"          
## [5997] "houses were like the eye sockets of skulls.  About me my imagination"       
## [5998] "found a thousand noiseless enemies moving.  Terror seized me, a horror"     
## [5999] "of my temerity.  In front of me the road became pitchy black as though"     
## [6000] "it was tarred, and I saw a contorted shape lying across the pathway.  I"    
## [6001] "could not bring myself to go on.  I turned down St. John's Wood Road,"      
## [6002] "and ran headlong from this unendurable stillness towards Kilburn.  I"       
## [6003] "hid from the night and the silence, until long after midnight, in a"        
## [6004] "cabmen's shelter in Harrow Road.  But before the dawn my courage"           
## [6005] "returned, and while the stars were still in the sky I turned once more"     
## [6006] "towards Regent's Park.  I missed my way among the streets, and"             
## [6007] "presently saw down a long avenue, in the half-light of the early dawn,"     
## [6008] "the curve of Primrose Hill.  On the summit, towering up to the fading"      
## [6009] "stars, was a third Martian, erect and motionless like the others."          
## [6010] ""                                                                           
## [6011] "An insane resolve possessed me.  I would die and end it.  And I"            
## [6012] "would save myself even the trouble of killing myself.  I marched on"        
## [6013] "recklessly towards this Titan, and then, as I drew nearer and the"          
## [6014] "light grew, I saw that a multitude of black birds was circling and"         
## [6015] "clustering about the hood.  At that my heart gave a bound, and I began"     
## [6016] "running along the road."                                                    
## [6017] ""                                                                           
## [6018] "I hurried through the red weed that choked St. Edmund's Terrace (I"         
## [6019] "waded breast-high across a torrent of water that was rushing down from"     
## [6020] "the waterworks towards the Albert Road), and emerged upon the grass"        
## [6021] "before the rising of the sun.  Great mounds had been heaped about the"      
## [6022] "crest of the hill, making a huge redoubt of it--it was the final and"       
## [6023] "largest place the Martians had made--and from behind these heaps there"     
## [6024] "rose a thin smoke against the sky.  Against the sky line an eager dog"      
## [6025] "ran and disappeared.  The thought that had flashed into my mind grew"       
## [6026] "real, grew credible.  I felt no fear, only a wild, trembling"               
## [6027] "exultation, as I ran up the hill towards the motionless monster.  Out"      
## [6028] "of the hood hung lank shreds of brown, at which the hungry birds"           
## [6029] "pecked and tore."                                                           
## [6030] ""                                                                           
## [6031] "In another moment I had scrambled up the earthen rampart and stood"         
## [6032] "upon its crest, and the interior of the redoubt was below me.  A"           
## [6033] "mighty space it was, with gigantic machines here and there within it,"      
## [6034] "huge mounds of material and strange shelter places.  And scattered"         
## [6035] "about it, some in their overturned war-machines, some in the now rigid"     
## [6036] "handling-machines, and a dozen of them stark and silent and laid in a"      
## [6037] "row, were the Martians--_dead_!--slain by the putrefactive and disease"     
## [6038] "bacteria against which their systems were unprepared; slain as the red"     
## [6039] "weed was being slain; slain, after all man's devices had failed, by"        
## [6040] "the humblest things that God, in his wisdom, has put upon this earth."      
## [6041] ""                                                                           
## [6042] "For so it had come about, as indeed I and many men might have"              
## [6043] "foreseen had not terror and disaster blinded our minds.  These"             
## [6044] "germs of disease have taken toll of humanity since the beginning of"        
## [6045] "things--taken toll of our prehuman ancestors since life began here."        
## [6046] "But by virtue of this natural selection of our kind we have developed"      
## [6047] "resisting power; to no germs do we succumb without a struggle, and to"      
## [6048] "many--those that cause putrefaction in dead matter, for instance--our"      
## [6049] "living frames are altogether immune.  But there are no bacteria in"         
## [6050] "Mars, and directly these invaders arrived, directly they drank and"         
## [6051] "fed, our microscopic allies began to work their overthrow.  Already"        
## [6052] "when I watched them they were irrevocably doomed, dying and rotting"        
## [6053] "even as they went to and fro.  It was inevitable.  By the toll of a"        
## [6054] "billion deaths man has bought his birthright of the earth, and it is"       
## [6055] "his against all comers; it would still be his were the Martians ten"        
## [6056] "times as mighty as they are.  For neither do men live nor die in vain."     
## [6057] ""                                                                           
## [6058] "Here and there they were scattered, nearly fifty altogether, in"            
## [6059] "that great gulf they had made, overtaken by a death that must have"         
## [6060] "seemed to them as incomprehensible as any death could be.  To me also"      
## [6061] "at that time this death was incomprehensible.  All I knew was that"         
## [6062] "these things that had been alive and so terrible to men were dead."         
## [6063] "For a moment I believed that the destruction of Sennacherib had been"       
## [6064] "repeated, that God had repented, that the Angel of Death had slain"         
## [6065] "them in the night."                                                         
## [6066] ""                                                                           
## [6067] "I stood staring into the pit, and my heart lightened gloriously,"           
## [6068] "even as the rising sun struck the world to fire about me with his"          
## [6069] "rays.  The pit was still in darkness; the mighty engines, so great and"     
## [6070] "wonderful in their power and complexity, so unearthly in their"             
## [6071] "tortuous forms, rose weird and vague and strange out of the shadows"        
## [6072] "towards the light.  A multitude of dogs, I could hear, fought over the"     
## [6073] "bodies that lay darkly in the depth of the pit, far below me.  Across"      
## [6074] "the pit on its farther lip, flat and vast and strange, lay the great"       
## [6075] "flying-machine with which they had been experimenting upon our denser"      
## [6076] "atmosphere when decay and death arrested them.  Death had come not a"       
## [6077] "day too soon.  At the sound of a cawing overhead I looked up at the"        
## [6078] "huge fighting-machine that would fight no more for ever, at the"            
## [6079] "tattered red shreds of flesh that dripped down upon the overturned"         
## [6080] "seats on the summit of Primrose Hill."                                      
## [6081] ""                                                                           
## [6082] "I turned and looked down the slope of the hill to where, enhaloed"          
## [6083] "now in birds, stood those other two Martians that I had seen"               
## [6084] "overnight, just as death had overtaken them.  The one had died, even"       
## [6085] "as it had been crying to its companions; perhaps it was the last to"        
## [6086] "die, and its voice had gone on perpetually until the force of its"          
## [6087] "machinery was exhausted.  They glittered now, harmless tripod towers"       
## [6088] "of shining metal, in the brightness of the rising sun."                     
## [6089] ""                                                                           
## [6090] "All about the pit, and saved as by a miracle from everlasting"              
## [6091] "destruction, stretched the great Mother of Cities.  Those who have only"    
## [6092] "seen London veiled in her sombre robes of smoke can scarcely imagine"       
## [6093] "the naked clearness and beauty of the silent wilderness of houses."         
## [6094] ""                                                                           
## [6095] "Eastward, over the blackened ruins of the Albert Terrace and the"           
## [6096] "splintered spire of the church, the sun blazed dazzling in a clear"         
## [6097] "sky, and here and there some facet in the great wilderness of roofs"        
## [6098] "caught the light and glared with a white intensity."                        
## [6099] ""                                                                           
## [6100] "Northward were Kilburn and Hampsted, blue and crowded with houses;"         
## [6101] "westward the great city was dimmed; and southward, beyond the"              
## [6102] "Martians, the green waves of Regent's Park, the Langham Hotel, the"         
## [6103] "dome of the Albert Hall, the Imperial Institute, and the giant"             
## [6104] "mansions of the Brompton Road came out clear and little in the"             
## [6105] "sunrise, the jagged ruins of Westminster rising hazily beyond.  Far"        
## [6106] "away and blue were the Surrey hills, and the towers of the Crystal"         
## [6107] "Palace glittered like two silver rods.  The dome of St. Paul's was"         
## [6108] "dark against the sunrise, and injured, I saw for the first time, by a"      
## [6109] "huge gaping cavity on its western side."                                    
## [6110] ""                                                                           
## [6111] "And as I looked at this wide expanse of houses and factories and"           
## [6112] "churches, silent and abandoned; as I thought of the multitudinous"          
## [6113] "hopes and efforts, the innumerable hosts of lives that had gone to"         
## [6114] "build this human reef, and of the swift and ruthless destruction that"      
## [6115] "had hung over it all; when I realised that the shadow had been rolled"      
## [6116] "back, and that men might still live in the streets, and this dear vast"     
## [6117] "dead city of mine be once more alive and powerful, I felt a wave of"        
## [6118] "emotion that was near akin to tears."                                       
## [6119] ""                                                                           
## [6120] "The torment was over.  Even that day the healing would begin.  The"         
## [6121] "survivors of the people scattered over the country--leaderless,"            
## [6122] "lawless, foodless, like sheep without a shepherd--the thousands who"        
## [6123] "had fled by sea, would begin to return; the pulse of life, growing"         
## [6124] "stronger and stronger, would beat again in the empty streets and pour"      
## [6125] "across the vacant squares.  Whatever destruction was done, the hand of"     
## [6126] "the destroyer was stayed.  All the gaunt wrecks, the blackened"             
## [6127] "skeletons of houses that stared so dismally at the sunlit grass of the"     
## [6128] "hill, would presently be echoing with the hammers of the restorers and"     
## [6129] "ringing with the tapping of their trowels.  At the thought I extended"      
## [6130] "my hands towards the sky and began thanking God.  In a year, thought"       
## [6131] "I--in a year. . ."                                                          
## [6132] ""                                                                           
## [6133] "With overwhelming force came the thought of myself, of my wife, and"        
## [6134] "the old life of hope and tender helpfulness that had ceased for ever."      
## [6135] ""                                                                           
## [6136] ""                                                                           
## [6137] ""                                                                           
## [6138] "CHAPTER NINE"                                                               
## [6139] ""                                                                           
## [6140] "WRECKAGE"                                                                   
## [6141] ""                                                                           
## [6142] ""                                                                           
## [6143] "And now comes the strangest thing in my story.  Yet, perhaps, it is"        
## [6144] "not altogether strange.  I remember, clearly and coldly and vividly,"       
## [6145] "all that I did that day until the time that I stood weeping and"            
## [6146] "praising God upon the summit of Primrose Hill.  And then I forget."         
## [6147] ""                                                                           
## [6148] "Of the next three days I know nothing.  I have learned since that,"         
## [6149] "so far from my being the first discoverer of the Martian overthrow,"        
## [6150] "several such wanderers as myself had already discovered this on the"        
## [6151] "previous night.  One man--the first--had gone to St. Martin's-le-Grand,"    
## [6152] "and, while I sheltered in the cabmen's hut, had contrived to"               
## [6153] "telegraph to Paris.  Thence the joyful news had flashed all over the"       
## [6154] "world; a thousand cities, chilled by ghastly apprehensions, suddenly"       
## [6155] "flashed into frantic illuminations; they knew of it in Dublin,"             
## [6156] "Edinburgh, Manchester, Birmingham, at the time when I stood upon the"       
## [6157] "verge of the pit.  Already men, weeping with joy, as I have heard,"         
## [6158] "shouting and staying their work to shake hands and shout, were making"      
## [6159] "up trains, even as near as Crewe, to descend upon London.  The church"      
## [6160] "bells that had ceased a fortnight since suddenly caught the news,"          
## [6161] "until all England was bell-ringing.  Men on cycles, lean-faced,"            
## [6162] "unkempt, scorched along every country lane shouting of unhoped"             
## [6163] "deliverance, shouting to gaunt, staring figures of despair.  And for"       
## [6164] "the food!  Across the Channel, across the Irish Sea, across the"            
## [6165] "Atlantic, corn, bread, and meat were tearing to our relief.  All the"       
## [6166] "shipping in the world seemed going Londonward in those days.  But of"       
## [6167] "all this I have no memory.  I drifted--a demented man.  I found myself"     
## [6168] "in a house of kindly people, who had found me on the third day"             
## [6169] "wandering, weeping, and raving through the streets of St. John's Wood."     
## [6170] "They have told me since that I was singing some insane doggerel about"      
## [6171] "\"The Last Man Left Alive! Hurrah!  The Last Man Left Alive!\"  Troubled"   
## [6172] "as they were with their own affairs, these people, whose name, much as"     
## [6173] "I would like to express my gratitude to them, I may not even give"          
## [6174] "here, nevertheless cumbered themselves with me, sheltered me, and"          
## [6175] "protected me from myself.  Apparently they had learned something of my"     
## [6176] "story from me during the days of my lapse."                                 
## [6177] ""                                                                           
## [6178] "Very gently, when my mind was assured again, did they break to me"          
## [6179] "what they had learned of the fate of Leatherhead.  Two days after I"        
## [6180] "was imprisoned it had been destroyed, with every soul in it, by a"          
## [6181] "Martian.  He had swept it out of existence, as it seemed, without any"      
## [6182] "provocation, as a boy might crush an ant hill, in the mere wantonness"      
## [6183] "of power."                                                                  
## [6184] ""                                                                           
## [6185] "I was a lonely man, and they were very kind to me.  I was a lonely"         
## [6186] "man and a sad one, and they bore with me.  I remained with them four"       
## [6187] "days after my recovery.  All that time I felt a vague, a growing"           
## [6188] "craving to look once more on whatever remained of the little life that"     
## [6189] "seemed so happy and bright in my past.  It was a mere hopeless desire"      
## [6190] "to feast upon my misery.  They dissuaded me.  They did all they could"      
## [6191] "to divert me from this morbidity.  But at last I could resist the"          
## [6192] "impulse no longer, and, promising faithfully to return to them, and"        
## [6193] "parting, as I will confess, from these four-day friends with tears, I"      
## [6194] "went out again into the streets that had lately been so dark and"           
## [6195] "strange and empty."                                                         
## [6196] ""                                                                           
## [6197] "Already they were busy with returning people; in places even there"         
## [6198] "were shops open, and I saw a drinking fountain running water."              
## [6199] ""                                                                           
## [6200] "I remember how mockingly bright the day seemed as I went back on my"        
## [6201] "melancholy pilgrimage to the little house at Woking, how busy the"          
## [6202] "streets and vivid the moving life about me.  So many people were"           
## [6203] "abroad everywhere, busied in a thousand activities, that it seemed"         
## [6204] "incredible that any great proportion of the population could have been"     
## [6205] "slain.  But then I noticed how yellow were the skins of the people I"       
## [6206] "met, how shaggy the hair of the men, how large and bright their eyes,"      
## [6207] "and that every other man still wore his dirty rags.  Their faces"           
## [6208] "seemed all with one of two expressions--a leaping exultation and"           
## [6209] "energy or a grim resolution.  Save for the expression of the faces,"        
## [6210] "London seemed a city of tramps.  The vestries were indiscriminately"        
## [6211] "distributing bread sent us by the French government.  The ribs of the"      
## [6212] "few horses showed dismally.  Haggard special constables with white"         
## [6213] "badges stood at the corners of every street.  I saw little of the"          
## [6214] "mischief wrought by the Martians until I reached Wellington Street,"        
## [6215] "and there I saw the red weed clambering over the buttresses of"             
## [6216] "Waterloo Bridge."                                                           
## [6217] ""                                                                           
## [6218] "At the corner of the bridge, too, I saw one of the common contrasts"        
## [6219] "of that grotesque time--a sheet of paper flaunting against a thicket"       
## [6220] "of the red weed, transfixed by a stick that kept it in place.  It was"      
## [6221] "the placard of the first newspaper to resume publication--the _Daily"       
## [6222] "Mail_.  I bought a copy for a blackened shilling I found in my pocket."     
## [6223] "Most of it was in blank, but the solitary compositor who did the thing"     
## [6224] "had amused himself by making a grotesque scheme of advertisement"           
## [6225] "stereo on the back page.  The matter he printed was emotional; the"         
## [6226] "news organisation had not as yet found its way back.  I learned"            
## [6227] "nothing fresh except that already in one week the examination of the"       
## [6228] "Martian mechanisms had yielded astonishing results.  Among other"           
## [6229] "things, the article assured me what I did not believe at the time,"         
## [6230] "that the \"Secret of Flying,\" was discovered.  At Waterloo I found the"    
## [6231] "free trains that were taking people to their homes.  The first rush"        
## [6232] "was already over.  There were few people in the train, and I was in no"     
## [6233] "mood for casual conversation.  I got a compartment to myself, and sat"      
## [6234] "with folded arms, looking greyly at the sunlit devastation that flowed"     
## [6235] "past the windows.  And just outside the terminus the train jolted over"     
## [6236] "temporary rails, and on either side of the railway the houses were"         
## [6237] "blackened ruins.  To Clapham Junction the face of London was grimy"         
## [6238] "with powder of the Black Smoke, in spite of two days of thunderstorms"      
## [6239] "and rain, and at Clapham Junction the line had been wrecked again;"         
## [6240] "there were hundreds of out-of-work clerks and shopmen working side by"      
## [6241] "side with the customary navvies, and we were jolted over a hasty"           
## [6242] "relaying."                                                                  
## [6243] ""                                                                           
## [6244] "All down the line from there the aspect of the country was gaunt"           
## [6245] "and unfamiliar; Wimbledon particularly had suffered.  Walton, by virtue"    
## [6246] "of its unburned pine woods, seemed the least hurt of any place along"       
## [6247] "the line.  The Wandle, the Mole, every little stream, was a heaped"         
## [6248] "mass of red weed, in appearance between butcher's meat and pickled"         
## [6249] "cabbage.  The Surrey pine woods were too dry, however, for the festoons"    
## [6250] "of the red climber.  Beyond Wimbledon, within sight of the line, in"        
## [6251] "certain nursery grounds, were the heaped masses of earth about the"         
## [6252] "sixth cylinder.  A number of people were standing about it, and some"       
## [6253] "sappers were busy in the midst of it.  Over it flaunted a Union Jack,"      
## [6254] "flapping cheerfully in the morning breeze.  The nursery grounds were"       
## [6255] "everywhere crimson with the weed, a wide expanse of livid colour cut"       
## [6256] "with purple shadows, and very painful to the eye.  One's gaze went"         
## [6257] "with infinite relief from the scorched greys and sullen reds of the"        
## [6258] "foreground to the blue-green softness of the eastward hills."               
## [6259] ""                                                                           
## [6260] "The line on the London side of Woking station was still undergoing"         
## [6261] "repair, so I descended at Byfleet station and took the road to"             
## [6262] "Maybury, past the place where I and the artilleryman had talked to the"     
## [6263] "hussars, and on by the spot where the Martian had appeared to me in"        
## [6264] "the thunderstorm.  Here, moved by curiosity, I turned aside to find,"       
## [6265] "among a tangle of red fronds, the warped and broken dog cart with the"      
## [6266] "whitened bones of the horse scattered and gnawed.  For a time I stood"      
## [6267] "regarding these vestiges. . . ."                                            
## [6268] ""                                                                           
## [6269] "Then I returned through the pine wood, neck-high with red weed here"        
## [6270] "and there, to find the landlord of the Spotted Dog had already found"       
## [6271] "burial, and so came home past the College Arms.  A man standing at an"      
## [6272] "open cottage door greeted me by name as I passed."                          
## [6273] ""                                                                           
## [6274] "I looked at my house with a quick flash of hope that faded"                 
## [6275] "immediately.  The door had been forced; it was unfast and was opening"      
## [6276] "slowly as I approached."                                                    
## [6277] ""                                                                           
## [6278] "It slammed again.  The curtains of my study fluttered out of the"           
## [6279] "open window from which I and the artilleryman had watched the dawn.  No"    
## [6280] "one had closed it since.  The smashed bushes were just as I had left"       
## [6281] "them nearly four weeks ago.  I stumbled into the hall, and the house"       
## [6282] "felt empty.  The stair carpet was ruffled and discoloured where I had"      
## [6283] "crouched, soaked to the skin from the thunderstorm the night of the"        
## [6284] "catastrophe.  Our muddy footsteps I saw still went up the stairs."          
## [6285] ""                                                                           
## [6286] "I followed them to my study, and found lying on my writing-table"           
## [6287] "still, with the selenite paper weight upon it, the sheet of work I had"     
## [6288] "left on the afternoon of the opening of the cylinder.  For a space I"       
## [6289] "stood reading over my abandoned arguments.  It was a paper on the"          
## [6290] "probable development of Moral Ideas with the development of the"            
## [6291] "civilising process; and the last sentence was the opening of a"             
## [6292] "prophecy: \"In about two hundred years,\" I had written, \"we may"          
## [6293] "expect----\"  The sentence ended abruptly.  I remembered my inability"      
## [6294] "to fix my mind that morning, scarcely a month gone by, and how I had"       
## [6295] "broken off to get my _Daily Chronicle_ from the newsboy.  I remembered"     
## [6296] "how I went down to the garden gate as he came along, and how I had"         
## [6297] "listened to his odd story of \"Men from Mars.\""                            
## [6298] ""                                                                           
## [6299] "I came down and went into the dining room.  There were the mutton"          
## [6300] "and the bread, both far gone now in decay, and a beer bottle"               
## [6301] "overturned, just as I and the artilleryman had left them.  My home was"     
## [6302] "desolate.  I perceived the folly of the faint hope I had cherished so"      
## [6303] "long.  And then a strange thing occurred.  \"It is no use,\" said a"        
## [6304] "voice.  \"The house is deserted.  No one has been here these ten days."     
## [6305] "Do not stay here to torment yourself.  No one escaped but you.\""           
## [6306] ""                                                                           
## [6307] "I was startled.  Had I spoken my thought aloud?  I turned, and the"         
## [6308] "French window was open behind me.  I made a step to it, and stood"          
## [6309] "looking out."                                                               
## [6310] ""                                                                           
## [6311] "And there, amazed and afraid, even as I stood amazed and afraid,"           
## [6312] "were my cousin and my wife--my wife white and tearless.  She gave a"        
## [6313] "faint cry."                                                                 
## [6314] ""                                                                           
## [6315] "\"I came,\" she said.  \"I knew--knew----\""                                
## [6316] ""                                                                           
## [6317] "She put her hand to her throat--swayed.  I made a step forward, and"        
## [6318] "caught her in my arms."                                                     
## [6319] ""                                                                           
## [6320] ""                                                                           
## [6321] ""                                                                           
## [6322] "CHAPTER TEN"                                                                
## [6323] ""                                                                           
## [6324] "THE EPILOGUE"                                                               
## [6325] ""                                                                           
## [6326] ""                                                                           
## [6327] "I cannot but regret, now that I am concluding my story, how little"         
## [6328] "I am able to contribute to the discussion of the many debatable"            
## [6329] "questions which are still unsettled.  In one respect I shall certainly"     
## [6330] "provoke criticism.  My particular province is speculative philosophy."      
## [6331] "My knowledge of comparative physiology is confined to a book or two,"       
## [6332] "but it seems to me that Carver's suggestions as to the reason of the"       
## [6333] "rapid death of the Martians is so probable as to be regarded almost as"     
## [6334] "a proven conclusion.  I have assumed that in the body of my narrative."     
## [6335] ""                                                                           
## [6336] "At any rate, in all the bodies of the Martians that were examined"          
## [6337] "after the war, no bacteria except those already known as terrestrial"       
## [6338] "species were found.  That they did not bury any of their dead, and the"     
## [6339] "reckless slaughter they perpetrated, point also to an entire ignorance"     
## [6340] "of the putrefactive process.  But probable as this seems, it is by no"      
## [6341] "means a proven conclusion."                                                 
## [6342] ""                                                                           
## [6343] "Neither is the composition of the Black Smoke known, which the"             
## [6344] "Martians used with such deadly effect, and the generator of the"            
## [6345] "Heat-Rays remains a puzzle.  The terrible disasters at the Ealing"          
## [6346] "and South Kensington laboratories have disinclined analysts for further"    
## [6347] "investigations upon the latter.  Spectrum analysis of the black powder"     
## [6348] "points unmistakably to the presence of an unknown element with a"           
## [6349] "brilliant group of three lines in the green, and it is possible that"       
## [6350] "it combines with argon to form a compound which acts at once with"
